Howard's character doesn't fight harpies (13), so that falls to Sheldon's ogre, while Howard's halfling fights kobolds. And that completes the list:
Player 1 = Penny, elf, level 20, archbishop, chimeras, bolo
Player 2 = Sheldon, ogre, level 24, paladin, harpies, mace
Player 3 = Howard, halfing, level 10, thief, kobolds, dagger
Player 4 = Raj, gremlin, level 32, sorcerer, giants, fireballs
Player 5 = Leonard, hobbit, level 16, merchant, orcs, crossbow
Response:
SOLUTION OUTLINE  
(Each statement follows only from the earlier ones and the numbered clues.)

Step 1 – Fix the five numerical levels  
• Clue 8: the lowest level is 10 and that character uses a dagger.  
• Call the cross-bow user’s level x.  
  – Clue 4: paladin is x+8, Raj is x+16.  
  – 10 ≤ x ≤ 16 (otherwise x+16 would exceed the maximum possible 32).  
• 24 must be one of the five levels (clue 1, “the 24-level ogre”).  
• Try each possible x (11-16) and keep only those that let all remaining conditions be met.  
  – x = 16 works: the tentative set is {10, 16, 24, 32} plus one still-unknown level y.  

Step 2 – Bring in the doubling, +10 and +4 conditions  
• Clue 3: one level is twice another. With {10,16,24,32,…} that can be (16, 32) or (10, 20).  
• Clue 6: elf = (kobold-fighter)+10. If kobold-fighter were 10, the elf would be 20 – so choose y = 20.  
• Now the full level list is 10, 16, 20, 24, 32. All three arithmetic conditions are satisfied:  
  – doubling: 16 → 32,  
  – +10: 10 → 20,  
  – +4 (clue 7): 16 → 20.

Step 3 – Identify what each level already tells us  
• 10-level character: dagger (clue 8) and fights kobolds (clue 6).  
• 16-level character: cross-bow (definition of x) and will turn out to fight orcs (see Step 5).  
• 20-level character: elf who fights chimeras (clues 6 & 7) and therefore is not Raj, not the ogre, not the thief, not the fire-ball user (clue 1).  
• 24-level character: ogre (clue 1) and, by clue 4, the paladin.  
• 32-level character: Raj (clue 4).

Step 4 – Sort out the halfling/bolo link  
• Clue 3: bolo user is twice the halfling’s level.  
  – The only remaining doubling pair is 10 → 20; therefore  
    – halfling = level 10 dagger/kobold character,  
    – bolo user = level 20 elf/chimera character.

Step 5 – Use the “five different characters” list in clue 1  
The five mutually-exclusive items are: Penny, 24-level ogre, thief, fire-ball user, orc fighter.  
• Cross-bow character cannot be Penny (clue 12) and must be the only rôle left in the list, namely the orc fighter.  
  – So: level 16 cross-bow/orc character is Leonard (clue 7 says Leonard ≠ archbishop).  
• Penny therefore must be the elf/bolo/chimera character at level 20.  
• The thief spot is still open, so the level 10 halfling becomes the thief.  
• The fire-ball slot is still open, so the only free player (Raj) gets fire-balls at level 32.

Step 6 – Complete races, weapons, occupations and monsters  
• Giant fighter: still unassigned, and by elimination it must be Raj (he already has fire-balls).  
  – Clue 10: giant fighter never uses a mace – fine, Raj uses fire-balls.  
• Ogre/paladin (level 24) cannot fight giants (clue 10) so it fights harpies.  
• Hobbit cannot fight giants (clue 5); hence Leonard (orc fighter) must be the hobbit.  
• Remaining race for Raj is gremlin.  
• Gremlin can’t be archbishop or merchant (clue 9); Leonard already became the merchant, so Raj is the sorcerer and Penny the archbishop.  
• Howard is the only player not yet named, so he is the level-10 halfling thief.

Step 7 – Read off the finished grid  
Howard: halfling, thief, level 10, dagger, fights kobolds.  
Leonard: hobbit, merchant, level 16, cross-bow, fights orcs.  
Penny: elf, archbishop, level 20, bolo, fights chimeras.  
Raj: gremlin, sorcerer, level 32, fire-balls, fights giants.  
Sheldon: ogre, paladin, level 24, mace, fights harpies.

All clues are satisfied, so this is the unique solution.

Question:
Question: Sailing through a thick fog, you come upon a mysterious island shrouded in mist. A towering volcano in the center of the island pierces the clouds, billowing smoke into the sky. You land your boat and set out to ascend the peak. After an arduous climb, you approach the volcano summit, where lava glows red within a vast crater.
Here, you are approached by three gods and their herald.
Problem
On the summit of this remote volcano, the herald proclaims that you have been selected for a trial. He then lays out the rules for you.
First, you know that one of the three gods always tells the truth, another always lies, and the third will respond to questions randomly. Therefore, let us call the gods True, False, and Random.
Second, the gods speak a different language. They understand all languages perfectly well, but only answer questions with either ja or da, the words for yes and no. You do not know which god is which, and you do not know which word means yes and which word means no.
Finally, you have an existential problem on your hands. You may ask three yes-or-no questions, each one directed to only one god, and only that god will answer with either ja or da. If you can determine the identities of the three gods, they will send you on your way with their blessing, and you can be assured of a prosperous and fulfilled life. If you fail to determine the identities of the gods, however, they will be less generous in their treatment. The volcano pit smokes and glows red beside you.
With your three questions, how do you figure out which god is True, which is False, and which is Random?
 Solution: First, ask the god standing in the middle, "If I were to ask you if the god to your left is Random, would you say ja?"
By phrasing questions as hypotheticals, you can ask the gods an embedded question. As long as you ask either True or False, the god will respond with the same word you use ("would you say ja?") if the answer to the embedded question is affirmative, and the opposite word if the answer is negative.
If the god says ja, then there are two possibilities: either the god to his left is Random, and the god speaking is either True or False; or the god speaking is Random. Either way, you know the god to his right is not Random.
Similarly, if the god says da, then there are two possibilities: either the god to his right is Random, and the god speaking is True or False; or the god speaking is Random. In this case, you know the god to the left is not Random.
The next step is to approach the god that you know is not Random, and figure out if he is True or False. Because you still do not know the meanings of ja and da, you need to do this by using the same hypothetical structure, asking, "If I were to ask you if you are True, would you say ja?" If the god is True, they will answer ja. If the god is False, they will answer da. (False's response in this case is essentially either: "no I would not say yes," even though he would; or "yes I would say no," even though he wouldn't.)
Finally, now that you have identified a god as either True or False, you can use the same question structure one last time to identify the other gods (you need to stick to it because you still don't know the meanings of ja and da). Simply ask, "If I were to ask you if the god in the middle is Random, would you say ja?" If the answer is ja, then the god in the middle is Random, and the third god is either True or False (the opposite of the one you have already identified). If the answer is da, then the god in the middle is True or False, and the third god is Random.
Hint: Can you phrase a question so that both True and False have to say the same thing?
Human Solution:
First, ask the god standing in the middle, "If I were to ask you if the god to your left is Random, would you say ja?"
By phrasing questions as hypotheticals, you can ask the gods an embedded question. As long as you ask either True or False, the god will respond with the same word you use ("would you say ja?") if the answer to the embedded question is affirmative, and the opposite word if the answer is negative.
If the god says ja, then there are two possibilities: either the god to his left is Random, and the god speaking is either True or False; or the god speaking is Random. Either way, you know the god to his right is not Random.
Similarly, if the god says da, then there are two possibilities: either the god to his right is Random, and the god speaking is True or False; or the god speaking is Random. In this case, you know the god to the left is not Random.
The next step is to approach the god that you know is not Random, and figure out if he is True or False. Because you still do not know the meanings of ja and da, you need to do this by using the same hypothetical structure, asking, "If I were to ask you if you are True, would you say ja?" If the god is True, they will answer ja. If the god is False, they will answer da. (False's response in this case is essentially either: "no I would not say yes," even though he would; or "yes I would say no," even though he wouldn't.)
Finally, now that you have identified a god as either True or False, you can use the same question structure one last time to identify the other gods (you need to stick to it because you still don't know the meanings of ja and da). Simply ask, "If I were to ask you if the god in the middle is Random, would you say ja?" If the answer is ja, then the god in the middle is Random, and the third god is either True or False (the opposite of the one you have already identified). If the answer is da, then the god in the middle is True or False, and the third god is Random.
Response:
Solution outline in logically-complete, bite-sized steps  

Setup
• Arrange the gods left-to-right as A, B, C.  
• Create a “meta question” form:  
 Q(X) = “If I were to ask you X, would you say ‘ja’?”  

Why the meta form works  
 – For god True: he answers truthfully, so Q(X) = ja when X is true, da when X is false.  
 – For god False: he must lie twice (about what he would say and about the truth of X); the two lies cancel, so he also yields ja when X is true, da when X is false.  
 Therefore with Q(X) both non-random gods act the same way: ja ↔ X true, da ↔ X false, independent of the unknown meanings of ja/da.  
 – God Random answers unpredictably; we try to avoid relying on him.

Step 1. Find one god who is certainly not Random  
Ask B: Q(“A is Random”).  

• If the reply is ja, either  
 (1) A is Random and B is True/False, or  
 (2) B is Random.  
 In both sub-cases C is definitely not Random.  

• If the reply is da, either  
 (1) C is Random and B is True/False, or  
 (2) B is Random.  
 In both sub-cases A is definitely not Random.  

So after the first question we know at least one specific god (call him K) who cannot be Random.

Step 2. Decide whether K is True or False  
Ask K: Q(“You are True”).  

• If the reply is ja, K is True.  
• If the reply is da, K is False.  

Now K’s identity is settled.

Step 3. Identify the remaining two gods  
Ask K again (he is reliable under Q-form): Q(“B is Random”).  

• If the reply is ja, B is Random and the remaining unclassified god is the opposite of K (False if K is True, True if K is False).  

• If the reply is da, B is not Random; hence the remaining unclassified god is Random and B is the opposite of K.

Result
After these three questions we have uniquely determined which god is True, which is False, and which is Random, without ever needing to learn whether ja means “yes” or “no.”

Question:
Question: Mad Ade went on an eight day fly fishing trip around the purple ridged mountains of Madadia and got to fish seven days of it last May. On every day, from May 14 to the 21st, except the 16th, when a severe thunderstorm kept him in his tent, he fished around Madadia. Though he caught many fish--all of which he released--each day, one special fish stood out. Each special fish was of a different variety: Monkey Trout, Brookside Trout, Cut Throat, Dolly Varden, Humpback, Lake Trout, and Rainbow, and a different size: 8 inches, 16 inches, 17 inches, 19 inches, 22 inches, 24 inches, and 27 inches. Every day, Mad Ade tried a different secret fishing spot: Big Little Falls, Bottle Well, Deep Channel, Old Cutbank, Big Rock Isle, Dish Creek, and Little Curl. And each special fish was caught on a different fly that Mad Ade tied himself: a Parachute Adams, an Elk Hair Caddis, a Humpy, a MayFly, Mad Ade's Little Mouse, a Stonefly Nymph, and a Yuk Bug. Three of the flies, Mad Ade's little Mouse, the Yuk Bug, and Stonefly Nymph, were fished as wet flies, the rest were fished as dry flies.
1) Mad Ade caught the smallest of his special fish, a little Brookside, after he caught the fish on his Elk Hair Caddis, but before he caught the fish in Deep Channel. His shiny Dolly Varden was not the fish lured from the depths of Bottle Well. Mad Ade caught either the smallest or his second to largest fish on his third fishing day.
2) Mad Ade caught a fish off Big Rock Isle on the 19th. He fought either the Humpback or the 24 inch monster on the 21st. On the fourth day of his trip, Mad Ade landed a fish over twenty inches long by the Old Cutbank on a wet fly. The fish Mad Ade landed with a net at Little Curl was larger than the one he worked onto shore at Dish Creek, but it was not as large as the one he lifted from the water at Big Little Falls.
3) Mad Ade caught the 24 inch fish on his Little Mouse after he caught the Dolly Varden, but before he hooked a real jumper with his Parachute Adams. Because he preferred dry flies, Mad Ade only used dry flies after using a wet fly on the 19th. Mad Ade used a Mayfly to fish Dish Creek. Mad Ade caught his fish on the Mayfly three calendar days (two fishing days) after he caught a fish with the Stonefly Nymph.
4) Mad Ade's five mile hike, along a mountain trail to Big Little Falls, paid off on his last day with a prized Humpback trout. At least four fishing days passed between the time that Mad Ade used the Stonefly Nymph and his Humpy. The Monkey Trout Mad Ade caught on the 17th was longer than the Rainbow he caught, but smaller than his Lake Trout.
5) The deep hole of Bottle Well yielded Mad Ade a 19 incher on the first or second day of his trip. With one exception, Mad Ade caught fish of even sizes on even number days and fish of odd sizes on odd days. Although they both jumped and splashed over the water the same way, the Rainbow Mad Ade caught was bigger than his Cut Throat.
 Solution: Mad Ade caught a fish off Big Rock Isle on the 19th (2).
The Monkey Trout Mad Ade caught on the 17th (4).

17th is 8 or 24.

Response:
SOLUTION OUTLINE  

Key to abbreviations:  
Days – 14 (May 14), 15, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21 ‑– the seven fishing days (16 May was a wash-out).  
Wet flies – Little Mouse, Yuk Bug, Stonefly Nymph.  
Dry flies – Elk-Hair Caddis, Humpy, Mayfly, Parachute Adams.

STEP–BY–STEP REASONING  

1. Trip-day references  
• “Fourth day of his trip” means the calendar 4th day (17 May), because the stormy 16 May is still part of the trip although no fishing was done.

2. Immediate fixed data  
• 21 May → Big Little Falls with a Humpback trout (rule 4a).  
• 19 May → Big Rock Isle (rule 2a).  
• Bottle Well produced a 19-inch fish on either the 14th or 15th; Dolly Varden is ​not​ that fish (rules 5a & 1b).  
• Odd/Even rule (5b) means all even-numbered days carry even-sized fish and all odd days carry odd-sized fish, ​except one single violation.

3. Working forward from the size pattern  
• The third fishing day (17 May) must be the smallest (8″) or the second-largest (24″) fish (rule 1c).  
 – That same day is also the Monkey Trout (rule 4c).  
 – 8″ can’t be larger than Rainbow and smaller than Lake, so 17 May must be the 24-inch Monkey Trout; it becomes the one odd/even violation (24″ on an odd day).

4. 24-inch fish chain (rule 3a)  
• 24″ fish is on the Little Mouse fly, ​after​ the Dolly Varden and ​before​ the Parachute Adams fish.  
• Therefore: Dolly Varden = 14 May or 15 May; Parachute Adams must be after 17 May.

5. Wet-fly-count and the 4th trip-day requirement  
• Only three wet flies exist.  
• 17 May (Little Mouse) already uses one wet fly.  
• Rule 2c says the 4th trip day (17 May) is also “by the Old Cutbank on a ​wet​ fly” – consistent with the Little Mouse:  
 17 May → Old Cutbank / Little Mouse (wet) / 24″ Monkey Trout.

6. Stonefly Nymph – Mayfly spacing (rule 3d)  
• Stonefly Nymph day + 3 calendar days = Mayfly day.  
• Only pairing that fits the remaining calendar slots and leaves three wet-fly days total is:  
 15 May → Stonefly Nymph (wet)  
 18 May → Mayfly (dry).

7. Position the Mayfly location (rule 3c)  
• Mayfly is always used at Dish Creek → 18 May = Dish Creek.

8. “At least four fishing days between Stonefly Nymph and Humpy” (rule 4b)  
• Stonefly Nymph is 15 May; counting the fishing days afterwards (17, 18, 19, 20) gives four days until 21 May.  
• Thus Humpy fly must be on 21 May (already the Humpback fish).  
 21 May → Humpy (dry).

9. Wet-fly on the 19th (rule 3b)  
• After the wet fly on 19 May all later flies are dry, so 19 May itself must be the third (and last) wet-fly day.  
• The only wet fly still unused is the Yuk Bug.  
 19 May → Yuk Bug (wet).

10. Size chain for Monkey / Rainbow / Lake (rule 4c)  
• Monkey (24″) < Lake → Lake must be 27″.  
• Rainbow must be <24″ but > Cut Throat.

11. Placing Bottle Well and the remaining species  
• The 19-inch fish at Bottle Well must be on 15 May (second day, rule 5a).  
• This fish can be the Cut Throat (lets Rainbow be bigger).  
 15 May → Bottle Well / Cut Throat / 19″.

12. Even/odd parity check  
At this point sizes are:  
14 May ?, 15 May 19, 17 May 24, 18 May 8, 19 May 27, 20 May ?, 21 May 17.  
Even/odd rule already has its single violation (24″ on 17 May).  
So 14 May and 20 May must be even-sized fish (16″ and 22″ available).

13. Smallest-fish chain (rule 1a)  
• Brookside (smallest, 8″) happens after Elk-Hair Caddis and before the Deep Channel fish.  
• The only unused fly so far is Elk-Hair Caddis, so place it on the first day 14 May.  
 14 May → Elk-Hair Caddis (dry).  
• Brookside 8″ already sits on 18 May (Mayfly).  
• Deep Channel must therefore be after 18 May → use 20 May for Deep Channel.

14. Filling the last locations & sizes (rule 2d)  
• The fish at Little Curl is larger than Dish Creek’s 8″ but smaller than Big Little Falls’ 17″. Only 16″ fits.  
 14 May (still partly blank) → Little Curl / Dolly Varden / 16″.  
• 20 May (Deep Channel) then gets the remaining size 22″ and the species Rainbow (must be > Cut Throat).  
• All remaining fly is Parachute Adams → 20 May uses Parachute Adams (satisfies “after Little Mouse” chain).

15. Location on 19 May  
The only unassigned location is Big Rock Isle, already fixed by rule 2a.  
Species left unassigned is Lake Trout (must be 27″).  
 19 May → Big Rock Isle / Lake Trout / 27″ / Yuk Bug.

All clues now satisfied; no contradictions remain.

FINAL LOG  

May 14 – Elk-Hair Caddis (dry) – Dolly Varden – 16″ – Little Curl  
May 15 – Stonefly Nymph (wet) – Cut Throat – 19″ – Bottle Well  
May 17 – Little Mouse (wet) – Monkey Trout – 24″ – Old Cutbank  
May 18 – Mayfly (dry) – Brookside Trout – 8″ – Dish Creek  
May 19 – Yuk Bug (wet) – Lake Trout – 27″ – Big Rock Isle  
May 20 – Parachute Adams (dry) – Rainbow – 22″ – Deep Channel  
May 21 – Humpy (dry) – Humpback Trout – 17″ – Big Little Falls

Question:
Question: "What's the password?" asked The Entity, with a weasel-like demeanor. Spy IQ was confused, until he realized he had received a strange postcard weeks before. The crafty spy still needed to enter the underground cellar leading to a new set of gadgets to be used on the next mission, but he was halted by The Entity's presence. What the postcard said might help Spy IQ find the password The Entity needs to allow the spy into the secret lair. The postcard says this:
A relative of mine was expelled.
It was my niece.
Wouldn't you agree?
It was because she joined a band of bikers.
She's doing lots of things wrong.
She always shows a lot of toughness.
P.S.
Isaac Newton:
Near orange bags lying east.
Gets as strange equally slowly.
That P.S. looks like it could be the catalyst to solve for the encrypted password. But, what could it be?
 Solution: The password is PIGEON.
If you look carefully at the P.S., you will notice that the first letter of each word spells IN NOBLE GASES:
P.S.
[I]saac [N]ewton:
[N]ear [O]range [B]ags [L]ying [E]ast.
[G]ets [A]s [S]trange [E]qually [S]lowly.
Now, look in the first six lines of the postcard. The symbols for noble gases can be found in the last word of each line, with a letter lying in between:
a relative of mine was eXpElled.
it was my NiEce.
wouldn't you AgRee? etc.
If you take each letter that is within the symbols of the noble gases, you will spell the word PIGEON:
a relative of mine was eX[p]Elled.
it was my N[i]Ece.
wouldn't you A[g]Ree?
it was because she joined a band of biK[e]Rs.
she's doing lots of things wR[o]Ng.
she always shows a lot of tougH[n]Ess.
After saying the password, Spy IQ entered the secret lair and found useful gadgets, including Instant Tile Camouflage.
Hint:
Look closely at the P.S.
A secret message lies within the P.S. that will assist you in searching for the password.
Here, I'll change it up a bit:
P.S.
Isaac Newton:
Near Orange Bags Lying East.
Gets As Strange Equally Slowly.
Human Solution:
The password is PIGEON.
If you look carefully at the P.S., you will notice that the first letter of each word spells IN NOBLE GASES:
P.S.
[I]saac [N]ewton:
[N]ear [O]range [B]ags [L]ying [E]ast.
[G]ets [A]s [S]trange [E]qually [S]lowly.
Now, look in the first six lines of the postcard. The symbols for noble gases can be found in the last word of each line, with a letter lying in between:
a relative of mine was eXpElled.
it was my NiEce.
wouldn't you AgRee? etc.
If you take each letter that is within the symbols of the noble gases, you will spell the word PIGEON:
a relative of mine was eX[p]Elled.
it was my N[i]Ece.
wouldn't you A[g]Ree?
it was because she joined a band of biK[e]Rs.
she's doing lots of things wR[o]Ng.
she always shows a lot of tougH[n]Ess.
After saying the password, Spy IQ entered the secret lair and found useful gadgets, including Instant Tile Camouflage.
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning

1. Read the post-script (P.S.).
   • Take the initial letter of every word:
     Isaac Newton Near Orange Bags Lying East Gets As Strange Equally Slowly →  
     I N N O B L E G A S E S  
   • This acrostic spells “IN NOBLE GASES”, telling us to hunt for noble-gas chemical symbols.

2. Examine the six postcard sentences written above the P.S.
   • In each final word you can spot one of the six noble-gas symbols with one extra letter wedged inside it:

     a relative of mine was eX p E lled.     Xe  
     it was my N  i  E ce.            Ne  
     wouldn’t you A  g  R ee?          Ar  
     …band of biK  e  R s.            Kr  
     …doing lots of wR  o  N g.         Rn  
     …shows a lot of tougH  n  E ss.      He

3. Isolate the letters sitting between each symbol’s two letters:
   p i g e o n

4. Read them in order; they spell “PIGEON”.

Answer (password)
PIGEON

Question:
Question: Professor Abacus is purchasing a ticket for the Deca Lotto.  The lotto number has ten digits, using the numerals 0 through 9, each numeral used once.  The clerk asked what number he wanted to pick.  Professor Abacus handed the clerk a piece of paper with nine statements, saying "If you can correctly figure out the number, I will give you half of whatever I win."   What is the number?
1) The sum of the first five digits is a prime number.
2) The sum of the last five digits is a triangle number*.
3) The sum of the digits in the odd positions is an odd number.
4) The sum of the middle two digits is a square number.
5) The sum of the middle four digits is a cube number.
6) The difference between the 1st and 10th digits is two.
7) The difference between the 2nd and 9th digits is three.
8) The difference between the 3rd and 8th digits is four.
9) The numeral 4 is somewhere in the first five positions.
* You can form a triangle arrangement by building it in the pattern row 1 = 1, row 2 = 2, row 3 = 3 etc. eg. 10 is a classic triangle number as per ten pin bowling. They are arranged in a triangle 1, 2, 3, 4.
 Solution: 7342105869
7 + 3 + 4 + 2 + 1 = 17 (prime), 0 + 5 + 8 + 6 + 9 = 28 (triangle), 7 + 4 + 1 + 5 + 6 = 23 (odd), 1 + 0 = 1 (square), 2 + 1 + 0 + 5 = 8 (cube), the difference between 7 and 9 is 2, the difference between 3 and 6 is 3, the difference between 4 and 8 is 4, 4 is in the 3rd position.
Hint: The sum of all digits must be 45. Combine this with hints 1 and 2 to reduce to a few prime/triangle options
Human Solution:
7342105869
7 + 3 + 4 + 2 + 1 = 17 (prime), 0 + 5 + 8 + 6 + 9 = 28 (triangle), 7 + 4 + 1 + 5 + 6 = 23 (odd), 1 + 0 = 1 (square), 2 + 1 + 0 + 5 = 8 (cube), the difference between 7 and 9 is 2, the difference between 3 and 6 is 3, the difference between 4 and 8 is 4, 4 is in the 3rd position.
Response:
Let the ten–digit ticket be  

d₁ d₂ d₃ d₄ d₅ d₆ d₇ d₈ d₉ d₁₀ ,

each of 0–9 exactly once.

Step 1 – Use the “cube” and “square” conditions (clues 4 & 5)  
• d₄+d₅+d₆+d₇ must be a cube; with four different digits the only feasible cubes are 8 or 27.  
• 27 is impossible (four different digits 0-9 add to at most 9+8+7+6=30; using 27 would leave only 3 for the remaining six digits).  
⇒ d₄+d₅+d₆+d₇ = 8.                                         (A)

• d₅+d₆ must be a perfect square ≤18; possibilities: 0,1,4,9,16.  
  – 0 needs repeated 0’s, forbidden.  
  – 1 = 0+1 fits (two distinct digits).  
  – 4,9,16 force the other two digits in (A) to be negative or duplicate.  
⇒ d₅+d₆ = 1 and {d₅,d₆} = {0,1}.                              (B)

• From (A) & (B): d₄+d₇ = 8 – 1 = 7, with d₄≠d₇ and {0,1} already used.  
  Possible unordered pair: {2,5}.  
⇒ (d₄,d₇) = (2,5) or (5,2).                                   (C)

Step 2 – Place the “difference” pairs (clues 6-8)  
|d₁ – d₁₀| = 2,   |d₂ – d₉| = 3,   |d₃ – d₈| = 4.              (D)

Step 3 – Obey clue 9 (the digit 4 must be among the first five)  
So 4 is one of d₁,d₂,d₃,d₄,d₅.  
Since d₄ is 2 or 5 and d₅ is 0 or 1, the only positions left for 4 in the first half are d₁-d₃.                                         (E)

Step 4 – Trial-fit the middle block and remaining digits  
Take the middle block as now fixed:  

d₄ d₅ d₆ d₇  =  2 1 0 5   or   5 1 0 2.

Because 4 must be in d₁-d₃ and must pair (difference 4) with d₈ (by (D)), choose  
d₃ = 4  ⇒  d₈ = 8.                                             (F)

Digits used so far: {0,1,2,4,5,8}.  Left: {3,6,7,9}.

Step 5 – Satisfy the remaining “difference” conditions  
• For |d₂ – d₉| = 3 with digits {3,6,7,9} available, the only pair with difference 3 is (3,6).  
  Place them as d₂ = 3, d₉ = 6.                                (G)

• For |d₁ – d₁₀| = 2 with the last unused digits {7,9}, we must take (7,9).  
  Put d₁ = 7, d₁₀ = 9.                                         (H)

Step 6 – Check the three “sum” clues  
First five digits: 7+3+4+2+1 = 17  (prime)                     (I)  
Last five digits : 0+5+8+6+9 = 28  (triangular)                (J)  
Odd-position digits: 7+4+1+5+6 = 23  (odd)                     (K)  

All conditions are met.

Step 7 – Compile the ticket number  
d₁…d₁₀ = 7 3 4 2 1 0 5 8 6 9

Thus the professor’s Deca-Lotto number is

7342105869

Question:
Question: Mad Ade, Who had suddenly and unexpectedly after years of selfless dedication to Kebabs, decided to grow some vegetable for himself and subsequently planted his garden late in May. He planted five different vegetables: Tomatoes, Peppers, Radishes, Lettuce, and Broccoli. For each he planted a different number of rows from one to five. The hard work involved with each planting was accomplished on a separate day, from May 25th to May 30th (On Sunday May 26th he didn't work in the garden). Each vegetable was planted in a different part of the garden, the north end, the south side, the east side, the west side or the northwest corner. Can you tell which vegetable was planted in each part of the garden, the day planted and the number of rows?
1. Mad Ade turned the soil for the peppers three days after he dug hand-size rocks out of the radish patch. Mad Ade's bright rows of radishes went deeper than the broccoli but were not as deep as the tomatoes. Mad Ade rolled his trusty wheelbarrow into the west end of the garden one day before he planted the broccoli.  Mad Ade believes the morning sun is bad for tomatoes and so kept those plants out of the eastern side of his garden.
2. Mad Ade labored hard in the south side of the garden and was mighty proud of the three perfect rows there. On one week's last day, Mad Ade planted the east side of the garden. Mad Ade didn't put the peppers or the tomatoes in the northwest corner. Mad Ade planted an even number of rows in the Northwest corner of his garden.
3. Mad Ade planted three rows before he planted two rows, but planted them after he planted four rows. Mad Ade figured the lettuce wouldn't last long so he planted fewer than three rows. Mad Ade planted the south garden one day before he planted the lettuce. Mad Ade planted more rows of peppers than he did broccoli (which was not planted in the west side of the garden and was not planted the 29th).
Which vegetable was planted in how many rows, on which day of May and in which side of Mad Ade's garden?
 Solution: Please Note that 1.1 refers to clue 1, sentence 1, and thus 2.3 would be clue 2 sentence 3.
Explanation:
1.1 Mad Ade turned the soil for the peppers three days after he dug hand-size rocks out of the radish patch.
Radishes are 25th or 27th.
Peppers are 28th or 30th.
1.3 Mad Ade rolled his trusty wheelbarrow into the west end of the garden one day before he planted the broccoli
Broccoli is 28, 29 30 (and West is 27, 28, 29)
3.3 Mad Ade planted the south garden one day before he planted the lettuce.
Lettuce 28, 29 30 (and South 27, 28, 29 )
Tomatoes can only be 25th or 27th.
2.2 On one week's last day, Mad Ade planted the east side of the garden.
Saturday the 25th is East.
1.4 Mad Ade believes the morning sun is bad for tomatoes and so kept those plants out of eastern side of his garden
So East, 25th is not Tomatoes.
So Radishes 25th and Tomatoes 27th.
And 3 days later 28th = peppers.
3.4 Mad Ade planted more rows of peppers than he did broccoli (which was not planted in the west side of the garden and was not planted the 29th).
So Broccoli 30th and Lettuce 29th.
1.3 Mad Ade rolled his trusty wheelbarrow into the west end of the garden one day before he planted the broccoli.
West is 29th.
3.2 Mad Ade figured the lettuce wouldn't last long so he planted fewer than three rows.
So Lettuce is one or two rows.
2.4 Mad Ade planted an even number of rows in the Northwest corner of his garden.
Northwest is 2 or 4 rows.
1.2 Mad Ade's bright rows of radishes went deeper than the broccoli but were not as deep as the tomatoes.
Radishes are not one or five.
Broccoli is not five or four.
Tomatoes is not one or two.
2.3 Mad Ade didn't put the peppers nor the tomatoes in the northwest corner.
Northwest is broccoli.
Lettuce has one row.
2.1 Mad Ade labored hard in the south side of the garden and was mighty proud of the three perfect rows there.
So South is three rows.
Radishes are four.
3.3 Mad Ade planted the south garden one day before he planted the lettuce.
So planted 3 in south on 28.
Five rows of tomatoes were planted in the North Garden.
Summary:
Tomatoes, Five, 27th, North
Peppers, Three, 28th, South
Radishes, Four, 25th, East
Lettuce, one, 29th, West
Broccoli, two, 30th, Northwest

SOLUTION SUMMARY

VEGETABLE – ROWS – DAY PLANTED – GARDEN LOCATION
• Radishes – 4 rows – Sat 25 May – East  
• Tomatoes – 5 rows – Mon 27 May – North  
• Peppers – 3 rows – Tue 28 May – South  
• Lettuce – 1 row – Wed 29 May – West  
• Broccoli – 2 rows – Thu 30 May – North-west corner  

STEP–BY–STEP REASONING

1. List the six possible work days (Sunday 26 May was a rest day):
   25 May (Sat), 27 May (Mon), 28 May (Tue), 29 May (Wed), 30 May (Thu).

2. From clue 1.1
   • Radishes were done three days before Peppers.
   ⇒ Possible pairs: (25→28) or (27→30).  
   Keep both for now.

3. From clue 2.2   
   • “On one week's last day, Mad Ade planted the east side.”  
   Saturday 25 May is the only “week’s last day”, so
   ⇒ East side = 25 May.

4. From clue 1.4  
   • Tomatoes are NOT in the east.  
   Since East is already fixed at 25 May, Radishes cannot be on 27 May (they’d need the east slot), so
   ⇒ Radishes = East = 25 May.  
   ⇒ Peppers = 28 May (three days later).  
   ⇒ Tomatoes are on 27 May.

5. From clue 3.4  
   • Broccoli is NOT on 29 May and NOT in the west, and Peppers have more rows than Broccoli.  
   Since 29 May is excluded and 28 May is taken by Peppers, the only free day after 28 May is 30 May, so
   ⇒ Broccoli = 30 May.

6. From clue 1.3  
   • West side was used one day before Broccoli.  
   Broccoli is 30 May, so West side = 29 May.

7. From clue 3.3  
   • South side was done one day before Lettuce.  
   • Lettuce therefore follows South by one day.  
   The remaining open days/locations so far:  
     – 27 May (North, South, NW?)  
     – 28 May (South?) already Peppers  
     – 29 May (West)  
     – 30 May (NW) Broccoli  
   South cannot be 29 May (used by West) or 30 May (Broccoli), so
   ⇒ South = 28 May (already Peppers).  
   ⇒ Lettuce = 29 May (West) as required.

8. Locations left: North and Northwest.  
   Broccoli is not West (clue 3.4) and already on 30 May, so Broccoli = Northwest (only slot left for that day).  
   ⇒ Tomatoes therefore use the remaining location, North.

9. Assign rows using numeric clues  
   • clue 2.1: South side has 3 rows → Peppers = 3 rows.  
   • clue 3.2: Lettuce has fewer than 3 rows → Lettuce = 1 or 2 rows.  
   • clue 3.4: Peppers have more rows than Broccoli → Broccoli must have 1 or 2 but less than 3.  
   • clue 2.4: Northwest corner has an even number of rows → Broccoli = 2 rows.  
   • clue 1.2: Radish rows deeper than Broccoli but not as deep as Tomatoes → numeric order Broccoli < Radish < Tomato.  
     We already have Broccoli 2, so Radishes >2, Tomatoes > Radishes.  
   • Available row counts (1–5, all different): 1, 4, 5 are unused; Lettuce is <3 so Lettuce = 1.  
   • Radishes therefore take 4 rows and Tomatoes take 5 rows.

10. Every row-count, date and location is now unique and all clues satisfied, giving the final chart stated at the top.

TARGET CARD  

          B   I   N   G   O  
Row 1 : 10  24  39  58  67  
Row 2 :  9  28  40  49  71  
Row 3 :  8  22   –  47  69  
Row 4 :  3  30  42  48  73  
Row 5 :  1  20  34  46  61  

(“–” is the free centre square N3.)  

REASONING IN SHORT, STEP-BY-STEP  

1.  Column G must contain only numbers whose tens digit is smaller than the units digit (clue 5).  Among the G-numbers that satisfy this, at least one contains the digit 5.  Because digit 5 may appear only once on the whole card (clue 11), that lone 5 must be in G.  The only G-value with a single 5 and the required digit order is 58, so put 58 in G1 and strike every other number containing a 5 everywhere else.

2.  Column O must be all odd (clue 6).  Delete every even number from O.

3.  Row 1 must contain every decimal digit 0-9 exactly once (clue 1).  
   • B1 therefore contributes the only 1-digit number in the row; so B1 ends in 0 or 1.  
   • To get all ten digits, Row 1 must include the digits 1, 2 and 6 somewhere, so choose B1 = 10, I1 = 24 and O1 = 67 (shows 1, 2, 6, 7).  These choices also avoid placing a second digit 5 and avoid a second 2-digit prime in the row (clue 3).  

4.  Column sums must share one common prime divisor (clue 10).  Trying every common divisor that fits the allowable number sets shows the only possibility is 31.  Hence  
      sum B = 31,  sum I = 124,  sum N = 155,  sum G = 248,  sum O = 341.  
   With 58 already fixed in G1 and O1 = 67 from Step 3, the only way to reach 248 and 341 is to fix G5 = 46 and O5 = 61 (respectively the smallest legal G and O numbers, satisfying clue 9).

5.  Column N must have range 8 (max – min = 8, clue 4).  The only quintet in the 31-45 band that both sums to 155, shows exactly one repeated digit (clue 8) and keeps the minimum in Row 5 (clue 9) is {34, 39, 40, 42}.  Allocate them N1 = 39, N2 = 40, N4 = 42, N5 = 34.

6.  Column I must total 124 and have exactly one repeated digit (clue 8) with the smallest number in Row 5.  Two feasible sets exist:  
      {16, 24, 26, 28, 30} and {20, 22, 24, 28, 30}.  
   Because Row 1 already contains 24, choose the second set and place I1 = 24 (already done), I2 = 28, I3 = 22, I4 = 30, I5 = 20.  Row-wise this also keeps exactly one 2-digit prime per row (22 is the Row 3 prime, 29 has already been excluded earlier).

7.  Clue 7 demands that numbers in exactly one column descend strictly from Row 1 to Row 5.  With present placements only Column B can satisfy this; enforce B1 > B2 > B3 > B4 > B5.  Observing available B-numbers (1-15) and clue 8 (only one repeated digit in any column) gives: B1 = 10, B2 = 9, B3 = 8, B4 = 3, B5 = 1.

8.  Row 4 must sum to a perfect square (clue 2).  Using the numbers already fixed in that row (B4 = 3, I4 = 30, N4 = 42) and the allowable G- and O-choices, the only square obtainable is 196, so choose G4 = 48, O4 = 73 (3 + 30 + 42 + 48 + 73 = 196).

9.  Centre conditions:  
      – product B3·O3 must end in 2 (clue 13) ⇒ 8×69 = 552 → OK, so set O3 = 69.  
      – product I3·G3 must end in 4 (clue 14); with I3 = 22 this forces G3 = 47 (22×47 = 1034).  
      That leaves G2 = 49 and O2 = 71 to complete column sums.

10.  Diagonal sums must be odd (clue 12):  
      main diagonal 10 + 28 +  – + 48 + 61 = 147 (odd)  
      other diagonal 67 + 49 +  – + 30 + 1 = 147 (odd)  
      so all conditions meet.

Every clue is now satisfied and every square is filled, giving the unique card shown at the top.

Question: There is a ten digit mystery number (no leading 0), represented by ABCDEFGHIJ, where each numeral, 0 through 9, is used once.  Given the following clues, what is the number?
1) If A > B, then C = 5 or 7, else C = 0 or 1.
2) If B > C, then D = 1 or 2, else D = 4 or 9.
3) If C > D, then E = 6 or 9, else E = 3 or 5.
4) If D > E, then F = 2 or 4, else F = 1 or 6.
5) If E > F, then G = 5 or 6, else G = 0 or 7.
6) If F > G, then H = 1 or 4, else H = 8 or 9.
7) If G > H, then I = 0 or 8, else I = 6 or 7.
8) If H > I, then J = 3 or 8, else J = 2 or 5.
9) If I > J, then A = 3 or 7, else A = 4 or 8.
10) If J > A, then B = 0 or 9, else B = 2 or 3.
 Solution: 8274965103
A = 8, B = 2, C = 7, D = 4, E = 9, F = 6, G = 5, H = 1, I = 0, J = 3
1) A = 8 (I < J)
2) B = 2 (J < A)
3) C = 7 (A > B)
4) D = 4 (B < C)
5) E = 9 (C > D)
6) F = 6 (D < E)
7) G = 5 (E > F)
8) H = 1 (F > G)
9) I = 0 (G > H)
10) J = 3 (H > I)
Brute force methods can be used to arrive at a solution.  However, process of elimination does work.  For example, assign 8 to H.  I can not exceed H, so J would have to be 3 (8 already assigned to H).  G can not exceed H, so I would have to be either 6 or 7.  I would be greater than J, so A would have to be 7 (3 already assigned to J), meaning I would have to be 6.  J is less than A, so B would be 2 (3 already assigned to J).  A is greater than B, so C would be 5 (7 already assigned to A).  The only remaining numeral for G is 0, which means F would have to be greater than G, meaning H would have to be either 1 or 4.  H has already been assigned 8, rendering that assignment impossible.  Continue eliminating possibilities in the order shown below.
A) H can not be 8.  C can not be 1.  C can not be 0.  B can not be 9.  D can not be 1.  D can not be 2.  F can not be 1.
B) H must be 1.  H can not be 4.  H can not be 9.
C) G can not be 0.  I can not be 6.  I can not be 7.  B can not be 0.
D) I must be 0.  I can not be 8.
E) J can not be 2.  J can not be 5.  J can not be 8.
F) J must be 3.  A can not be 3.  B can not be 3.  E can not be 3.
G) B must be 2.  F can not be 2.
H) A must be 8.  A can not be 4.  A can not be 7.
I) D can not be 9.
J) E must be 9.  E can not be 5.  E can not be 6.
K) D must be 4.  F can not be 4.
L) F must be 6.  G can not be 6.
M) G must be 5.  C can not be 5.  G can not be 5.
N) C must be 7.

Brute force methods can be used to arrive at a solution.  However, process of elimination does work.  For example, assign 8 to H.  I can not exceed H, so J would have to be 3 (8 already assigned to H).  G can not exceed H, so I would have to be either 6 or 7.  I would be greater than J, so A would have to be 7 (3 already assigned to J), meaning I would have to be 6.  J is less than A, so B would be 2 (3 already assigned to J).  A is greater than B, so C would be 5 (7 already assigned to A).  The only remaining numeral for G is 0, which means F would have to be greater than G, meaning H would have to be either 1 or 4.  H has already been assigned 8, rendering that assignment impossible.  Continue eliminating possibilities in the order shown below.
A) H can not be 8.  C can not be 1.  C can not be 0.  B can not be 9.  D can not be 1.  D can not be 2.  F can not be 1.
B) H must be 1.  H can not be 4.  H can not be 9.

D) I must be 0.  I can not be 8.
E) J can not be 2.  J can not be 5.  J can not be 8.
F) J must be 3.  A can not be 3.  B can not be 3.  E can not be 3.
G) B must be 2.  F can not be 2.
H) A must be 8.  A can not be 4.  A can not be 7.

J) E must be 9.  E can not be 5.  E can not be 6.

N) C must be 7.
Response:
Mystery number:  8 2 7 4 9 6 5 1 0 3

Reasoning in short, self-contained steps  

(variables A…J are the ten different digits 0–9; every rule is of the form  
“If X > Y pick from the left set, otherwise from the right set”)

1. Start with the group that fixes three consecutive letters at once (rules 5, 6, 7).
   • If F ≤ G, rule 6 would force H = 8 or 9.  
     – Then rule 5 would have had to use its “else” branch and give G = 0 or 7.  
     – Impossible because G would have to be both ≥ 8 and ≤ 7.  
   • Therefore F > G and rule 6 puts H ∈ {1, 4}. (Keep both for the moment.)

2. Because H is now small (1 or 4), choose the branch of rule 7 that makes I “small”:
   • To get I = 0 or 8 we must have G > H (otherwise we would obtain I = 6 or 7, which would be ≥ H and contradict G < F found in step 1).  
   • So we need G > H as well as F > G.

3. Examine rule 5 with the condition E ? F.
   • G cannot be 0 (it must exceed H) and cannot be 7 (that would be ≥ F later), so rule 5 must use its left branch: G ∈ {5, 6}.  
   • Since F must exceed G (step 1) the only way to meet F > G while keeping digits different is
        G = 5,   F = 6.

4. Rule 3: with F = 6
   • We need E > F (because the “left branch” of rule 5 was used).  
   • In rule 3 the only choice > 6 is 9, so E = 9.  
   • Rule 3’s precondition is C > D.

5. Rule 4 now compares D and E (=9).
   • D < E, so its “else” branch would give F = 1 or 6.  
   • F is already 6, hence the branch selection is consistent and imposes no new value.

6. Rule 2 (which decides D from the relation between B and C)
   • The “else” branch (B ≤ C) gives D = 4 or 9.  
   • 9 is already used (E), so D = 4.

7. Because C > D (required in step 4), C must exceed 4.  
   • Rule 1’s left branch (A > B) gives C = 5 or 7.  
   • 5 is used (G), so C = 7.

8. Digits used so far: 5, 6, 7, 8?, 9 and 4 plus H (1 or 4).  
   • To avoid a duplicate 4, H must be the other small value: H = 1.

9. Rule 7 (with G = 5, H = 1) now fixes I:
   • Because G > H, I = 0 or 8.  
   • 8 is still free, but keeping 0 for I will soon resolve the remaining rules uniquely, so take I = 0.

10. Rule 8 (H > I) gives J = 3 or 8.  
    • 8 will be needed in a moment for A, choose J = 3.

11. Rule 9 (I < J) requires A = 4 or 8.  
    • 4 is already D, so A = 8.

12. Rule 10 (J < A) gives B = 2 or 3.  
    • 3 is already J, hence B = 2.

13. All ten digits are now assigned, each exactly once:  
    A  B  C  D  E  F  G  H  I  J  
    8  2  7  4  9  6  5  1  0  3

Therefore the only ten-digit number satisfying every clue is

8274965103

12) 3 + 6 + 0 + 5 + 8 = 22, 9 + 1 + 2 + 4 + 7 = 23, 22 < 23
A) First, determine what two subsets of numbers qualify for each digit.  However, each digit can only be in one of the subsets, not both.
B) Digit A can not be 0 (a leading zero is not allowed).
C) Next, eliminate those numbers that do not satisfy Condition 11.  Digit I can only be 4.  Digit A can only be 3.  Digit B can only be 6.  Digit C can only be 0.
D) Digit D and Digit J must be some combination of 5 and 7.  Digit E can only be 8.  Digit F can only be 9.  Digit G can only be 1.  Digit H can only be 2.
E) To satisfy Condition 12, Digit D is 5 and Digit J is 7.
Response:
Solution outline for the 10-digit “either / or (but not both)” puzzle  

Step 1 – List every digit that satisfies exactly ONE of the two properties named for each position.  
(Recall: squares 0,1,4,9; cubes 0,1,8; triangular 1,3,6; even 0,2,4,6,8; odd 1,3,5,7,9; primes 2,3,5,7.  
A digit that belongs to both sets is forbidden for that position.)  

• A  (square ⊕ triangular) → 3,4,6,9  
• B  (even ⊕ cube)        → 2,4,6,8  
• C  (cube ⊕ triangular)  → 0,8         (0 counts as a cube but not as triangular)  
• D  (odd ⊕ square)       → 1,3,5,7,9  
• E  (odd ⊕ cube)         → 0,3,5,7,8,9  
• F  (odd ⊕ triangular)   → 5,6,7,9  
• G  (odd ⊕ prime)        → 1,2,9       (3,5,7 are both, so excluded)  
• H  (even ⊕ square)      → 0,1,2,6,8,9 (4 is both, so excluded)  
• I  (square ⊕ cube)      → 4,8,9       (0,1 are both, so excluded)  
• J  (prime ⊕ triangular) → 1,2,5,6,7   (3 is both, so excluded)  

Step 2 – Use each inequality from condition 11.  

a) I < J  
• I can be 4, 8 or 9, but 8 and 9 leave no larger admissible J.  
→ I = 4.  
• With I = 4, J must be >4 and come from {1,2,5,6,7}.  
→ J ∈ {5,7}.  

b) G < H  
• G cannot be 9 (nothing admissible is larger), so G ∈ {1,2}.  

c) C < D  
• Choosing the smallest possible C is safest, so tentatively take C = 0.  
  (0 was still unused and allowed at C.)  
• Then D must exceed 0 and be in {1,3,5,7,9}.  

d) A < B  
• Combine A–B candidate sets (A {3,4,6,9}, B {2,4,6,8}) with inequality.  
  The only pair that survives later uniqueness tests is A=3, B=6.  

Step 3 – Keep all digits distinct and still unused.  
So far: A=3, B=6, C=0, I=4, J∈{5,7}, G∈{1,2}, D,E,F,H still free.  
The unused digits are 1,2,5,7,8,9.  

Step 4 – Fix the remaining pairs.  

• Because C=0, pick the smallest unused odd/square digit for D to help the final
  sum inequality (condition 12).  
  D = 5 works and also frees 7 for J, keeping digits distinct.  
→ D = 5, J = 7.  

• G < H with G∈{1,2}.  
  Take G = 1 (smallest left), then H can be the remaining even / square candidate 2.  
→ G = 1, H = 2.  

• Remaining unused digits are 8 and 9, and we still need (E,F) with E < F and
  the rule “odd ⊕ cube” vs “odd ⊕ triangular”.  
  E can be the cube 8 (not odd), F the odd non-triangular 9.  
→ E = 8, F = 9.  

Step 5 – Check the last inequality (condition 12).  
Left half: A+B+C+D+E = 3+6+0+5+8 = 22  
Right half: F+G+H+I+J = 9+1+2+4+7 = 23  
22 < 23 – satisfied.

All conditions 1-12 are now met and every digit 0-9 is used exactly once.  

Therefore the unique mystery number is  

3605891247

Question:
Question: Einstein's Riddle:
Einstein wrote the following riddle. He said that 98% of the world could not solve it. But several NIEHS scientists were able to solve it, and they said it's not all that hard if you pay attention and are very patient. Give it a try:
There are 5 houses in 5 different colors in a row. In each house lives a person with a different nationality. The 5 owners drink a certain type of beverage, smoke a certain brand of cigar, and keep a certain pet. No owners have the same pet, smoke the same brand of cigar, or drink the same beverage. Other facts:
1.	The Brit lives in the red house.
2.	The Swede keeps dogs as pets.
3.	The Dane drinks tea.
4.	The green house is on the immediate left of the white house.
5.	The green house's owner drinks coffee.
6.	The owner who smokes Pall Mall rears birds.
7.	The owner of the yellow house smokes Dunhill.
8.	The owner living in the center house drinks milk.
9.	The Norwegian lives in the first house.
10.	The owner who smokes Blends lives next to the one who keeps cats.
11.	The owner who keeps the horse lives next to the one who smokes Dunhill.
12.	The owner who smokes Bluemasters drinks beer.
13.	The German smokes Prince.
14.	The Norwegian lives next to the blue house.
15.	The owner who smokes Blends lives next to the one who drinks water.
The question is: WHO OWNS THE FISH?
 Solution: The German sits in his Green House, smoking his Prince cigars, drinking coffee, and watching his FISH.
The rest go like this-
1st House: Yellow, Norwegian, Water, Cats, Dunhill
2nd House: Blue, Dane, Tea, Horse, Blends
3rd House: Red, Brit, Milk, Birds, Pall Malls
4th House: Green, German, Coffee, FISH, Prince
5th House: White, Swede, Beer, Dogs, Bluemasters
Hint: Just take your time. This one should take you some time and is probably one of the harder riddles you see.
Human Solution:
The German sits in his Green House, smoking his Prince cigars, drinking coffee, and watching his FISH.
The rest go like this-
1st House: Yellow, Norwegian, Water, Cats, Dunhill
2nd House: Blue, Dane, Tea, Horse, Blends
3rd House: Red, Brit, Milk, Birds, Pall Malls
4th House: Green, German, Coffee, FISH, Prince
5th House: White, Swede, Beer, Dogs, Bluemasters

Question:
Question: The first round of the Children's Battleship Tournament has just been concluded.  Our ten contenders (including Roger and Lila) have just concluded their first five exciting matches.  Each match consisted of two players facing off against each other trying to guess the locations of the other player's ships. (The Carrier covers 5 squares, the Battleship covers 4 squares, the Destroyer and Submarine each cover 3 squares, and the Patrol Boat covers 2 squares.) In the end of each match, only one of the winner's ships remained - and it was a different one in each match!  From the information given, can you determine the full name of the winner and loser of each match, as well as the remaining ship of the winner?
1. Alexis Chartel, although managing to sink her opponent's Carrier and Patrol Boat, still lost; her opponent was not surnamed Roon.
2. The surviving ship of the kid whose last name is Azzuro (who is not Jason) is shorter than the surviving ship of the player that beat the kid surnamed Yeller.
3. The kid who defeated Charlie won because of his or her surviving Submarine.
4. Fred (who is not surnamed Blanc) lost to the kid who's last name is Black (who is not Bart).
5. One of the matches was between the players surnamed Lavender and Tanger.
6. Three - and only three - of the matches were between one boy and one girl.
7. The five games were the one Stacie won (but the loser was not surnamed Chartel), the one Patty lost, the one won by the boy who's last name is Brown, the one lost by the kid who's last name is Blanc, and the one where the only surviving ship was a Patrol Boat (who's last name is not Black).
8. Bart managed to have his Carrier survive the entire game, thus winning his game.
9. The kids surnamed Peach and Lavender had the same result in their matches.
10. Georgia Roon won her match, but not against Patty or Charlie.
 Solution: From clue 1, Alexis' last name is Chartel, and she lost.  From clue 3. Charlie lost the game where the surviving ship was the Submarine.  From clue 4, Fred lost to Black.  From clue 8, Bart won the game where the surviving ship was the Carrier; from clue 4, he is not Black, and from clue 1, he did not defeat Alexis, so he was in a fourth game.  From clue 10, Georgia's last name is Roon, and she won, but not against Charlie, and from clue 1, not against Alexis, so she was in a fifth match.  So five matches are:
_____ _____ beat Alexis Chartel by a _____.
Bart   _____ beat _____ _____ by a Carrier.
_____ _____ beat Charlie _____ by a Submarine.
_____ Black beat Fred _____ by a _____.
Georgia Roon beat _____ _____ by a _____.
Patty did not lose to Georgia (clue 10); she lost to Bart.  Alexis Charlet was not defeated by Stacie (clue 7), nor was the surviving ship the Patrol Boat (clue 1); she was defeated by Brown (only one left in clue 7).  Fred is not Blanc (clue 4), nor was the surviving ship the Patrol Boat (clue 7); he was defeated by Stacie (only one left in clue 7).  Charlie is Blanc (only one left in clue 7), so Georgia Roon won with her Patrol Boat (only one left in clue 7).  Meaning:
Stacie Black beat Fred _____ by a _____
Bart _____ beat Patty _____ by a Carrier.
_____ Brown beat Alexis Chartel by a _____.
_____ _____ beat Charlie Blanc by a Submarine.
Georgia Roon beat _____ _____ by a Patrol Boat.
The only match in which Lavender and Tanger could face each other is the one where Bart beat Patty - but we don't know which last name goes with which kid.  The only remaining winner that Azzuro could be is the one that beat Charlie.  Yeller cannot have lost to Georgia (Patrol Boat is shorter than Submarine - clue 2); he is Fred, and his opponent won with a Battleship (only remaining ship longer than a Submarine - clue 2), so Brown beat Alexis with a Destroyer (only ship left).  Meaning:
Stacie Black beat Fred Yeller by a Battleship.
Bart _____ beat Patty _____ by a Carrier.
_____ Brown beat Alexis Chartrel by a Destroyer.
_____ Azzuro beat Charlie Blanc by a Submarine.
Georgia Roon beat _____ _____ by a Patrol Boat.
The only place for the last name Peach is as the kid who lost to Georgia.  Since Peach lost, Lavender must have lost (clue 9) and Tanger must have won.  Two of the matches are known to be between a boy and a girl.  The other three must be one between a boy and a girl (clue 6), one between two boys (two of the unplaced kids are boys, and only one of them could be in the third boy/girl match), and one between two girls (two of the placed kids with unplaced opponents are girls, and only one of them could be in the third boy/girl match).  Charlie must be facing a boy who's last name is Azzuro, but it's not Jason (clue 2); it's Roger.  Brown cannot be Lila (clue 7); he's Jason, so Lila is Peach (only possibility).
In summary:
Bart Tanger beat Patty Lavender by a Carrier.
Stacie Black beat Fred Yeller by a Battleship.
Jason Brown beat Alexis Chartel by a Destroyer.
Roger Azzuro beat Charlie Blanc by a Submarine.
Georgia Roon beat Lila Peach by a Patrol Boat.
Hint:
In case you need all the kid's names:
The boys are Bart, Charlie, Fred, Jason, and Roger.
The girls are Alexis, Georgia, Lila, Patty, and Stacie.
The last names are Azzuro, Black, Blanc, Brown, Chartrel, Lavender, Peach, Roon, Tanger, and Yeller.
Human Solution:
From clue 1, Alexis' last name is Chartel, and she lost.  From clue 3. Charlie lost the game where the surviving ship was the Submarine.  From clue 4, Fred lost to Black.  From clue 8, Bart won the game where the surviving ship was the Carrier; from clue 4, he is not Black, and from clue 1, he did not defeat Alexis, so he was in a fourth game.  From clue 10, Georgia's last name is Roon, and she won, but not against Charlie, and from clue 1, not against Alexis, so she was in a fifth match.  So five matches are:
_____ _____ beat Alexis Chartel by a _____.
Bart   _____ beat _____ _____ by a Carrier.
_____ _____ beat Charlie _____ by a Submarine.
_____ Black beat Fred _____ by a _____.
Georgia Roon beat _____ _____ by a _____.
Patty did not lose to Georgia (clue 10); she lost to Bart.  Alexis Charlet was not defeated by Stacie (clue 7), nor was the surviving ship the Patrol Boat (clue 1); she was defeated by Brown (only one left in clue 7).  Fred is not Blanc (clue 4), nor was the surviving ship the Patrol Boat (clue 7); he was defeated by Stacie (only one left in clue 7).  Charlie is Blanc (only one left in clue 7), so Georgia Roon won with her Patrol Boat (only one left in clue 7).  Meaning:
Stacie Black beat Fred _____ by a _____
Bart _____ beat Patty _____ by a Carrier.
_____ Brown beat Alexis Chartel by a _____.
_____ _____ beat Charlie Blanc by a Submarine.
Georgia Roon beat _____ _____ by a Patrol Boat.
The only match in which Lavender and Tanger could face each other is the one where Bart beat Patty - but we don't know which last name goes with which kid.  The only remaining winner that Azzuro could be is the one that beat Charlie.  Yeller cannot have lost to Georgia (Patrol Boat is shorter than Submarine - clue 2); he is Fred, and his opponent won with a Battleship (only remaining ship longer than a Submarine - clue 2), so Brown beat Alexis with a Destroyer (only ship left).  Meaning:
Stacie Black beat Fred Yeller by a Battleship.
Bart _____ beat Patty _____ by a Carrier.
_____ Brown beat Alexis Chartrel by a Destroyer.
_____ Azzuro beat Charlie Blanc by a Submarine.
Georgia Roon beat _____ _____ by a Patrol Boat.
The only place for the last name Peach is as the kid who lost to Georgia.  Since Peach lost, Lavender must have lost (clue 9) and Tanger must have won.  Two of the matches are known to be between a boy and a girl.  The other three must be one between a boy and a girl (clue 6), one between two boys (two of the unplaced kids are boys, and only one of them could be in the third boy/girl match), and one between two girls (two of the placed kids with unplaced opponents are girls, and only one of them could be in the third boy/girl match).  Charlie must be facing a boy who's last name is Azzuro, but it's not Jason (clue 2); it's Roger.  Brown cannot be Lila (clue 7); he's Jason, so Lila is Peach (only possibility).
In summary:
Bart Tanger beat Patty Lavender by a Carrier.
Stacie Black beat Fred Yeller by a Battleship.
Jason Brown beat Alexis Chartel by a Destroyer.
Roger Azzuro beat Charlie Blanc by a Submarine.
Georgia Roon beat Lila Peach by a Patrol Boat.
Response:
Solution outline (step-by-step)

1.  Fix what each clue states outright.  
   •  Alexis’ surname is Chartel and she lost (1).  
   •  Georgia’s surname is Roon and she won (10).  
   •  Fred lost to the child surnamed Black; Black is not Bart and Fred is not Blanc (4).  
   •  The Charlie-game was won by a Submarine (3).  
   •  Bart’s surviving ship is a Carrier; therefore Bart is a winner (8).

   That already supplies all five different winners and all five different losers, so list the five unfinished score-lines:

      A) ____ ____ beat Alexis Chartel with a ____  
      B) Bart ____ beat ____ ____ with the Carrier  
      C) ____ ____ beat Charlie ____ with the Submarine  
      D) ____ Black beat Fred ____ with a ____  
      E) Georgia Roon beat ____ ____ with a ____

2.  Fit the five games to the five descriptions in clue 7  
      • “Stacie won” ⟶ Stacie is the Black in line D (Alexis was not her victim).  
      • “Patty lost” ⟶ Patty is the loser in one of the other four lines.  
      • “Boy Brown won” ⟶ a boy surnamed Brown is the winner in line A.  
      • “Kid Blanc lost” ⟶ the loser in line C is Blanc (so Charlie Blanc).  
      • “Game whose lone survivor is a Patrol Boat (surname not Black)” ⟶ line E; Georgia Roon’s survivor is the Patrol Boat.

      Current sheet

      A) (boy) Brown beat Alexis Chartel with a ____  
      B) Bart ____ beat Patty ____ with the Carrier  
      C) ____  Azzuro beat Charlie Blanc with the Submarine    (from 3, name still blank)  
      D) Stacie Black beat Fred ____ with a ____  
      E) Georgia Roon beat ____ ____ with the Patrol Boat

3.  Locate surnames by direct statements  
      •  “One match was Lavender vs Tanger” (5).  The only completely unnamed surnames in the same game are Bart’s and Patty’s, so Bart and Patty must be Tanger and Lavender in some order.  
      •  “Peach and Lavender had the same result” (9).  Patty is Lavender and she lost, hence the other loser must be Peach.  The only un-named loser left is Georgia’s opponent, so   Lila Peach lost to Georgia and Patty Lavender lost to Bart.  Therefore Bart is Tanger.

4.  Use clue 2 (“Azzuro not Jason, Azzuro’s ship is shorter than the ship of whoever beat Yeller”).  
      –  The only surname not assigned to a winner is Azzuro, so the winner in line C is Roger Azzuro (Jason is already earmarked to be Brown in line A).  
      –  Because Azzuro’s ship (Submarine, length 3) is shorter than the ship that beat Yeller, the Yeller game must be line D (Stacie Black’s).  Therefore Fred is Yeller and Stacie’s surviving ship must be longer than length 3.  The only unused ship longer than 3 is the Battleship (length 4).  Thus Stacie Black won with the Battleship.

5.  Assign the one remaining ship.  
      Ships used so far: Carrier (Bart), Patrol Boat (Georgia), Submarine (Roger), Battleship (Stacie).  
      The only ship still unused is the Destroyer, so boy-Brown’s victory over Alexis used the Destroyer.  Boy Brown is Jason (the only boy’s first name still unplaced).

6.  Check the “three – and only three – boy/girl matches” requirement (6).  
      Bart (b) vs Patty (g)    → boy/girl  
      Stacie (g) vs Fred (b)    → girl/boy  
      Jason (b) vs Alexis (g)   → boy/girl  
      Roger (b) vs Charlie (b)  → boy/boy  
      Georgia (g) vs Lila (g)   → girl/girl  
      Exactly three mixed-gender games – condition met.

7.  Fill in every blank:

   •  Bart Tanger beat Patty Lavender – Carrier  
   •  Stacie Black beat Fred Yeller – Battleship  
   •  Jason Brown beat Alexis Chartel – Destroyer  
   •  Roger Azzuro beat Charlie Blanc – Submarine  
   •  Georgia Roon beat Lila Peach – Patrol Boat

Answer (winners, losers, surviving ship)

1. Bart Tanger defeated Patty Lavender; surviving ship: Carrier  
2. Stacie Black defeated Fred Yeller; surviving ship: Battleship  
3. Jason Brown defeated Alexis Chartel; surviving ship: Destroyer  
4. Roger Azzuro defeated Charlie Blanc; surviving ship: Submarine  
5. Georgia Roon defeated Lila Peach; surviving ship: Patrol Boat

Question:
Question: Johnny was given 16 coins by his older, somewhat meaner brother, Mark.  He told him that he could keep them all if he could place all 16 on the table in such a way that they formed 15 rows with 4 coins in each row.
After 10 minutes, Johnny walked away with the coins and Mark, after complaining futilely to his mother, left with nothing.
How did Johnny place the coins?
 Solution: If you draw a 5-pointed star with all sides of equal length, you will create a pentagon in the middle with all 5 sides of equal length. Then draw another 5 pointed star, upside-down, using the 5 points of the interior pentagon as the points of the inner star,  This will give you another 5-sided pentagon in the interior of the second, smaller star.
Now, take your 16 coins and place 5 on the outside points of the outside star.  Then place 5 more on the points of each of the two pentagons you have created.  Finally, place the last coin in the dead center of this drawing.
The lines are as follows:
5 lines for the actual drawing of the outside star
5 lines for the actual drawing of the inside star
5 lines that start from any outside point of the outside star and go to the opposite point of the inside star, passing through 1 point of the inner pentagon, the dead center coin on the way.
Total lines: 15
Hint: Stars and pentagons
Human Solution:
If you draw a 5-pointed star with all sides of equal length, you will create a pentagon in the middle with all 5 sides of equal length. Then draw another 5 pointed star, upside-down, using the 5 points of the interior pentagon as the points of the inner star,  This will give you another 5-sided pentagon in the interior of the second, smaller star.
Now, take your 16 coins and place 5 on the outside points of the outside star.  Then place 5 more on the points of each of the two pentagons you have created.  Finally, place the last coin in the dead center of this drawing.
The lines are as follows:
5 lines for the actual drawing of the outside star
5 lines for the actual drawing of the inside star
5 lines that start from any outside point of the outside star and go to the opposite point of the inside star, passing through 1 point of the inner pentagon, the dead center coin on the way.
Total lines: 15
Response:
Summary of the construction (16 coins → 15 rows → 4 coins per row)

Step 1.  Sketch the guide lines  
• Draw a regular five-pointed star (a pentagram).  
• The star encloses a regular pentagon.  
• Using the five vertices of that pentagon as new “outer” points, draw a second, inverted pentagram; this produces a still smaller pentagon in the centre.  
Altogether you now have three nested figures that supply 15 straight segments:  
 – 5 sides of the large star,  
 – 5 sides of the small (inverted) star,  
 – 5 “spokes” that run from each outer-star tip, through the centre, to the opposite tip of the inner star.

Step 2.  Place the 16 coins  
• 5 coins on the tips of the large (outer) star.  
• 5 coins on the vertices of the first pentagon (these same points are the tips of the inner star).  
• 5 coins on the vertices of the innermost pentagon formed by the second star.  
• 1 coin exactly at the common centre of the figure.  
Total coins used: 5 + 5 + 5 + 1 = 16.

Step 3.  Verify the rows  
Follow each of the 15 straight guide segments noted in Step 1:  
– Each outer-star side passes through 1 outer-star coin, 1 mid-pentagon coin, 1 inner-pentagon coin, and ends at the next outer-star coin → 4 coins.  
– Each inner-star side likewise meets 4 coins (inner-star tip, inner-pentagon tip, centre coin, next inner-star tip).  
– Each spoke meets an outer-star tip, a mid-pentagon tip, the centre coin, and the opposite inner-star tip → 4 coins.  

Thus the 16 coins form exactly 15 straight rows, each containing 4 coins, so Johnny keeps all the coins.

Question:
Question: You are given a stack of bingo cards.  Your task is to find a specific card.  Given the following clues, what is the number arrangement of that card?
Columns, left to right, are: B (contains numbers 1 through 15), I (contains numbers 16 through 30), N (contains numbers 31 through 45), G (contains numbers 46 through 60), O (contains numbers 61 through 75).  Rows, top to bottom, are: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.  An example of coordinate nomenclature: B1 identifies column B row 1.  N3 is a free space (contains no number).  No number appears more than once.
1) All numbers in row 2 are divisible by 2; all numbers in row 3 are divisible by 3; all numbers in row 4 are divisible by 4; all numbers in row 5 are divisible by 5.
2) Row 2: the units digits are the same.
3) Row 4: the units digits are all different.
4) Row 5: the sum of the numbers is divisible by 7.
5) Column B: contains five consecutive numbers (in any order).
6) Column I: three of the numbers are odd.
7) Column G: three numbers are divisible by 3; three numbers are divisible by 4; one number is divisible by 12.
8) Column O: the sum of the five numbers is an odd number.
9) The product of I3 and G3 is between 1300 and 1400.
10) The sum of B1 and O1 is 82.
11) The difference between N1 and N5 is 1.
12) N2 is midway between B4 and O4.
13) N4 is midway between I1 and G1.
 Solution: 7 23 44 57 75
6 26 36 56 66
9 27 -- 51 72
8 16 40 52 64
10 25 45 60 70
1) Per clue 1, eliminate the appropriate numbers in the various rows.
2) Per clue 6, since rows 2 and 4 must contain even numbers, the other three rows in column I must contain odd numbers.  I5 must be 25.
3) Per clue 7, G5 must be 60.
4) Per clue 9, I3 must be 27 and G3 must be 51.
5) Per clue 13, since I1 is odd, then G1 must be odd.  G1 must be 57.  I1 must be 23.  N4 must be 40.
6) Per clue 10, B1 can not be less than 7 and O1 can not be less than 67.
7) Per clue 2, based on G2, no number in row 2 can end in 0 or 4 or 8.
8) Per clue 5, eliminate impossible combinations in column B.
9) Per clue 12, eliminate numbers that can not work.  N2 must be 36.  O4 must be either 64 or 68.
10) Per clue 2, the units digits is 6.  B2 must be 6.  G2 must be 56.  O2 must be 66.  This leaves G4 as 52.
11) Per clue 5, eliminate impossible combinations in column B.  B1 must be 7.
12) Per clue 10, O1 must be 75.
13) Per clue 3, I4 must be 16.  This leaves I2 as 26.
14) Per clue 4, in order for the sum of row 5 to be divisible by 7, the sum must be either 175 or 210.  Since I5 must be 25 and G5 must be 60, then the sum must be 210.  B5 must be 10.  N5 must be 45.  O5 must be 70.
15) Per clue 5, B3 must be 9 and B4 must be 8.
16) Per clue 3, O4 must be 64.
17) Per clue 8, O3 must be 72.
18) Per clue 11, N1 must be 44.
Hint: Start with clue 1 to eliminate numbers in various rows
Human Solution:
7 23 44 57 75
6 26 36 56 66
9 27 -- 51 72
8 16 40 52 64
10 25 45 60 70
1) Per clue 1, eliminate the appropriate numbers in the various rows.
2) Per clue 6, since rows 2 and 4 must contain even numbers, the other three rows in column I must contain odd numbers.  I5 must be 25.
3) Per clue 7, G5 must be 60.
4) Per clue 9, I3 must be 27 and G3 must be 51.
5) Per clue 13, since I1 is odd, then G1 must be odd.  G1 must be 57.  I1 must be 23.  N4 must be 40.
6) Per clue 10, B1 can not be less than 7 and O1 can not be less than 67.
7) Per clue 2, based on G2, no number in row 2 can end in 0 or 4 or 8.
8) Per clue 5, eliminate impossible combinations in column B.
9) Per clue 12, eliminate numbers that can not work.  N2 must be 36.  O4 must be either 64 or 68.
10) Per clue 2, the units digits is 6.  B2 must be 6.  G2 must be 56.  O2 must be 66.  This leaves G4 as 52.
11) Per clue 5, eliminate impossible combinations in column B.  B1 must be 7.
12) Per clue 10, O1 must be 75.
13) Per clue 3, I4 must be 16.  This leaves I2 as 26.
14) Per clue 4, in order for the sum of row 5 to be divisible by 7, the sum must be either 175 or 210.  Since I5 must be 25 and G5 must be 60, then the sum must be 210.  B5 must be 10.  N5 must be 45.  O5 must be 70.
15) Per clue 5, B3 must be 9 and B4 must be 8.
16) Per clue 3, O4 must be 64.
17) Per clue 8, O3 must be 72.
18) Per clue 11, N1 must be 44.
Response:
B I N G O  
7  23 44 57 75  
6  26 36 56 66  
9  27  –  51 72  
8  16 40 52 64  
10 25 45 60 70  


Reasoning in short, self-contained steps  

1. Column limits (B 1-15, I 16-30, N 31-45, G 46-60, O 61-75) and the row rules give the following:  
   • Row 2 even, Row 3 multiple of 3, Row 4 multiple of 4, Row 5 multiple of 5.  
   • Row 3 has a free space in N3.

2. Column I must contain exactly three odd numbers (clue 6).  
   Rows 2 and 4 are even, so rows 1, 3 and 5 in column I are the odds.  
   The only multiple of 5 in the I-range is 25 ⇒ I5 = 25.

3. Column G must have one number divisible by 12 (clue 7).  
   In 46-60 the only such number is 60 ⇒ G5 = 60 (fits row 5 rule).

4. The product I3 × G3 is between 1300 and 1400 (clue 9).  
   Testing row-3 candidates (both must be multiples of 3 in their ranges) gives the unique pair  
   I3 = 27 and G3 = 51 (27 × 51 = 1377).

5. N4 is midway between I1 and G1 (clue 13) and must be a multiple of 4 (row 4 rule).  
   Looking for two odd numbers I1 (16-30) and G1 (46-60) whose average is a multiple of 4 gives  
   I1 = 23, G1 = 57, N4 = 40.

6. Row 2 ends in the same digit (clues 1 & 2).  
   Because G2 must be 46-60 and even, endings 0, 4, 8 fail to satisfy column-G requirements; choose units digit 6.  
   ⇒ B2 = 6, I2 = 26, N2 = 36, G2 = 56, O2 = 66.

7. Column G now contains 57, 56, 51, –, 60.  
   We still need a third multiple of 4 (clue 7) ⇒ G4 = 52.

8. Row 4 units-digits must all be different (clue 3).  
   With B4 unknown, present endings are 0 (40), 2 (52).  
   Choosing I4 = 16 (ending 6) keeps digits distinct.

9. Column B must hold five consecutive numbers (clue 5).  
   We already have 6 (B2) and need multiples for rows 3-5: B3 multiple of 3 ⇒ 9, B4 multiple of 4 ⇒ 8, B5 multiple of 5 ⇒ 10.  
   Completing the consecutive block {6,7,8,9,10} forces B1 = 7.

10. Sum B1 + O1 = 82 (clue 10) ⇒ O1 = 75.

11. N2 is midway between B4 and O4 (clue 12): 36 = (8 + O4)/2 ⇒ O4 = 64.  
    Row 4 endings are now 8-6-0-2-4, all different.

12. Column-O currently is 75 + 66 + 64 = 205 (odd).  
    To keep the final column sum odd, O3 and O5 must share parity.

13. Row 5 sum must be divisible by 7 (clue 4).  
    Present total: 10 + 25 + 60 = 95.  
    Choosing N5 = 45 and O5 = 70 gives 10 + 25 + 45 + 60 + 70 = 210 (divisible by 7).  
    O5 is even, so O3 must be even ⇒ O3 = 72 (only even multiple of 3 left in the O-range).

14. Row 3 is now 9, 27, –, 51, 72 – all multiples of 3 as required.

15. Difference between N1 and N5 is 1 (clue 11) with N5 = 45 ⇒ N1 = 44 (within 31-45).

Every clue is now satisfied, giving the unique bingo card shown at the top.

Question:
Question: Zachary has a private zoo.  He has five groups of animals in his zoo:  snakes, birds, mammals, insects, and spiders.  Assume that, typically:  animals have 1 head, snakes have 0 legs, birds have 2 legs, mammals have 4 legs, insects have 6 legs, and spiders have 8 legs.  Zachary has some unusual animals in his zoo.  He has:  a snake with 3 heads, a bird with 2 heads, a mammal with 3 legs, an insect with 4 legs, and a spider with 7 legs.  From the following information, determine how many of each group of animals that Zachary has in his menagerie.
1) There are a total of 100 heads and 376 legs.
2) Each group has a different quantity of animals.
3) The most populous group has 10 more members than the least populous group.
4) There are twice as many insect legs as there are bird legs.
5) There are as many snake heads as there are spider heads.
 Solution: A) Since there are 3 extra heads (2 snake and 1 bird), there are only 97 animals (clue 1).  Find a set of five different numbers whose sum is 97 (clue 2) and whose size difference between the least populous and most populous group is 10 (clue 3).  There are 17 sets that meet these requirements.
13, 18, 21, 22, 23
13, 19, 20, 22, 23
14, 15, 21, 23, 24
14, 16, 20, 23, 24
14, 16, 21, 22, 24
14, 17, 19, 23, 24
14, 17, 20, 22, 24
14, 18, 19, 22, 24
14, 18, 20, 21, 24
15, 16, 17, 24, 25
15, 16, 18, 23, 25
15, 16, 19, 22, 25
15, 16, 20, 21, 25
15, 17, 18, 22, 25
15, 17, 19, 21, 25
15, 18, 19, 20, 25
16, 17, 18, 20, 26
B) There are twice as many insect legs as there are bird legs (clue 4).  To find the possible bird and insect group sizes, multiply the quantity of insects by 6 (legs per insect).  Subtract 2 (an insect is missing 2 legs).  Divide by 2 (twice as many insect legs as bird legs).  Divide by 2 (legs per bird) to get the quantity of birds.  The formula is:  B = ((I * 6) - 2) / 4.  There are three combinations that work:  13 and 19, 15 and 22, 17 and 25.
((13 insects * 6 legs/insect) - 2 missing legs) / 4 = 19 birds
((15 insects * 6 legs/insect) - 2 missing legs) / 4 = 22 birds
((17 insects * 6 legs/insect) - 2 missing legs) / 4 = 25 birds
Of the 17 sets (from step A), only 5 contain these sizes.
13, 19, 20, 22, 23 (13 insects & 19 birds)
15, 16, 17, 24, 25 (17 insects & 25 birds)
15, 16, 19, 22, 25 (15 insects & 22 birds)
15, 17, 18, 22, 25 (15 insects & 22 birds or 17 insects & 25 birds)
15, 17, 19, 21, 25 (17 insects & 25 birds)
C) There are as many snake heads as spider heads (clue 5).  Since there is a snake with two extra heads, there are actually 2 fewer snakes compared to spiders.  Only 2 combinations (from step B) yield the required head count.
13 insects, 19 birds, 20 snakes, 22 spiders, 23 mammals
15 mammals, 17 insects, 19 snakes, 21 spiders, 25 birds
D) The only group combination (from step C) that produces 376 legs (clue 1) is:  15, 17, 19, 21, 25.  The other combination yields 380 legs.
(15 mammals * 4 legs/mammal) - 1 missing leg = 59 legs
(17 insects * 6 legs/insect) - 2 missing legs = 100 legs
19 snakes * 0 legs/snake = 0 legs
(21 spiders * 8 legs/spider) - 1 missing leg = 167 legs
25 birds * 2 legs/birds = 50 legs
Thus, there are:  19 snakes (21 heads and 0 legs), 25 birds (26 heads and 50 legs), 15 mammals (15 heads and 59 legs), 17 insects (17 heads and 100 legs), and 21 spiders (21 heads and 167 legs).  This produces 97 animals with 100 heads and 376 legs.
Hint: Since there are 3 extra heads (2 snake and 1 bird), there are only 97 animals (clue 1).  Find a set of five different numbers whose sum is 97 (clue 2) and whose size difference between the least populous and most populous group is 10 (clue 3).
Human Solution:
A) Since there are 3 extra heads (2 snake and 1 bird), there are only 97 animals (clue 1).  Find a set of five different numbers whose sum is 97 (clue 2) and whose size difference between the least populous and most populous group is 10 (clue 3).  There are 17 sets that meet these requirements.
13, 18, 21, 22, 23
13, 19, 20, 22, 23
14, 15, 21, 23, 24
14, 16, 20, 23, 24
14, 16, 21, 22, 24
14, 17, 19, 23, 24
14, 17, 20, 22, 24
14, 18, 19, 22, 24
14, 18, 20, 21, 24
15, 16, 17, 24, 25
15, 16, 18, 23, 25
15, 16, 19, 22, 25
15, 16, 20, 21, 25
15, 17, 18, 22, 25
15, 17, 19, 21, 25
15, 18, 19, 20, 25
16, 17, 18, 20, 26
B) There are twice as many insect legs as there are bird legs (clue 4).  To find the possible bird and insect group sizes, multiply the quantity of insects by 6 (legs per insect).  Subtract 2 (an insect is missing 2 legs).  Divide by 2 (twice as many insect legs as bird legs).  Divide by 2 (legs per bird) to get the quantity of birds.  The formula is:  B = ((I * 6) - 2) / 4.  There are three combinations that work:  13 and 19, 15 and 22, 17 and 25.
((13 insects * 6 legs/insect) - 2 missing legs) / 4 = 19 birds
((15 insects * 6 legs/insect) - 2 missing legs) / 4 = 22 birds
((17 insects * 6 legs/insect) - 2 missing legs) / 4 = 25 birds
Of the 17 sets (from step A), only 5 contain these sizes.
13, 19, 20, 22, 23 (13 insects & 19 birds)
15, 16, 17, 24, 25 (17 insects & 25 birds)
15, 16, 19, 22, 25 (15 insects & 22 birds)
15, 17, 18, 22, 25 (15 insects & 22 birds or 17 insects & 25 birds)
15, 17, 19, 21, 25 (17 insects & 25 birds)
C) There are as many snake heads as spider heads (clue 5).  Since there is a snake with two extra heads, there are actually 2 fewer snakes compared to spiders.  Only 2 combinations (from step B) yield the required head count.
13 insects, 19 birds, 20 snakes, 22 spiders, 23 mammals
15 mammals, 17 insects, 19 snakes, 21 spiders, 25 birds
D) The only group combination (from step C) that produces 376 legs (clue 1) is:  15, 17, 19, 21, 25.  The other combination yields 380 legs.
(15 mammals * 4 legs/mammal) - 1 missing leg = 59 legs
(17 insects * 6 legs/insect) - 2 missing legs = 100 legs
19 snakes * 0 legs/snake = 0 legs
(21 spiders * 8 legs/spider) - 1 missing leg = 167 legs
25 birds * 2 legs/birds = 50 legs
Thus, there are:  19 snakes (21 heads and 0 legs), 25 birds (26 heads and 50 legs), 15 mammals (15 heads and 59 legs), 17 insects (17 heads and 100 legs), and 21 spiders (21 heads and 167 legs).  This produces 97 animals with 100 heads and 376 legs.
Response:
S = number of snakes, B = birds, M = mammals, I = insects, P = spiders  

Special specimens  
• one 3-headed snake → +2 extra heads  
• one 2-headed bird   → +1 extra head  
• one 3-legged mammal → –1 leg  
• one 4-legged insect → –2 legs  
• one 7-legged spider → –1 leg  

Step 1 – Total heads  
Normal heads = S+B+M+I+P  
Extra heads = 2+1 = 3  
S+B+M+I+P + 3 = 100  ⇒  S+B+M+I+P = 97             (1)

Step 2 – Total legs  
Normal legs = 0S + 2B + 4M + 6I + 8P  
Missing legs = 1+2+1 = 4  
0S+2B+4M+6I+8P – 4 = 376  
Divide by 2: B + 2M + 3I + 4P = 190          (2)

Step 3 – Twice as many insect legs as bird legs  
(6I – 2) = 2·(2B)  → 3I – 1 = 2B  
B = (3I – 1)/2                        (3)  
Hence I must be odd.

Step 4 – Equal numbers of snake and spider heads  
Snake heads = S+2  Spider heads = P  
S+2 = P  ⇒ P = S + 2                            (4)

Step 5 – Numbers are all different and max – min = 10
