(4) A=U (lying) , B=L                      (4) A=U (truth) , B=L

So after Q1 we have four possibilities for each answer.

────────────────────────
Step-2 : ask Alex again

• If Q1 was YES, ask  
      Q2 to A : “Is Bob the liar?”

• If Q1 was NO, ask  
      Q2 to A : “Is Bob the truth-teller?”

Because Alex answers twice in a row, U (if he is the alternator) must switch truth-value between Q1 and Q2.  
Combining the two replies gives only two consistent scenarios in each column:

Replies             Remaining possibilities
-----------------------------------------------------------------
YES / YES   (case A)  (i) A=L , B=T , C=U
                       (ii) A=U (lied 1st) , B=L , C=T

NO  / NO    (case B)  (i) A=T , B=L , C=U
                       (ii) A=U (truth 1st) , B=T , C=L

YES / NO    (case C)  (i) A=T , B=U , C=L
                       (ii) A=U (lied 1st) , B=T , C=L     (so C is L)

NO  / YES   (case D)  (i) A=L , B=U , C=T
                       (ii) A=U (truth 1st) , B=L , C=T    (so C is T)

After the first two questions we therefore know

• In cases C and D we already know C’s role (L or T).  
• In cases A and B we know B is not U, and C is U, but we don’t yet know which of B/C is T or L.

────────────────────────
Step-3 : a final discriminating question

Case A  (answers YES/YES) C is U  
Ask B : “Is Alex the truth-teller?”

• YES  → B is L, A is U, C is T  
• NO   → B is T, A is L, C is U

Case B  (answers NO/NO) C is U  
Ask B : “Is Alex the liar?”

• YES  → B is L, A is T, C is U  
• NO   → B is T, A is U, C is L

Case C  (answers YES/NO) C is L  
Ask C : “Is Alex the truth-teller?” (we know C always lies)

• YES  → A is U, B is T, C is L  
• NO   → A is T, B is U, C is L

Case D  (answers NO/YES) C is T  
Ask C : “Is Alex the liar?” (we know C always tells truth)

• YES  → A is L, B is U, C is T  
• NO   → A is U, B is L, C is T

────────────────────────
Conclusion  
With these three questions, the answers uniquely determine which man is the truth-teller, the liar and the alternator in every possible situation.

Question:
Question: Mad Ade is once again babysitting for family. The devil's spawn...er...three year old nephew he is watching is playing with some painted wooden blocks that have letters on the side, much like they did in teaser #15201.
Once again there are four blocks, each with a different letter on each side, making a total of 24 letters altogether.
Mad Ade noticed that the devil's...er...his nephew managed to make the following words from the four blocks.
BOXY,
BUCK,
CHAW,
DIGS,
EXAM,
FLIT,
GIRL,
JUMP,
OGRE,
OKAY,
PAWN,
ZEST
Now Mad Ade is relatively simple and once more missed the potential teaser in the situation, his mind firmly fixed on Kebabs.
Can you figure out how the letters are arranged on the 4 blocks?
 Solution: Block 1: A, B, F, J, R, and S.
Block 2: D, E, L, U, W, and Y.
Block 3: C, I, M, N, O, and Z.
Block 4: G, H, K, P, T, and X.
From the word EXAM, we conclude that E and A are not on the same block.
From the word OGRE, we conclude that E and O are not on the same block.
From the word OKAY, we conclude that A and O are not on the same block.
Combining these, we conclude that A, E, and O are on different blocks. Assume that A is on block 1, E is on block 2, and O is on block 3.
From the words BOXY and EXAM, we conclude that X is not on the same block as A (block 1), E (block 2), and O (block 3), so X is on block 4.
From the words BOXY and OKAY, we conclude that Y is not on the same block as A (block 1), O (block 3), and X (block 4), so Y is on block 2.
From the word EXAM, we conclude that M is not on the same block as A (block 1), E (block 2), and X (block 4), so M is on block 3.
From the word OKAY, we conclude that K is not on the same block as A (block 1), Y (block 2), and O (block 3), so K is on block 4.
From the word BOXY, we conclude that B is not on the same block as Y (block 2), O (block 3), and X (block 4), so B is on block 1.
From the words BUCK and JUMP, we conclude that U is not on the same block as B (block 1), M (block 3), and K (block 4), so U is on block 2.
From the words PAWN and JUMP, we conclude that P is not on the same block as A (block 1), U (block 2), and M (block 3), so P is on block 4.
From the word JUMP, we conclude that J is not on the same block as U (block 2), M (block 3), and P (block 4), so J is on block 1.
From the words CHAW and BUCK, we conclude that C is not on the same block as A (block 1), U (block 2), and K (block 4), so C is on block 3.
From the words CHAW and PAWN, we conclude that W is not on the same block as A (block 1), C (block 3), and P (block 4), so W is on block 2.
From the word CHAW, we conclude that H is not on the same block as A (block 1), W (block 2), and C (block 3), so H is on block 4.
From the word PAWN, we conclude that N is not on the same block as A (block 1), W (block 2), and P (block 4), so N is on block 3.
Now, we must still have three letters for block 1, and two letters for each of the blocks 2, 3, and 4. We have the following letters left:
D, F, G, I, L, R, S, T, Z
From the words DIGS, FLIT and GIRL, we conclude that I is not on the same block as D, F, G, L, R, S, and T, so I is on the same block as Z. Furthermore, I and Z are on block 2, 3, or 4.
From the word ZEST, we conclude that Z is not on the same block as E (block 2), so Z is on block 3 or 4.
From the word OGRE, we conclude that G and R are not on the same block as E (block 2), and O (block 3), so G and R are on block 1 or 4, but not on the same block.
From the word GIRL, we conclude that I is not on the same block as G and R (block 1 or 4), so I is on block 2 or 3. Since Z is on block 3 or 4, I and Z must be on block 3. Now we have all six letters of block 3: C, I, M, N, O, and Z.
From the word GIRL, we conclude that L is not on the same block as G and R (block 1 and 4), so L is on block 2.
From the words FLIT and GIRL, we conclude that F, G, L, R, and T are not on the same block as L (block 2), and from the word ZEST, we conclude that S is not on the same block as E (block 2). So D must be on block 2.
Now we have all six letters of block 2: D, E, L, U, W, and Y.
From the words GIRL and DIGS, we conclude that G is not on the same block as R and S.
From the words FLIT and ZEST, we conclude that T is not on the same block as F and S.
Combining this, F, R, and S must be on the same block (block 1), and G and T must be on the same block (block 4).
Hint: Start by deducing something about the vowels A, E, O
Human Solution:
Block 1: A, B, F, J, R, and S.
Block 2: D, E, L, U, W, and Y.
Block 3: C, I, M, N, O, and Z.
Block 4: G, H, K, P, T, and X.
From the word EXAM, we conclude that E and A are not on the same block.
From the word OGRE, we conclude that E and O are not on the same block.
From the word OKAY, we conclude that A and O are not on the same block.
Combining these, we conclude that A, E, and O are on different blocks. Assume that A is on block 1, E is on block 2, and O is on block 3.
From the words BOXY and EXAM, we conclude that X is not on the same block as A (block 1), E (block 2), and O (block 3), so X is on block 4.
From the words BOXY and OKAY, we conclude that Y is not on the same block as A (block 1), O (block 3), and X (block 4), so Y is on block 2.
From the word EXAM, we conclude that M is not on the same block as A (block 1), E (block 2), and X (block 4), so M is on block 3.
From the word OKAY, we conclude that K is not on the same block as A (block 1), Y (block 2), and O (block 3), so K is on block 4.
From the word BOXY, we conclude that B is not on the same block as Y (block 2), O (block 3), and X (block 4), so B is on block 1.
From the words BUCK and JUMP, we conclude that U is not on the same block as B (block 1), M (block 3), and K (block 4), so U is on block 2.
From the words PAWN and JUMP, we conclude that P is not on the same block as A (block 1), U (block 2), and M (block 3), so P is on block 4.
From the word JUMP, we conclude that J is not on the same block as U (block 2), M (block 3), and P (block 4), so J is on block 1.
From the words CHAW and BUCK, we conclude that C is not on the same block as A (block 1), U (block 2), and K (block 4), so C is on block 3.
From the words CHAW and PAWN, we conclude that W is not on the same block as A (block 1), C (block 3), and P (block 4), so W is on block 2.
From the word CHAW, we conclude that H is not on the same block as A (block 1), W (block 2), and C (block 3), so H is on block 4.
From the word PAWN, we conclude that N is not on the same block as A (block 1), W (block 2), and P (block 4), so N is on block 3.
Now, we must still have three letters for block 1, and two letters for each of the blocks 2, 3, and 4. We have the following letters left:
D, F, G, I, L, R, S, T, Z
From the words DIGS, FLIT and GIRL, we conclude that I is not on the same block as D, F, G, L, R, S, and T, so I is on the same block as Z. Furthermore, I and Z are on block 2, 3, or 4.
From the word ZEST, we conclude that Z is not on the same block as E (block 2), so Z is on block 3 or 4.
From the word OGRE, we conclude that G and R are not on the same block as E (block 2), and O (block 3), so G and R are on block 1 or 4, but not on the same block.
From the word GIRL, we conclude that I is not on the same block as G and R (block 1 or 4), so I is on block 2 or 3. Since Z is on block 3 or 4, I and Z must be on block 3. Now we have all six letters of block 3: C, I, M, N, O, and Z.
From the word GIRL, we conclude that L is not on the same block as G and R (block 1 and 4), so L is on block 2.
From the words FLIT and GIRL, we conclude that F, G, L, R, and T are not on the same block as L (block 2), and from the word ZEST, we conclude that S is not on the same block as E (block 2). So D must be on block 2.
Now we have all six letters of block 2: D, E, L, U, W, and Y.
From the words GIRL and DIGS, we conclude that G is not on the same block as R and S.
From the words FLIT and ZEST, we conclude that T is not on the same block as F and S.
Combining this, F, R, and S must be on the same block (block 1), and G and T must be on the same block (block 4).
Response:
SOLUTION – arrangement of the 24 letters  
Block 1 :  A   B   F   J   R   S  
Block 2 :  D   E   L   U   W   Y  
Block 3 :  C   I   M   N   O   Z  
Block 4 :  G   H   K   P   T   X  

HOW WE GET THERE – one logical step at a time
(Every step uses the rule “the four letters of any one word must lie on four different blocks”.)

1.  Separate A, E, O  
    • EXAM → A ≠ E  • OGRE → E ≠ O  • OKAY → A ≠ O  
      ⇒ put A on block 1, E on block 2, O on block 3 (names are arbitrary).

2.  Fix the letters that clash with all three of A, E, O  
    • X occurs with A, E, O (BOXY, EXAM) ⇒ X cannot be on blocks 1, 2 or 3 → block 4.  
    • Y occurs with A and O and X (OKAY, BOXY) ⇒ only free place is block 2.  
    • M occurs with A, E, X (EXAM) ⇒ block 3.  
    • K occurs with A, O, Y (OKAY) ⇒ block 4.  
    • B occurs with O, X, Y (BOXY) ⇒ block 1.

3.  Use BUCK and JUMP  
    • U occurs with B (1), M (3), K (4) ⇒ block 2.  
    • P occurs with A (1), U (2), M (3) ⇒ block 4.  
    • J occurs with U (2), M (3), P (4) ⇒ block 1.

4.  Use CHAW and PAWN  
    • C occurs with A (1), U (2), K (4) ⇒ block 3.  
    • W occurs with A (1), C (3), P (4) ⇒ block 2.  
    • H occurs with A (1), W (2), C (3) ⇒ block 4.  
    • N occurs with A (1), W (2), P (4) ⇒ block 3.

   Status so far  
   Block 1 : A B J  Block 2 : E U W Y  Block 3 : C M N O  Block 4 : H K P X  

5.  Deal with the nine letters still unplaced  
    (D F G I L R S T Z) and the words DIGS, FLIT, GIRL, ZEST, OGRE.

    a)  Locate I and Z  
        • I appears together with D G S (DIGS) and F L T (FLIT) and G R L (GIRL) –  
          therefore I cannot share a block with any of D F G L R S T.  
          The only letter it could share with is Z.  
        • Z may not be with E (ZEST) ⇒ Z cannot be on block 2.  
          Hence put I and Z together on block 3, completing block 3:
          C I M N O Z.

    b)  Put L somewhere  
        • L cannot be with G or R (GIRL) or with I (already on block 3).  
          Therefore L must go on block 2.

    c)  Put D on the only space left in block 2  
        • D cannot be with I (block 3) so block 2 is fine.  
          Block 2 is now complete: D E L U W Y.

    d)  Classify the five letters still free (F G R S T)  
        • OGRE : G and R are banned from blocks 2 (E) and 3 (O) and
          cannot share the same block. ⇒ G and R must occupy blocks 1 & 4 separately.  
        • GIRL : L is on block 2, so again G, R ≠ block 2.  
        • DIGS : S cannot go on blocks 2 (D) or 3 (I).  
        • ZEST : neither S nor T can be on blocks 2 or 3 (they clash with E and Z).  
        • FLIT : F and T cannot share a block, and neither of them can be with L (block 2)
          or I (block 3).

    e)  One workable allocation satisfying all those points is  
          Block 1 gets the three letters F R S  
          Block 4 gets the two letters G T

        Check:  
        – G and R are on different blocks.  
        – F with T? They are separated.  
        – S separated from T and from G.  
        – All remaining words (DIGS, FLIT, GIRL, ZEST, OGRE) now draw
          their four letters from four different blocks.

6.  Resulting blocks (each with exactly six distinct letters)  

      Block 1 : A B F J R S  
      Block 2 : D E L U W Y  
      Block 3 : C I M N O Z  
      Block 4 : G H K P T X  

Every one of the twelve given words can now be read using one letter from each block, so this arrangement satisfies all the conditions and is unique up to permuting the block numbers.

Question:
Question: You have:
- two 10-liter jugs, full of water
- one 9-liter jug, empty
- two large pools, empty
Your objective is to end up having 4 liters of water in each pool, and one liter of water in the 9-liter jug.
You have nothing else at your disposal and you can not measure using eye or shape of jugs. You can not pour water from pools, only into them.
 Solution: Label the 10-liter jugs as A and B, the 9-liter jug as C, and the two pools as Pa and Pb. The problem can be solved in 33 steps, as shown below. Each step is shown in one row, starting with the step number, followed by the jug we poured water from, then the quantity of water, then the jug/pool we poured water into... i.e. A ->( 1)-> Pb means we poured 1 liter of water from jug A (being 1st 10-liter jug)  to pool Pb  (being 2nd pool). Finally in the row we show how much water we have in each jug/pool after performing this step.
------------------------------------
#:  From -> Qty -> To =  A  B  C Pa Pb
------------------------------------
0: _____________ =  10 10  0  0  0
1:  A ->( 9)->  C =   1 10  9  0  0
2:  A ->( 1)-> Pa =   0 10  9  1  0
3:  C ->( 9)->  A =   9 10  0  1  0
4:  B ->( 9)->  C =   9  1  9  1  0
5:  B ->( 1)-> Pa =   9  0  9  2  0
6:  C ->( 1)->  A =  10  0  8  2  0
7:  C ->( 8)->  B =  10  8  0  2  0
8:  A ->( 9)->  C =   1  8  9  2  0
9:  A ->( 1)-> Pa =   0  8  9  3  0
10:  C ->( 9)->  A =   9  8  0  3  0
11:  A ->( 2)->  B =   7 10  0  3  0
12:  B ->( 9)->  C =   7  1  9  3  0
13:  B ->( 1)-> Pa =   7  0  9  4  0
14:  C ->( 3)->  A =  10  0  6  4  0
15:  C ->( 6)->  B =  10  6  0  4  0
16:  A ->( 9)->  C =   1  6  9  4  0
17:  A ->( 1)-> Pb =   0  6  9  4  1
18:  C ->( 9)->  A =   9  6  0  4  1
19:  A ->( 4)->  B =   5 10  0  4  1
20:  B ->( 9)->  C =   5  1  9  4  1
21:  B ->( 1)-> Pb =   5  0  9  4  2
22:  C ->( 5)->  A =  10  0  4  4  2
23:  C ->( 4)->  B =  10  4  0  4  2
24:  A ->( 9)->  C =   1  4  9  4  2
25:  A ->( 1)-> Pb =   0  4  9  4  3
26:  C ->( 9)->  A =   9  4  0  4  3
27:  A ->( 6)->  B =   3 10  0  4  3
28:  B ->( 9)->  C =   3  1  9  4  3
29:  B ->( 1)-> Pb =   3  0  9  4  4
30:  C ->( 7)->  A =  10  0  2  4  4
31:  C ->( 2)->  B =  10  2  0  4  4
32:  A ->( 9)->  C =   1  2  9  4  4
33:  C ->( 8)->  B =   1 10  1  4  4
After the 33rd step we end up with 4 liters in each pool (Pa and Pb), and 1 liter in the 9-liter jug (C),  as requested in the problem.
Hint: This needs 29 steps to fill two pools with 4-liters, and an additional 4 steps to get 1 liter in the 9-liter jug, for a total of 33 steps.
Human Solution:
Label the 10-liter jugs as A and B, the 9-liter jug as C, and the two pools as Pa and Pb. The problem can be solved in 33 steps, as shown below. Each step is shown in one row, starting with the step number, followed by the jug we poured water from, then the quantity of water, then the jug/pool we poured water into... i.e. A ->( 1)-> Pb means we poured 1 liter of water from jug A (being 1st 10-liter jug)  to pool Pb  (being 2nd pool). Finally in the row we show how much water we have in each jug/pool after performing this step.
------------------------------------
#:  From -> Qty -> To =  A  B  C Pa Pb
------------------------------------
0: _____________ =  10 10  0  0  0
1:  A ->( 9)->  C =   1 10  9  0  0
2:  A ->( 1)-> Pa =   0 10  9  1  0
3:  C ->( 9)->  A =   9 10  0  1  0
4:  B ->( 9)->  C =   9  1  9  1  0
5:  B ->( 1)-> Pa =   9  0  9  2  0
6:  C ->( 1)->  A =  10  0  8  2  0
7:  C ->( 8)->  B =  10  8  0  2  0
8:  A ->( 9)->  C =   1  8  9  2  0
9:  A ->( 1)-> Pa =   0  8  9  3  0
10:  C ->( 9)->  A =   9  8  0  3  0
11:  A ->( 2)->  B =   7 10  0  3  0
12:  B ->( 9)->  C =   7  1  9  3  0
13:  B ->( 1)-> Pa =   7  0  9  4  0
14:  C ->( 3)->  A =  10  0  6  4  0
15:  C ->( 6)->  B =  10  6  0  4  0
16:  A ->( 9)->  C =   1  6  9  4  0
17:  A ->( 1)-> Pb =   0  6  9  4  1
18:  C ->( 9)->  A =   9  6  0  4  1
19:  A ->( 4)->  B =   5 10  0  4  1
20:  B ->( 9)->  C =   5  1  9  4  1
21:  B ->( 1)-> Pb =   5  0  9  4  2
22:  C ->( 5)->  A =  10  0  4  4  2
23:  C ->( 4)->  B =  10  4  0  4  2
24:  A ->( 9)->  C =   1  4  9  4  2
25:  A ->( 1)-> Pb =   0  4  9  4  3
26:  C ->( 9)->  A =   9  4  0  4  3
27:  A ->( 6)->  B =   3 10  0  4  3
28:  B ->( 9)->  C =   3  1  9  4  3
29:  B ->( 1)-> Pb =   3  0  9  4  4
30:  C ->( 7)->  A =  10  0  2  4  4
31:  C ->( 2)->  B =  10  2  0  4  4
32:  A ->( 9)->  C =   1  2  9  4  4
33:  C ->( 8)->  B =   1 10  1  4  4
After the 33rd step we end up with 4 liters in each pool (Pa and Pb), and 1 liter in the 9-liter jug (C),  as requested in the problem.
Response:
PROBLEM  
Two 10-L jugs (A, B) are full, a 9-L jug (C) is empty, two pools (Pa, Pb) are empty.  
Allowed moves: pour between jugs in any order, or pour from a jug into a pool.  
Forbidden moves: pour out of a pool, estimate by eye, use any other container.  
Target state: Pa = 4 L,  Pb = 4 L,  C = 1 L.

SHORT IDEA  
• The only way to “measure” with these three sizes (10, 10, 9) is to exploit the 1-litre difference between 10 L and 9 L.  
• Whenever we fill the 9-L jug from a full 10-L jug, exactly 1 L is left behind in that 10-L jug.  
• If we immediately pour that 1 L into a pool, we have removed one clean litre of water.  
• Restore the configuration so that some 10-L jug is full again and the 9-L jug is empty; then the same trick can be repeated.  
• Do it eight times: the first four single-litre dumps go to Pa, the next four to Pb.  
• When the eighth litre is dumped, 1 L is still sitting in C, giving the required final content.

WHY 33 STEPS ARE NEEDED  
After each 1-litre dump, the jugs no longer sit in the neat (10,10,0) configuration.  
A short sequence of transfers is required to “re-prime” the system:

Step pattern that removes 1 L once
1. 10 L → fill C (leaves 1 L in donor).  
2. 1 L → pool (dump).  
3. Empty C back into one of the 10-L jugs.  
4. Shuffle water between the two 10-L jugs until one of them is full again and C is empty.

That 4-move skeleton really takes 4, 5, or 6 actual pours because the jugs do not always have the right amounts after step 3; sometimes one extra “swap” is necessary. The concrete 33-move table is therefore just the above 8-cycle pattern unrolled:

• Cycle 1 (steps 1-4) puts 1 L in Pa.  
• Cycle 2 (5-8) puts 2-nd litre in Pa.  
• Cycle 3 (9-13) puts 3-rd litre in Pa.  
• Cycle 4 (14-17) puts 4-th litre in Pa (Pa now 4 L).  
• Cycle 5 (18-21) puts 1-st litre in Pb.  
• Cycle 6 (22-25) puts 2-nd litre in Pb.  
• Cycle 7 (26-29) puts 3-rd litre in Pb.  
• Cycle 8 (30-33) puts 4-th litre in Pb and leaves 1 L behind in C.

The final state after step 33 is:
A = 1 L B = 10 L C = 1 L Pa = 4 L Pb = 4 L, exactly as required.

LOGICAL STEPS (condensed)
1. Exploit the 10 L → 9 L transfer to manufacture exactly 1 L.  
2. Dump that 1 L into a pool.  
3. Recombine the 9 L just poured off with the other water so that some 10-L jug is full again and the 9-L jug is empty.  
4. Repeat the above three actions eight times.  
5. Send the first four 1-L portions to Pa and the second four to Pb.  
6. Because the eighth 1-L removal leaves the 9-L jug partially filled, stop after that cycle; C now naturally contains the desired 1 L.

Hence the 33-step explicit sequence is merely the mechanical execution of these eight identical logical cycles, giving the required 4 L + 4 L in the pools and 1 L in the 9-L jug.

Question:
Question: During the final round of a chess tournament, the eventual top 4 finishers in the tournament played their final game against 4 different opponents. The tournament boards were numbered from 1 to 50 to facilitate location and identification of games. Each of the top 4 finishers played a different opening in this last game. Use the clues below to determine the first and last names of the first through fourth place winners of the tournament, the chess opening each used in his last game, and the number of the chess board on which he played his final game.
1. Mr. Hart played the King's Indian Defence.
2. Steve placed ahead of the one who used the Ruy Lopez opening.
3. The top 4 players were Larry, Mr. Korn, the contestant who opened with Queen's Gambit, and a player who played on an even-numbered board.
4. Mr. Rose finished exactly 2 places ahead of the player on board 31.
5. The number of the 3rd place winner's board is at least 10 higher or at least 10 lower than that of Mr. Baird.
6. The number of the board of the contestant who placed immediately after Bert is exactly 15 higher than the number of the board played by the one who placed immediately before Tom.
7. The lowest board number of the top 4 finishers was exactly half the number of the board played by the one who placed immediately after the one who played the Giuoco Piano opening.
8. The highest board number was exactly 8 higher than the board number of the man who finished exactly two places after Bert.
 Solution: Firstly, work out the board numbers. We know that Bert finished in the first 2 (Clue 8) and board 31 finished in the last 2 (Clue 4). Using all combinations of these, we can eliminate all but the correct numbers, ie 16, 31, 32 and 40.
After we know the numbers, the rest falls into place.
First: Steve Rose, Queen's Gambit, board 40
Second: Bert Baird, Ruy Lopez, board 16
Third: Tom Korn, Giuoco Piano, board 31
Fourth: Larry Hart, King's Indian, board 32
Hint: All other information (First name, Surname, Moves, Positions) are given in the puzzle, apart from the board numbers. The key to this puzzle is figuring them out, and then everything falls into place. Try different combinations, there is only one that works.
Human Solution:
Firstly, work out the board numbers. We know that Bert finished in the first 2 (Clue 8) and board 31 finished in the last 2 (Clue 4). Using all combinations of these, we can eliminate all but the correct numbers, ie 16, 31, 32 and 40.
After we know the numbers, the rest falls into place.
First: Steve Rose, Queen's Gambit, board 40
Second: Bert Baird, Ruy Lopez, board 16
Third: Tom Korn, Giuoco Piano, board 31
Fourth: Larry Hart, King's Indian, board 32
Response:
SOLUTION AT A GLANCE  
1st – Steve Rose – Queen’s Gambit – Board 40  
2nd – Bert Baird – Ruy Lopez – Board 16  
3rd – Tom Korn – Giuoco Piano – Board 31  
4th – Larry Hart – King’s Indian Defence – Board 32  

REASONING IN SHORT, LOGICAL STEPS  

Step 1 (Relative places for Bert and Mr Rose)  
• Clue 8 (“two places after Bert”) means Bert can only be 1st or 2nd.  
• Clue 4 (“Mr Rose finished exactly 2 places ahead of the player on board 31”) puts Mr Rose either 1st (ahead of 3rd) or 2nd (ahead of 4th).  
• Try Bert = 1st.  Then Rose must be 2nd and board 31 must be 4th.  Clue 8 now says the highest board equals the 3rd-place board + 8, but that 3rd-place board would still be lower than Rose’s board, so Rose’s board would be higher than the “highest” board—impossible.  
• Therefore Bert is 2nd; consequently Mr Rose is 1st and board 31 belongs to the 3rd-place finisher.

Step 2 (Using the 15-point difference)  
• With Bert in 2nd, “the contestant who placed immediately after Bert” is the 3rd-place man (on board 31).  
• Clue 6 says his board (31) is exactly 15 higher than the board of the man “immediately before Tom.”  
• To make 31 = ( board before Tom )+15, the board before Tom must be 16.  
 Thus board 16 belongs to the player who precedes Tom.  
• Because it is Bert who precedes the still-unknown Tom, Bert plays on board 16.

Step 3 (Getting the remaining two board numbers)  
• We now have boards 16 (Bert) and 31 (3rd place).  
• Clue 8: the highest board number = board of the man two places after Bert + 8.  
 Two places after Bert (2nd) is the 4th-place man. Call his board x.  
 Thus the highest board = x + 8.  
• Clue 7 says the LOWEST board of the top four is exactly half the board of the player immediately after the Giuoco Piano opener.  
 So the lowest board must be 16 (we already have no smaller number), and the board immediately after the Giuoco Piano opener must be 32.  
 Hence x = 32 and the highest board is 40.  
• The full list of boards is therefore 16, 31, 32, 40, with 40 necessarily in 1st place (the only remaining empty spot) and 32 in 4th.

Step 4 (Placing the Giuoco Piano)  
• Board 32 is the board “immediately after” the Giuoco Piano player (Clue 7), so Giuoco Piano must have been used by the 3rd-place man (on board 31).

Step 5 (Adding the openings and surnames)  
• Clue 1: Mr Hart played the King’s Indian Defence → King’s Indian goes to Larry Hart.  Larry is 4th (board 32).  
• Clue 2: Steve finished ahead of the Ruy Lopez user.  Steve is already 1st, so Ruy Lopez cannot be 1st; the only unused opening spot ahead of which Steve can finish is 2nd.  Therefore Ruy Lopez belongs to the 2nd-place player (Bert).  
• The only opening still unassigned is Queen’s Gambit; it goes to Steve (1st) by elimination.  
• Clue 3 states the top four include Larry, Mr Korn, the Queen’s Gambit player, and someone on an even board.  We already have Larry (4th), Queen’s Gambit (Steve), and even boards (16 and 32).  The remaining unassigned surname is Korn, so Tom (the only first name not paired with a surname yet) must be Mr Korn – and he is indeed 3rd.

All slots are now filled with no contradictions, and every clue is satisfied, giving the unique solution listed at the top.

Question:
Question: In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
^ stands for N, F, D, R, or E
{ stands for A, W, L, T, or O
@ stands for M, E, C, A, or B
] stands for L, P, O, A, or T
The four letter code word, {@^], can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
 Solution: Warp and Weft.
Hint: The words start with "W"
Human Solution: Warp and Weft.
Response:
PROBLEM  
Each of the four symbols in {@^] represents one (and only one) letter chosen from the set written under it.  
      {  →  A  W  L  T  O  
      @  →  M  E  C  A  B  
      ^  →  N  F  D  R  E  
      ]  →  L  P  O  A  T  
Find two English words that (1) fit the same pattern {@^] and (2) are opposites.

SOLUTION IN SIMPLE, LOGICAL STEPS  

1. Identify the restrictions for each position.  
   • 1st letter must be one of A,W,L,T,O.  
   • 2nd letter must be one of M,E,C,A,B.  
   • 3rd letter must be one of N,F,D,R,E.  
   • 4th letter must be one of L,P,O,A,T.  

2. Look for meaningful four-letter English words that satisfy those four independent choices.  
   – One quick way is to scan common word lists or mentally try combinations beginning with the rarer first-position letters W or T (because words starting with those are easier to think of).

3. Notice the word WARP satisfies all four position rules:  
   W (allowed in { )  
   A (allowed in @ )  
   R (allowed in ^ )  
   P (allowed in ] )

4. Seek a second word, built from the same symbol sets, that is the opposite of WARP.  
   – In weaving, the WARP (length-wise yarns) is perpendicular to the WEFT (cross-wise yarns), so “warp” and “weft” are natural opposites.  
   – Check that WEFT also obeys the four position rules:  
     W (in { )  
     E (in @ )  
     F (in ^ )  
     T (in ] )

5. Both words fit the pattern and are opposites in meaning within the context of weaving.

ANSWER  
The coded string {@^] can be read as WARP or as WEFT, two opposite directions in weaving.

Question:
Question: In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
! stands for Y, E, G, P, or T
@ stands for F, B, A, Q, or T
# stands for R, E, A, N, or Z
$ stands for F, E, N, S, or H
% stands for S, T, Y, M, or W
^ stands for P, D, E, H, or C
& stands for U, K, H, T, or B
* stands for O, J, G, I, or Z
? stands for E, L, D, N, or C
The nine letter code word, ^*$%@#&?!, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
 Solution: Construct and Dismantle.
Hint: Building
Human Solution: Construct and Dismantle.
Response:
SOLUTION SUMMARY  
Opposite words: CONSTRUCT and DISMANTLE  

REASONING BROKEN INTO SIMPLE, LOGICALLY-COMPLETE STEPS  

1. List the nine symbol positions in the given order:  
   1 (^) 2 (*) 3 ($) 4 (%) 5 (@) 6 (#) 7 (&) 8 (?) 9 (!)

2. Write the five possible letters for each symbol (copied from the statement):  
   ^ = P D E H C  
   * = O J G I Z  
   $ = F E N S H  
   % = S T Y M W  
   @ = F B A Q T  
   # = R E A N Z  
   & = U K H T B  
   ? = E L D N C  
   ! = Y E G P T  

3. Look for ordinary 9-letter English words that can be spelled by choosing one permitted letter for each position.  
   • Try CONSTRUCT (C O N S T R U C T).  
   • Check each letter against the allowed set in its position:  
     ^ (C) ✓ * (O) ✓ $ (N) ✓ % (S) ✓ @ (T) ✓  
     # (R) ✓ & (U) ✓ ? (C) ✓ ! (T) ✓  
     All nine letters are legal ⇒ CONSTRUCT is valid.

4. Search for another 9-letter English word that can be formed with a different choice of letters at the same nine positions.  
   • Try DISMANTLE (D I S M A N T L E).  
   • Verify each letter:  
     ^ (D) ✓ * (I) ✓ $ (S) ✓ % (M) ✓ @ (A) ✓  
     # (N) ✓ & (T) ✓ ? (L) ✓ ! (E) ✓  
     All nine letters are also legal ⇒ DISMANTLE is valid.

5. Check the relationship between the two words just found.  
   CONSTRUCT and DISMANTLE have opposite meanings.

6. Conclusion: the coded sequence ^*$%@#&?! can legitimately be read in two ways, yielding the antonyms CONSTRUCT and DISMANTLE.

Question:
Question: With the death of Arthur Minit, the legendary country of MADADIA's only clock maker, no one else had much experience yet with making clocks. The new church of MADADIA had just been completed and a new clock was needed to fit into the bell tower. A clock was made by the locals, using the books of Arthur Minit as a guide.The newly made clock was officially put into use when it showed 6 o'clock. But soon it was noticed that the hour-hand and minute-hand had been interchanged and attached to the wrong spindles. The result was that the hour-hand moved with a speed twelve times higher than the minute-hand. When a clock maker arrived from another area, a remarkable thing happened: on the moment he inspected the clock, it showed exactly the right time.
The Question: If the clock started in the 6 o'clock position, then what was the first moment that it showed the correct time again?
 Solution: Suppose that a second pair of hands turns together with the wrong pair of hands, but then in the correct way. When the wrong pair is in the same position as the correct pair, this means that the time is shown in the right way. First look at the hour-hands that are at the twelve. One turns with the correct speed, the other with a speed that is twelve times as small. These two hands are in the same position again when the 'slow' hand has progressed x minutes. The fast hand then has progressed 60+x minutes. For the time x that passed, then holds: (60+x)/12 = x. This means that x = 5 5/11 minutes.
For the minutes-hands that start at six holds the same. The confused clock therefore shows the correct time again at 5 5/11 minutes past 7.
Hint: Suppose that a second pair of hands turns together with the wrong pair of hands, but then in the correct way. When the wrong pair is in the same position as the correct pair, this means that the time is shown in the right way.
Human Solution:
Suppose that a second pair of hands turns together with the wrong pair of hands, but then in the correct way. When the wrong pair is in the same position as the correct pair, this means that the time is shown in the right way. First look at the hour-hands that are at the twelve. One turns with the correct speed, the other with a speed that is twelve times as small. These two hands are in the same position again when the 'slow' hand has progressed x minutes. The fast hand then has progressed 60+x minutes. For the time x that passed, then holds: (60+x)/12 = x. This means that x = 5 5/11 minutes.
For the minutes-hands that start at six holds the same. The confused clock therefore shows the correct time again at 5 5/11 minutes past 7.
Response:
SUMMARY OF THE SOLUTION  

Goal  
Starting from 6 : 00 with the hands interchanged (hour–hand 12 × faster than the minute–hand), find the first later instant at which the clock nevertheless shows the correct time.

Step-by-step reasoning  

1. Identify the real angular speeds  
   • Minute spindle (normal): 360° per hour = 6°/min  
   • Hour spindle (normal): 360° per 12 h = 30°/h = 0.5°/min  
   After interchange these speeds belong to the wrong hands, so  
   – “Fast” hand (now called hour-hand) rotates 6°/min.  
   – “Slow” hand (now called minute-hand) rotates 0.5°/min.

2. Fix the starting positions at 6 : 00  
   Fast hand points to 6  ➔ 180°.  
   Slow hand points to 12 ➔   0°.

3. Express their positions t minutes later  
   Wrong clock:  
      Fast hand: 180° + 6t  
      Slow hand:   0° + 0.5t  
   Correct clock that started simultaneously:  
      Correct minute-hand:   0° + 6t  
      Correct hour-hand:    180° + 0.5t

4. Impose the “looks correct” condition  
   The wrong slow hand must coincide with the correct minute-hand, i.e.  
        0.5t ≡ 6t (mod 360).  
   Rearranging: 5.5t = 360  ⇒  t = 360 / 5.5 = 720/11 minutes  
                           = 65 5/11 minutes.

5. Check the other hand (consistency)  
   180° + 6t – (180° + 0.5t) = 5.5t = 360°, so the fast hand also lines up properly; the condition is satisfied for both hands.

6. Translate t into clock time  
   65 5/11 minutes = 1 h 5 5/11 min.  
   Adding this to the start time 6 : 00 gives  
        7 : 05  5/11.

Answer  
The first moment after 6 : 00 at which the faulty clock shows the correct time is 7 : 05  5/11 (i.e. 5 5⁄11 minutes past 7).

Question:
Question: You roll five dice.
If you roll 5, 3, 2, 1, 6 you get 8 points.
2, 2, 3, 5, 1 = 8 points
6, 5, 4, 3, 2 = 8 points
1, 2, 6, 6, 6 = 6 points
2, 2, 5, 6, 6 = 6 points
4, 3, 6, 2, 6 = ? points
 Solution: 7 points. You get one point per vowel.
Hint: Think about how you spell the numbers
Human Solution: 7 points. You get one point per vowel.
Response:
PROBLEM  
Find the rule that turns any roll of five ordinary dice into the stated scores and then apply it to the throw 4 – 3 – 6 – 2 – 6.

SOLUTION (answer): 7 points.  
Underlying rule: “One point is awarded for every vowel that appears when the face value is written in English.”

REASONING, STEP-BY-STEP  
1. Examine given data: three different rolls are worth 8 points, two different rolls are worth 6 points.  
2. Any rule depending on sums, products, pairs, etc. would usually make the same digits always give the same score, yet the first three rolls contain very different numerical patterns but share the score 8. So the rule must use some non-arithmetical property of the faces.  
3. Write each face value as an English word:  
   1 → ONE, 2 → TWO, 3 → THREE, 4 → FOUR, 5 → FIVE, 6 → SIX.  
4. Count vowels (A, E, I, O, U) in each word:  
   ONE = 2, TWO = 1, THREE = 2, FOUR = 2, FIVE = 2, SIX = 1.  
5. Check the first example roll 5 – 3 – 2 – 1 – 6:  
   FIVE(2) + THREE(2) + TWO(1) + ONE(2) + SIX(1) = 8 ✔  
   All other given rolls reproduce their stated totals the same way, confirming the rule.  
6. Apply the rule to 4 – 3 – 6 – 2 – 6:  
   FOUR(2) + THREE(2) + SIX(1) + TWO(1) + SIX(1) = 7.  

Therefore the throw 4, 3, 6, 2, 6 is worth 7 points.

Question:
Question: Five pirates are trying to split up 1000 gold pieces.  The rules are as follows:
Pirate #1 must divide the gold up in such a way that a majority of the pirates (including himself) agree to.  If he does not get a majority vote, he will be killed, and pirate #2 will get to propose a solution to the remaining 3 pirates, and the same rules will follow.  This continues until someone comes up with a plan that earns a majority vote.
What is the most amount of gold pieces that pirate #1 can keep to himself, and what would his proposal be?
The pirates are infinitely greedy, infinitely ruthless (the more dead pirates the better), and infinitely intelligent.
 Solution: Like the hint says, start backwards:
If there are two pirates left (#4 & #5), #4 has no options.  No matter what he proposes, pirate #5 will disagree, resulting in a 1-1 vote (no majority).  #5 will kill #4 and will keep all of the gold.
Now say there are 3 pirates left.  #4 has to agree with whatever #3 decides, because if he doesn't #3 will be killed (because #5 won't vote for #3's proposal no matter what it is).  #3 will just propose that he keep all of the gold and will get a 2-1 vote in his favor.
Now if there are 4 pirates left:
#3 won't vote for #2's proposal because if #2's fails, #3 will get all of the gold. #4 and #5 know that they will get nothing if the decision goes to #3, so they will vote for #2's proposal if he gives them one gold piece each. Therefore, #2 would keep 998 gold, and #4 and #5 would each get one gold.
So let's wrap this up:
Pirate #1 needs 2 other votes.  He will not get a vote from #2 because #2 will get 998 gold if #1's plan fails.
#1 offers #3 one gold piece to vote for him, which #3 will accept (if it gets to #2's plan, #3 will get nothing).
#1 then offers #4 or #5 (doesn't matter which) two gold pieces, which is more than they would get with #2's plan.
So #1 can end up with 997 gold pieces, with #3 getting one piece and #4 or #5 getting two pieces.
...whew!
Hint: Start backwards - what would pirate #4's options be if the first 3 pirates were killed?
Human Solution:
Like the hint says, start backwards:
If there are two pirates left (#4 & #5), #4 has no options.  No matter what he proposes, pirate #5 will disagree, resulting in a 1-1 vote (no majority).  #5 will kill #4 and will keep all of the gold.
Now say there are 3 pirates left.  #4 has to agree with whatever #3 decides, because if he doesn't #3 will be killed (because #5 won't vote for #3's proposal no matter what it is).  #3 will just propose that he keep all of the gold and will get a 2-1 vote in his favor.
Now if there are 4 pirates left:
#3 won't vote for #2's proposal because if #2's fails, #3 will get all of the gold. #4 and #5 know that they will get nothing if the decision goes to #3, so they will vote for #2's proposal if he gives them one gold piece each. Therefore, #2 would keep 998 gold, and #4 and #5 would each get one gold.
So let's wrap this up:
Pirate #1 needs 2 other votes.  He will not get a vote from #2 because #2 will get 998 gold if #1's plan fails.
#1 offers #3 one gold piece to vote for him, which #3 will accept (if it gets to #2's plan, #3 will get nothing).
#1 then offers #4 or #5 (doesn't matter which) two gold pieces, which is more than they would get with #2's plan.
So #1 can end up with 997 gold pieces, with #3 getting one piece and #4 or #5 getting two pieces.
...whew!
Response:
SOLUTION IN SIMPLE, LOGICAL STEPS  

Notation  
• P1 … P5 = the five pirates (P1 proposes first, P5 last).  
• A proposal passes only if STRICTLY more than half of the pirates who are still alive vote Yes.  
• Each pirate’s preference order is:  
  1. Stay alive  
  2. Get as much gold as possible  
  3. If gold is equal, see as many other pirates die as possible  

Step-0  (one pirate left)  
Alive: P5  Needed Yes-votes: 1  
P5 automatically keeps the 1000 coins.

Step-1  (two pirates left)  
Alive: P4, P5  Needed Yes-votes: 2  
• Any proposal by P4 needs P5’s vote.  
• No matter how much P4 offers, P5 can get the SAME gold (1000) and one more death by voting No.  
⇒ P4’s plan always fails; P4 is killed.  
Baseline outcome if P4 dies: P5 gets 1000, P4 0.

Step-2  (three pirates left)  
Alive: P3, P4, P5  Needed Yes-votes: 2  
• If P3 is killed, we revert to Step-1, where P4 dies and P5 gets everything.  
• Therefore P4, who would otherwise die, will accept ANY positive-or-zero offer from P3.  
• P3 needs only one extra vote, and he can get P4’s for free.  
Proposal: P3 keeps 1000; P4 0; P5 0.  
Votes: P3 Yes, P4 Yes, P5 No → 2-1 passes.  
Baseline if P3 dies: P4 0, P5 0.

Step-3  (four pirates left)  
Alive: P2, P3, P4, P5  Needed Yes-votes: 3  
• If P2 dies we fall back to Step-2, where P3 keeps all 1000 and P4, P5 get nothing.  
• So P2 must buy two of the three other votes.  
  – P3 will vote No no matter what (he gets 1000 if P2 dies).  
  – P4 and P5 each get 0 in the fallback case; offer them 1 coin each and they are better off.  
Proposal: P2 998, P4 1, P5 1, P3 0.  
Votes: P2 Yes, P4 Yes, P5 Yes → 3-1 passes.  
Baseline if P2 dies: P3 1000, P4 0, P5 0.

Step-4  (all five pirates alive)  
Alive: P1 … P5  Needed Yes-votes: 3  
• If P1 dies we revert to Step-3, whose result is  
  P2 998, P3 0, P4 1, P5 1.  
Baselines for each voter:  
  P2 — 998  P3 — 0  P4 — 1  P5 — 1  
• P2 will never support P1 (he expects 998 if P1 dies).  
• Cheapest two voters to bribe are P3 (needs >0) and one of {P4, P5} (needs >1).  
Choose P3 and, say, P4.  
Offer: P3 1 coin, P4 2 coins.  
Proposal: P1 997, P3 1, P4 2, P2 0, P5 0.  
Votes: P1 Yes, P3 Yes, P4 Yes → 3-2 passes.

Answer  
The greatest number of gold pieces P1 can guarantee for himself is 997.  
A winning proposal is:  
P1 = 997, P3 = 1, P4 = 2, P2 = 0, P5 = 0.

Question:
Question: How is it possible that 3 + 4 = 5?
 Solution: Using VECTORS
i.e. 3 m North + 4 m East
= 5 metres North East
3^2 = 9
4^2 = 16
9 + 16 = 25
SQ Root of 25 = 5
Human Solution:
Using VECTORS
i.e. 3 m North + 4 m East
= 5 metres North East
3^2 = 9
4^2 = 16
9 + 16 = 25
SQ Root of 25 = 5
Response:
PROBLEM  
Explain how the statement “3 + 4 = 5” can be true.

SOLUTION (vector viewpoint) – step-by-step  
1. Decide what “+” means.  
   • Instead of ordinary (scalar) addition, treat “+” as vector addition.

2. Assign the two numbers to perpendicular vectors.  
   • Let one vector be 3 m due North.  
   • Let the other be 4 m due East.

3. Form the resultant vector.  
   • Because the two original vectors are perpendicular, the displacement forms a right-angled triangle whose legs are 3 and 4.

4. Compute the magnitude of the resultant with the Pythagorean theorem.  
   • Resultant length = √(3² + 4²) = √(9 + 16) = √25 = 5 m.

5. State the outcome in words.  
   • “3 m North + 4 m East gives a single displacement of 5 m toward the North-East.”

Thus 3 (units in one orthogonal direction) plus 4 (units in a perpendicular direction) results in a single 5-unit vector, so “3 + 4 = 5” is correct when “+” denotes vector addition rather than ordinary arithmetic addition.

Question:
Question: You are given a stack of bingo cards.  Your task is to find a specific card.  Given the following clues, what is the number arrangement of that card?
Columns, left to right, are: B (contains numbers 1 through 15), I (contains numbers 16 through 30), N (contains numbers 31 through 45), G (contains numbers 46 through 60), O (contains numbers 61 through 75).  Rows, top to bottom, are: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.  An example of coordinate nomenclature: B1 identifies column B row 1.  N3 is a free space (contains no number).  No number appears more than once.
1) For each column, the numbers are in either ascending order or descending order.
2) Row 1: the numbers are prime.
3) Row 5: the numbers are composite.
4) Column I: the numbers are spaced at equal intervals.
5) Column O: the numbers are spaced at different intervals.
6) The sum of the numbers in Row 1 equals the sum of the numbers in Row 5.
7) The product of B4 and O5 equals the product of B5 and O4.
8) The product of I2 and G2 equals the product of I3 and G3.
9) N4 is midway between B4 and G4.
10) Each column has one multiple of 6.
11) There is only one square number on the card.
 Solution: 11 17 41 59 61
12 18 36 57 63
13 19 -- 54 66
14 20 33 52 70
15 21 32 46 75
1) Per clue 2, eliminate non-prime numbers from Row 1.
2) Per clue 3, eliminate non-composite numbers from Row 5.
3) Per clue 1, eliminate numbers that do not fit any possible (ascending or descending) sequence from Rows 2 through 4.
4) Per clue 4, determine the possible sequences for Column I.  In conjunction with clue 8, eliminate numbers from Columns I and G.
5) Per clue 10, I2 must be 18 or 24, and G3 must be 48 or 54.  Eliminate additional numbers from Column G.
6) Per clue 7, determine what combinations of numbers work.  Eliminate those that to not work from B4, B5, O4, and O5.
7) Per clue 5, in order to have four different intervals, the spread from top to bottom must be at least 10.  Eliminate from O1: 67 and 71.  Eliminate from O5: 64 and 70.  In conjunction with clue 7, only one combination of numbers works:  O4 must be 70, O5 must be 75, B4 must be 14, and B5 must be 15.  This leaves O1 as 61.
8) Per clue 10, 66 must be in either O2 or O3.  66 can not be in O2, because that would create an interval of 5 (which already exists between O4 and O5) between O1 and O2.  O3 must be 66.  O2 must be either 63 or 64.
9) Per clue 9, N4 must be 33 and G4 must be 52.  This leaves G1 as 59, G2 as 57, and G3 as 54.
10) Per clues 4 and 8, Column I can be determined.  I1 must be 17, I2 must be 18, I3 must be 19, I4 must be 20, and I5 must be 21.
11) Per clue 6, Column N must be in descending order.  N5 must be 32.
12) Per clue 6, the only combination of numbers that works produces a sum of 189.  B1 must be 11, N1 must be 41, G5 must be 46.
13) Per clue 1, B2 must be 12 and B3 must be 13.
14) Per clue 10, N2 must be 36.  Per clue 11, O2 must be 63.
Hint:
1) Per clue 2, eliminate non-prime numbers from Row 1.
2) Per clue 3, eliminate non-composite numbers from Row 5.
3) Per clue 1, eliminate numbers that do not fit any possible (ascending or descending) sequence from Rows 2 through 4.
Human Solution:
11 17 41 59 61
12 18 36 57 63
13 19 -- 54 66
14 20 33 52 70
15 21 32 46 75
1) Per clue 2, eliminate non-prime numbers from Row 1.
2) Per clue 3, eliminate non-composite numbers from Row 5.
3) Per clue 1, eliminate numbers that do not fit any possible (ascending or descending) sequence from Rows 2 through 4.
4) Per clue 4, determine the possible sequences for Column I.  In conjunction with clue 8, eliminate numbers from Columns I and G.
5) Per clue 10, I2 must be 18 or 24, and G3 must be 48 or 54.  Eliminate additional numbers from Column G.
6) Per clue 7, determine what combinations of numbers work.  Eliminate those that to not work from B4, B5, O4, and O5.
7) Per clue 5, in order to have four different intervals, the spread from top to bottom must be at least 10.  Eliminate from O1: 67 and 71.  Eliminate from O5: 64 and 70.  In conjunction with clue 7, only one combination of numbers works:  O4 must be 70, O5 must be 75, B4 must be 14, and B5 must be 15.  This leaves O1 as 61.
8) Per clue 10, 66 must be in either O2 or O3.  66 can not be in O2, because that would create an interval of 5 (which already exists between O4 and O5) between O1 and O2.  O3 must be 66.  O2 must be either 63 or 64.
9) Per clue 9, N4 must be 33 and G4 must be 52.  This leaves G1 as 59, G2 as 57, and G3 as 54.
10) Per clues 4 and 8, Column I can be determined.  I1 must be 17, I2 must be 18, I3 must be 19, I4 must be 20, and I5 must be 21.
11) Per clue 6, Column N must be in descending order.  N5 must be 32.
12) Per clue 6, the only combination of numbers that works produces a sum of 189.  B1 must be 11, N1 must be 41, G5 must be 46.
13) Per clue 1, B2 must be 12 and B3 must be 13.
14) Per clue 10, N2 must be 36.  Per clue 11, O2 must be 63.
Response:
FINAL CARD  

B   I   N   G   O  
11  17  41  59  61  
12  18  36  57  63  
13  19  --  54  66  
14  20  33  52  70  
15  21  32  46  75  


REASONING – SIMPLE, LOGICALLY‐COMPLETE STEPS  

1.  Row restrictions  
    • Row 1 must be prime; list the primes in every column range.  
    • Row 5 must be composite; list the composites in every column range.  

2.  Column monotonicity (clue 1)  
    • Each column is either wholly ascending or wholly descending, so once Row 1 and Row 5 are fixed, the three middle rows must lie strictly between them in the chosen order.  
    • This immediately forces Column B to be ascending (prime at top, composite at bottom) and Column N to be descending (prime at top, composite at bottom).

3.  Column I – equal spacing (clue 4)  
    • Five numbers between 16 and 30, evenly spaced.  
    • Common differences that give five members inside the range are 1, 2, or 3.  
    • d = 2 gives 16-24, d = 3 gives 16-28 – both place an even number (not prime) in Row 1, contradicting clue 2.  
    • Therefore d = 1 and the column is 17-18-19-20-21 (ascending).

4.  Cross-product restriction (clue 8) fixes G2 and G3  
    • I2·G2 = I3·G3 → 18·G2 = 19·G3  
    • Smallest descending pair in the 46-60 range that satisfies this ratio is G2 = 57, G3 = 54.  
    • Column G is now descending.

5.  “One multiple of 6 per column” (clue 10) now accounted for in B (12), I (18), N (36), G (54).  
    • Column O must therefore supply the fifth multiple of 6.

6.  Column-product restriction (clue 7) links B4, B5, O4, O5  
    • Let B4=x, B5=y, O4=p, O5=q with x<y (ascending B) and p<q (descending or ascending still unknown).  
    • y/x = q/p  →  xp = yq.  Smallest distinct ascending B4,B5 and legal O4,O5 (61-75) giving an integral solution is:  
        B4 = 14, B5 = 15, O4 = 70, O5 = 75 (check 14·75 = 15·70).  
    • Column B confirmed ascending 11-12-13-14-15.

7.  Column O – all four gaps different (clue 5)  
    • With 70 and 75 fixed at the bottom, choose O1-O3 so consecutive differences are all unequal.  
    • 61-63-66-70-75 has gaps 2,3,4,5 – all different and keeps the column ascending.  
    • 66 supplies the fifth multiple of 6 (clue 10).

8.  Midpoint condition (clue 9) fixes N4 and G4  
    • N4 is midway between B4 and G4 ⇒ N4 = (14 + G4)/2.  
    • N column is descending and Row 4 must be composite; the only value that keeps integers and the column descending is N4 = 33, G4 = 52.

9.  Finish Column G  
    • Column must be descending: G1 must exceed 57.  The only prime available (for Row 1) in 46-60 >57 is 59.  
    • G5 must be <52, composite, and give the column its single multiple of 6 (already 54), so choose the smallest remaining composite 46.  
    • Column G is now 59-57-54-52-46.

10.  Square-number restriction (clue 11)  
     • 36 is the only square number in 31-45, so put 36 at N2 (keeps the column descending and supplies N’s multiple of 6).

11.  Row-sum restriction (clue 6) determines the last two unknowns  
     • Current Row 1 sum: B1 + 17 + 41 + 59 + 61 = B1 + 178  
     • Current Row 5 sum: 15 + 21 + N5 + 46 + 75 = N5 + 157  
     • Equality gives B1 + 178 = N5 + 157 → N5 = B1 + 21.  
     • Column N is descending, so N5 must be <32 (because N4 = 33).  Pair (11,32) meets all conditions: B1 = 11 (prime), N5 = 32 (composite).

12.  Complete Column N and check multiples of 6  
     • N column now 41-36-----------33-32 – descending as required.

13.  Fill the remaining blanks in Column B (ascending)  
     • Numbers left in 1-15 not yet used and keeping the prime→composite pattern are 12 and 13, so B2 = 12, B3 = 13.  
     • Column B now supplies its multiple of 6 (12).

14.  All clues verified  
     • Each column monotone.  
     • Row 1 all prime, Row 5 all composite.  
     • I equal-step, O unequal-step.  
     • Row-1 sum equals Row-5 sum (189).  
     • Products and midpoint checks satisfied.  
     • One multiple of 6 in every column and only one square (36).  

Hence the unique bingo card shown at the top satisfies every clue.

Question:
Question: One day, a college student named Tina walked into her logic class and waited for her fun day of logic once again.  Finally the professor, Professor C. D. Rock, walked in saying, "I just went through some stuff and stumbled upon an old family tree, that belonged to my grandparents, that gave me an idea.  I have here a few clues, and you have to use them to figure out their family tree!"
Tina then gets the clues, and tries to work them out. Unfortunately this puzzle is a little harder than the normal ones Professor C. D. Rock gives out.  Can you help her?
The family tree consists of two grandparents, who had 3 children, each of whom get married and have 2 children.
Males: Cole, Cristian, Jason, Neil, and Steve
Females: Amanda, Ashley, Beth, Erin, Kaitlyn, Katherine, Makayla, Payton, and Tammy
Clues:
1. One of Makayla's cousins is Jason's son.
2. One of Ashley's aunts is Tammy.
3. Tammy's brother-in-law is Neil's son.
4. Kaitlyn's sister is Ashley's cousin.
5. Ashley's uncle, Steve, is Erin's brother-in-law.
6. The three uncles are Payton's dad, Cristian, and Katherine's son.
7. The three aunts are Kaitlyn's mom, Ashley's mom, and Cristian's sister-in-law.
8. Jason's brother is Ashley's dad.
9. Amanda's sister is Steve's niece.
10. Beth is not Cole's aunt.
 Solution: The grandparents are Katherine and Neil, who had 3 sons: Cristian, Jason, and Steve.
Cristian married Erin, and had Ashley and Amanda.
Jason married Beth, and had Payton and Cole.
Steve married Tammy, and had Makayla and Kaitlyn.
Hint: Use paper and pencil, it's almost impossible to do in your head.
Human Solution:
The grandparents are Katherine and Neil, who had 3 sons: Cristian, Jason, and Steve.
Cristian married Erin, and had Ashley and Amanda.
Jason married Beth, and had Payton and Cole.
Steve married Tammy, and had Makayla and Kaitlyn.
Response:
Solution (short form)

Grandparents:  Neil (grand­father) and Katherine (grand­mother)

Their three children (all sons):  
• Cristian  • Jason  • Steve  

Spouses of the sons:  
Cristian – Erin  Jason – Beth  Steve – Tammy  

Grandchildren (two per couple):  
Cristian & Erin → Ashley, Amanda  
Jason & Beth  → Payton, Cole  
Steve & Tammy → Makayla, Kaitlyn  


Reasoning, split into simple, self-contained steps

1.  “The three uncles are Payton’s dad, Cristian, and Katherine’s son.”
    • All three uncles are males in generation 2.  
    • Therefore every child of the grand­parents is male; the middle generation is three sons.

2.  Label the still-unknown grand­parents Gm (grand­mother) and Gf (grand­father).  
    “Tammy’s brother-in-law is Neil’s son” puts the male name Neil in the grand­parent generation (only that generation can “have a son”).  
    ⇒ Grandfather = Neil, Grandmother = Katherine.

3.  Put the names Neil and Katherine at the top; list their three sons as blanks S1, S2, S3.

4.  Use the “uncle” clue again: the three uncles are  
       – Payton’s dad  – Cristian  – Katherine’s son (= one of S1–S3)  
    Cristian is therefore one of the sons, and Payton’s dad is another son.

5.  Turn to the grandchildren names.  Because each middle-generation couple has exactly two children, Payton’s dad’s wife must be the mother of Payton and one other child.  The only female remaining who can later be called an “aunt” is Beth or Tammy or Erin.  Keep this in mind.

6.  “Jason’s brother is Ashley’s dad.”  
    ⇒ Jason is one son; Ashley’s dad (therefore Cristian) is another.  
    So far we have sons:  Cristian and Jason.  The remaining son must be Steve (the only male name left).

7.  We now know all three sons: Cristian, Jason, Steve.  
    That matches clue 6 perfectly: the uncles are Payton’s dad (Jason), Cristian, and Katherine’s son (Steve).

8.  Decide marriages with the daughter-in-law clues.
    • “One of Ashley’s aunts is Tammy.”  
      Ashley is Cristian’s child, so Tammy must be married to one of Cristian’s brothers, i.e. to Steve or Jason.  
    • “Ashley’s uncle, Steve, is Erin’s brother-in-law.”  
      Erin must therefore be married to Cristian (only then is Steve her brother-in-law).  
    • So Cristian–Erin is fixed.

9.  From the previous two bullets Tammy is married to Steve (otherwise Ashley would have no aunt Tammy).  
    That leaves Beth to marry the remaining son, Jason.

10.  Allocate the grandchildren using the remaining cousin/aunt clues.
     • Cristian & Erin already have Ashley (mentioned); they must have one more child, so give them Amanda.  
     • “One of Makayla’s cousins is Jason’s son.”  
       Put Makayla as a child of Steve & Tammy; then Jason & Beth must have a son (Cole) so that the statement is satisfied.  
     • “Kaitlyn’s sister is Ashley’s cousin.”  
       If Makayla is Steve’s daughter, give him the second daughter Kaitlyn; her sister Makayla is indeed Ashley’s cousin.  
     • That automatically makes Jason & Beth’s second child Payton.

11.  Finally check every clue: each is now true, including  
     “Beth is not Cole’s aunt” (she is his mother) and  
     “Amanda’s sister is Steve’s niece” (Amanda’s sister is Ashley, Cristian’s child, hence Steve’s niece).

All clues are satisfied, so the tree above is the unique solution.

Question:
Question: I am a word of five letters. Multiply my fifth by two and you have my first. Divide my first by twenty and you have my third. Divide my third by five and you have my second or fourth.
 Solution: CIVIL.
L (50) multiplied by 2 equal C (100).
Divide C by 20 and you have V. Divide V by 5 and you have I.
Hint: Roman numerals
Human Solution:
CIVIL.
L (50) multiplied by 2 equal C (100).
Divide C by 20 and you have V. Divide V by 5 and you have I.
Response:
Answer: CIVIL

Reasoning – broken into clear, self-contained steps

1.  Translate the puzzle into algebra  
   • Let the five letters be A B C D E (in that order).  
   • Clues become numerical equalities:  
     a) 2 × value(E) = value(A)  
     b) value(A) ÷ 20 = value(C)  
     c) value(C) ÷ 5 = value(B) = value(D)

2.  Decide what “value” means  
   • Ordinary alphabet positions (A = 1, B = 2 …) do not make nice multiples of 2, 5, or 20.  
   • Roman-numeral letters, however, are expressly numerical:  
     I = 1, V = 5, X = 10, L = 50, C = 100, D = 500, M = 1000.

3.  Use clue (b) first because it fixes a convenient scale  
   • value(A) ÷ 20 = value(C) means value(A) must be 20 × an existing Roman value.  
   • Small Roman values are 1, 5, 10, 50, 100 … ; multiplying any of them by 20 gives 20, 100, 200, 1000 …  
   • The only product that is itself a Roman-numeral value is 100 (which is C).  
   ⇒ A = C = 100 → letter A is C, letter C is V? (Not yet; see next step.)

4.  Determine C from the same clue  
   • value(C) = value(A) ÷ 20 = 100 ÷ 20 = 5.  
   • Roman numeral 5 is V.  
   ⇒ C = V.

5.  Apply clue (c) to get letters 2 and 4  
   • value(B) = value(D) = value(C) ÷ 5 = 5 ÷ 5 = 1.  
   • Roman numeral 1 is I.  
   ⇒ B = I and D = I.

6.  Apply clue (a) to get the fifth letter  
   • 2 × value(E) = value(A) = 100 → value(E) = 50.  
   • Roman numeral 50 is L.  
   ⇒ E = L.

7.  Assemble the word  
   • A B C D E = C I V I L → CIVIL.

Every clue is satisfied:
   • 2 × L(50) = C(100) ✔  
   • C(100) ÷ 20 = V(5) ✔  
   • V(5) ÷ 5 = I(1) = I(1) ✔

Therefore the required five-letter word is “CIVIL.”

Question:
Question: Use the numbers 1 to 4 in each column and row, and then add 0, 1, or 2 zeros after each number that needs it so that the numbers add up to the numbers listed below the grid.
X A B C D
1. _ _ _ _
2. _ _ _ _
3. _ _ _ _
4. _ _ _ _
Rows:
1. 640
2. 442
3. 55
4. 442
Columns:
A. 316
B. 433
C. 280
D. 550
 Solution: 010 400 200 030
300 002 040 100
004 001 030 020
002 030 010 400
Hint: Think digit-by-digit. Consider the ones digit first (look at all the 0's!)
Response:
S T E P ‑ B Y ‑ S T E P  R E A S O N I N G

1.  What may appear in a cell  
   • Each entry must be one of 1, 2, 3, 4 followed by 0, 1 or 2 zeros.  
   • Hence the only 12 admissible values are  
     1  2  3  4  10 20 30 40 100 200 300 400.  
   • In every row and every column the basic digits 1–4 must all occur exactly once
     (zeros are ignored for this purpose).

2.  Analyse the “extreme” rows  
   • Row-3 total = 55, far too small to contain any hundreds.  
     The only way to reach 55 with four different basic digits is  
     30 + 20 + 4 + 1.   
     ⇒ Row-3 contains {30, 20, 4, 1}.  
   • Row-1 total = 640, the largest sum.  
     To reach 640 we must take one 400 and one 200, leaving 40.  
     The remaining two different digits must be 30 and 10.  
     ⇒ Row-1 contains {400, 200, 30, 10}.  

3.  Work out the two remaining 442-rows  
   442 can be obtained with the following digit-distinct quadruples  
     400 + 30 + 10 + 2  or  300 + 100 + 40 + 2.  
   ⇒ Use one set for Row-2 and the other for Row-4.

4.  Fix Column-D (sum = 550)  
   Row-1 still has 30, Row-3 has 20; both are natural “end-of-row” numbers.  
   Add 100 (from the 300 + 100 + 40 + 2 row) and 400 (from the 400 + 30 + 10 + 2 row):  
     30 + 100 + 20 + 400 = 550.  
   ⇒ Column-D becomes 30 / 100 / 20 / 400 (Rows 1-4).

5.  Fix Column-B (sum = 433)  
   Remaining unused numbers that fit the rows give the unique tally  
     400 (Row-1) + 2 (Row-2) + 1 (Row-3) + 30 (Row-4) = 433.  
   ⇒ Column-B becomes 400 / 002 / 001 / 030.

6.  Fix Column-C (sum = 280)  
   What is still left for each row yields exactly  
     200 + 40 + 30 + 10 = 280.  
   ⇒ Column-C is 200 / 040 / 030 / 010.

7.  Column-A is then forced, and its total automatically checks (316).  

8.  All row totals, column totals and “one-of-each-digit” requirements are satisfied, so the grid is complete.

F I N A L  G R I D  

             A      B      C      D  
Row 1   010   400   200   030  
Row 2   300   002   040   100  
Row 3   004   001   030   020  
Row 4   002   030   010   400

Question:
Question: Mary Beem, who was a wife, mother of four and grandmother of nine, was shot to death by an angry relative. Find out the name of the relative it was by piecing together the relationships of each person with the clues below.
The killer's sister was suspicious of her sibling and confirmed her distrust by talking to three people: her grandfather Bob, her cousin Bo, and her uncle (blood relative) Bill. She called the police, and the suspect was apprehended at the victim's funeral service. Only the direct descendants and their spouses were present. (Note: None of Mary's grandchildren were married or had kids, and no two people have the same first name.)
1. Bill was talking with his brother-in-law Barry.
2. Bart, Buck, and Bruce (who were all brothers) were by their grandmother's casket.
3. Mary's daughter May, who was with her husband Ben, had their two children: Missy and Bernie.
4. Mo, Bob's son-in-law, was comforting his wife Robin, and both were keeping an eye on their sons.
5. Bo was by himself in a corner grieving, while his sister Molly was talking with their cousin Megan.
6. Myra was consoling one of her two children, Brad, who had been very close to his grandmother.
7. Bob was with his daughter Maria.
NOTE: Each of the 4 couples has at least 2 kids.
WHO IS THE KILLER?
 Solution: From the killer's sister's conversation, Bob is Mary's husband, Bill is one of Mary's children, and Bo is a grandchild.
From clue 1 and 2, Barry was a spouse, and since Bart, Buck and Bruce were all brothers, they were the set of three kids. Clue 3 is straightforward - Mary's daughter May is married to Ben and has two kids: Missy and Bernie.
From 4, Robin is a daughter and Bob her spouse.  From 5, Bo and Molly are siblings and grandchildren (since they have a cousin present). Megan has to be from the last couple.  Mo and Robin could only have been parents to the three boys (Bart Bruce and Buck), since all other siblings were a boy and girl.
Clue 6 gives the name of the remaining child, Brad, who must be a sibling of Megan. Both have a mother by the name of Myra. It is unknown at this point if Myra is a spouse or a direct relative.
Since clue 7 says that Bob (Mary's husband) was with his daughter Maria, Myra becomes a spouse. Then, by default, Bo and Molly belong to Maria.
So now, knowing that the killer's sister is COUSIN to Bo, Bill's NIECE, and Bob's GRANDDAUGHTER, the killer must be BERNIE.
Hint:
Draw a family tree.
Each of the 4 children of Mary Beem has a spouse, and each couple has children.  Since all must have at least two kids, only one couple has three kids (a total of 9 grandchildren).
Human Solution:
From the killer's sister's conversation, Bob is Mary's husband, Bill is one of Mary's children, and Bo is a grandchild.
From clue 1 and 2, Barry was a spouse, and since Bart, Buck and Bruce were all brothers, they were the set of three kids. Clue 3 is straightforward - Mary's daughter May is married to Ben and has two kids: Missy and Bernie.
From 4, Robin is a daughter and Bob her spouse.  From 5, Bo and Molly are siblings and grandchildren (since they have a cousin present). Megan has to be from the last couple.  Mo and Robin could only have been parents to the three boys (Bart Bruce and Buck), since all other siblings were a boy and girl.
Clue 6 gives the name of the remaining child, Brad, who must be a sibling of Megan. Both have a mother by the name of Myra. It is unknown at this point if Myra is a spouse or a direct relative.
Since clue 7 says that Bob (Mary's husband) was with his daughter Maria, Myra becomes a spouse. Then, by default, Bo and Molly belong to Maria.
So now, knowing that the killer's sister is COUSIN to Bo, Bill's NIECE, and Bob's GRANDDAUGHTER, the killer must be BERNIE.
Response:
Solution outline (logically-separated, self-contained steps)

1. Fix the top of the tree  
   • The person the killer’s sister talks to as “Grandpa Bob” must be Mary’s husband.  
   • “Uncle Bill” must therefore be one of Bob & Mary’s four children.  
   • “Cousin Bo” is a grand-child (same generation as the sister).

2. List the four married children of Bob & Mary  
   Clue 3 already gives one couple: May & Ben.  
   Clue 4 makes Robin a daughter (Mo is Bob’s son-in-law).  
   Clue 7 makes Maria a daughter (she is standing with Bob).  
   The fourth child is Bill (named in step 1).  
   → Children: Bill, May, Robin, Maria – each married.

3. Attach every spouse by using the brother-in-law statement  
   Bill is talking to “his brother-in-law Barry” (Clue 1).  
   Because May is with Ben and Robin with Mo, Barry must be married to Maria.  
   That leaves Myra (Clue 6) to be Bill’s wife.  
   → Couples: Bill-Myra, May-Ben, Robin-Mo, Maria-Barry.

4. Distribute all the grandchildren so every couple has at least two  
   a) May & Ben already have Missy and Bernie (Clue 3).  
   b) Robin & Mo have “their sons” (plural, unnamed in Clue 4). Bart, Buck and Bruce are three brothers (Clue 2) and the only grandsons still free, so they are Robin & Mo’s.  
   c) Maria & Barry must take the remaining paired grandchildren Bo & Molly (Clue 5 describes them as siblings).  
   d) Bill & Myra therefore get the last two grandchildren, Brad (named in Clue 6) and his sister Megan (mentioned in Clue 5).  
   All four couples now have ≥ 2 children.

5. Identify the killer’s sister (the informant)  
   Requirements from the opening paragraph:  
      – she is Bob’s grand-daughter,  
      – she is Bill’s niece,  
      – she is Bo’s cousin, and  
      – she is female (“sister”).  
   The only female grandchildren who satisfy all three relationship conditions are  
      ▸ Missy (child of May) and  
      ▸ Molly (child of Maria).  
   Molly’s brother (Bo) cannot be the killer because Bo is the person she talked to.  
   Therefore the sister must be Missy.

6. Determine which sibling of Missy is the killer  
   Missy’s only sibling is Bernie (Clue 3).  
   → Bernie is the relative who shot Mary Beem.

Answer: Bernie

Question:
Question: Edward, Howard, and John are three high school students each of whom is taking three of the four subjects, biology, chemistry, history, and mathematics. One day while talking about their programs they made the following statements.
Edward: There is just one subject we're all taking. I'm the only one of us who is taking mathematics. No two of us are taking the same three subjects. John is wrong when he says that Howard and I are both taking chemistry.
Howard: Ed is the only one of us who is taking history. John and I are taking the same subjects. We're all taking biology. Two of us are taking both chemistry and biology.
John: We're all taking mathematics. Howard is taking history. Ed is taking one subject that I'm not. Both Howard and Ed are taking chemistry.
If two and only two of each boy's statements are true, what subjects is each boy taking?
 Solution: Edward: chemistry, biology, history
Howard: chemistry, biology, mathematics
John: biology, mathematics, history
Hint: It is true that there is only one subject they are all taking.
Human Solution:
Edward: chemistry, biology, history
Howard: chemistry, biology, mathematics
John: biology, mathematics, history
Response:
Answer  
Edward: Biology, Chemistry, History  
Howard: Biology, Chemistry, Mathematics  
John: Biology, History, Mathematics  

Reasoning in simple, self-contained steps  

1.  “Exactly two true” rule  
   Each boy utters four sentences; for every boy exactly two must be true and two must be false.  

2.  Start with Howard’s sentences H3 and H4  
   H3: “We’re all taking Biology.”  
   H4: “Two of us are taking both Chemistry and Biology.”  
   •  If H3 were false, at most one of H1, H2, H4 could be true, contradicting the ‘exactly two’ rule.  
   •  Hence H3 is TRUE → everybody studies Biology.  
   •  To reach the quota of two truths for Howard, make H4 TRUE as well.  
     ⇒ Exactly two boys take both Chemistry and Biology.  

3.  Consequences of H4 being true  
   Since everybody already has Biology, H4 forces exactly two boys to add Chemistry.  
   Call them (for the moment) “the Chemistry pair.”  

4.  Use John’s sentences  
   Let us try to make J4 (“Both Howard and Ed are taking Chemistry”) TRUE; that will automatically give us the Chemistry pair required by H4.  
   So J4 is TRUE → Edward and Howard are the Chemistry pair.  
   John now has one true statement and still needs exactly one more.  
   •  J1 (“We’re all taking Mathematics”) would add a second common subject (Math) for everyone, contradicting Edward’s E1 (examined in a moment), so set J1 = FALSE.  
   •  Decide later between J2 (“Howard is taking History”) and J3 (“Ed is taking one subject that I’m not”).  

5.  Fill Howard’s list so far  
   Howard already has Biology and Chemistry.  
   H1 (“Ed is the only one of us taking History”) must be FALSE (otherwise H1,H3 would already give Howard his two truths and H4 would have to be false).  
   Therefore at least one other boy besides Edward takes History → Edward certainly has History.  
   H2 (“John and I are taking the same subjects”) is therefore FALSE (because if it were true John would have to contain Chemistry, contradicting the Chemistry-pair count of exactly two).  
   Howard now has his two true sentences (H3, H4) and his list is: Biology, Chemistry, plus one more subject that is not History; so the missing subject must be Mathematics.  
   → Howard = B C M.  

6.  Decide which second statement of John is true  
   We already fixed J1 FALSE and J4 TRUE.  
   •  If J2 (“Howard is taking History”) were TRUE it would contradict the conclusion in step 5 that Howard lacks History.  
   •  Consequently J2 is FALSE and J3 must be TRUE to give John his second truth.  
   J3 TRUE = “Ed is taking one subject that I’m (John) not.”  

7.  Build John’s list  
   John already has Biology (step 2).  
   J3 is TRUE and J4 is TRUE, so:  
   •  Edward has Chemistry (from step 4).  
   •  For J3 to be true, Edward must have exactly one subject that John lacks. Because Edward has Chemistry, John must NOT have Chemistry.  
   •  John still needs two more subjects besides Biology that are not both Chemistry; choose History (to satisfy step 5: someone besides Ed has History) and Mathematics.  
   → John = B H M.  

8.  Complete Edward’s list  
   So far Edward is in the Chemistry pair (has Chemistry) and has History (step 5); everybody has Biology (step 2).  
   → Edward = B C H.  

9.  Check Edward’s own sentences  
   E1: “There is just ONE subject we’re all taking.”  
        True (Biology is the only universal subject).  
   E2: “I am the ONLY one taking Mathematics.”  
        False (Ed doesn’t take Mathematics at all).  
   E3: “No two of us are taking the same three subjects.”  
        True (Ed = B C H, Howard = B C M, John = B H M are all different).  
   E4: “John is wrong when he says that Howard and I are both taking Chemistry.”  
        False (John’s J4 is actually correct).  
   Edward now has exactly two true statements (E1, E3).  

10.  Verification  
    •  Howard: true statements H3 and H4 only.  
    •  John: true statements J3 and J4 only.  
    •  Each boy takes exactly three of the four subjects; Biology is the sole subject common to all; all other requirements are met.  

Therefore:  
Edward – Biology, Chemistry, History  
Howard – Biology, Chemistry, Mathematics  
John – Biology, History, Mathematics

Question:
Question: During one meeting with a clan of ninjas, it has been noticed that more ninjas have turned up to the meeting than usual. The ninjas realised that these infiltrators must be the enemy of the ninjas (the pirates). Each person dressed as a ninja at the meeting made a statement. The cunning ninjas lied about their fellow ninjas in order to remain secret and told the truth about the pirates. The pirates tried to mock the cunningness by lying about the pirates and telling the truth about the ninjas. From the following statements, can you identify the ninjas and pirates?
Ninja A: Ninja B is a ninja
Ninja B: Ninja C belongs to Ninja A's group
Ninja C: Ninja C doesn't belong to Ninja F's group
Ninja D: Ninja A belongs to Ninja B's group
Ninja E: Ninja B belongs to Ninja C's group
Ninja F: Ninja E belongs to Ninja A's group
Remember, the ninjas and pirates will lie about individual ninjas or pirates, not groups of ninjas or pirates.
 Solution: Ninja A is a pirate
Ninja B is a ninja
Ninja C is a ninja
Ninja D is a pirate
Ninja E is a pirate
Ninja F is a ninja
Ninja A said that Ninja B is a ninja. This is because Ninja A is a pirate and Ninja B is a ninja, so Ninja A told the truth.
Ninja B said that Ninja C belongs to Ninja A's group. Ninja B is a ninja and Ninja C is a ninja, so Ninja B lied.
Ninja C said that Ninja C doesn't belong to Ninja F's group. Ninja C is obviously from the same group as Ninja C, so Ninja C lied.
Ninja D said that Ninja A belongs to Ninja B's group. Ninja D is a pirate and Ninja A is a pirate so Ninja D lied.
Ninja E said that Ninja B belongs to Ninja C's group. Ninja E is a pirate and Ninja B is a ninja, so Ninja E told the truth.
Ninja F said that Ninja E belongs to Ninja A's group. Ninja F is a ninja and Ninja E is a pirate, so Ninja F told the truth.
Hint: Think about what Ninja A said, first.
Human Solution:
Ninja A is a pirate
Ninja B is a ninja
Ninja C is a ninja
Ninja D is a pirate
Ninja E is a pirate
Ninja F is a ninja
Ninja A said that Ninja B is a ninja. This is because Ninja A is a pirate and Ninja B is a ninja, so Ninja A told the truth.
Ninja B said that Ninja C belongs to Ninja A's group. Ninja B is a ninja and Ninja C is a ninja, so Ninja B lied.
Ninja C said that Ninja C doesn't belong to Ninja F's group. Ninja C is obviously from the same group as Ninja C, so Ninja C lied.
Ninja D said that Ninja A belongs to Ninja B's group. Ninja D is a pirate and Ninja A is a pirate so Ninja D lied.
Ninja E said that Ninja B belongs to Ninja C's group. Ninja E is a pirate and Ninja B is a ninja, so Ninja E told the truth.
Ninja F said that Ninja E belongs to Ninja A's group. Ninja F is a ninja and Ninja E is a pirate, so Ninja F told the truth.
Response:
SIMPLE STEP–BY–STEP REASONING  

Notation  
N(x)  = “x is a ninja”  
P(x)  = “x is a pirate” (the only other possibility)  
x ~ y = “x belongs to y’s group” (i.e. both ninjas or both pirates)  

Rule table  
• A ninja lies whenever the person (or at least one of the people) mentioned is a ninja;  
  he tells the truth when everybody mentioned is a pirate.  
• A pirate lies whenever the person (or at least one of the people) mentioned is a pirate;  
  he tells the truth when everybody mentioned is a ninja.  

(That is exactly the wording: “ninjas lied about their fellow ninjas and told the truth about the pirates; pirates lied about the pirates and told the truth about the ninjas.”)  

Step 1 – Translate every statement  

S1  (A):  N(B)  
S2  (B):  C ~ A  
S3  (C):  C ∉ F   (i.e. C ≁ F)  
S4  (D):  A ~ B  
S5  (E):  B ~ C  
S6  (F):  E ~ A  

Step 2 – Show that B must be a ninja  

• If B were a pirate, S1 (“B is a ninja”) would be false.  
  – A would then have spoken falsely about a pirate.  
  – Only a pirate lies about a pirate, so A would also have to be a pirate.  
• With A and B both pirates, S4 (“A ~ B”) would be true.  
  – D would therefore have told the truth about pirates, something only a ninja can do,  
    so D would be a ninja.  
• But S4 mentions pirates, and ninjas MUST lie when a ninja is involved; contradiction.  

Hence B cannot be a pirate; therefore B is a ninja.

Step 3 – Deduce A’s allegiance from S1  

S1 is now TRUE (“B is a ninja”).  
The speaker, A, is telling the truth about a ninja.  
Only a pirate does that, so A is a pirate.

(We already have A = P, B = N.)

Step 4 – Use S2 (“C ~ A”) with the knowledge A = P  

S2 is spoken by a ninja (B).  
Because C’s allegiance is unknown while A is pirate, S2 is talking about at least one pirate;  
a ninja must therefore tell the truth—IF the other person were a pirate—but has to lie about a fellow ninja.  
Since B must lie about the fellow-ninja part, S2 is FALSE.  
Falsehood of C ~ A gives C ≁ A, i.e. C ≠ A ⇒ C is NOT a pirate ⇒ C is a ninja.

(We now have C = N.)

Step 5 – Evaluate S5 (“B ~ C”)  

Spoken by E (unknown so far).  
We already know B = N and C = N, so “B ~ C” is TRUE.  
A TRUE statement about ninjas can be spoken only by a pirate.  
Therefore E is a pirate.  (E = P.)

Step 6 – Evaluate S6 (“E ~ A”)  

Spoken by F (unknown).  
We have just found E = P and previously A = P, so “E ~ A” is TRUE.  
This is a statement about pirates; telling the truth about pirates is something only a ninja does.  
Hence F is a ninja.  (F = N.)

Step 7 – Check S3 (“C ≁ F”)  

Spoken by C (a ninja).  
We already have C = N, F = N, so “C ≁ F” is FALSE.  
A ninja must indeed lie about a fellow ninja, so S3 is consistent.

Step 8 – Check S4 (“A ~ B”)  

Spoken by D (still unknown).  
“A ~ B” compares A = P with B = N ⇒ statement is FALSE.  
That is a false statement involving a pirate, so it must have been uttered by a pirate.  
Therefore D is a pirate.  (D = P.)
