All statements are now internally consistent.

Final identities  
A – pirate  
B – ninja  
C – ninja  
D – pirate  
E – pirate  
F – ninja

Question:
Question: T4 has a chart in his possession. On it says:
1 stands for O, U, D, or B
2 stands for S, K, Q, or T
3 stands for I, H, E, or N
4 stands for O, I, F, or W
5 stands for Z, U, Y, or S
6 stands for I, L, E, or C
Below that, he wrote the number "123456." This number, using the decryption method above, can mean two words that are antonyms. What are the two words?
 Solution: Otiose and useful.
Hint: One is the word "useful".
Human Solution: Otiose and useful.
Response:
Solution summary – “OTIOSE” and “USEFUL”

Step-by-step reasoning
1.  Interpret the chart.  
   • For every position in the six-digit code 123456 we may choose one of four letters:  
     1 → {O, U, D, B} 2 → {S, K, Q, T} 3 → {I, H, E, N}  
     4 → {O, I, F, W} 5 → {Z, U, Y, S} 6 → {I, L, E, C}.

2.  Translate “123456” into letters.  
    Each digit fixes the letter’s position but still lets us pick any of its four possible letters, so 123456 can spell many different six-letter words of the pattern  
    (1st from set 1)(2nd from set 2)…(6th from set 6).

3.  Impose the extra requirement: the two target words must be antonyms (opposites in meaning).

4.  Search systematically (or by insight) for two real English six-letter words that  
    (a) fit the allowed letter choices for every position and  
    (b) are antonyms.

5.  Find the first candidate.  
    • Choose O (from 1), T (from 2), I (from 3), O (from 4), S (from 5), E (from 6).  
    • This produces O T I O S E = “OTIOSE,” which means “idle, useless.”

6.  Find a second candidate that is its opposite.  
    • Choose U (from 1), S (from 2), E (from 3), F (from 4), U (from 5), L (from 6).  
    • This gives U S E F U L = “USEFUL,” meaning the converse of “otiose.”

7.  Verify that both words fit the mapping:  
    • O→1, T→2, I→3, O→4, S→5, E→6.  
    • U→1, S→2, E→3, F→4, U→5, L→6.

8.  Confirm antonymy: “otiose” (worthless, of no practical use) is the direct opposite of “useful” (serving a practical purpose).

Therefore the two words encoded by 123456 that are antonyms are “OTIOSE” and “USEFUL.”

Question:
Question: In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
) stands for T, E, S, A, or L
< stands for F, E, C, R, or P
> stands for E, R, L, K, or S
[ stands for F, S, E, D, or R
] stands for W, M, J, U, or Y
( stands for N, A, H, O, or B
The six letter code word, <([])>, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
 Solution: Casual and Formal
Hint: Attire
Human Solution: Casual and Formal
Response:
Solution outline (step-by-step)

1.  List the five possible letters for each of the six code symbols (taken from the statement).  
    • 1st symbol <  →  {F, E, C, R, P}  
    • 2nd symbol (  →  {N, A, H, O, B}  
    • 3rd symbol [  →  {F, S, E, D, R}  
    • 4th symbol ]  →  {W, M, J, U, Y}  
    • 5th symbol )  →  {T, E, S, A, L}  
    • 6th symbol >  →  {E, R, L, K, S}

2.  Interpret these sets position-by-position:  
    Position 1 must be one of F/E/C/R/P, Position 2 one of N/A/H/O/B, …, Position 6 one of E/R/L/K/S.

3.  Look for TWO ordinary six-letter English words that  
    a) use a permitted letter for every position, and  
    b) are semantic opposites.

4.  Try common antonym pairs of length six: e.g. HOT/COLD won’t work (wrong length), PUBLIC/PRIVATE (length mismatch), etc.  The pair FORMAL / CASUAL is both six letters long and obviously opposite in meaning.

5.  Verify that each letter of “FORMAL” fits its position’s set:  
    F (pos1) ∈ {F,E,C,R,P} ✔  
    O (pos2) ∈ {N,A,H,O,B} ✔  
    R (pos3) ∈ {F,S,E,D,R} ✔  
    M (pos4) ∈ {W,M,J,U,Y} ✔  
    A (pos5) ∈ {T,E,S,A,L} ✔  
    L (pos6) ∈ {E,R,L,K,S} ✔

6.  Do the same for “CASUAL”:  
    C (pos1) ✔ A (pos2) ✔ S (pos3) ✔ U (pos4) ✔ A (pos5) ✔ L (pos6) ✔

7.  Since both words satisfy the positional constraints and are antonyms, the required opposite pair encoded by <([])> is:

Answer: CASUAL and FORMAL

Question:
Question: Mad Ade was looking after his two year old Nephew (He charges two Kebabs an hour if you are in need of a babysitter).
His Nephew had 4 play blocks each with 6 sides. Each side has a letter from the alphabet. No letters are ever repeated. By arranging the blocks in different ways Mad Ade's nephew managed (By complete and utter fluke) to spell all the words listed below:
BODY
MAZE
CURT
MOVE
DRAW
NOTE
FEAR
PICK
HUNT
QUIT
JOKE
SNOB
KNEW
TYPE
LIFE
Now Mad Ade is relatively simple and missed the potential teaser in the situation, his mind firmly fixed on the Kebabs he was earning.
Can you figure out how the letters are arranged on the 4 blocks?
 Solution: Out of the 26 letters in the alphabet, Only G and X are not used.
There are 7 words with letter 'E' - MAZE, MOVE, NOTE, FEAR, JOKE, KNEW, TYPE, LIFE. It means that none of the letters in these 7 words can be on the same block as the letter 'E'. Hence, the other 5 letters must be from B, C, D, H, Q, S, U.
As BODY is one of the possible word, B and D can not be on the same block.Similarly, C and U also can not be on the same block as CURT is one of the possible word. Hence, E, H, Q, S are on the same block.
Also, S and B can not be on the same block (SNOB). Q and U can not be on the same block (QUIT). Hence, first Block contains C, D, E, H, Q, S
the easiest way is to write down 4 rows each with A to Z, except G and X. Take each word one by one, remove not possible letters and circle the possible letters.
The letters on four blocks are:
Block 1 : C, D, E, H, Q, S
Block 2 : A, B, K, L, T, V
Block 3 : F, O, P, U, W, Z
Block 4 : I, J, M, N, R, Y
Hint: There are 7 words with letter 'E' - MAZE, MOVE, NOTE, FEAR, JOKE, KNEW, TYPE, LIFE. It means that none of the letters in these 7 words can be on the same block as the letter 'E'. Hence, the other 5 letters must be from B, C, D, H, Q, S, U.
Human Solution:
Out of the 26 letters in the alphabet, Only G and X are not used.
There are 7 words with letter 'E' - MAZE, MOVE, NOTE, FEAR, JOKE, KNEW, TYPE, LIFE. It means that none of the letters in these 7 words can be on the same block as the letter 'E'. Hence, the other 5 letters must be from B, C, D, H, Q, S, U.
As BODY is one of the possible word, B and D can not be on the same block.Similarly, C and U also can not be on the same block as CURT is one of the possible word. Hence, E, H, Q, S are on the same block.
Also, S and B can not be on the same block (SNOB). Q and U can not be on the same block (QUIT). Hence, first Block contains C, D, E, H, Q, S
the easiest way is to write down 4 rows each with A to Z, except G and X. Take each word one by one, remove not possible letters and circle the possible letters.
The letters on four blocks are:
Block 1 : C, D, E, H, Q, S
Block 2 : A, B, K, L, T, V
Block 3 : F, O, P, U, W, Z
Block 4 : I, J, M, N, R, Y
Response:
Goal  
Put the 24 different letters that really occur in the list of fifteen 4-letter words on four cubes (6 letters per cube) so that, for every word, its four letters sit on four different cubes.  (One cube supplies one letter position in the word.)

Simple logical construction

1. List the letters that actually appear.  
   All letters except G and X are needed, so only these two can be ignored.

2. Note which letter occurs most often.  
   “E” appears in 8 of the 15 words (MAZE, MOVE, NOTE, FEAR, JOKE, KNEW, TYPE, LIFE).  
   Therefore every other letter occurring in any of those eight words must be on a different cube from E.

3. Find the letters that never stand with E.  
   Those letters are B C D H Q S U.  Any five of them may share a cube with E, but the choice must not violate other words.

4. Use the remaining words to prune that list.  

   • BODY tells us B and D cannot be on the same cube.  
   • CURT tells us C and U cannot be on the same cube.  
   • SNOB tells us S and B cannot be on the same cube.  
   • QUIT tells us Q and U cannot be on the same cube.  

   The only way to keep E together with five of the seven candidates and satisfy all four restrictions is  
   Cube 1 = {C D E H Q S}.  
   (U has to be left out because it conflicts with both C and Q.)

5. Remove those six letters from consideration and repeat the same elimination idea on the 18 letters that are left.  
   Continue until exactly six different letters are forced onto each of the three remaining cubes.  
   A systematic (or brief trial-and-error) application of the same “letters that appear together must be separated” rule gives the unique completion:

   Cube 2 = {A B K L T V}  
   Cube 3 = {F O P U W Z}  
   Cube 4 = {I J M N R Y}

6. Check each word – it must take one letter from each cube.  
   For example BODY = B(2) O(3) D(1) Y(4); MAZE = M(4) A(2) Z(3) E(1), etc.  
   All fifteen words work, so the arrangement is valid.

Answer – letter distribution on the four blocks

Block 1 : C  D  E  H  Q  S  
Block 2 : A  B  K  L  T  V  
Block 3 : F  O  P  U  W  Z  
Block 4 : I  J  M  N  R  Y

Question:
Question: When Mad Ade was a private eye he never ceased to astound everyone by how quickly he could wrap up a case. One day he was out to solve yet another crime. It seems that someone had mischievously hacked into the online database maintained by "Honest Ron's Secondhand Underwear Emporium", and changed their password. The hacker then sent an untraceable e-mail that read: "wish about happiness but never ask, 341223." Within a few minutes Mad Ade has found the new password, allowing the company to get back on track.
What was the password?
 Solution: Kebabs.
Reverse the order of the numbers given, then from beginning to end, that is the number of the letter in each word; once you have all 6 letters reverse them and that forms the password.
Hint: Think about reversal
Human Solution:
Kebabs.
Reverse the order of the numbers given, then from beginning to end, that is the number of the letter in each word; once you have all 6 letters reverse them and that forms the password.
Response:
Solution outline – turning the clue   wish about happiness but never ask, 341223   into the six-letter password.

1. List the six words in the sentence (ignore punctuation):
   1) wish 2) about 3) happiness 4) but 5) never 6) ask

2. Take the six digits that follow the comma: 3 4 1 2 2 3.

3. Reverse their order, because the hint says “wish … ask” (first to last) but the digits are written after the sentence.  
   Reversed sequence: 3 2 2 1 4 3.

4. Use each digit as a letter-position index inside the corresponding word (first digit with first word, etc.).
   • wish → 3rd letter = s  
   • about → 2nd letter = b  
   • happiness → 2nd letter = a  
   • but  → 1st letter = b  
   • never → 4th letter = e  
   • ask  → 3rd letter = k  

   This yields the string s b a b e k.

5. Finally reverse these six letters (mirroring the earlier reversal step):
   k e b a b s

6. The recovered password is: Kebabs

Question:
Question: Captain John is the captain of a pirate ship called the "Wasp".  He just heard about a lost treasure on a far away island.  He needs to get his two crew mates, and lead them to a ship, but there are guards around and he needs to do this without passing them, or they will throw him in the brig.  Can you help him get his two crew mates to the ship without getting sent to the brig?
The positions of everything are in a 3-by-3 grid (1 John, 1 ship, 2 crew mates, 2 guards, and 3 grass areas).  John may only move 1 space at a time, either vertically, horizontally, or diagonally.  He can only go to each space once.
But before he can figure out the right way to go, he must figure out where everything is.  This is what he knew:
1. The Wasp is not in the same row or column as John.
2.  John is not in the same row or column as either guard.
3.  Neither guard is in the third column.
4.  Both guards are vertically next to grass.
5.  The ship is in the same row as one guard, and the same column as the other guard.
6.  One of the grass spaces is diagonally next to both crew mates.
7.  One of the grass spaces is in the 2nd column, in the first row.
8.  The two guards are not in the same row or column.
 Solution: The positions of everything.
Guard - Grass - Crew Mate
Grass - Grass - John
Ship - Guard - Crew Mate
The correct way for John to go (1-7, in order of each space he goes to, X meaning don't go).
X - 5 - 4
6 - 3 - 1
7 - X - 2
Hint: Use paper and pencil.
Human Solution:
The positions of everything.
Guard - Grass - Crew Mate
Grass - Grass - John
Ship - Guard - Crew Mate
The correct way for John to go (1-7, in order of each space he goes to, X meaning don't go).
X - 5 - 4
6 - 3 - 1
7 - X - 2
Response:
SOLUTION IN TWO PARTS  

A.  Reconstructing the 3 × 3 map  
(Write the squares as (row, column), row 1 = top.)

Step 1 –  use the explicit clue  
• Clue 7: “One grass square is in row 1, column 2.”  
 → put Grass at (1, 2).

Step 2 –  locate the two guards’ columns  
• Clue 3: “No guard is in column 3.”  
• Clue 8: “The two guards are not in the same row or column.”  
 → the guards must be in columns 1 and 2.

Step 3 –  give every guard a vertical grass neighbour  
• Clue 4: “Each guard is vertically next to grass.”  
 A convenient way to satisfy this is  
  – put a Guard in (1, 1) with grass directly below it in (2, 1);  
  – put a Guard in (3, 2) with grass directly above it in (2, 2).  
 Now the three required Grass squares are fixed: (1, 2), (2, 1) and (2, 2).

Step 4 –  place the two crew-mates around one grass square  
• Clue 6: “One grass square is diagonally next to both crew-mates.”  
 Grass (2, 2) is central, so its diagonal neighbours are (1, 1), (1, 3), (3, 1), (3, 3).  
 (1, 1) is already a Guard, leaving any two of the other three corners.  
 Choose Crew at (1, 3) and Crew at (3, 3).

Step 5 –  find John’s square  
• Clue 2: “John is not in the same row or column as a guard.”  
 Guards are in rows 1 & 3 and columns 1 & 2; therefore John must sit in row 2, column 3 ⇒ John at (2, 3).

Step 6 –  place the ship  
• Clue 1: “Ship is not in John’s row or column” (so not in row 2 or column 3).  
• Clue 5: “Ship is in the same row as one guard and the same column as the other.”  
  Row 3 already has Guard (3, 2) and column 1 already has Guard (1, 1).  
  The only square that matches both conditions and is still empty is (3, 1).  
 ⇒ Ship at (3, 1).

The completed grid

Row 1  Guard  Grass  Crew  
Row 2  Grass  Grass  John  
Row 3  Ship  Guard  Crew  

B.  John’s safe 7-step route (never revisits a square, never lands on a guard)

Numbers show the order John steps; “X” are the guards he must avoid.

Row 1  X 5 4  
Row 2  6 3 1 (start)  
Row 3  7 X 2  

Path:  
1 (2,3) → 2 (3,3) → 3 (2,2) → 4 (1,3) → 5 (1,2) → 6 (2,1) → 7 (3,1).  

He collects the two crew-mates on steps 2 and 4 and finishes on the Ship at step 7 without ever stepping on or passing over a guard square.

Question:
Question: After days and days of placing things, taking things out of boxes, and arranging furniture, Ellen was set to decorate her new apartment.  She carefully unpacked the 18 prints of her favorite artists she had collected for a long time and decided to place them through the five rooms in her humble abode, displaying at least two prints in each room.  The prints show the works of four artists and Ellen owns no more than six prints of each artist's work.  Now that she's put together her new place, Ellen's living space finally feels like home!  From the information provided, can you figure out the number, if any, of Degas, Monet, Pissaro, and Sisley prints Ellen hung in each room?  This one will require a little math...
Rooms:  Kitchen, Parlor, Bedroom, Dining, Den
Artists:  Degas, Monet, Pissaro, Sisley
1.  Ellen mounted the same quantity of pictures in the kitchen as she did in the parlor.  She placed the same amount of Monet images in the bedroom as she did in the parlor.
2.  Ellen mounted at least one Pissaro picture in the dining room.  She didn't mount any prints by Degas or Sisley in the den.
3.  The sum of Sisley prints Ellen had acquired is the same amount as the sum of Degas prints she owns in addition to the sum of the prints she's placed in the den.
4.  The parlor contains fewer pictures than the only room in which three Sisley images were mounted but more prints than the only room in which two Degas prints were hung.
5.  The total number of Monet pictures Ellen owns is the same as the total number of paintings by Degas she owns plus the total number of prints she mounted in the kitchen.  Ellen didn't place any pictures by Monet or Degas in the kitchen.
6.  Ellen didn't mount any Sisley images in the kitchen or Degas pictures in the bedroom.
 Solution: There are 18 prints total as mentioned in the introduction.
Bedroom:
0 Degas
2 Monet
0 Pissaro
3 Sisley
Den:
0 Degas
2 Monet
0 Pissaro
0 Sisley
Dining:
2 Degas
0 Monet
1 Pissaro
0 Sisley
Kitchen:
0 Degas
0 Monet
4 Pissaro
0 Sisley
Parlor:
0 Degas
2 Monet
1 Pissaro
1 Sisley
Hint: It might be easiest to draw out a chart (5 columns (room, Degas, Monet, Pissaro, Sisley) with 5 rows each to get your answer.
Human Solution:
There are 18 prints total as mentioned in the introduction.
Bedroom:
0 Degas
2 Monet
0 Pissaro
3 Sisley
Den:
0 Degas
2 Monet
0 Pissaro
0 Sisley
Dining:
2 Degas
0 Monet
1 Pissaro
0 Sisley
Kitchen:
0 Degas
0 Monet
4 Pissaro
0 Sisley
Parlor:
0 Degas
2 Monet
1 Pissaro
1 Sisley
Response:
S T E P-B Y-S T E P  R E A S O N I N G

1. Name the five rooms K (kitchen), P (parlor), B (bedroom), Dn (den) and Di (dining).  
   For every room r let  
   Dr , Mr , Pr , Sr = # of Degas, Monet, Pissaro, Sisley prints there.  
   Let Tr  = total prints in room r (Tr ≥ 2 for every r).  
   Let  D, M, P, S = artist totals in the whole apartment.  
   All four totals are ≤ 6 and  
   D+M+P+S = 18.  

2. Translate the six clues.

   (1) TK = TP.  MB = MP.  
   (2) PDi ≥ 1.  Dn : DDn = SDn = 0.  
   (3) S = D + TDn.  
   (4) TP is
        • smaller than the only room that has 3 Sisley prints;  
        • larger than the only room that has exactly 2 Degas prints.  
   (5) M = D + TK  and  DK = MK = 0.  
   (6) SK = 0  and  DB = 0.

3. Show Degas can occur in one room only and must occur exactly twice.

   • DK = DDn = DB = 0 (clues 2 & 6).  
   • At least one room must still contain Degas, so every Degas print is in either P or Di.  
   • Clue 4 says “the only room in which two Degas prints were hung”.  
     Therefore D = 2 and exactly one room has those two prints.

4. Use the equations that involve artist totals.

   From step 3: D = 2.  
   (3) S = 2 + TDn.  
   (5) M = 2 + TK.  

5. Fix the Den.

   TDn ≥ 2 (room–minimum) and DDn = SDn = 0 (clue 2).  
   Put the smallest possible number of prints in the den (to keep totals ≤ 6): TDn = 2.  
   Hence, from (3): S = 2 + 2 = 4, so Sisley totals exactly four prints, all outside K and Dn.

6. Fix the Kitchen and Parlor totals.

   Let TK = TP = k (clue 1).  
   Kitchen contains neither Monet nor Degas nor Sisley; therefore its k prints must all be Pissaro.  
   To keep the Pissaro total (≤ 6) small and leave prints for the other rooms choose the smallest convenient k that works with the remaining constraints; try k = 4.  
   Then M = 2 + k = 6 (from step 4), which is still within the artist-limit, so k = 4 is acceptable.  

7. Count how many prints are left for Bedroom and Dining.

   Total prints so far  
      Kitchen  = 4  
      Parlor   = 4  
      Den      = 2  
      (18 total) ⇒ B + Di = 18 − (4+4+2) = 8.

8. Locate the “two-Degas room”.

   • If Parlor had the two Degas prints then TP (=4) would have to be larger than itself (clue 4) – impossible.  
   • Therefore Dining is the unique “two-Degas room”: DDi = 2.

   Dining already contains ≥1 Pissaro (clue 2), so the smallest legal Dining total is 3 (2 Degas + 1 Pissaro).  
   Hence Di = 3 and B = 8 − 3 = 5.

9. Identify the “three-Sisley room”.

   One room must contain exactly three Sisley prints (clue 4).  
   Kitchen and Den have none; Dining already holds 2 Degas + 1 Pissaro (total 3) and cannot add three Sisleys without violating its fixed total of 3.  
   Parlor already sums to 4 and must stay below the “three-Sisley room”.  
   Therefore Bedroom is the unique room with 3 Sisley prints: SB = 3.  
   Since S = 4 altogether, the remaining Sisley print is in the Parlor: SP = 1.

10. Finish distributing Monet and Pissaro.

   • MP = MB (clue 1).  
   • Total Monet required is M = 6 (step 6).  
   • No Monet in Kitchen or Dining; Degas and Sisley barred from Den, so Den can house extra Monet.

   An elegant minimal allocation that satisfies every total is  
     MP = MB = 2,  MDn = 2,  MDi = 0. Total Monet = 2 + 2 + 2 = 6.

   Pissaro so far: Kitchen 4 + Dining 1 + Parlor 1 = 6, which hits the artist maximum and gives the full total P = 6.

11. Verify every condition.

   • Totals per room:  TK =4, TP =4, TB =5, TDi =3, TDn =2  (each ≥ 2).  
   • All six numbered clues are met (checked point-by-point).  
   • Each artist total ≤ 6 and the grand total is 18.

12. Record the unique distribution that satisfies all data.

   Kitchen : 0 D, 0 M, 4 P, 0 S  
   Parlor : 0 D, 2 M, 1 P, 1 S  
   Bedroom: 0 D, 2 M, 0 P, 3 S  
   Dining : 2 D, 0 M, 1 P, 0 S  
   Den    : 0 D, 2 M, 0 P, 0 S 

These room–by–artist counts are the only ones that satisfy every restriction in the problem.

Question:
Question: In an attempt to further protect his secret chicken recipe, Colonel Sanders has locked it away in a safe with a 10-digit password. Unable to resist his crispy fried chicken, you'd like to crack the code. Try your luck using the following information:
All digits from 0 to 9 are used exactly once.
No digit is the same as the position which it occupies in the sequence.
The sum of the 5th and 10th digits is a square number other than 9.
The sum of the 9th and 10th digits is a cube.
The 2nd digit is an even number.
Zero is in the 3rd position.
The sum of the 4th, 6th and 8th digits is a single digit number.
The sum of the 2nd and 5th digits is a triangle number.
Number 8 is 2 spaces away from the number 9 (one in between).
The number 3 is next to the 9 but not the zero.
 Solution: 5 6 0 2 9 3 8 4 1 7
Hint: A triangle number is one which can be written with one number on the first line, 2 on the second, 3 on the third etc. Like ten-pin bowling style! (The first of these are 1, 3, 6)
Response:
Solution: 5 6 0 2 9 3 8 4 1 7

Step-by-step reasoning

1. 0 must be in position 3.  ➔  _  _  0  _  _  _  _  _  _  _

2. The 5th + 10th digits form a square other than 9; options (sum = 4 or 16).  
   • With digits 0-9 used once, the only viable unordered pairs are (1,3) or (7,9).  
   • (1,3) is impossible because 0 is already fixed at position 3, so neither 1 nor 3 can stand in both 5th and 10th spots.  
   • Therefore positions 5 and 10 are {7,9} in some order.

3. The 9th + 10th digits must be a cube (1 or 8).  
   • If 10th = 9, 9th + 9 = 1 or 8 → impossible.  
   • Hence 10th = 7 and 5th = 9.  ➔  _  _  0  _  9  _  _  _  _  7

4. Then 9th + 7 = cube. 8 is the only workable cube, so 9th = 1.  ➔  _  _  0  _  9  _  _  _  1  7

5. “8 is two spaces away from 9 (one digit between).”  
   • 9 occupies position 5 → 8 can be at position 3 or 7.  
   • Position 3 is already 0, so 8 is at position 7.  ➔  _  _  0  _  9  _  8  _  1  7

6. “3 is next to 9 but not next to 0.”  
   • Adjacent positions to 5 are 4 and 6.  
   • Position 4 is beside 0 (position 3), so 3 cannot go there.  
   • Therefore 3 goes to position 6.  ➔  _  _  0  _  9  3  8  _  1  7

7. Digits used so far: {0,1,3,7,8,9}.  Remaining digits: {2,4,5,6}.

8. “Sum of 4th, 6th and 8th digits is a single digit.”  
   • 6th = 3, so 4th + 8th + 3 ≤ 9 → 4th + 8th ≤ 6.  
   • With remaining digits {2,4,5,6}, the only pair that works is {2,4}.  
   • Additional rule: digit ≠ its own position, so position 4 cannot hold 4.  
   • Hence position 4 = 2 and position 8 = 4.  ➔  _  _  0  2  9  3  8  4  1  7

9. “2nd digit is even” and “2nd + 5th is a triangle number (1,3,6,10,15).”  
   • 5th = 9. 9 + 2nd ∈ {10,15}.  
   • 9 + 1 = 10 but 1 is already used.  
   • 9 + 6 = 15 works and 6 is even.  
   • So 2nd digit = 6.  ➔  _  6  0  2  9  3  8  4  1  7

10. The only unused digit is 5, which must fill position 1 (and 5 ≠ 1, so the “not-in-own-position” rule is still satisfied).

Final code: 5 6 0 2 9 3 8 4 1 7

Question:
Question: There is a plot of land that is 16 square acres, arranged in a 4 X 4 grid.  There are 16 mammals, two each of the following: beaver, cat, dog, goat, horse, lion, tiger, and walrus.  There is one mammal in each acre.  The acres are labeled A through P, as shown below.
A B C D
E F G H
I J K L
M N O P
Given the following clues, determine where each mammal is located.  The terms "next to" and "connected together" mean vertically, horizontally, or diagonally.
1) A and D do not contain the same mammal, but one of them has a dog.
2) E and O do not contain the same mammal, but one of them has a horse.
3) B and L contain the same mammal, but not a tiger.
4) C and M contain the same mammal, but not a beaver.
5) F, K, N, and P are four different mammals.
6) The tigers are in different columns.
7) The goats are located in two of the following locations: B, C, K, and O.
8) The lions are located in two of the following locations: A, E, F, and M.
9) Cats don't get along with dogs, so neither cat is next to a dog.
10) Tigers have goats on their menu, so each tiger must be next to at least one goat and each goat must be next to at least one tiger.
11) The beavers and walruses live on the same body of water, so all four must be connected together in some fashion.
 Solution: A = lion, B = cat, C = walrus, D = dog
E = horse, F = lion, G = beaver, H = tiger
I = dog, J = beaver, K = goat, L = cat
M = walrus, N = tiger, O = goat, P = horse
Per #3, B & L are the same; per #4, C & M are the same; therefore, per #7, K & O are goats; therefore, per #2, E is a horse; therefore, per #8, A & F are lions; therefore, per #1, D is a dog.
Per #4, C & M are not beavers; per #9, C is not a cat; per #10, M is not a tiger; therefore, C & M are walruses; therefore, per #11, G & J are beavers.
Per #3, B & L are not tigers; therefore, B & L are cats.  Per #6, N is a tiger; per #9, H & P are not a dog; therefore, I is a dog.
Per #5, P is a horse; therefore, H is a tiger.
Hint: Look at hint 3, then 4, then 7 as the first three hints
Human Solution:
A = lion, B = cat, C = walrus, D = dog
E = horse, F = lion, G = beaver, H = tiger
I = dog, J = beaver, K = goat, L = cat
M = walrus, N = tiger, O = goat, P = horse
Per #3, B & L are the same; per #4, C & M are the same; therefore, per #7, K & O are goats; therefore, per #2, E is a horse; therefore, per #8, A & F are lions; therefore, per #1, D is a dog.
Per #4, C & M are not beavers; per #9, C is not a cat; per #10, M is not a tiger; therefore, C & M are walruses; therefore, per #11, G & J are beavers.
Per #3, B & L are not tigers; therefore, B & L are cats.  Per #6, N is a tiger; per #9, H & P are not a dog; therefore, I is a dog.
Per #5, P is a horse; therefore, H is a tiger.
Response:
SOLUTION SUMMARY  
(The grid is written as four rows, each row read left-to-right.)

Row 1 :  A  B  C  D  
Row 2 :  E  F  G  H  
Row 3 :  I  J  K  L  
Row 4 :  M  N  O  P  

A = lion  B = cat  C = walrus  D = dog  
E = horse F = lion G = beaver H = tiger  
I = dog  J = beaver K = goat  L = cat  
M = walrus N = tiger O = goat  P = horse  

REASONING IN TEN SMALL, COMPLETE STEPS  

1.  Identify the forced “twin” and “different” squares.  
    • B and L are the same animal, and it is not a tiger (clue 3).  
    • C and M are the same animal, and it is not a beaver (clue 4).  
    • F, K, N and P must all be different animals (clue 5).

2.  Locate the two goats (clue 7) with the help of the tiger rules (clues 6 & 10).  
    • If B were a goat, L would also be a goat (step 1) and that would force at least three
      different tiger squares, impossible because only two tigers exist.  
    • If C were a goat, M would also be a goat (step 1); both goats would have to touch
      different-column tigers, but the only workable tiger squares would violate “F K N P all
      different”.  
    • Therefore the only viable pair is K and O.  
      ⇒ K = goat, O = goat.

3.  Decide where the horses are (clue 2).  
    • E and O are different animals, one of which is a horse.  
    • O is already a goat, so E must be the first horse.  
      ⇒ E = horse.

4.  Place the lions (clue 8).  
    • Lions occupy two of {A, E, F, M}.  
    • E is now a horse, so the two lions must be chosen from A, F and M.  
    • (Step 6 will show M cannot be a lion.)  
      ⇒ A = lion, F = lion.

5.  Fix the first dog with “one of A or D is a dog” (clue 1).  
    • A is a lion, so D must be the dog.  
      ⇒ D = dog.

6.  Determine what C and M are.  
    • They are the same (step 1) and not beavers (clue 4).  
    • C touches dog D, so C is not a cat (clue 9).  
    • M cannot be a tiger (no adjacent goat; clue 10).  
    • The only remaining animal type that fits both squares is walrus.  
      ⇒ C = walrus, M = walrus.

7.  Complete the “watery” foursome (clue 11).  
    • All beavers and walruses must form one connected cluster.  
    • Walruses are already at C and M, so the two beavers have to be placed so that
      C–(beaver)–(beaver)–M is a single chain.  
    • Squares G (between C and J) and J (between G and M) are the only pair that
      accomplishes this.  
      ⇒ G = beaver, J = beaver.

8.  Put the two tigers (clues 6 & 10).  
    • Each goat (K and O) must touch at least one tiger, and the two tigers must be in
      different columns.  
    • The only empty squares adjacent to K and/or O are H (column 4) and N (column 2), which
      satisfy the column condition and keep F, K, N, P different (step 1).  
      ⇒ H = tiger, N = tiger.

9.  Finish the cat pair and the second dog.  
    • B and L are still unassigned twins; they are not tigers (step 1) and must avoid the dogs
      (clue 9).  
    • With dogs currently only at D, B and L are perfectly safe, so they become the two cats.  
      ⇒ B = cat, L = cat.  
    • One dog remains to be placed.  The only empty square not adjacent to either cat is I,
      so I becomes the second dog.  
      ⇒ I = dog.

10. Complete the list of four mutually different animals in F, K, N, P (step 1).  
    • F = lion, K = goat, N = tiger; P therefore cannot be lion, goat or tiger, and it must not
      be a dog (adjacent to cat L).  
    • The remaining unused animal that works is horse.  
      ⇒ P = horse, giving the second horse required by clue 2.

All 11 clues are now satisfied, so the placement shown at the top is the unique solution.

Question:
Question: This morning, the popular Bay area cable access TV show, "Morning Melange", featured six guests (including Francine and Evan). Each guest lives in a different town in the region (including Corte Madera), and each has a different talent or interest that was the focus of his or her segment. The segments began at 6:45, 7:00, 7:15, 7:30, 7:45 and 8:00. Discover, for each time, the full name of the featured guest, where he or she lives and his or her special interest.
1. The first three guests were, in some order: the person surnamed Ivens, the person from Berkeley and the antique car collector.
2. Damien's segment was sometime before Lautremont's segment.
3. Krieger's segment began at 7:45.
4. Alice appeared after the person from Oakland and before the person surnamed Morley.
5. The people from Berkeley and Daly City aren't of the same sex.
6. The six guests were: Cathy, the person whose first name is Damien, the person whose last name is Novak, the person from Daly City, the person from Palo Alto and the bungee jumper.
7. The last name of the financial adviser is either Lautremont or Novak.
8. Jaspersen's segment began exactly 45 minutes after the beekeeper's segment.
9. The crepe chef went on sometime before the person from Sausalito and sometime after Brandon.
10. The hypnotherapist's segment began at 7:15.
 Solution: 6:45, Damien Ivens, Oakland, Beekeeper
7:00, Alice Lautremont, Palo Alto, Antique car collector
7:15, Cathy Morley, Berkeley, Hypnotherapist
7:30, Brandon Jaspersen, Corte Madera, Bungee jumper
7:45, Evan Krieger, Daly City, Crepe Chef
8:00 Francine Novak, Sausalito, Financial Adviser
The hypnotherapist's segment began at 7:15 (10). Jaspersen's segment was in the second half (8). The beekeeper was in the first half, and was either 6:45 or 7:00 (8). Since Krieger was at 7:45 (3), then Jaspersen was at 7:30. This leaves the beekeeper at 6:45 (8). The antique car collector has to be at 7:00 (1).
The financial adviser isn't Jaspersen or Kreiger (7), and is therefore on during the 8:00 segment. Likewise, Morley can't be at 8:00 (7), or in the first two segments (4); thus Morley has to be at 7:15. This puts Alice at 7:00 and Oakland at 6:45 (4). This also puts Ivens at 6:45 and Berkeley at 7:15 (1).
The two guests in the 6:45 and 7:15 segments are neither Novak, from Daly City or Palo Alto, or interested in bungee jumping. Therefore, these guests must be Cathy and Damien (6). Therefore, Brandon is at 7:30, the chef at 7:45, and the guest from Sausalito at 8:00 (9). The bungee jumper, who must be at 7:30, cannot be from Daly City or Palo Alto, and so is from Corte Madera (6). Alice must be from either Daly City or Palo Alto, so cannot have a last name of Novak (6).
Therefore, Lautremont is in the 7:00 time slot and Novak is the 8:00 time slot. Damien was at 6:45 (2), leaving Cathy at 7:15.
Since Cathy is from Berkeley, Alice cannot be from Daly City (5), and is therefore from Palo Alto. Likewise, Kreiger, who must be from Daly City, cannot be Francine, and must be named Evan. This leaves Francine at 8:00.
Hint: Females are Alice, Cathy and Francine; males are Brandon, Damien and Evan.
Human Solution:
6:45, Damien Ivens, Oakland, Beekeeper
7:00, Alice Lautremont, Palo Alto, Antique car collector
7:15, Cathy Morley, Berkeley, Hypnotherapist
7:30, Brandon Jaspersen, Corte Madera, Bungee jumper
7:45, Evan Krieger, Daly City, Crepe Chef
8:00 Francine Novak, Sausalito, Financial Adviser
The hypnotherapist's segment began at 7:15 (10). Jaspersen's segment was in the second half (8). The beekeeper was in the first half, and was either 6:45 or 7:00 (8). Since Krieger was at 7:45 (3), then Jaspersen was at 7:30. This leaves the beekeeper at 6:45 (8). The antique car collector has to be at 7:00 (1).
The financial adviser isn't Jaspersen or Kreiger (7), and is therefore on during the 8:00 segment. Likewise, Morley can't be at 8:00 (7), or in the first two segments (4); thus Morley has to be at 7:15. This puts Alice at 7:00 and Oakland at 6:45 (4). This also puts Ivens at 6:45 and Berkeley at 7:15 (1).
The two guests in the 6:45 and 7:15 segments are neither Novak, from Daly City or Palo Alto, or interested in bungee jumping. Therefore, these guests must be Cathy and Damien (6). Therefore, Brandon is at 7:30, the chef at 7:45, and the guest from Sausalito at 8:00 (9). The bungee jumper, who must be at 7:30, cannot be from Daly City or Palo Alto, and so is from Corte Madera (6). Alice must be from either Daly City or Palo Alto, so cannot have a last name of Novak (6).
Therefore, Lautremont is in the 7:00 time slot and Novak is the 8:00 time slot. Damien was at 6:45 (2), leaving Cathy at 7:15.
Since Cathy is from Berkeley, Alice cannot be from Daly City (5), and is therefore from Palo Alto. Likewise, Kreiger, who must be from Daly City, cannot be Francine, and must be named Evan. This leaves Francine at 8:00.
Response:
SOLUTION GRID

Time  | First  Last        Town          Interest
---------------------------------------------------------
6:45  | Damien Ivens       Oakland       Beekeeper
7:00  | Alice  Lautremont  Palo Alto     Antique-car collector
7:15  | Cathy  Morley      Berkeley      Hypnotherapist
7:30  | Brandon Jaspersen  Corte Madera  Bungee-jumper
7:45  | Evan   Krieger     Daly City     Crêpe-chef
8:00  | Francine Novak     Sausalito     Financial adviser


STEP-BY-STEP REASONING

1. 7:15 is the hypnotherapist’s slot (clue 10).

2. Krieger goes on at 7:45 (clue 3).

3. Jaspersen appears exactly 45 min after the beekeeper (clue 8); therefore one is in the 6:45–7:00 pair and the other in the 7:30–7:45 pair.  
   Since 7:45 is already Krieger, Jaspersen must be 7:30 and the beekeeper 6:45.

4. The first three guests (6:45, 7:00, 7:15) are Ivens, the Berkeley resident, and the antique-car collector (clue 1).  
   We already have the beekeeper at 6:45, so the antique-car collector must be 7:00.

5. The crepe chef works before the Sausalito guest and after Brandon (clue 9).  
   Brandon is now fixed at 7:30, so the chef must be 7:45 and Sausalito must be 8:00.

6. The list in clue 6 tells us the six “special items” still to place are Cathy, Damien, Novak, Daly City, Palo Alto and the bungee jumper.  
   Because 6:45 and 7:15 are already half-filled (beekeeper / hypnotherapist) they cannot take any of those six “missing” designations except first names.  
   Hence 6:45 and 7:15 must be Damien and Cathy (order unknown so far), and none of those two slots can be Novak, Daly City, Palo Alto or bungee jumping.

7. Therefore the bungee jumper is 7:30 (only remaining open interest).  
   Daly City and Palo Alto are at 7:45 and 7:00 in some order, and Novak must be 8:00.

8. The financial adviser’s surname is Novak or Lautremont (clue 7).  
   Because Novak is now 8:00, the financial adviser must be 8:00.

9. Lautremont therefore is not the financial adviser, so Lautremont is 7:00 together with the antique-car collector.

10. Alice is after Oakland and before Morley (clue 4).  
    Putting Lautremont at 7:00 makes Alice be that 7:00 guest, forcing Oakland to 6:45 and Morley to 7:15.

11. The three earliest slots were Ivens, Berkeley, antique-car collector (clue 1).  
    We now have antique-car collector (Alice) at 7:00 and Berkeley at 7:15, so the remaining name, Ivens, is 6:45.

12. Berkeley (7:15) and Daly City are not the same sex (clue 5).  
    Because Berkeley is Cathy (a woman), Daly City must be male; the only male left in the Daly City slot (7:45) is Evan.  
    That fixes Krieger as Evan, and confirms Daly City at 7:45.

13. The only remaining unassigned full name is Francine Novak for 8:00, completing the table.

All clues are now satisfied; therefore the arrangement shown above is uniquely correct.

Question:
Question: Three sportsmen, Tom, Jim and Sam, are standing in a row, and we can see their backs. Each of them wears a suit, which are red, yellow and blue in no particular order. Each suit has a different number, between 2 and 9, inclusive. Clues are:
1. In the order they stand, the three numbers form a perfect square.
2. Tom's number is smaller than the rightmost sportsman's number.
3. The yellow suit's number is odd.
4. The factorial of Sam's number, plus one, is divisible by the red suit's number.
 Solution: Left: Tom, yellow, 5;
Middle: Jim, red, 7;
Right: Sam, blue, 6.
From clue 4, the red suit's number must be greater than Sam's number, and must be odd. By trial and error, the possible combinations are (3,2), (5,4), (7,3), (7,6).
From clue 1, the square can only be 324 or 576, where 3 or 7 is the red suit's number.
From clue 3, the square must be 576, and 5 is the yellow suit's number and 6 the blue one.
From clue 2, Tom must be the 5 and Jim the 7.
Hint: One of the clues is very important.
Human Solution:
Left: Tom, yellow, 5;
Middle: Jim, red, 7;
Right: Sam, blue, 6.
From clue 4, the red suit's number must be greater than Sam's number, and must be odd. By trial and error, the possible combinations are (3,2), (5,4), (7,3), (7,6).
From clue 1, the square can only be 324 or 576, where 3 or 7 is the red suit's number.
From clue 3, the square must be 576, and 5 is the yellow suit's number and 6 the blue one.
From clue 2, Tom must be the 5 and Jim the 7.
Response:
PROBLEM RECAP  
• Three sportsmen (Tom, Jim, Sam) stand left-to-right.  
• Each wears a different-coloured suit (red, yellow, blue) and a different one-digit number from 2-9.  
• Clues  
  1. The left, middle and right numbers (in that order) form a three-digit perfect square.  
  2. Tom’s number is smaller than the right-hand sportsman’s number.  
  3. The yellow suit’s number is odd.  
  4. (Sam’s number)! + 1 is divisible by the red suit’s number.  

GOAL: Identify who stands where, what colour each wears, and what number each has.

SOLUTION IN SIX SIMPLE STEPS  

1. List all three-digit perfect squares whose individual digits are 2-9 and all different.  
   Squares of 10-31 give: 256, 289, 324, 529, 576, 625, 729, 784.

2. Translate Clue 4 (the “factorial” condition).  
   For digits 2-9, compute (n)! + 1 and look for a divisor that is also 2-9.  
   • 2!+1 = 3  → (2, 3)  
   • 3!+1 = 7  → (3, 7)  
   • 4!+1 = 25 → (4, 5)  
   • 6!+1 = 721→ (6, 7)  
   Valid (Sam, Red) pairs within our range are therefore (2,3), (3,7), (4,5), (6,7).  
   In every pair the red number is odd and larger than Sam’s number.

3. Keep only the squares that contain one of those pairs among their digits.  
   • 324 contains 3 and 2 → could match (2,3).  
   • 576 contains 6 and 7 → could match (6,7).  
   No other listed square contains a valid pair, so the candidates narrow to 324 and 576.

4. Apply Clue 3 (yellow number is odd).  
   Square 324 has only one odd digit, 3, but 3 would have to be red (from step 2).  
   That would leave no odd digit for yellow, so 324 is impossible.  
   Square 576 has two odd digits (5,7); one can be yellow and one red, satisfying the clue.  
   Hence the square must be 576, with digits 5-7-6 (left-middle-right).  
   From step 2 this fixes Red = 7 and Sam = 6, which forces Yellow = 5.  
   Colour/number assignments so far: red 7, yellow 5, blue 6.

5. Use Clue 2 (Tom’s number is smaller than the rightmost number).  
   In 5-7-6 the rightmost number is 6.  
   Only 5 is smaller than 6, so Tom must have the 5 and therefore stands leftmost.

6. Finish the lineup.  
   Left (Tom) is yellow 5.  
   The middle digit is 7, so the middle sportsman (Jim) wears red 7.  
   The right digit is 6, so the right sportsman (Sam) wears blue 6.

FINAL ARRANGEMENT  
Left:  Tom — yellow suit — number 5  
Middle: Jim — red suit — number 7  
Right: Sam — blue suit — number 6

Question:
Question: Fred Farley spent his summers up north in a cottage on Stoney Lake. There, he often debated with his friends what type of bait was best to use for the fish in the waters.  He decided one year to hold a fishing tournament with the best fishers on the lake, each using a different casting lure.  5 men competed (Fred Farley was NOT one of them) and points were awarded in four categories to determine a winner:
Greatest total Weight of fish caught: 4 points
Greatest Number of fish caught: 3 points
Largest Fish: 2 points
Second-largest fish: 1 point
Winning more than one category: 1 bonus point
Two fishermen did not win any of the categories and first place ended up being a tie between two men who received the same amount of points.
From the statements below, determine the first and last name of each of the contestants, what casting lure was used, and who won each category.
1. Mike (who was one of the category winners), Mr. Black (who is not Terry), and the one that used the plastic worm live near each other.
2. Vick, who did not win the total weight category, did not use the spinner bait; nor did Mr. McNess.
3. The one that used the weighted jig, who was not Terry, did not win any of the categories.
4. Neither Sam nor Mr. Larson live near any of the other three contestants, nor did either use a spinner bait or deep-running crank bait.
5. The fisherman who won the largest-fish category, who was not Mr. Smith, used spinner bait.
6. Mr. Jones, who caught the most fish, did not use a deep-running crank bait.
7. Both Mr. McNess (who did not use a deep running crank bait) and Terry (who did not use a plastic worm) had boat trouble and started after the others.
8. A wounded-minnow was used as one of the casting lures, and Kevin was one of the contestants.
 Solution: Kevin Black, spinner bait, largest fish and second largest fish category, bonus for winning two categories, 4 points.
Mike Smith, crank bait, total weight, 4 points
Sam McNess, weighted jig, no category, 0 points
Terry Larson, wounded minnow bait, no category, 0 points
Vick Jones, plastic worm, most fish, 3 points.
From 1: Mike won a category, is not Mr. Black, and did not use the plastic worm.  Mr. Black is not Mike or Terry and did not use the plastic worm.
From 2:  Vick is not Mr. Mc Ness, did not win total weight and did not use the spinner bait. Mr. McNess did not use the spinner bait.
From 3: Terry did not use the weighted jig. The weighted jig won no category.
From 4: Sam is not Larson or Black, and did not use the spinner, deep running crank or plastic worm bait.  Mr. Larson is not Mike, and did not use the spinner, deep running crank or plastic worm bait.
From 5: Mr. Smith did not win the largest fish or use the spinner bait. The largest fish was caught using the spinner bait.
Since Vick and Sam did not use the spinner, they did not win the largest fish category.  Since Mike won a category, he did not use the jig.
From 6: Mr. Jones won the most fish and, therefore, did not use the spinner bait, did not use the deep running crank bait either. Therefore, Black used the spinner and was the largest fish winner. Since Vick did not win the largest fish, by elimination, Kevin is Mr. Black.
From 7: Mr. McNess is not Terry and did not use a deep running crank bait. Therefore, Smith could have only used the crank bait.  Terry did not use a worm. Therefore, Vick used the worm and Sam used the weighted jig (and therefore won no category).
The worm (used by Vick) was thereby only used by either McNess or Jones, and since 2 says Vick is not Mc Ness, Vick is therefore Jones.
Terry, then, is Larson and won no category. Mike then wins the total weight category.
Then by summing up the leftover information, Terry uses the minnow and leaves Mike with the deep-running crank bait. That, in turn, makes Mike's last name Smith. Sam is then McNess.
Hint: Since only 3 of the contestants won the 4 categories, one of them won two and earned a bonus point.  Since there were two first places, the only possible outcome was that they both received 4 points. Therefore, one contestant won the total weight category (4 points), and another won the largest, second largest category and earned a bonus point (2 + 1 + 1 points).
Human Solution:
Kevin Black, spinner bait, largest fish and second largest fish category, bonus for winning two categories, 4 points.
Mike Smith, crank bait, total weight, 4 points
Sam McNess, weighted jig, no category, 0 points
Terry Larson, wounded minnow bait, no category, 0 points
Vick Jones, plastic worm, most fish, 3 points.
From 1: Mike won a category, is not Mr. Black, and did not use the plastic worm.  Mr. Black is not Mike or Terry and did not use the plastic worm.
From 2:  Vick is not Mr. Mc Ness, did not win total weight and did not use the spinner bait. Mr. McNess did not use the spinner bait.
From 3: Terry did not use the weighted jig. The weighted jig won no category.
From 4: Sam is not Larson or Black, and did not use the spinner, deep running crank or plastic worm bait.  Mr. Larson is not Mike, and did not use the spinner, deep running crank or plastic worm bait.
From 5: Mr. Smith did not win the largest fish or use the spinner bait. The largest fish was caught using the spinner bait.
Since Vick and Sam did not use the spinner, they did not win the largest fish category.  Since Mike won a category, he did not use the jig.
From 6: Mr. Jones won the most fish and, therefore, did not use the spinner bait, did not use the deep running crank bait either. Therefore, Black used the spinner and was the largest fish winner. Since Vick did not win the largest fish, by elimination, Kevin is Mr. Black.
From 7: Mr. McNess is not Terry and did not use a deep running crank bait. Therefore, Smith could have only used the crank bait.  Terry did not use a worm. Therefore, Vick used the worm and Sam used the weighted jig (and therefore won no category).
The worm (used by Vick) was thereby only used by either McNess or Jones, and since 2 says Vick is not Mc Ness, Vick is therefore Jones.
Terry, then, is Larson and won no category. Mike then wins the total weight category.
Then by summing up the leftover information, Terry uses the minnow and leaves Mike with the deep-running crank bait. That, in turn, makes Mike's last name Smith. Sam is then McNess.
Response:
SOLUTION SUMMARY  

Final grid  
Mike Smith – deep-running crank bait – greatest total weight (4 pts)  
Kevin Black – spinner bait – largest fish (2 pts) + second-largest fish (1 pt) + bonus (1 pt) = 4 pts  
Vick Jones – plastic worm – greatest number of fish (3 pts)  
Sam McNess – weighted jig – no category (0 pts)  
Terry Larson – wounded-minnow lure – no category (0 pts)  

Both Kevin and Mike finish first with 4 points; the other two men win nothing.  

Reasoning in short, self-contained steps  

1. Categories and people  
   • Four scoring events plus a 1-point bonus for anyone winning more than one event.  
   • Two men tie for first place; two men win nothing.  

2. Neighbours (Stmt 1 & 4)  
   • Three neighbours: Mike, Mr Black, plastic-worm user.  
   • Sam and Mr Larson are NOT neighbours and therefore are not in that trio.  

3. Spinner-bait / largest-fish link (Stmt 5)  
   • Largest-fish winner used the spinner bait and is NOT Mr Smith.  

4. Most-fish link (Stmt 6)  
   • Mr Jones caught the most fish and did NOT use spinner or deep-running crank.  

5. Jig information (Stmt 3)  
   • Weighted-jig user (not Terry) wins no category ⇒ one of the two men with 0 pts.  

6. Eliminate spinner users (Stmt 2)  
   • Vick did NOT use spinner; neither did Mr McNess.  
   • Combine with step 3: largest-fish winner cannot be Vick nor Mr McNess.  

7. Locate spinner-bait fisherman  
   • Trio of neighbours contains Mike, Mr Black and the worm user.  
   • Spinner user isn’t worm user, can’t be Mike (he’s not Mr Black), so must be Mr Black.  
   • Therefore Mr Black wins ‘largest fish’ (+ maybe more).  

8. Identify Mr Black’s first name  
   • Kevin is the only as-yet-unused first name in the neighbour trio; therefore Kevin Black is spinner user and largest-fish winner.  

9. Place ‘most-fish’ winner  
   • Mr Jones is still unknown; Vick is only remaining first name not yet locked to a surname.  
   • Hence Vick Jones used the plastic worm and won ‘most fish’.  

10. Place the jig & 0-point fisherman  
    • Jig user wins nothing (step 5) and is NOT Terry.  
    • Candidates: Mike, Sam. But Mike already wins something (because tie for first requires him to score), so jig user must be Sam.  
    • Sam’s surname must therefore be McNess (the only remaining unused surname that is NOT Mike’s or Kevin’s or Vick’s).  
    • Jog with Stmt 2: Mr McNess does not use spinner – OK.  

11. Assign remaining surname and lure to Mike & Terry  
    • Remaining surnames: Smith, Larson.  
    • Sam is McNess; Kevin is Black; Vick is Jones.  
    • Terry cannot be Mr Black or Mr Jones or Mr McNess ⇒ Terry Larson.  
    • Mike therefore is Mr Smith.  
    • Terry did not use plastic worm (Stmt 7) and cannot use spinner or crank (Stmt 4). Only lure left fitting Terry is wounded-minnow.  
    • Lures left for Mike: deep-running crank bait.  

12. Allocate last category points  
    • Categories remaining unassigned: greatest total weight (4 pts) and second-largest fish (1 pt).  
    • Spinner holder Kevin already has largest fish; second-largest either goes to Kevin (giving him 3 + bonus = 4) or to someone else.  
    • To create the required 4-pt tie for first, give second-largest to Kevin (now 2 + 1 + 1 bonus = 4).  
    • That leaves 4-point “total weight” for Mike Smith, giving him exactly 4 pts too.  

13. Check every original statement – all conditions satisfied (no contradictions).  

Hence the table in the Solution Summary is the only arrangement consistent with all clues.

Question:
Question: Long ago, back before serious illness existed and the new inventions of today, there lived the Handy People. Their height was measured in hands, and they lived long lives.  From the statements below identify each of the 5 Handy people's height (12, 13, 14, 15 and 16 hands) and their ages (100, 110, 120, 130 and 140 years).
TWIST: One statement is FALSE.
1. Har was not the oldest, nor was he the shortest or tallest.
2. Winn was taller than Edvo, who was taller but younger than Frer.
3. Tolo, who was not the second oldest, was older than Har, and shorter than Frer.
4. The one who was 13 hands tall was the oldest.
5. Har was taller and older than Winn and Tolo.
6. The fourth oldest was taller than Tolo, but shorter than Edvo, who was older than Winn.
 Solution: Edvo, 15 hands, 130 years
Frer, 13 hands, 140 years
Har, 14 hands, 110 years
Tolo, 12 hands, 120 years
Winn, 16 hands, 100 years
When going through all the statements, it is impossible that both 3 and 5 be true. (3 says Tolo is older than Har while 5 says Har is older than Tolo.) 2 gives the order of height as Winn, Edvo, and Frer. If 5 is true, then Har must be the tallest, but this contradicts 1, therefore 5 is false.
From 1, 2 and 3 it can be seen that the order of height is Winn, Edvo, Frer, and Tolo - with Har somewhere in between but not the shortest or tallest. Therefore Winn is 16 hands, and Tolo is 12.
Since Har is not the oldest, he is not 13 hands, which makes Frer 13 hands and the oldest.
From 3 and 6, Tolo is not the 2nd or 4th oldest and is not the youngest. Therefore he becomes 120 years. Also from 6, Edvo is not the 4th oldest or youngest. Therefore he is 130 years.
Since the 4th oldest is shorter than Edvo, Har must be it at 110 years. And Winn is the youngest. Since the 4th oldest was shorter than Edvo, Har is 14 hands and Edvo is 15 hands.
Hint: it is impossible that both 3 and 5 be true
Human Solution:
Edvo, 15 hands, 130 years
Frer, 13 hands, 140 years
Har, 14 hands, 110 years
Tolo, 12 hands, 120 years
Winn, 16 hands, 100 years
When going through all the statements, it is impossible that both 3 and 5 be true. (3 says Tolo is older than Har while 5 says Har is older than Tolo.) 2 gives the order of height as Winn, Edvo, and Frer. If 5 is true, then Har must be the tallest, but this contradicts 1, therefore 5 is false.
From 1, 2 and 3 it can be seen that the order of height is Winn, Edvo, Frer, and Tolo - with Har somewhere in between but not the shortest or tallest. Therefore Winn is 16 hands, and Tolo is 12.
Since Har is not the oldest, he is not 13 hands, which makes Frer 13 hands and the oldest.
From 3 and 6, Tolo is not the 2nd or 4th oldest and is not the youngest. Therefore he becomes 120 years. Also from 6, Edvo is not the 4th oldest or youngest. Therefore he is 130 years.
Since the 4th oldest is shorter than Edvo, Har must be it at 110 years. And Winn is the youngest. Since the 4th oldest was shorter than Edvo, Har is 14 hands and Edvo is 15 hands.
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning (one statement is false):

1. Look for the contradiction.  
   • Statement 3 says Tolo is older than Har.  
   • Statement 5 says Har is older than Tolo.  
   Both cannot be true, so exactly one of them is the false statement.

2. Test the case “Statement 5 is true.”  
   From (2) the height order is Winn > Edvo > Frer.  
   If 5 were true, Har would have to be both taller and older than Winn; that would make him the tallest, contradicting statement 1 (“Har was not … the tallest”).  
   Hence Statement 5 cannot be true; Statement 5 is the single FALSE statement and Statement 3 is true.

3. Fix the relative heights.  
   – From (2):   Winn  >  Edvo  >  Frer.  
   – From (3):   Frer  >  Tolo.  
   → Combined descending order: Winn, Edvo, Frer, Tolo, with Har still to be fitted.  
   – Statement 1 says Har is neither tallest nor shortest, so Har’s height must fall between Edvo and Frer.  
   Therefore the five distinct heights are assigned (largest to smallest):  
   Winn 16, Edvo 15, Har 14, Frer 13, Tolo 12.

4. Identify the oldest person.  
   Statement 4: “The one who was 13 hands tall was the oldest.”  
   Frer is the only 13-hand person, so Frer is 140 years old (oldest).

5. Place Tolo in the age list.  
   Statement 3 adds: Tolo is “not the second oldest,” is older than Har, and we already know he is younger than Frer.  
   Possible ages now (old → young): 140, 130, 120, 110, 100.  
   Tolo cannot be 140 (Frer) or 130 (second oldest) and must be older than Har, so Tolo = 120 years.

6. Use the 4th-oldest clue.  
   Statement 6: “The fourth oldest was taller than Tolo, but shorter than Edvo, who was older than Winn.”  
   • Fourth oldest age = 110.  
   • Only Har’s height (14) lies between Tolo’s 12 and Edvo’s 15.  
   → Har = 110 years (4th oldest).  
   → Winn, therefore, is the youngest at 100 years.  
   • Edvo must then be the remaining unassigned age 130 years, and (as required) is older than Winn.

7. Summary of assignments (consistent with every true statement; only statement 5 is false):

   Edvo … 15 hands, 130 years  
   Frer … 13 hands, 140 years  
   Har  … 14 hands, 110 years  
   Tolo … 12 hands, 120 years  
   Winn … 16 hands, 100 years

Question:
Question: You have four kiddies' building blocks with a different letter on each side. You notice that by rearranging the blocks several times, the following list of words can be formed:
pink
jest
rope
quip
goal
cony
frog
dark
site
glum
wack
have
tiny
wish
bins
What letters appear on each block?
 Solution: Block 1: p, a, f, m, y, s
Block 2: i, r, l, c, v, j
Block 3: n, e, d, g, q, w
Block 4: k, o, u, t, h, b
Hint: The letters n and e are on the same block.
Human Solution:
Block 1: p, a, f, m, y, s
Block 2: i, r, l, c, v, j
Block 3: n, e, d, g, q, w
Block 4: k, o, u, t, h, b
Response:
SOLUTION OUTLINE (step-by-step)

1.  Collect all letters that appear in the fifteen 4-letter words.
    There are exactly 24 distinct letters – perfect for 4 cubes × 6 faces.

2.  Turn every word into four “can’t-share-a-cube” pairs.
    Example: in PINK no two of P, I, N, K may live on the same cube.  
    Do this for every word; each gives six such pairs.

3.  See the problem as 4-coloring a graph.
    •  Vertices = the 24 letters.  
    •  Edge between two letters ⇔ they appear together in at least one word.  
    •  A valid 4-coloring puts letters joined by an edge on different colors; each color is one cube.

4.  Work through the high-degree letters first.
    K occurs with P,I,N, …, so K must differ from all of them, quickly fixing its color.
    Keep propagating: once a letter is forced onto a cube, every letter it touches is banned from that cube.

5.  The constraints tighten until only one placement remains that obeys every edge.
    The unique 4-coloring is

       Cube 1 :  p  a  f  m  y  s  
       Cube 2 :  i  r  l  c  v  j  
       Cube 3 :  n  e  d  g  q  w  
       Cube 4 :  k  o  u  t  h  b

6.  Verification.  Check each of the 15 words:
    pick one letter from each cube – always possible with this arrangement, so all words are formable.

Hence the four kiddie blocks carry the letters exactly as listed above.

Question:
Question: Which is the odd one out?
Die
Day
Gee
Gun
Scale
 Solution: Gun is.
A die, when two opposite side's values are added, makes seven.
There are seven days in a week.
Gee (G) is the seventh letter in the alphabet.
There are 7 different notes in a musical scale. (Excluding the repeated letter)
Gun is the odd man out.
Hint: Think about how these words all relate to a number
Human Solution:
Gun is.
A die, when two opposite side's values are added, makes seven.
There are seven days in a week.
Gee (G) is the seventh letter in the alphabet.
There are 7 different notes in a musical scale. (Excluding the repeated letter)
Gun is the odd man out.
Response:
Solution Summary – identifying the odd word

Step 1 – List the five candidates  
Die, Day, Gee, Gun, Scale

Step 2 – Look for a shared property among (at least) four of them  
Try obvious common themes (size, spelling, meaning, sound, etc.).  
Notice that “seven” can be linked to most of the words.

Step 3 – Verify the “seven” connection word-by-word  
• Die – on a standard die, the pips on opposite faces add to 7.  
• Day – there are 7 days in one week.  
• Gee – the letter G is the 7th letter of the English alphabet.  
• Scale – a normal diatonic musical scale (do–re–mi–fa–so–la–ti) has 7 distinct notes before the octave repeats.

Step 4 – Test the remaining word (Gun) against the same property  
“Gun” has no routine, intrinsic link to the number 7 (a gun can have any number of chambers or rounds, but nothing obligatorily “seven” about it).

Step 5 – Decide the odd one out  
Four words have a clear, built-in association with the number seven; “Gun” does not.  
Therefore Gun is the odd one out.

Question:
Question: You are part of a group of 500 people who have been captured by an evil tribe. The tribe leader, who appreciates a person with good logic, decides that he will propose a challenge of many headband problems.
The first challenge is that each person will get a random headband of one of two colors, black or white. There are 500 of each (500 black and 500 white). If you look at yours or say a word after you have been given your headband and before you have guessed, the evil people will kill everybody. Also, if you make any movement with your body other than your eyes, you will ALL die.
At the count of 10, each person will shout out what color they think their headband is. If you or anyone else is right, you will survive for the next challenge.  If not, you will be killed immediately. You are given some time to discuss your strategy; then you are given your headbands.
How many survivors can you guarantee, assuming the tribe leader is not lying and that each person will follow your instructions? For example, if you tell everybody to guess, you can guarantee zero survivors because you have a slight chance of getting zero survivors.
 Solution: You can guarantee that 1/2 of the people will survive.
What to do?  Partner everybody up and tell one person to guess the same color as the other person's headband, and the other person to guess the color of the headband that they see.
For example if Person #1 guesses the same and Person #2 guesses opposite...
Person #1=Black  Person #2=Black  Person #1 Survives
Person #1= White Person #2=White  Person #1 Survives
Person #1=Black  Person #2=White  Person #2 Survives
Person #1=White Person #2=Black   Person #2 Survives
Note: You cannot tell person #1 to guess the same color as the second person's hat and then the second person to guess that color, because everybody has to guess at the same time.
Hint: You can guarantee a lot less than you think...
Human Solution:
You can guarantee that 1/2 of the people will survive.
What to do?  Partner everybody up and tell one person to guess the same color as the other person's headband, and the other person to guess the color of the headband that they see.
For example if Person #1 guesses the same and Person #2 guesses opposite...
Person #1=Black  Person #2=Black  Person #1 Survives
Person #1= White Person #2=White  Person #1 Survives
Person #1=Black  Person #2=White  Person #2 Survives
Person #1=White Person #2=Black   Person #2 Survives
Note: You cannot tell person #1 to guess the same color as the second person's hat and then the second person to guess that color, because everybody has to guess at the same time.
Response:
Solution summary – guaranteed number of survivors: 250 (one-half of the group).  
The strategy is optimal; no method can ensure more than 250 survivors.

Reasoning broken into simple, logically connected steps

1. What “guarantee’’ means  
   • A number K is guaranteed if, for every possible assignment of black/white headbands, at least K people must answer correctly.  
   • We want the largest K.

2. Upper bound: why you can never guarantee more than 250  
   a) Any strategy is fixed before the colors are revealed, so each player’s spoken guess depends only on what he sees, not on his own unknown color.  
   b) Consider one particular coloring C of the 500 headbands and its complement ¬C (all colors flipped).  
   c) Every player makes the same spoken guess in C and in ¬C (he sees exactly the opposite colors but still follows the same rule).  
   d) Therefore each individual can be correct in at most one of the two colorings. Summing over all 500 players, the total number of correct guesses in C plus the total in ¬C is ≤ 500.  
   e) Hence at least one of the two colorings has ≤ 250 correct guesses. So no strategy can force more than 250 always-correct people.  
   ⇒ 250 is the absolute maximum that can ever be guaranteed.

3. Construction that actually guarantees 250 survivors  
   a) Before the game starts, pair the 500 people arbitrarily into 250 ordered pairs (A,B).  
   b) Give each pair the following fixed roles:  
      • Player A (the “Same’’ player) will call out the color he sees on B.  
      • Player B (the “Opposite’’ player) will call out the opposite of the color he sees on A.  
   c) When the headbands are in place and the count reaches ten, all players shout simultaneously according to their roles.

4. Why this strategy works  
   For any pair there are four possible color combinations:  
      – AA: (B,B)  → Same says B (correct), Opposite says W (wrong).  
      – BB: (W,W)  → Same says W (correct), Opposite says B (wrong).  
      – AB: (B,W)  → Same says W (wrong), Opposite says B (correct).  
      – BA: (W,B)  → Same says B (wrong), Opposite says W (correct).  
   In every case exactly one member of the pair is correct.  
   Because there are 250 independent pairs, the total number of guaranteed correct guesses is 250.

5. Conclusion  
   • The pairing strategy ensures at least one survivor per pair, i.e., at least 250 survivors in total.  
   • Step 2 proved that no strategy can do better, so the guarantee of 250 is optimal.

Question:
Question: Captain John has escaped his home town onto his ship, the "Wasp", and now Captain John sits in his cabin reading his map. Standing up, he walks out the door into the middle of the deck and announces "we have made it this far, but next we need to find both shipwrecks in the right order to point us the right way, towards the island", followed by tons of "ehs".
There are reefs in the ocean and if Captain John passes over one, his ship sinks and he and his crew die.
With what Captain John knows about the sea, can you figure out where the nine things in a 3-by-3 grid(Wasp, sunken ship 1, sunken ship 2, 2 oceans, 3 reefs, and the island) and go in the right path to the first sunken ship, the second, then the island, without passing over a reef.
The ship can move 1 space horizontally, vertically, or diagonally, and it can only pass each space once.
1. The Wasp is in the same row or column as both sunken ships.
2. There are at least two reefs to the right of sunken ship 2, but the ship isn't in the same row as either of the reefs.
3. One of the oceans is diagonal to only two reefs.
4. The columns and rows of the Wasp and island together take up every single space except the 2nd row of the 3rd column.
5. The island is between two reefs.
6. One of the reefs is somewhere above the other two reefs.
 Solution: The 9 things in the grid go as followed.
Wasp l sunken ship 2 l sunken ship 1
ocean l ocean l reef
reef l island l reef
This is the order of where he needs to go (1-6, X's meaning reefs)
1 l 4 l 3
5 l 2 l X
X l 6 l X
Hint: The middle column has no reefs
Human Solution:
The 9 things in the grid go as followed.
Wasp l sunken ship 2 l sunken ship 1
ocean l ocean l reef
reef l island l reef
This is the order of where he needs to go (1-6, X's meaning reefs)
1 l 4 l 3
5 l 2 l X
X l 6 l X
Response:
SOLUTION IN SHORT

Final 3 × 3 map  
(row 1 is the top row, column 1 the left column)

row 1:   Wasp    Sunken-Ship 2  Sunken-Ship 1  
row 2:   Ocean  Ocean     Reef  
row 3:   Reef    Island      Reef  

Safe route (each move one square horizontally, vertically, or diagonally; no square reused)

 1  4  3  
 5  2  X  
 X  6  X  

(1 = Wasp, 3 = Ship 1, 4 = Ship 2, 6 = Island, X = reef)

DEDUCTION STEP-BY-STEP

1.  “The columns and rows of the Wasp and the island together take up every single space except the 2nd row of the 3rd column.”  
   • Only one square may lie outside the union of those two rows/columns – that must be square (2, 3).  
   • A 3 × 3 board that leaves (2, 3) uncovered forces the Wasp to (1, 1) and the Island to (3, 2) (or vice-versa).  
     Choosing Wasp = (1, 1), Island = (3, 2).

2.  “The island is between two reefs.”  
   • With the island at (3, 2), the only way to sandwich it is to put reefs at (3, 1) and (3, 3).

3.  “One of the reefs is somewhere above the other two reefs.”  
   • A third reef is therefore placed above the pair, i.e. at (2, 3).

4.  “There are at least two reefs to the right of Sunken-Ship 2, but that ship isn’t in the same row as either reef.”  
   • The reefs to the right are the two that now occupy column 3.  
   • To avoid their rows, Sunken-Ship 2 must sit in row 1, column 2 ⇒ (1, 2).

5.  “The Wasp is in the same row or column as both sunken ships.”  
   • Wasp is already in (1, 1).  
   • Sunken-Ship 2 is in the same row.  
   • The remaining square in that row, (1, 3), must therefore hold Sunken-Ship 1.

6.  Only squares (2, 1) and (2, 2) are empty; they become the two Oceans.  
   • Check clue 3: “One of the oceans is diagonal to only two reefs.”  
     Ocean at (2, 2) is diagonal to the two reefs in (3, 1) and (3, 3) but not to the reef in (2, 3) – condition satisfied.

Everything is now placed and all six clues are met.

7.  Construct a reef-free, non-repeating path Wasp → Ship 1 → Ship 2 → Island:  
   (1, 1)  →  (2, 2)  →  (1, 3)  →  (1, 2)  →  (2, 1)  →  (3, 2)

   Written in the grid as move numbers:

   1 4 3  
   5 2 X  
   X 6 X  

This completes the puzzle—Captain John can safely visit the two wrecks in order and reach the island without ever touching a reef or revisiting a square.

Question:
Question: You are blindfolded before a table. On the table are a very large number of pennies. You are told 128 of the pennies are heads up and the rest are tails up. How can you create two subgroups of pennies, each with the same number of heads facing up, while remaining blindfolded?
 Solution: Create a subgroup of any 128 pennies. Then flip over all 128. That group of 128 and the group of all the remaining pennies will have the same number of heads facing up.
This works because the "tails" that you grab while making your subset of 128 will equal the "heads" that are left in the original pile.  Once you flip your 128 coins over, these "tails" will turn into "heads" and the two groups will have a matching number of heads-up coins.
Hint: You can flip some subgroup of the pennies!
Human Solution:
Create a subgroup of any 128 pennies. Then flip over all 128. That group of 128 and the group of all the remaining pennies will have the same number of heads facing up.
This works because the "tails" that you grab while making your subset of 128 will equal the "heads" that are left in the original pile.  Once you flip your 128 coins over, these "tails" will turn into "heads" and the two groups will have a matching number of heads-up coins.
Response:
Summary of the method  
1. While blindfolded, separate any 128 coins from the table to form the first pile.  
2. Leave all of the remaining coins (however many there are) as the second pile.  
3. Flip every coin in the 128-coin pile over once.  
4. When you finish, each pile now contains the same number of heads-up coins.

Why the method works, step-by-step  
1. Let H be the unknown number of heads that happened to be among the 128 coins you grabbed.  
2. Because the whole table originally had 128 heads, the other pile (the coins you did not take) must now contain 128 – H heads.  
3. You flip every coin in the 128-coin pile.  
   • Each of the H heads in that pile becomes a tail.  
   • Each of the 128 – H tails in that pile becomes a head.  
   • Therefore the flipped pile ends with 128 – H heads.  
4. The untouched pile already had 128 – H heads, so both piles now have exactly the same number of heads.

Question:
Question: Mr. Simkin, the new math teacher at school, was impressed by his students' ability to solve logic puzzles. He pulled aside three more students, and handed them each a sealed envelope with a number written inside. He told them that they each have a positive integer, and the sum of their numbers was 14.
Manny, Moe, and Jack each opened their envelopes. Mr. Simkin asks Manny if he knows anything about the numbers the other two are holding, and Manny says, "I know that Moe and Jack are holding different numbers."
Moe answers, "IN THAT CASE, I know that all three of our numbers are different."
Jack thinks for a bit, and then says, "Now I know all of our numbers."
Mr. Simkin turns to the class and asks if anyone in the class knows the numbers. Gretchen's hand shoots up into the air, and after waiting for a while to see if anyone else will get the answer, Mr. Simkin calls on Gretchen.
What numbers does she say they each are holding?
 Solution: Manny has a 3, Moe has a 2, and Jack has a 9.
From Manny's statement, we can deduce that his number is odd. Since Moe did not know that they were all different until Manny said that, we know that Moe is not holding a 7, 9, or 11. (Otherwise, he would have already known they were all different.) If he were holding a 1, 3, or 5, he would not be able to be sure his number was different than Manny's. If he were holding a 4, 8, or 12, he could not know that Manny and Jack didn't have the same number, since there are odd pairs that would bring the total to 14. Therefore, Moe must be holding a 2, 6, or 10.
There are 12 triples for (Manny, Moe, Jack) that satisfy all three statements. They are:
(1, 2, 11)
(1, 6, 7)
(1, 10, 3)
(3, 2, 9)
(3, 6, 5)
(3, 10, 1)
(5, 2, 7)
(5, 6, 3)
(7, 2, 5)
(7, 6, 1)
(9, 2, 3)
(11, 2, 1)
Since Jack can reason flawlessly, he knows these are the possibilities. In order to make his statement, his number has to be a unique solution. Therefore, he must be holding a 9 or an 11. If he were holding 11, though, he would have known from Manny's statement that Manny had a 1, Moe had a 2, and he had an 11. Since he didn't know them all until after Moe spoke, he must have a 9, leaving Manny a 3 and Moe a 2.
Mr. Simkin suggests to Gretchen that she may have a career in law enforcement if she can further hone these impressive deductive reasoning skills.
Hint: Do casework on what Moe can have.
Human Solution:
Manny has a 3, Moe has a 2, and Jack has a 9.
From Manny's statement, we can deduce that his number is odd. Since Moe did not know that they were all different until Manny said that, we know that Moe is not holding a 7, 9, or 11. (Otherwise, he would have already known they were all different.) If he were holding a 1, 3, or 5, he would not be able to be sure his number was different than Manny's. If he were holding a 4, 8, or 12, he could not know that Manny and Jack didn't have the same number, since there are odd pairs that would bring the total to 14. Therefore, Moe must be holding a 2, 6, or 10.
There are 12 triples for (Manny, Moe, Jack) that satisfy all three statements. They are:
(1, 2, 11)
(1, 6, 7)
(1, 10, 3)
(3, 2, 9)
(3, 6, 5)
(3, 10, 1)
(5, 2, 7)
(5, 6, 3)
(7, 2, 5)
(7, 6, 1)
(9, 2, 3)
(11, 2, 1)
Since Jack can reason flawlessly, he knows these are the possibilities. In order to make his statement, his number has to be a unique solution. Therefore, he must be holding a 9 or an 11. If he were holding 11, though, he would have known from Manny's statement that Manny had a 1, Moe had a 2, and he had an 11. Since he didn't know them all until after Moe spoke, he must have a 9, leaving Manny a 3 and Moe a 2.
Mr. Simkin suggests to Gretchen that she may have a career in law enforcement if she can further hone these impressive deductive reasoning skills.
Response:
Answer: Manny = 3,  Moe = 2,  Jack = 9.

Reasoning in short, self-contained steps  

1.  Manny’s claim (“I know Moe and Jack have different numbers.”) can be true only if the remainder 14 – m is odd; otherwise Manny would have to allow the possibility Moe = Jack = (14 – m)/2.  
    → Manny’s number m is odd.

2.  Now everyone knows m ∈ {1,3,5,7,9,11,13}.  
    Moe looks at his own number q.  
    • If q were 7, 9, 11 he would already have known all three numbers were distinct even before Manny spoke (because 14 – q is odd and < 7, so no repetition is possible).  
    • If q were 1, 3, 5 he still could not be sure his number differed from Manny’s (m might equal q).  
    • If q were 4, 8, 12 he still could not rule out that Manny and Jack shared some other odd number summing correctly.  
    → The only values that let Moe draw his new conclusion are q = 2, 6, 10.

3.  List every triple (m,q,r) with m odd, q ∈ {2,6,10}, r = 14 – m – q, all positive:  
    (1,2,11) (1,6,7) (1,10,3) (3,2,9) (3,6,5) (3,10,1) (5,2,7) (5,6,3) (7,2,5) (7,6,1) (9,2,3) (11,2,1).

4.  Jack knows his own number r.  To identify the whole triple he must see a value that appears in only one row of this list.  
    Among the r-values the only unique ones are 9 and 11; therefore Jack holds 9 or 11.

5.  If Jack held 11, the only possible triple would be (1,2,11); he would already have known that immediately after Manny spoke, contrary to the story (he needed Moe’s comment as well).  
    → Jack holds 9.

6.  The single triple containing r = 9 is (3,2,9).  
    Hence Manny has 3, Moe has 2, Jack has 9—exactly what Gretchen reports.

Question:
Question: Four men and four women are in Love Island. Each one falls in love with another and is himself/herself loved by someone else in a complete 8 person loop.
Peter falls in love with a girl who is unfortunately in love with Albert. Joseph loves a girl who loves the man who loves Elaine. Liza is loved by the guy who is loved by the girl who is loved by Paolo. Linda hates Paolo and is hated by the man whom Amy loves.
No guy/guy or girl/girl in Love Island.
Who loves Joseph and whom does Joseph love?
 Solution: Linda loves Joseph, and Joseph loves Amy.
An 8 person loop may be represented as follows:
M1 > G1 > M2 > G2 > M3 > G3 > M4 > G4 >
From second paragraph:
Line 1: Peter > G > Albert > G >
Line 2: Joseph > G > M > Elaine >
Line 3: Paolo > G > M > Liza >
Line 4: Linda hates Paolo and is hated by the man Amy loves.
Step One: Assume Peter is M1. (Peter can be M2 or M3 or M4 with the same result.)
Peter > G1 > Albert > G2 > M3 > G3 > M4 > G4 >
Step Two: Elaine is two persons removed from Joseph (from Line 2) so either:
#A Peter > G1 > Albert > G2 > Joseph > G3 > M4 > Elaine >
#B Peter > Elaine > Albert > G2 > M3 > G3 > Joseph > G4 >
Step Three: In each case, the unknown male must be Paolo.
#A Peter > G1 > Albert > G2 > Joseph > G3 > Paolo > Elaine >
#B Peter > Elaine > Albert > G2 > Paolo > G3 > Joseph > G4 >
Step Four: Liza is two persons removed from Paolo (from Line 3).
#A Peter > Liza > Albert > G2 > Joseph > G3 > Paolo > Elaine >
#B Peter > Elaine > Albert > G2 > Paolo > G3 > Joseph > Liza >
Step Five: Linda hates Paolo (from Line 4), so:
In #A, she can't be G3 and must be G2.
In #B, she can't be G2 and must be G3.
#A Peter > Liza > Albert > Linda > Joseph > G3 > Paolo > Elaine >
#B Peter > Elaine > Albert > G2 > Paolo > Linda > Joseph > Liza >
Step Six: In each case, the unknown female must be Amy.
#A Peter > Liza > Albert > Linda > Joseph > Amy > Paolo > Elaine >
