Totaling 10 people in all (Alex, David, Jamie, Jessica, John, Justin, Lincoln, Martha, Mary and Tina).
1.  One of Jamie's ancestors was David.
2.  John's sister gave birth to Tina.
3.  Mary went bowling with her nephew last Saturday.
4.  Alex is cousins with one of the girls.
5.  Justin married Mary.
6.  Jessica is not an ancestor, nor cousin of Tina.
7. Lincoln's brother showed Justin's son his baseball cards.
 Solution: Martha and David were the grandparents.
They gave birth to John and Mary.
John married Jessica, who gave birth to Lincoln and Alex.
Mary married Justin and gave birth to Tina and Jamie.
Human Solution:
Martha and David were the grandparents.
They gave birth to John and Mary.
John married Jessica, who gave birth to Lincoln and Alex.
Mary married Justin and gave birth to Tina and Jamie.
Response:
SUMMARY OF THE FAMILY TREE  
Grandparents: David (husband) and Martha (wife)  
Their children: John (son) and Mary (daughter)  
John’s family: John married Jessica; their children are Lincoln and Alex  
Mary’s family: Mary married Justin; their children are Tina and Jamie  

STEP–BY–STEP REASONING  

1. Fix the basic structure  
   • 2 grandparents → 2 children → each child marries → each couple has 2 children (total 10 people).

2. Use the explicit marriage clue  
   • Clue 5: “Justin married Mary.”  
     ⇒ Mary is one of the grandparents’ two children; Justin is her spouse.

3. Determine Mary’s sibling and Tina’s mother  
   • Clue 2: “John’s sister gave birth to Tina.”  
     ⇒ John and Mary must be the two siblings, and Mary (John’s sister) is Tina’s mother.  
     ⇒ John is the second child of the grandparents.

4. Place Justin and Tina in Mary’s sub-family  
   • From steps 2 & 3: Mary + Justin are parents of Tina.

5. Identify Mary’s nephew and John’s children  
   • Clue 3: “Mary went bowling with her nephew.”  
     ⇒ John must have at least one son (Mary’s nephew).

6. Decide who marries John  
   • Remaining adult women: Jessica and Martha.  
   • Martha must be a grandparent’s name (only female left for that role in step 1).  
   • Therefore Jessica is John’s wife.  
   • Clue 6 confirms consistency: “Jessica is not an ancestor nor cousin of Tina.” As John’s wife, Jessica is Tina’s aunt, not ancestor/cousin—clue satisfied.

7. Fix the grandparents’ names  
   • Adults not yet placed as grandparents: David and Martha.  
   • Clue 1: “One of Jamie’s ancestors was David.” Makes sense only if David is a grandparent.  
   • So grandparents are David & Martha.

8. Allocate the four grandchildren names  
   • John + Jessica must have two children, at least one son (from step 5).  
   • Remaining unused children’s names: Alex, Lincoln, Jamie.  
   • Clue 7: “Lincoln’s brother showed Justin’s son his baseball cards.”  
        – Lincoln must have a brother → John’s children are Lincoln and his brother (Alex).  
        – “Justin’s son” identifies Jamie as male and child of Justin.  
        – The brother (Alex) shows cards to Jamie, matching the clue.  
   • Clue 4: “Alex is cousins with one of the girls.” Alex’s cousins are Tina (girl) and Jamie (boy); so Alex must be cousin of Tina—consistent.

   Therefore:  
     – John + Jessica: Lincoln (son) & Alex (son)  
     – Mary + Justin: Tina (daughter) & Jamie (son)

All clues are satisfied, giving the family tree stated in the summary.

Question:
Question: Two children, who were all tangled up in their reckoning of the days of the week, paused on their way to school to straighten matters out. "When the day after tomorrow is yesterday," said Priscilla, "then 'today' will be as far from Sunday as that day was which was 'today' when the day before yesterday was tomorrow!"
On which day of the week did this puzzling prattle occur?
 Solution: The two children were so befogged over the calendar that they had started on their way to school on Sunday morning!
Human Solution: The two children were so befogged over the calendar that they had started on their way to school on Sunday morning!
Response:
Solution Outline – split into small, self-contained steps  

1.  Give every day a number.  
   Sunday = 0, Monday = 1, … , Saturday = 6.  
   Arithmetic with days is done “mod 7”, because the week repeats every seven days.

2.  Translate the first clause.  
   “The day after to-morrow” is today + 2.  
   That day will be called “yesterday” exactly one day after it happens, i.e. three days from now.  
   So the clause “When the day after to-morrow is yesterday …” is talking about the day
   today + 3.

3.  Translate the second clause.  
   “… the day which was ‘today’ when the day before yesterday was to-morrow …”  
   “The day before yesterday” is today – 2.  
   For that to be called “to-morrow” we must look three days earlier, because  
   (today – 3) + 1  =  today – 2.  
   Hence the clause refers to the day today – 3.

4.  Restate Priscilla’s comparison with symbols.  
   On the day (today + 3) the distance of “to-day” from Sunday must equal the distance of (today – 3) from Sunday.

5.  Define “distance from Sunday”.  
   Because the week is a circle, the distance from Sunday to a day d is the smaller of  
   d (mod 7) and 7 – d (mod 7).  
   (Example: Wednesday, 3, is three days away; Thursday, 4, is also three days away.)

6.  Set up the equality.  
   distance(today + 3)  =  distance(today – 3)

7.  Check the seven possible values of “today”.  
   For today = 0 (Sunday):  
     today + 3 = 3  →  distance 3  
     today – 3 = –3 ≡ 4 → distance 3   ✓  (equal)  
   For any other value (1 through 6) the two distances are 3 and 2, or 2 and 1, etc., and never equal.

8.  Conclusion.  
   The equality of distances is satisfied only when today = 0.  
   Therefore the children were having their earnest discussion on Sunday.

Answer: they started off to school on a Sunday morning.

Question:
Question: What inference can you draw from the following statements:
1. Some alligators carry umbrellas in the shower.
2. Only those that know that flying fish live in trees prefer caramel candy to chocolate.
3. Certain days are set aside for alligators to watch rabbits play hockey.
4. Some large reptiles are steeplechasers.
5. Only steeplechasers can watch hockey games.
6.Those alligators that carry umbrellas in the shower know that flying fish live in the trees.
7. Those that prefer chocolate to caramel candy cannot be steeplechasers.
8. Steeplechasers are vegetarians.
 Solution: Only alligators that are vegetarians are allowed to watch rabbits play hockey.
Human Solution: Only alligators that are vegetarians are allowed to watch rabbits play hockey.
Response:
Reasoning – step by step

1. Statement 5: “Only steeplechasers can watch hockey games.”  
   Logical form Watch-hockey → Steeplechaser.

2. Statement 8: “Steeplechasers are vegetarians.”  
   Logical form Steeplechaser → Vegetarian.

3. Chain steps 1 and 2:  
   Watch-hockey → Steeplechaser → Vegetarian,  
   so Watch-hockey → Vegetarian.

4. Statement 3: “Certain days are set aside for alligators to watch rabbits play hockey.”  
   This tells us that the creatures doing the watching are alligators.

5. Combine steps 3 and 4:  
   Alligators that watch hockey are vegetarians; conversely, to be allowed to watch hockey one must be both an alligator (by context of statement 3) and a vegetarian (from step 3).

Inference

Therefore only those alligators that are vegetarians are permitted to watch rabbits play hockey.

Question:
Question: Biggie Nuff, Baron of Grey Matter, now living in Shapeless, Mass., was dying from a newly developed allergy to water, and wanted his will to reflect the common inheritance law of his father's native country.  Biggie's wife, Faerie, was pregnant at the time with what would be the first child for either of them.  Biggie's new will stated that if his child were a boy, the son would get 2/3 of his estate, and his widow would get 1/3.  If the child were a girl, the widow would get 2/3 of the estate, and the daughter would get 1/3.
In due time, Biggie died, and the authorities read his will, holding dispensation of the estate until the child was born.  Five months after Biggie's death, Faerie delivered ... normal, healthy twins, a boy (whom she named Manny) and a girl (whom she named Goodie).
The estate's executor immediately appealed to the Shapeless magistrate to rule on the proper division for the estate.  After a great deal of arguing and deep thought, plus several failed attempts to raise Biggie's spirit with a seance, the judge rendered a fair decision.
How did they divide Biggie's estate?
 Solution: The judge reasoned that Biggie intended to give his wife half as much as a son, or twice as much as a daughter.  Therefore, he ruled that Manny gets 4/7 of the estate, Faerie gets 2/7, and Goodie gets 1/7.
(This is supposedly a real decision in Massachusetts, according to the Reader's Digest puzzle book in which I first read this, copyright 1967.  Obviously, I've changed the names).
Human Solution:
The judge reasoned that Biggie intended to give his wife half as much as a son, or twice as much as a daughter.  Therefore, he ruled that Manny gets 4/7 of the estate, Faerie gets 2/7, and Goodie gets 1/7.
(This is supposedly a real decision in Massachusetts, according to the Reader's Digest puzzle book in which I first read this, copyright 1967.  Obviously, I've changed the names).
Response:
SUMMARY OF THE JUDGE’S REASONING

Step 1 – Translate each clause of the will into a simple ratio.  
• “If the child is a boy, he gets 2/3 and the widow 1/3.”  
 ⇒ Boy : Widow = 2 : 1.  
• “If the child is a girl, the widow gets 2/3 and the girl 1/3.”  
 ⇒ Widow : Girl = 2 : 1  (or Girl : Widow = 1 : 2).

Step 2 – Combine the two ratios so they are all expressed in the same direction (heirs’ shares compared to the widow).  
From the first clause: Boy : Widow = 2 : 1.  
From the second clause: Girl : Widow = 1 : 2  ⇒  Girl : Widow = 1 : 2.

Step 3 – Put all three heirs in a single proportional chain.  
Boy : Widow = 2 : 1  
Widow : Girl  = 2 : 1  
Multiply the two ratios to link Boy directly to both others:  
Boy : Widow : Girl = (2 × 2) : (1 × 2) : 1 = 4 : 2 : 1.

Step 4 – Convert the proportion into fraction shares of the whole estate.  
Total “parts” = 4 + 2 + 1 = 7.  
Boy (Manny) gets 4 parts → 4⁄7 of the estate.  
Widow (Faerie) gets 2 parts → 2⁄7 of the estate.  
Girl (Goodie) gets 1 part  → 1⁄7 of the estate.

Step 5 – State the final division ordered by the court.  
Manny: 4/7  Faerie: 2/7  Goodie: 1/7.

Each step follows logically from the previous ones, honoring both conditional wishes of the will simultaneously for the unexpected case of twins.

Question:
Question: The American Jukebox Twist Contest has been the talk of local high schools for weeks, so it's no surprise that Arnold's Diner is jammed full with twisting teenagers hoping to take home the trophy.  The competition is going to be fierce, as eight pairs of champion twisters, each from a different school, have entered.  As the makeshift dance floor fills with poodle skirts and blue suede shoes, each couple was asked to request a different song to be played during the marathon, which is expected to last long into the night.  From the information provided, name the young man and young woman who make up each couple, determine the high school each pair attends and the song they requested.
You will need to draw out a rectangular 2 x 4 grid (A - D on top, E - H on bottom) with the center line representing a row of tables in order to help determine who was in what position on the dance floor.
Positions:  A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H
Boys:  Bill, Curt, Danny, Donald, George, Ricky, Steve, Tony
Girls:  Cindy, Jenny, Laurie, Laverne, Nancy, Sheryl, Veronica, Wendy
Schools:  Jefferson, Lakewood, Lincoln, Oceanside, Riverdale, Roosevelt, Washington, Westerberg
Songs:  "Let's Twist Again",  "The Peppermint Twist", "Twist and Shout", "Twist, Twist, Senora", "The Twist", "Twistin' USA", "Twisting the Night Away", "Dear Lady Twist"
1.  Bill and his partner aren't the couple representing Washington High (which isn't Laurie's school).  Neither George (who isn't dancing with Wendy) nor Tony attends Roosevelt High.
2.  The couples in positions C, F, and H requested "Twist and Shout", "Dear Lady Twist," and "Twistin' USA", in some order.  The couple from Lakewood High, who requested "Twist and Shout", isn't in position F.
3.  Donald and his partner (who aren't the Oceanside High students) requested "The Peppermint Twist".  Wendy and her partner requested "Twisting the Night Away".  Cindy and her partner (who attend Lincoln High) requested "Twistin' USA".
4.  Curt and his partner, the Roosevelt High couple, and Sheryl and her partner are all dancing on the same side of the tables.
5.  Ricky and the couple from Roosevelt High are dancing at diagonally opposite ends of the restaurant.  Bill and the Twist champions from Jefferson High are the other pairs dancing at diagonally opposite ends of the restaurant.
6.  Couples A, D, E, and H are Laverne and her partner, Jenny and her partner, the couple who attend Washington high, and the ones who requested "Twist, Twist Senora", in some order.
7.  Sheryl isn't immediately next to either Nancy or her partner or Laverne and her partner.  Cindy is immediately next to, and due right of, Steve and his partner.
8.  Nancy and her partner (who attend Westerberg High) are directly across the tables from the Washington High couple; one of these couples requested "Dear Lady Twist".  The couple in position A requested "Let's Twist Again".
 Solution: A, Danny & Jenny, Roosevelt, "Let's Twist Again"
B, Donald & Sheryl, Riverdale, "The Peppermint Twist"
C, Curt & Laurie, Lakewood, "Twist and Shout"
D, Bill & Nancy, Westerberg, "Twist, Twist Senora"
E, Steve & Laverne, Jefferson, "The Twist"
F, George & Cindy, Lincoln, "Twistin' USA"
G, Tony & Wendy, Oceanside, "Twisting the Night Away"
H, Ricky & Veronica, Washington, "Dear Lady Twist"
Hint: A regular Logic Grid drawn out could help too if you have a good imagination.
Human Solution:
A, Danny & Jenny, Roosevelt, "Let's Twist Again"
B, Donald & Sheryl, Riverdale, "The Peppermint Twist"
C, Curt & Laurie, Lakewood, "Twist and Shout"
D, Bill & Nancy, Westerberg, "Twist, Twist Senora"
E, Steve & Laverne, Jefferson, "The Twist"
F, George & Cindy, Lincoln, "Twistin' USA"
G, Tony & Wendy, Oceanside, "Twisting the Night Away"
H, Ricky & Veronica, Washington, "Dear Lady Twist"
Response:
Solution in Brief  
A 2×4 rectangle of positions is labeled left-to-right A–D on the upper row, E–H on the lower.  After all clues are applied the eight couples line up as shown:

A  Danny & Jenny  Roosevelt  “Let’s Twist Again”  
B  Donald & Sheryl Riverdale  “The Peppermint Twist”  
C  Curt & Laurie  Lakewood  “Twist and Shout”  
D  Bill & Nancy  Westerberg  “Twist, Twist Senora”  
E  Steve & Laverne Jefferson  “The Twist”  
F  George & Cindy Lincoln  “Twistin’ USA”  
G  Tony & Wendy  Oceanside  “Twisting the Night Away”  
H  Ricky & Veronica Washington “Dear Lady Twist”

Step-by-Step Reasoning  

1.  Clue 2 says C, F, H use the songs Twist and Shout, Dear Lady Twist, Twistin’ USA.  
    • Clue 3 makes Twistin’ USA Cindy’s/Lincoln’s song.  
    • Clue 7 puts Cindy immediately right of Steve, which is only possible in F (with Steve in E).  
       ⇒  F = Cindy/Lincoln/Twistin’ USA and E holds Steve.

2.  Twist and Shout and Dear Lady Twist remain for C and H.  
    • Lakewood + Twist and Shout isn’t in F (clue 2) so Lakewood must be the couple in C.  
       ⇒  C = Lakewood/Twist and Shout; H = Dear Lady Twist.

3.  Dear Lady Twist is requested either by Washington or Nancy/Westerberg (clue 8).  
    Since H has that song and is a corner, H must be one of those two couples; the other must be the
    diagonally opposite corner D (because A–E and D–H are the only across-the-tables corner pairs).  

4.  Steve sits in corner E.  The diagonal pairs of opposite corners are A–H and D–E.  
    Clue 5: one diagonal is Ricky & Roosevelt, the other Bill & Jefferson.  
    – Putting Jefferson with Steve gives diagonal D–E = Bill & Jefferson, so Bill occupies D.  
    – Then A–H = Ricky & Roosevelt, making A the Roosevelt couple and Ricky in H.  

5.  Corner categories (clue 6) must be spread over A, D, E, H:  
    Laverne’s pair, Jenny’s pair, Washington’s pair, and the “Twist, Twist Senora” pair.  
    H already has Dear Lady Twist; thus “Twist, Twist Senora” must be at some other corner.  

6.  From step 3, H and D are the Washington and Westerberg (Nancy) corners, but Bill (in D) is
    not allowed to be Washington (clue 1).  
       ⇒  H = Washington (Ricky & Veronica), D = Westerberg (Bill & Nancy).  
       ⇒  D, which lacks a song, gets “Twist, Twist Senora” to satisfy the corner-category list.  

7.  Another corner category still missing is Laverne; Steve’s partner in E therefore must be Laverne, and E’s song (still open) becomes “The Twist” (the only song not yet used).  
    That also makes E = Jefferson, completing the Bill/Jefferson diagonal requirement.

8.  Clue 8 fixes the last unassigned corner song: A must request “Let’s Twist Again.”  
    A already owns Roosevelt; its couple is still unnamed.

9.  Clue 4 puts Curt & partner, the Roosevelt couple (A), and Sheryl & partner on the same side.
    With A in the top row, Sheryl must also be top-row; the only free top seat is B, so B = Sheryl.  
    Curt therefore occupies the remaining top position C (already Lakewood/Twist and Shout).  
       ⇒  C = Curt & Laurie (only unused top-row girl).  

10. Clue 3 assigns Donald & partner “The Peppermint Twist”; the only unfilled seat is B, so  
       B = Donald & Sheryl, song “The Peppermint Twist,” school Riverdale (the last unused name).  

11. Bottom-row seat G is still vacant.  Remaining boy/girl are Tony & Wendy; Clue 3 says Wendy’s couple wants “Twisting the Night Away,” and Clue 1 says Tony is not Roosevelt (true), so  
       G = Tony & Wendy, song “Twisting the Night Away,” school Oceanside (last unused school).

12. One boy (Danny) and one girl (Jenny) are still unused; they must be the Roosevelt couple in A, giving  
       A = Danny & Jenny, Roosevelt, “Let’s Twist Again.”

All eight positions now have one unique boy, girl, school and song, and every clue is satisfied.

Question:
Question: At the annual Pottstown Rose Show, Mr. Tom Thorne, an avid rose grower, entered his six best new hybrid roses.  He did extremely well, taking home 28 ribbons.  From the following clues, can you figure out how many blue ribbons and how many red ribbons each rose received?
Names of Roses are:  Pretty in Pink, Ravishing Red, Simply Silver, Mrs. Thelma Thorne, Very Violet and Yummy Yellow.
1.  No two roses won the same total number of ribbons.
2.  "Pretty in Pink" won one-quarter of the total amount, which was the same amount as the number that "Ravishing Red", "Yummy Yellow" and "Simply Silver" won together.
3.  "Very Violet" won the same number of ribbons as both "Mrs.Thelma Thorne" and "Simply Silver" together.
4.  Three-quarters of "Ravishing Red's" ribbons were red.
5.  One-third of "Mrs. Thelma Thorne's" ribbons were blue; "Yummy Yellow" won just one blue ribbon.
6.  "Simply Silver" won an equal number of blue and red ribbons.
7.  "Very Violet" won the same number of blue ribbons as "Pretty in Pink".
8.  "Very Violet" won as many red ribbons as were won by "Mrs. Thelma Thorne" and "Ravishing Red" together.
 Solution: Pretty in Pink - 1 Blue - 6 Red
Ravishing Red - 1 Blue - 3 Red
Simply Silver - 1 Blue - 1 Red
Mrs. Thelma Thorne - 2 Blue - 4 Red
Very Violet - 1 Blue - 7 red
Yummy Yellow - 1 Blue only
Human Solution:
Pretty in Pink - 1 Blue - 6 Red
Ravishing Red - 1 Blue - 3 Red
Simply Silver - 1 Blue - 1 Red
Mrs. Thelma Thorne - 2 Blue - 4 Red
Very Violet - 1 Blue - 7 red
Yummy Yellow - 1 Blue only
Response:
SOLUTION OUTLINE (step-by-step)

1.  Translate each statement into algebra.
    • Let each rose have totals T (ribbons), B (blue), R (red).
      Roses:  P, R, S, M, V, Y.

2.  Use the global information.
    • Total ribbons = 28.                                    
    • Clue 2a: “Pretty in Pink” won one-quarter of all ribbons.  
      ⇒ T_P = 28 ⁄ 4 = 7.

3.  Exploit the rest of Clue 2.
    • T_P equals the combined totals of Ravishing R, Yummy Y and Simply S.  
      ⇒ T_R + T_Y + T_S = 7.

4.  Apply Clue 4 to narrow T_R.
    • Three-quarters of R’s ribbons are red → T_R must be a multiple of 4.  
      Smallest possible multiple (and it must leave room for S and Y) is 4.  
      ⇒ T_R = 4 → R_R = 3, R_B = 1.

5.  Fix Yummy Y from Clue 5.
    • Y won “just one blue ribbon,” so it won exactly one ribbon in total.  
      ⇒ T_Y = 1, Y_B = 1, Y_R = 0.

6.  Deduce Simply S’s total.
    • From Step 3: T_R + T_Y + T_S = 7  
      ⇒ 4 + 1 + T_S = 7 → T_S = 2.  
    • Clue 6 says S’s blue = red → S_B = 1, S_R = 1.

7.  Determine totals for M and V (the only roses not fixed yet).
    • Ribbons used so far: 7 + 4 + 1 + 2 = 14.  
      ⇒ T_M + T_V = 28 − 14 = 14.                       …(i)
    • Clue 3: V’s total equals M’s total plus S’s total.  
      ⇒ T_V = T_M + T_S = T_M + 2.                     …(ii)
    • Solve (i) & (ii): T_M + (T_M + 2) = 14 → T_M = 6, T_V = 8.

8.  Split M’s ribbons with Clue 5.
    • One-third of M’s ribbons are blue → M_B = 6 ⁄ 3 = 2, M_R = 4.

9.  Split V’s ribbons with Clues 7 & 8.
    • Clue 8: V’s red ribbons equal M’s red + R’s red = 4 + 3 = 7.  
      ⇒ V_R = 7.
    • Total V ribbons is 8, so V_B = 8 − 7 = 1.
    • Clue 7 is automatically satisfied: V_B (1) equals P_B (still unknown).

10.  Finish Pretty-in-Pink.
    • T_P = 7 and V_B = P_B = 1 → P_B = 1.  
      ⇒ P_R = 7 − 1 = 6.

11.  Verify all clues.
    • All numerical conditions and “different totals” requirement are met.

FINAL RIBBON COUNTS
• Pretty in Pink:        1 blue, 6 red  (total 7)
• Ravishing Red:         1 blue, 3 red  (total 4)
• Simply Silver:         1 blue, 1 red  (total 2)
• Mrs. Thelma Thorne:    2 blue, 4 red  (total 6)
• Very Violet:           1 blue, 7 red  (total 8)
• Yummy Yellow:          1 blue, 0 red  (total 1)

Question: Well... The Winning Combination is back.. but with a twist!  You are a millionaire... but you have now become very greedy and a cheater.  You spend lots of money on selfish things, and are finding yourself very short of money.  The show has refused to let you back on after you meanly insulted the host.
But you are sneakier than that.  Now, your son has applied to be a contestant and has successfully made it on.  He, however, has nowhere near the brain power as you, so you have figured out another device, being the greedy person you are, to help your son out and claim half a million more.
He is secretly wearing a very cleverly disguised earpiece which you will talk to him through.  Whilst you sit at home, with a pen and paper, he will recite the clues into your ear and you must solve them for him!
You grip your pen... with headphones and microphone in place, and wait for him to start reciting.
The combination is spaced out like this... ??-??-??-??.  A 'set' refers to a set of two numbers.
"OK, Dad...
1. The sum of the digits in the third set is less than 14 but greater than 10.
2. The third set of numbers is 13 smaller than the fourth set.
3. If you multiply the second set of numbers by 2 and add 7, then you will get the first set of numbers.
4. The sum of the digits in the fourth set is greater than the sum of the digits in the first set.
5. There are no 0's, 3's or 6's in the combination.  Every other number is in the combination.
6. The first set of two digits is a square number (for example 81 is a square number... 9x9).
Hurry, Dad, hurry!"
 Solution: The solution is 49-21-75-88.
First of all, we know that there are no 0's, 3's or 6's in the combination and that every other digit appears at least once (clue 5).
OK, we'll start on the first set.
We know it's a square number (clue 6).
The only available square numbers that don't have a 0, 3 or 6 in them are:
25
49
81
Now, read clue 3.  This tells us that multiplying the second set of numbers by 2 and then adding 7 will give us the first set.
So you must work backwards from the three numbers we know are the possibilities.
81 - 7 = 74 / 2 = 37.  However, we know there are no 3's in the combination so this can't be right.
25 - 7 = 18 / 2 = 9.  This can't be right, because written down it would be 09 and we know there are no 0's.
So that leaves with 49.
49 - 7 = 42 / 2 = 21.
Now we know this much:
49-21-??-??
Now we must work on the last two sets.
Clue 2 tells us that the third set is 13 smaller than the fourth set.
Here are the possible combinations:
11-24
12-25
14-27
15-28
28-41
29-42
41-54
42-55
44-57
45-58
58-71
59-72
71-84
72-85
74-87
75-88
78-91
79-92
81-94
82-95
84-97
85-98
Now, we must remember clue 5 - this tells us that every number will appear in the combination at least once, apart from 0, 3 and 6.
Currently, we have 1, 2, 4 and 9 in... so that leaves out 5, 7 and 8.
So now we review the list... there are only three possible combinations that include 5, 7 and 8:
58-71
75-88
72-85
Now, we read clue 4.  This tells us the sum of the digits in the fourth set is greater than the sum of the digits in the first set.  The sum of the digits in the first set is 13 (4 + 9), and so the only one greater than that is the 75-88 combination (8 + 8 = 16).
So there we have it.
49-21-75-88.
(P.S. Sorry if this offended anybody, not that I think it would, but in my other teaser people were complaining so I'm just putting this in here for warning).
Hint: The numbers in the first set are not higher than 60.

Response:
Solution outline for the code ??-??-??-??  

Step 1 – Digits that can appear  
• Forbidden: 0, 3, 6.  
• Required (at least once): 1, 2, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9.  

Step 2 – Find the 1st set (a two-digit perfect square, clue 6)  
Allowed squares: 25, 49, 81.  

Step 3 – Use the link between 1st and 2nd sets (clue 3)  
(second set) × 2 + 7 = (first set).  
• For 81: (81 – 7)/2 = 37  → contains 3 (forbidden) → reject.  
• For 25: (25 – 7)/2 = 9  → would be 09 (contains 0) → reject.  
• For 49: (49 – 7)/2 = 21  → digits 2,1 allowed → accept.  
Thus 1st set = 49, 2nd set = 21.  
Digits used so far: 1,2,4,9.  Still missing: 5, 7, 8.  

Step 4 – Relate 3rd and 4th sets (clue 2)  
3rd set = (4th set) – 13.  List every allowed pair of two-digit numbers, 13 apart, that avoid 0, 3, 6:  
11-24, 12-25, 14-27, 15-28, 28-41, 29-42, 41-54, 42-55, 44-57, 45-58, 58-71, 59-72, 71-84, 72-85, 74-87, 75-88, 78-91, 79-92, 81-94, 82-95, 84-97, 85-98.  

Step 5 – Force the remaining digits 5, 7, 8 to appear (clue 5)  
Only three pairs contain all of 5, 7, 8 somewhere in the pair:  
58-71, 72-85, 75-88.  

Step 6 – Apply the digit-sum comparison (clue 4)  
Sum of digits in 1st set = 4 + 9 = 13.  
Need (digit-sum of 4th set) > 13.  
• 58-71: 4th set = 71 → 7+1 = 8 (too small).  
• 72-85: 4th set = 85 → 8+5 = 13 (not greater).  
• 75-88: 4th set = 88 → 8+8 = 16 (> 13) → works.  

Step 7 – Check the 3rd-set digit-sum requirement (clue 1)  
3rd set here is 75: 7+5 = 12, which is > 10 and < 14 → satisfies clue 1.  

All clues satisfied and every allowed digit appears at least once.  
Final winning combination: 49-21-75-88.

Question:
Question: In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
* stands for T, L, M, V, or Y
# stands for S, H, C, M, or B
^ stands for F, S, K, I, or O
$ stands for O, W, G, U, or P
The four letter code word, #$^*, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
 Solution: Boom and Bust.
Human Solution: Boom and Bust.
Response:
SOLUTION SUMMARY
Opposite words: BOOM and BUST

REASONING – STEP BY STEP

1.  Clarify the code pattern  
    The coded word has four positions:  #  $  ^  *  
    Each position must be filled by one letter chosen from its allowed set.  
    • # → { S, H, C, M, B }  
    • $ → { O, W, G, U, P }  
    • ^ → { F, S, K, I, O }  
    • * → { T, L, M, V, Y }

2.  Translate the requirement  
    We need two different English four-letter words that  
    • fit the same pattern #$^*, and  
    • are antonyms (opposites).

3.  Narrow the search with the first letter (#)  
    The two words must start with the same letter, and that letter has to be one of S, H, C, M, B.  
    Skimming common four-letter antonym pairs that share an initial letter, only a few plausible “first-letter-B” pairs exist (e.g., “boom/bust,” “best/…,” etc.).  
    “Boom” and “bust” are well-known economic opposites and both begin with B, which is in the # set.

4.  Check “BOOM” against the code restrictions  
    B  ( # set ) → allowed  
    O  ( $ set ) → allowed  
    O  ( ^ set ) → allowed  
    M  ( * set ) → allowed  
    Therefore “BOOM” fits the pattern.

5.  Check “BUST” against the code restrictions  
    B  ( # set ) → allowed  
    U  ( $ set ) → allowed  
    S  ( ^ set ) → allowed  
    T  ( * set ) → allowed  
    Therefore “BUST” also fits the pattern.

6.  Confirm they are antonyms  
    “Boom” = period of rapid growth or success.  
    “Bust” = period of failure or collapse.  
    They are standard opposites in economic and colloquial usage.

7.  Conclude  
    The only pair that simultaneously satisfies the symbol constraints and the “opposites” requirement is the pair BOOM / BUST.

Answer: BOOM and BUST

Question:
Question: There are three students Anu, Bob and Coy. They have exactly three books - one on Physics, one on Chemistry and one on Math. Each of these three books belongs to exactly one of the students. As I wanted to know the names of the respective owners of the books I asked them about the owners of the books. The following are the answers given by Anu, Bob and Coy.
Anu : Physics book belongs to me. Maths book does not belong to Bob. Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Bob : Physics book does not belong to me. Chemistry book belongs to Coy. Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
Coy : Physics book does not belong to Anu. Maths book does not belong to me. Chemistry book does not belong to Bob.
I knew that exactly one of them always speaks the truth, exactly  one of them always lies and the third one alternates between truth and lie, in any order.
Which of the following statements can then be concluded?
1) Anu always tells the truth.
2) Coy always lies.
3) Bob is the owner of the Chemistry book.
NOTE: Out of the given set of 3 statements, it is not necessary that one and only one statement can be concluded. One or more statements can be concluded.
 Solution: All the three given statements can be concluded.
The given statements are
1) Anu always tells the truth.
2) Coy always lies.
3) Bob is the owner of the Chemistry book.
The answers given by Anu, Bob and Coy to my query about the owners of the Physics, Chemistry and Maths books are as follows :-
Anu : Physics book belongs to me. Maths book does not belong to Bob. Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Bob : Physics book does not belong to me. Chemistry book belongs to Coy. Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
Coy : Physics book does not belong to Anu. Maths book does not belong to me. Chemistry book does not belong to Bob.
Case 1 : Let us assume that Anu always tells the truth.
Then according to Anu's answer,
Physics book belongs to Anu.
Chemistry book belongs to Bob.
Maths book belongs to Coy.
Comparing Anu's reply with that of Bob's and Coy's replies, we can infer that
Bob speaks the truth, lies and speaks the truth respectively when he says that the Physics book does not belong to him, the Chemistry book belongs to Coy and the Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
Coy lies three times when he says that the Physics book does not belong to Anu, the Maths book does not belong to him and the Chemistry book does not belong to Bob.
Hence under Case 1, Anu always speaks the truth, Bob alternates between truth and lie and Coy always lies. Also in this case the Chemistry book belongs to Bob.
Case 2 : Let us assume that Bob always tells the truth.
Then according to Bob's answer,
Physics book belongs to Anu.
Maths book belongs to Bob.
Chemistry book belongs to Coy.
Comparing Bob's reply with that of Anu's and Coy's replies, we can infer that
Anu speaks the truth, lies and lies respectively when he says that the Physics book belongs to him, the Maths book does not belong to Bob and the Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Coy lies, speaks the truth and speaks the truth respectively when he says that the Physics book does not belong to Anu, the Maths book does not belong to him and the Chemistry book does not belong to Bob.
Hence under Case 2, Bob always speaks the truth, Anu and Coy alternate between truth and lie and hence this case is not possible since it is given that exactly one of them always speaks the truth, exactly  one of them always lies and the third one alternates between truth and lie, in any order.
Case 3 : Let us assume that Coy always tells the truth. Here we can again make two sub cases.
a) According to Coy's answer,
Maths book belongs to Anu.
Physics book belongs to Bob.
Chemistry book belongs to Coy.
Comparing Coy's reply with that of Anu's and Bob's replies, we can infer that
Anu lies, speaks the truth and lies respectively when he says that the Physics book belongs to him, the Maths book does not belong to Bob and the Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Bob lies, speaks the truth and lies respectively when he says that the Physics book does not belong to him, the Chemistry book belongs to Coy and the Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
This case is not possible since both Anu and Bob are alternating between truth and lie and there is no one person who always lies.
b) According to Coy's answer,
Chemistry book belongs to Anu.
Maths book belongs to Bob.
Physics book belongs to Coy.
Comparing Coy's reply with that of Anu's and Bob's replies, we can infer that
Anu lies, lies and speaks the truth respectively when he says that the Physics book belongs to him, the Maths book does not belong to Bob and the Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Bob speaks the truth, lies and speaks the truth respectively when he says that the Physics book does not belong to him, the Chemistry book belongs to Coy and the Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
This case is also not possible since both Anu and Bob are alternating between truth and lie and there is no one person who always lies.
Hence among the three cases, only Case 1 can be considered to be a valid case wherein Anu always speaks the truth, Bob alternates between truth and lie, Coy always lies and the Chemistry book belongs to Bob. Hence all the given statements 1, 2 and 3 can be concluded.
Human Solution:
All the three given statements can be concluded.
The given statements are
1) Anu always tells the truth.
2) Coy always lies.
3) Bob is the owner of the Chemistry book.
The answers given by Anu, Bob and Coy to my query about the owners of the Physics, Chemistry and Maths books are as follows :-
Anu : Physics book belongs to me. Maths book does not belong to Bob. Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Bob : Physics book does not belong to me. Chemistry book belongs to Coy. Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
Coy : Physics book does not belong to Anu. Maths book does not belong to me. Chemistry book does not belong to Bob.
Case 1 : Let us assume that Anu always tells the truth.
Then according to Anu's answer,
Physics book belongs to Anu.
Chemistry book belongs to Bob.
Maths book belongs to Coy.
Comparing Anu's reply with that of Bob's and Coy's replies, we can infer that
Bob speaks the truth, lies and speaks the truth respectively when he says that the Physics book does not belong to him, the Chemistry book belongs to Coy and the Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
Coy lies three times when he says that the Physics book does not belong to Anu, the Maths book does not belong to him and the Chemistry book does not belong to Bob.
Hence under Case 1, Anu always speaks the truth, Bob alternates between truth and lie and Coy always lies. Also in this case the Chemistry book belongs to Bob.
Case 2 : Let us assume that Bob always tells the truth.
Then according to Bob's answer,
Physics book belongs to Anu.
Maths book belongs to Bob.
Chemistry book belongs to Coy.
Comparing Bob's reply with that of Anu's and Coy's replies, we can infer that
Anu speaks the truth, lies and lies respectively when he says that the Physics book belongs to him, the Maths book does not belong to Bob and the Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Coy lies, speaks the truth and speaks the truth respectively when he says that the Physics book does not belong to Anu, the Maths book does not belong to him and the Chemistry book does not belong to Bob.
Hence under Case 2, Bob always speaks the truth, Anu and Coy alternate between truth and lie and hence this case is not possible since it is given that exactly one of them always speaks the truth, exactly  one of them always lies and the third one alternates between truth and lie, in any order.
Case 3 : Let us assume that Coy always tells the truth. Here we can again make two sub cases.
a) According to Coy's answer,
Maths book belongs to Anu.
Physics book belongs to Bob.
Chemistry book belongs to Coy.
Comparing Coy's reply with that of Anu's and Bob's replies, we can infer that
Anu lies, speaks the truth and lies respectively when he says that the Physics book belongs to him, the Maths book does not belong to Bob and the Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Bob lies, speaks the truth and lies respectively when he says that the Physics book does not belong to him, the Chemistry book belongs to Coy and the Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
This case is not possible since both Anu and Bob are alternating between truth and lie and there is no one person who always lies.
b) According to Coy's answer,
Chemistry book belongs to Anu.
Maths book belongs to Bob.
Physics book belongs to Coy.
Comparing Coy's reply with that of Anu's and Bob's replies, we can infer that
Anu lies, lies and speaks the truth respectively when he says that the Physics book belongs to him, the Maths book does not belong to Bob and the Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Bob speaks the truth, lies and speaks the truth respectively when he says that the Physics book does not belong to him, the Chemistry book belongs to Coy and the Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
This case is also not possible since both Anu and Bob are alternating between truth and lie and there is no one person who always lies.
Hence among the three cases, only Case 1 can be considered to be a valid case wherein Anu always speaks the truth, Bob alternates between truth and lie, Coy always lies and the Chemistry book belongs to Bob. Hence all the given statements 1, 2 and 3 can be concluded.
Response:
Summary of the solution (broken into self-contained logical steps)

STEP 1 – Translate every statement.  
A = “Physics is Anu’s”, A̅B = “Maths is not Bob’s”, A̅C = “Chemistry is not Coy’s”  (Anu)  
B̅  = “Physics is not Bob’s”, BC = “Chemistry is Coy’s”, B̅A = “Maths is not Anu’s”  (Bob)  
A̅  = “Physics is not Anu’s”, C̅  = “Maths is not Coy’s”, C̅B = “Chemistry is not Bob’s” (Coy)

STEP 2 – Note the meta–rule.  
Exactly one pupil is a Truth-teller (T), exactly one is a Liar (L), and the third alternates (A).

STEP 3 – Assume Anu is the Truth-teller and read her three claims literally.  
• Physics = Anu, • Maths ≠ Bob, • Chemistry ≠ Coy.  
With three books and three owners, the only possible allocation is  
 Physics → Anu, Chemistry → Bob, Maths → Coy.

STEP 4 – Check Bob’s three sentences under this allocation.  
(1) “Physics is not Bob’s” – TRUE  
(2) “Chemistry is Coy’s” – FALSE  
(3) “Maths is not Anu’s” – TRUE  
Pattern T-F-T = alternation → Bob can be the Alternator.

STEP 5 – Check Coy’s three sentences under the same allocation.  
(1) “Physics is not Anu’s” – FALSE  
(2) “Maths is not Coy’s” – FALSE  
(3) “Chemistry is not Bob’s” – FALSE  
All three are false → Coy is the Liar.

STEP 6 – The role pattern (Anu=T, Bob=A, Coy=L) obeys the meta-rule, so the assumption in Step 3 is self-consistent.

STEP 7 – Try making Bob the Truth-teller instead.  
His literal claims give a different ownership set (Physics→Anu, Maths→Bob, Chemistry→Coy).  
That set forces both Anu and Coy to alternate, leaving nobody to be the Liar → violates the meta-rule → impossible.

STEP 8 – Try making Coy the Truth-teller.  
Either of the two ownership sets his three truths allow makes both Anu and Bob alternate, again leaving no Liar → impossible.

STEP 9 – Conclusion.  
Anu must be the Truth-teller, Coy the Liar, Bob the Alternator, and the ownership is  
 Physics – Anu, Chemistry – Bob, Maths – Coy.

What can be deduced?  
1) Anu always tells the truth – YES.  
2) Coy always lies – YES.  
3) Bob owns the Chemistry book – YES.

Therefore all three given statements are valid conclusions.

Question:
Question: Grobi is a very unique creature.
Grobi:
1...is round in shape.
2...is six inches in diameter.
3...lives on an acre-sized flat field.
4...moves only by jumping; cannot walk, crawl, fly, or move in any manner other than jumping.
5...can jump, in any one jump, a minimum of 6 inches or a maximum of 72 inches (6 feet) across the field (cannot jump straight up-down).  Grobi can therefore, in any one jump, jump any distance across the field at or between the 6-72 inch limits.
6...can jump directly north, south, east, or west only; cannot jump diagonally.
7...must jump four times in any one direction (N-S-E-W) before changing direction (N-S-E-W) or to continue in the same direction (N-S-E-W).
8...dines on mushrooms which grow in the field.  The mushrooms grow to a maximum of six inches in diameter and to a height of an inch.
9...can ingest a mushroom only by landing directly atop the mushroom.
10...is very adept at precisely determining distances.
One day Grobi - happily jumping around in the middle of the field - locates a six-inch diameter mushroom six inches away (center of Grobi to center of mushroom distance) directly west of Grobi.
Grobi quickly (and accurately) calculates that FOUR jumps is the fastest way to get to the mushroom and eat, which Grobi does.
Describe the route taken by Grobi to eat the mushroom including the direction of jumps, each approximate jump-distance, and the specific number of jumps in each direction.
 Solution: Grobi had already taken ONE jump to the east (in a new four-jump 'direction' series) when the mushroom was located to the west.  Grobi therefore had to take THREE more jumps to the east before being able to change direction and head back west.  Grobi took three minimum jumps (six inches or so each) to the east and then a long (24 inches or so) FOURTH jump to the west to land atop the mushroom.
No other conditions would solve the puzzle as written:
1.  If Grobi had been jumping west (as part of a four-jump 'direction' series), or had just concluded a four-jump 'direction' series, then the mushroom could have been attained in one jump.
2.  If Grobi had been jumping north or south (as part of a four-jump 'direction' series) then four additional jumps (even if able to change direction) would have put Grobi out of alignment with the mushroom.
3.  If Grobi had been jumping east (and had done two or three jumps as part of a four-jump 'direction' series) then the mushroom could have been attained in two or three additional jumps and not the four that was Grobi's correct calculation.
Hint: No need to "invent" anything new for Grobi such as extraordinary motivating or grasping or ingestion appendages.  The problem can be solved using the information given.  Key words in the puzzle are "happily jumping around".
Human Solution:
Grobi had already taken ONE jump to the east (in a new four-jump 'direction' series) when the mushroom was located to the west.  Grobi therefore had to take THREE more jumps to the east before being able to change direction and head back west.  Grobi took three minimum jumps (six inches or so each) to the east and then a long (24 inches or so) FOURTH jump to the west to land atop the mushroom.
No other conditions would solve the puzzle as written:
1.  If Grobi had been jumping west (as part of a four-jump 'direction' series), or had just concluded a four-jump 'direction' series, then the mushroom could have been attained in one jump.
2.  If Grobi had been jumping north or south (as part of a four-jump 'direction' series) then four additional jumps (even if able to change direction) would have put Grobi out of alignment with the mushroom.
3.  If Grobi had been jumping east (and had done two or three jumps as part of a four-jump 'direction' series) then the mushroom could have been attained in two or three additional jumps and not the four that was Grobi's correct calculation.
Response:
Answer (Route in the minimum four jumps)

1.  At the instant Grobi spots the mushroom, he has just finished the FIRST jump of a new “east-bound set”.  
   – Direction already taken: East  
   – Jumps already made in that set: 1 of the required 4

2.  Rule 7 now forces Grobi to complete the remaining three jumps toward the east before he may change direction.  
   – Jump #1 after the discovery: East about 6 in.  
   – Jump #2 after the discovery: East about 6 in.  
   – Jump #3 after the discovery: East about 6 in.  
   (After these three short hops the four-jump east set is finished.)

3.  Grobi is now free to start a new set in any cardinal direction, so he starts a west-bound set.  
   – Jump #4 after the discovery: West about 24 in.  

   Because the net effect of the four post-discovery jumps is  
   (+6 + 6 + 6 − 24) in. = −6 in.,  
   Grobi ends up exactly 6 inches west of the spot at which he first saw the mushroom—i.e. he lands squarely on top of it and eats it.

Thus the minimum-time (four-jump) route is:
• East 6 in.  
• East 6 in.  
• East 6 in.  
• West 24 in.  

Reasoning in simple steps

1.  Grobi must make moves in blocks of four jumps pointing the same way (Rule 7).  
2.  The mushroom is only one short (6-in.) jump to the west, so if Grobi were free to turn west immediately he could reach it in one jump.  
3.  Because Grobi instead computes that four jumps are still necessary, he must already be locked into the middle of a block that is NOT finished yet.  
4.  If he were in a western block (or had just finished one), one jump would suffice—contradiction.  
5.  If he were in a northern or southern block, completing that block plus turning toward the mushroom would leave him north or south of it—he would miss the target.  
6.  If he were in an eastern block with two or three jumps already done, finishing that block and returning would take only two or three further jumps—also contradicting the “fastest is four” information.  
7.  Therefore he must have done exactly one eastward jump when he noticed the mushroom. He must complete the three remaining eastward jumps, then may turn west.  
8.  Choosing the minimum legal length (6 in.) for each of those three mandatory east jumps and a legal 24-in. westward jump brings him to the mushroom in exactly four jumps, satisfying all conditions.

Question:
Question: A king heard that the nearby kingdoms were being destroyed by a fierce dragon. He called forth his most trusted and skilled knights to meet and plan how to protect the kingdom.  The 6 knights, Sir William, Sir Andrew, Sir Luke, Sir Calvin, Sir Charles and Sir Vincent, decided that two knights would venture out to find and slay the dragon while the other 4 would defend the kingdom.
From the statements below, which two knights went to seek the dragon?
1. If neither Sir William or Sir Vincent rode out, then Sir Calvin did.
2. If either Sir Calvin or Sir Vincent went to kill the dragon, then Sir Andrew did not.
3.  If neither Sir Andrew or Sir William were of the brave two that left the kingdom, then Sir Charles was.
4.  If neither Sir Luke or Sir Andrew went out, then Sir Vincent did.
5. If Sir William was one of the two, then either Sir Calvin or Sir Charles was with him.
6. If Sir Vincent was not of the two who went to slay the dragon, then neither was Sir Andrew nor Sir Charles.
 Solution: Sir Vincent and Sir Charles went out of the kingdom to slay the dragon.
If statement 1 is valid, Calvin was one of the two that left. If not, either William or Vincent was one of the two. Therefore the PAIR could not be Andrew and Luke, Sir Andrew and Charles or Luke and Charles.
From 3, the PAIR that left was not Luke and Calvin, Luke and Vincent or Calvin and Vincent. From 4, the two could not have been William and Calvin, William and Charles or Calvin and Charles.
From 5, William did not venture out and therefore from 4 the pair was not William and Calvin or William and Charles.
From 6, Vincent must have been one of the two since the statement identifies three of the four knights not eliminated. From 2, Vincent was one of the two, and by elimination, the other is Charles.
Human Solution:
Sir Vincent and Sir Charles went out of the kingdom to slay the dragon.
If statement 1 is valid, Calvin was one of the two that left. If not, either William or Vincent was one of the two. Therefore the PAIR could not be Andrew and Luke, Sir Andrew and Charles or Luke and Charles.
From 3, the PAIR that left was not Luke and Calvin, Luke and Vincent or Calvin and Vincent. From 4, the two could not have been William and Calvin, William and Charles or Calvin and Charles.
From 5, William did not venture out and therefore from 4 the pair was not William and Calvin or William and Charles.
From 6, Vincent must have been one of the two since the statement identifies three of the four knights not eliminated. From 2, Vincent was one of the two, and by elimination, the other is Charles.
Response:
Let  

W = Sir William went out  
A = Sir Andrew went out  
L = Sir Luke went out  
Ca = Sir Calvin went out  
Ch = Sir Charles went out  
V = Sir Vincent went out  

Exactly TWO of the six variables must be true.

Rewrite each statement as a logical implication.

1. (¬W ∧ ¬V) → Ca  
2. (Ca ∨ V) → ¬A  
3. (¬A ∧ ¬W) → Ch  
4. (¬L ∧ ¬A) → V  
5. W → (Ca ∨ Ch)  
6. ¬V → (¬A ∧ ¬Ch)

Step-by-step reasoning

Step 1.  Show that Vincent must be one of the two.  
• Assume ¬V (Vincent stays).  
 From (6) we get ¬A and ¬Ch.  
 The pair must then be chosen from {W, L, Ca}.  
 But (5) forbids the pair {W,L} because W would need Ca or Ch with him.  
 Try {W,Ca}: rule 4 now has ¬L ∧ ¬A true, so V would have to go – contradiction.  
 Try {L,Ca}: rule 3 has ¬A ∧ ¬W true, so Ch must go – gives a third knight.  
 All possibilities with ¬V fail, so our assumption is impossible.  
Therefore V is out; V is one member of the pair.

Step 2.  Andrew cannot be the second knight.  
With V out, rule 2 gives ¬A, so A stays.

Step 3.  William cannot be the second knight.  
Suppose W goes with V.  
Rule 5 then demands Ca or Ch go as well, giving a third knight – impossible.  
So W stays (¬W is true).

Step 4.  If William stays and Andrew stays, rule 3 forces Charles to go.  
Because ¬A and ¬W are both true, (3) ⇒ Ch.  
Hence Ch must be the second knight.

Step 5.  Verify that the pair (V, Ch) satisfies every rule.  
• Rule 1: antecedent (¬W ∧ ¬V) is false (V goes), so the rule holds.  
• Rule 2: antecedent true (V goes), conclusion ¬A true – satisfied.  
• Rule 3: antecedent true (¬A ∧ ¬W), conclusion Ch true – satisfied.  
• Rule 4: antecedent true (¬L ∧ ¬A), conclusion V true – satisfied.  
• Rule 5: antecedent false (W stays) – satisfied.  
• Rule 6: antecedent false (¬V) – satisfied.  

Every rule is honored with no surplus knights.

Conclusion  
The only combination consistent with all six statements is:

Sir Vincent and Sir Charles rode out to slay the dragon.

Question:
Question: My entire family lives on Braingle Street, and for some strange reason I got to choose where everyone lives.
My mother Vera lives at 2005 Braingle St.
My cousin Lucy lives at 1150 Braingle St.
Where do I live?
 Solution: The addresses are based on the first letters of the residents' relations to me, converted to Roman Numerals.
My Mother Vera = MMV = 2005
My Cousin Lucy = MCL = 1150
This leaves "Me" living at 1000 Braingle Street.
I could also accept 1 Braingle St. (referring to myself as "I") as a valid answer.
Hint: If Lucy changed her name to Irene, she'd have to move to 1101 Braingle St.
Human Solution:
The addresses are based on the first letters of the residents' relations to me, converted to Roman Numerals.
My Mother Vera = MMV = 2005
My Cousin Lucy = MCL = 1150
This leaves "Me" living at 1000 Braingle Street.
I could also accept 1 Braingle St. (referring to myself as "I") as a valid answer.
Response:
Solution outline in simple, complete steps  

1. Observe the given addresses  
   • Mother Vera → 2005  
   • Cousin Lucy → 1150  

2. Take the first letter of each word describing the person’s relationship and name:  
   • Mother Vera → M M V  
   • (My) Cousin Lucy → M C L  

3. Notice that each of those letters is a Roman-numeral symbol:  
   M = 1000,  C = 100,  L = 50,  V = 5,  (I = 1)

4. Convert the strings of letters to numbers by simple addition (no subtraction rule is used here):  
   • M M V → 1000 + 1000 + 5 = 2005  
   • M C L → 1000 + 100 + 50 = 1150  

5. Apply the same rule to yourself.  The relationship word is “Me,” whose first (and only) letter is M.  
   • M → 1000  

6. Therefore, the address for “Me” is 1000 Braingle Street.  

7. An alternate wording—referring to yourself as “I”—would give the Roman numeral I = 1, hence 1 Braingle Street is also defensible.

Question:
Question: Mad Ade's cousin Steve lies a lot. He tells the truth on only one day in a week.
One day he said: "I lie on Mondays and Tuesdays."
The next day he said: "Today is either Sunday, Saturday, or Thursday."
The next day he said: "I lie on Fridays and Wednesdays."
On which day of the week does Steve tell the truth?
 Solution: Mad Ade's cousin  Steve tells the truth on Tuesdays
The first and third statements are incompatible; they cannot of course both be true, and they can only be lies if on one of the days mentioned Steve tells the truth. But, they have no such day in common. Therefore one of them must be true, and the other must refer to that day. Looking at the second statement (which must be a lie, as there can at most be one true statement and we have one), the first day cannot be Wednesday, Friday or Saturday. Therefore, the first statement cannot be true, since the third cannot refer to it by day. Therefore, the third statement is true, and must (from the first statement) be a Monday or Tuesday. Statement two, however, rules out Monday, leaving only Tuesday as the 'day of truth'. Thus: 'one day' is a Sunday; on the third day (Tuesday) Steve is truthful.
Human Solution:
Mad Ade's cousin  Steve tells the truth on Tuesdays
The first and third statements are incompatible; they cannot of course both be true, and they can only be lies if on one of the days mentioned Steve tells the truth. But, they have no such day in common. Therefore one of them must be true, and the other must refer to that day. Looking at the second statement (which must be a lie, as there can at most be one true statement and we have one), the first day cannot be Wednesday, Friday or Saturday. Therefore, the first statement cannot be true, since the third cannot refer to it by day. Therefore, the third statement is true, and must (from the first statement) be a Monday or Tuesday. Statement two, however, rules out Monday, leaving only Tuesday as the 'day of truth'. Thus: 'one day' is a Sunday; on the third day (Tuesday) Steve is truthful.
Response:
Solution Outline  

1.  Exactly one day each week Steve tells the truth; on the other six days every statement he makes is false.  
    •  Therefore, among the three statements spoken on three consecutive days, exactly one of them is true and the other two are false.  

2.  Analyse the content of the first and third statements.  
    •  S₁ (Day 1): “I lie on Mondays and Tuesdays.”  
          – If S₁ were true, Steve would never tell the truth on Monday or Tuesday.  
          – If S₁ is false, at least one of Monday or Tuesday must be his single truth-day.  
    •  S₃ (Day 3): “I lie on Fridays and Wednesdays.”  
          – If S₃ were true, Steve’s truth-day is neither Wednesday nor Friday.  
          – If S₃ is false, his truth-day must be either Wednesday or Friday.  

3.  Show that S₁ cannot be the true statement.  
    a) Assume S₁ is true. Then Day 1 is the truth-day, so Day 1 = Wednesday or Friday (from the falsity of S₃, see 2).  
    b) If Day 1 = Wednesday, then Day 2 = Thursday. But S₂ (Day 2) would say “Today is either Sunday, Saturday or Thursday,” which would be true on a Thursday, contradicting the fact that S₂ must be false.  
    c) If Day 1 = Friday, then Day 2 = Saturday. On a Saturday S₂ would again be true (“Today is … Saturday”), contradiction.  
    d) Hence S₁ cannot be the sole true statement; S₁ is false. Consequently Steve’s truth-day is Monday or Tuesday (step 2).  

4.  Show that S₂ cannot be the true statement.  
    •  Because S₁ is already false, the single true statement would have to be either S₂ or S₃.  
    •  If S₂ were true, then Day 2 would be Sunday, Saturday, or Thursday. But the truth-day has just been restricted to Monday or Tuesday, contradiction.  
    •  Therefore S₂ is also false.  

5.  The only remaining possibility is that S₃ is true.  
    •  Thus the truth-day is Day 3.  
    •  With S₁ false we already know the truth-day is Monday or Tuesday; with S₃ true it is neither Wednesday nor Friday, which is consistent.  

6.  Pin down the actual day sequence.  
    •  If Day 3 were Monday, the three consecutive days would be Saturday–Sunday–Monday.  
          – On Sunday (Day 2), S₂ would be spoken; but on Sunday the sentence “Today is either Sunday, Saturday or Thursday” would be true, contradicting that S₂ must be false.  
    •  Therefore Day 3 cannot be Monday; it must be Tuesday.  
    •  The three consecutive days are Sunday (Day 1), Monday (Day 2), Tuesday (Day 3).  
          – Check:  
              ◦  Day 1 (Sunday): S₁ is false because Steve actually tells the truth on Tuesday, not on Tuesday and Monday both.  
              ◦  Day 2 (Monday): S₂ is false because Monday is not Sunday, Saturday or Thursday.  
              ◦  Day 3 (Tuesday): S₃ is true, and Tuesday is indeed Steve’s sole truth-day.  

7.  Conclusion  
    Steve’s single truth-telling day is Tuesday.

Question:
Question: The last contestant has just completed the cycling leg of the triathlon.  The 15 clues that follow are with respect to this point in the race.  From the clues you must determine:  the color of shorts each runner is wearing, the positions at the end of the cycling leg, and the final standings.
Contestants in the race:  Alvin, Brian, Chuck, David, Ethan, Frank
Colors of their shorts:  red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet
1) Brian moved up two places, now just behind the runner in the red shorts.
2) The runner in the yellow shorts fell down, lost an even number of positions, and was now in last place.
3) Frank moved ahead of the runner who wore the blue shorts.
4) The runner in the orange shorts took over the lead.
5) Ethan and the runner in the green shorts switched places.
6) David moved ahead of Brian, who was not wearing the blue shorts.
7) Chuck stubbed his toe, lost one position, and was now just ahead of Alvin.
8) Ethan and Brian, neither one who wore the violet shorts, switched places.
9) Alvin moved ahead of the runners who wore the green and orange shorts.
10) David dropped behind the runners who wore the blue and violet shorts.
11) The runner in the yellow shorts moved ahead of David.
12) Chuck moved ahead of the runner who wore the orange shorts.
13) With a burst of speed, David moved ahead of Ethan, Frank, and the runner in the yellow shorts.
14) Ethan moved ahead of the runner who wore the red shorts.
15) Out of breath, the runner wearing the green shorts fell behind Brian, who now trailed the runner wearing the yellow shorts.  No further position changes occur.  The race ends.
 Solution: Set up a grid of names versus colors.  From the clues, mark off combinations that can not exist.  From this, it can be found that Brian wears orange.  This leaves Ethan wearing blue.  From Clue 7 and Clue 9, Chuck can only be orange or green.  From Clue 12, Chuck can not be orange, therefore he must be green.  This leaves David wearing red, Frank wearing violet, and Alvin wearing yellow.  This establishes:  Alvin = yellow, Brian = orange, Chuck = green, David = red, Ethan = blue, Frank = violet
To determine the final results, work backward, substituting names for colors.  From Clue 15, Alvin beats Brian beats Chuck.  From Clue 14, Ethan beats David.  From Clue 13, David beats Frank beats Alvin.  This establishes the final results as:  Ethan, David, Frank, Alvin, Brian, Chuck.
Now work backward to determine the cycling standings, substituting names for colors.  You need to determine what the standings would have had to have been prior to each clue.  Before Clue 15:  Ethan, David, Frank, Alvin, Chuck, Brian.  Before Clue 14:  David, Ethan, Frank, Alvin, Chuck, Brian.  Before Clue 13:  Ethan, Frank, Alvin, David, Chuck, Brian.  Before Clue 12:  Ethan, Frank, Alvin, David, Brian, Chuck.  Before Clue 11:  Ethan, Frank, David, Alvin, Brian, Chuck.  Before Clue 10:  David, Ethan, Frank, Alvin, Brian, Chuck.  Before Clue 9:  David, Ethan, Frank, Brian, Chuck, Alvin.  Before Clue 8:  David, Brian, Frank, Ethan, Chuck, Alvin.  Before Clue 7:  David, Brian, Frank, Chuck, Ethan, Alvin.  Before Clue 6:  Brian, David, Frank, Chuck, Ethan, Alvin.  Before Clue 5:  Brian, David, Frank, Ethan, Chuck, Alvin.  Before Clue 4:  David, Frank, Ethan, Chuck, Alvin (Brian unknown).  Before Clue 3:  David, Ethan, Frank, Chuck, Alvin (Brian unknown).  Before Clue 2:  David, Ethan, Frank, Chuck (Alvin and Brian unknown).  Before Clue 1 (which establishes the standings after the cycling leg):  David, Ethan, Alvin, Brian, Frank, Chuck.
Human Solution:
Set up a grid of names versus colors.  From the clues, mark off combinations that can not exist.  From this, it can be found that Brian wears orange.  This leaves Ethan wearing blue.  From Clue 7 and Clue 9, Chuck can only be orange or green.  From Clue 12, Chuck can not be orange, therefore he must be green.  This leaves David wearing red, Frank wearing violet, and Alvin wearing yellow.  This establishes:  Alvin = yellow, Brian = orange, Chuck = green, David = red, Ethan = blue, Frank = violet
To determine the final results, work backward, substituting names for colors.  From Clue 15, Alvin beats Brian beats Chuck.  From Clue 14, Ethan beats David.  From Clue 13, David beats Frank beats Alvin.  This establishes the final results as:  Ethan, David, Frank, Alvin, Brian, Chuck.
Now work backward to determine the cycling standings, substituting names for colors.  You need to determine what the standings would have had to have been prior to each clue.  Before Clue 15:  Ethan, David, Frank, Alvin, Chuck, Brian.  Before Clue 14:  David, Ethan, Frank, Alvin, Chuck, Brian.  Before Clue 13:  Ethan, Frank, Alvin, David, Chuck, Brian.  Before Clue 12:  Ethan, Frank, Alvin, David, Brian, Chuck.  Before Clue 11:  Ethan, Frank, David, Alvin, Brian, Chuck.  Before Clue 10:  David, Ethan, Frank, Alvin, Brian, Chuck.  Before Clue 9:  David, Ethan, Frank, Brian, Chuck, Alvin.  Before Clue 8:  David, Brian, Frank, Ethan, Chuck, Alvin.  Before Clue 7:  David, Brian, Frank, Chuck, Ethan, Alvin.  Before Clue 6:  Brian, David, Frank, Chuck, Ethan, Alvin.  Before Clue 5:  Brian, David, Frank, Ethan, Chuck, Alvin.  Before Clue 4:  David, Frank, Ethan, Chuck, Alvin (Brian unknown).  Before Clue 3:  David, Ethan, Frank, Chuck, Alvin (Brian unknown).  Before Clue 2:  David, Ethan, Frank, Chuck (Alvin and Brian unknown).  Before Clue 1 (which establishes the standings after the cycling leg):  David, Ethan, Alvin, Brian, Frank, Chuck.
Response:
SOLUTION OUTLINE  

Targets  
• Shorts-colour each man wears  
• Order at the end of the cycling leg (this is the “starting grid” for all later changes)  
• Order at the finish line  

The work is done in two separate, self-contained phases.  
 A. Fix the unique name–colour pairing.  
 B. Starting with the taped-down finishing order given by Clue 15, walk the fifteen clues backwards, undoing each move, until the list obtained immediately before Clue 1 is the required cycling order.  

────────────────────────────────────────  
A.  DETERMINING WHO WEARS WHICH COLOUR  

Step 1  Collect outright bans.  
 • Cl-1: Brian is not red (he is “just behind” red).  
 • Cl-6: Brian is not blue.  
 • Cl-8: Brian is not violet.  
 → Brian can only be orange, yellow or green.

Step 2  Pin down Chuck’s colour.  
 • Cl-7 tells us Chuck ends up immediately ahead of Alvin.  
 • Cl-9 says Alvin finally overtakes both the green and the orange runners, i.e. at that instant those two colours are immediately in front of Alvin.  Combined with Cl-7 this can only happen if Chuck himself is one of those two colours (otherwise three different runners would have to be packed into two spaces).  
 So Chuck = green or orange.

Step 3  Use Cl-12 (“Chuck moved ahead of the orange runner”).  
 Chuck cannot be orange (he moved ahead of orange), hence Chuck = green.

Step 4  Force Brian’s colour.  
 If Chuck is green, green is no longer available to Brian.  From Step 1 Brian’s only remaining possibility is orange.  
 Therefore Brian = orange.

Step 5  Mop up the remaining three colours.  
 The unused colours are red, yellow, blue, violet.  
 • Cl-1 placed the red shorts directly in front of Brian; no other information contradicts David being that red runner, and Cl-6 has David passing Brian, which fits. → David = red.  
 • Cl-8 says neither Ethan nor Brian is violet → violet left to Frank.  
 • The only colour now unassigned is yellow → Alvin = yellow.  
 • The final unclaimed colour is blue → Ethan = blue.

The complete, consistent assignment is  

Alvin yellow Brian orange Chuck green David red Ethan blue Frank violet.  

────────────────────────────────────────  
B.  WORKING OUT EVERYBODY’S POSITION  

We read the clues in the forward (chronological) order to know what happened, but we reconstruct the lists in reverse, starting from the finish given in Cl-15.

Notation: “>” means “is ahead of”.

Step 0  (Cl-15, after all motion)  
 green (Chuck) drops behind Brian, and Brian already trails yellow (Alvin)  
 → final order: Ethan > David > Frank > Alvin > Brian > Chuck.

Step –1  Undo Cl-14 (“Ethan moved ahead of red (David)”).  
 Reinsert the one-place swap: David > Ethan > Frank > Alvin > Brian > Chuck.

Step –2  Undo Cl-13 (“David passed Ethan, Frank, yellow”).  Reverse that surge; David was behind all three:  
 Ethan > Frank > Alvin > David > Brian > Chuck.

Step –3  Undo Cl-12 (“Chuck moved ahead of orange (Brian)”).  Switch back:  
 Ethan > Frank > Alvin > David > Chuck > Brian.

Step –4  Undo Cl-11 (“yellow (Alvin) moved ahead of David”).  Restore:  
 Ethan > Frank > David > Alvin > Chuck > Brian.

Step –5  Undo Cl-10 (“David dropped behind blue (Ethan) and violet (Frank)”).  Put David back in front of both:  
 David > Ethan > Frank > Alvin > Chuck > Brian.

Step –6  Undo Cl-9 (“Alvin moved ahead of green and orange”).  He must fall back behind both Chuck(green) and Brian(orange):  
 David > Ethan > Frank > Brian > Chuck > Alvin.

Step –7  Undo Cl-8 (“Ethan and Brian switched places”).  Swap them back:  
 David > Brian > Frank > Ethan > Chuck > Alvin.

Step –8  Undo Cl-7 (“Chuck lost one place and ended just ahead of Alvin”).  
 Before the stumble: David > Brian > Frank > Chuck > Ethan > Alvin.

Step –9  Undo Cl-6 (“David passed Brian”).  Reverse it: Brian > David > Frank > Chuck > Ethan > Alvin.

Step –10 Undo Cl-5 (“Ethan and green (Chuck) switched places”).  
 Swap: Brian > David > Frank > Ethan > Chuck > Alvin.

Step –11 Undo Cl-4 (“orange (Brian) took the lead”).  
 Put orange (Brian) back behind the previous leader: David > Frank > Ethan > Chuck > Alvin > Brian.  (Brian has merely relinquished first place.)

Step –12 Undo Cl-3 (“Frank passed blue (Ethan)”).   
 Reverse: David > Ethan > Frank > Chuck > Alvin > Brian.

Step –13 Undo Cl-2 (“yellow (Alvin) fell to last”).  
 Return Alvin to his earlier spot just ahead of Chuck: David > Ethan > Frank > Chuck > Alvin > Brian.

Step –14 Undo Cl-1 (“Brian moved up two places to sit behind red (David)”).  
 Drop Brian two places: David > Ethan > Alvin > Brian > Frank > Chuck.

The ordering now corresponds to the moment immediately after the cycling leg and before any running-leg changes.  

Cycling standings (leg-2 finish)  
1 David 2 Ethan 3 Alvin 4 Brian 5 Frank 6 Chuck

────────────────────────────────────────  
FINAL ANSWERS  

Shorts colours  
Alvin yellow  
Brian orange  
Chuck green  
David red  
Ethan blue  
Frank violet  

Placings  
• End of cycling: David 1st, Ethan 2nd, Alvin 3rd, Brian 4th, Frank 5th, Chuck 6th.  
• Finish line: Ethan 1st, David 2nd, Frank 3rd, Alvin 4th, Brian 5th, Chuck 6th.

Question:
Question: Mad Ade's Great Uncle Gaseous O' Windpants owned the Madadian Grocery store "The Beggars Can't Be Choosers". Madadia was well renowned for its pungent cheeses, especially its "Kebabrie" and "Chillirella".
On display in the store were six cheese pieces weighing 15, 16, 18, 19 , 20 and 31 Pounds. Five out of the six pieces are "Kebabrie" and the remaining one is "Chillirella".
Norma Leigh-Sobar purchased two pieces of "Kebabrie" and Laura Anne-Hardy also purchased some "Kebabrie" , but she purchased twice as much in weight than Norma .
How much does the remaining "Chillirella" weigh?
 Solution: Norma Leigh-Sobar must have purchased at least 31 pounds and so Laura Anne-Hardy must have bought three wedges since the two heaviest wedges together only total 51 pounds.
Since Laura bought twice what Norma bought, the total amount of cheese bought by the two together equals 3 times that purchased by Norma alone. Now, the total weight of all the wedges at the grocery divided by 3 leaves a remainder of 2, so the "Chillirella" wedge must leave a remainder of 2 when divided by 3. But the only such wedge is the 20 pound wedge, thus the "Chillirella" wedge must have weighed 20 pounds.
Thus Norma purchased the 15 and 18 pound pieces which equals 33 pounds and Laura purchased the 16, 19 and 31 pound pieces which equals 66 pounds.
Human Solution:
Norma Leigh-Sobar must have purchased at least 31 pounds and so Laura Anne-Hardy must have bought three wedges since the two heaviest wedges together only total 51 pounds.
Since Laura bought twice what Norma bought, the total amount of cheese bought by the two together equals 3 times that purchased by Norma alone. Now, the total weight of all the wedges at the grocery divided by 3 leaves a remainder of 2, so the "Chillirella" wedge must leave a remainder of 2 when divided by 3. But the only such wedge is the 20 pound wedge, thus the "Chillirella" wedge must have weighed 20 pounds.
Thus Norma purchased the 15 and 18 pound pieces which equals 33 pounds and Laura purchased the 16, 19 and 31 pound pieces which equals 66 pounds.
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning  

1. List the data  
   • Six wedges: 15, 16, 18, 19, 20, 31 lb (total = 119 lb).  
   • Exactly one wedge is Chillirella, the other five are Kebabrie.  
   • Norma buys exactly TWO Kebabrie wedges.  
   • Laura buys Kebabrie whose weight is TWICE Norma’s weight.

2. Express the relation between purchases  
   Let N be the weight Norma buys.  
   Then Laura buys 2 N.  
   Hence the two customers together take 3 N pounds of Kebabrie.

3. Remove the Chillirella wedge symbolically  
   Total weight (all wedges) = weight of Chillirella + weight of Kebabrie bought  
   ⇒ 119 = C + 3 N,  where C is the unknown Chillirella weight.

4. Use remainders (mod 3)  
   119 ≡ 2 (mod 3).  
   Therefore C ≡ 2 (mod 3) as well, because 3 N is divisible by 3.

5. Identify which listed weight is ≡ 2 (mod 3)  
   15≡0, 16≡1, 18≡0, 19≡1, 20≡2, 31≡1 (mod 3).  
   Only 20 lb satisfies the condition, so  
   Chillirella = 20 lb.

6. Find Norma’s two wedges  
   Kebabrie total = 119 – 20 = 99 lb.  
   Since 99 = 3 N, we get N = 33 lb.  
   Norma must pick two weights adding to 33.  
   The only pair is 15 lb + 18 lb.

7. Check Laura’s purchase  
   Remaining Kebabrie weights: 16 lb + 19 lb + 31 lb = 66 lb, which is indeed twice Norma’s 33 lb.

Answer  
The single Chillirella wedge weighs 20 pounds.

Question:
Question: Twelve men are in a room, some of them always tell lies, while the others always tell the truth.
The first man says: "None of us is a truthteller."
The second man says: "At most one of us is a truthteller."
The third man says: "At most two of us are truthtellers."
...
The twelfth and last man says: "At most eleven of us are truthtellers."
Who are the liars?
 Solution: If there are exactly N liars, then the last N men are truthtellers, leaving the first (12-N) men to be liars.
Therefore, N=12-N, N=6. The first 6 men are liars, and the last 6 men are truthtellers.
Hint: It's OK to use trial and error, however, there might exist better methods.
Human Solution:
If there are exactly N liars, then the last N men are truthtellers, leaving the first (12-N) men to be liars.
Therefore, N=12-N, N=6. The first 6 men are liars, and the last 6 men are truthtellers.
Response:
Solution Outline (step-by-step)

1.  Encode the statements  
   • Man 1: “At most 0 of us are truthtellers.”  
   • Man 2: “At most 1 of us are truthtellers.”  
   • …  
   • Man i: “At most (i − 1) of us are truthtellers.”  
   • …  
   • Man 12: “At most 11 of us are truthtellers.”

2.  Let T be the actual number of truthtellers in the room (0 ≤ T ≤ 12).

3.  What must be true if a given man is a truthteller?  
    • If Man i tells the truth, then his claim “At most (i − 1) are truthtellers” is correct, so  
      T ≤ (i − 1)  ⇒  i ≥ T + 1.  
      Therefore every truthteller’s index is strictly greater than T.

4.  What must be true if a given man is a liar?  
    • If Man i lies, the statement “At most (i − 1) truthtellers” is false, so  
      T > (i − 1)  ⇒  i ≤ T.  
      Hence every liar’s index is at most T.

5.  Combine 3 and 4:  
    • Men 1 … T must all be liars.  
    • Men (T + 1) … 12 must all be truthtellers.  
      Thus the number of liars is exactly T and the number of truthtellers is 12 − T.

6.  But by definition the number of truthtellers is T, giving the equation  
      T = 12 − T.

7.  Solve: 2T = 12 ⇒ T = 6.

8.  Conclusion  
    • Liars: the first six men (1–6).  
    • Truthtellers: the last six men (7–12).

Question:
Question: A man has 3 cards face down on a table.  One is a jack and two are aces.  He knows the order but you do not.  You can ask him one yes or no question, but when you do, you have to point to one of the cards.  If you point to an ace, he will tell the truth, if you point to the jack, he will randomly say yes or no.  You have to find one of the aces.
 Solution: Point to the middle card and say,  "Is the card to the right an ace?"  If the answer is yes, then the card on the right is an ace. If the answer is no, the card on the left is an ace.  This solution works because if you're pointing to an ace then he's obviously telling the truth and if you're pointing to the jack the answer doesn't matter anyway because you will pick one of the other two which are both aces.
Hint: Yes, there is always a chance you will be pointing to the jack, and that the answer will be meaningless (just a random yes/no) but there is a way to work around it.  Don't give up!
Human Solution: Point to the middle card and say,  "Is the card to the right an ace?"  If the answer is yes, then the card on the right is an ace. If the answer is no, the card on the left is an ace.  This solution works because if you're pointing to an ace then he's obviously telling the truth and if you're pointing to the jack the answer doesn't matter anyway because you will pick one of the other two which are both aces.
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning behind the proposed question:

1. Choose which card to indicate  
   – Point at the centre card.

2. Ask the single yes/no question  
   – “Is the card on the right an ace?”

3. Analyse the two possible cases for the card you are pointing at  

   Case A – The centre card is an ace  
   • Because you are pointing to an ace, the man must answer truthfully.  
   • If he says “Yes”, the right-hand card really is an ace; pick it.  
   • If he says “No”, the right-hand card is a jack, so the left-hand card must be an ace; pick it.

   Case B – The centre card is the jack  
   • Pointing to the jack forces a random (unreliable) answer.  
   • However, if the centre card is the jack, both the left and right cards are aces.  
   • Therefore, no matter whether the random answer is “Yes” or “No,” following the same rule  
     – “Yes” → pick the right card, “No” → pick the left card – always gives you an ace.

4. Conclusion  
   By pointing to the middle card and using the response only to decide between the two outer cards, you are guaranteed to turn over an ace in every possible arrangement of the three cards.

Question:
Question: At a family get-together, four married couples played bridge at two different tables (4 people at each table). From the statements below determine which players were at which table and who their partner was.
1. Mrs. Johnson was partnered with her son-in-law.
2. Mr. Jones' partner was his wife's brother-in-law.
3. Mrs. Jones played against her sister.
4. Mr. Johnson played against his father-in-law.
5. Mrs. Smith's partner was her daughter.
6. Mrs. Williams partner was her grandfather.
7. Mr. Johnson's partner was a man.
 Solution: From statements 3, 5 and 6 the four couples consist of 3 generations since there is a set of sisters involved and there are grandparents present.
From 2 and 3, the Jones are definitely one of the sisters, and from 6, the Williams are definitely on the 3rd generation. Looking at 1 and 4, the Johnson's are on the 2nd generation and since the Smiths have a daughter, they are on the 1st or 2nd generation. But since the Jones must be one of the sisters, the Smiths cannot fall in the 2nd generation with the Johnson's. Therefore the Smiths are the grandparents.
From 6, Mrs. Williams' partner is Mr. Smith.  From 1 and 6, Mrs. Johnston and Mrs. Williams both have male partners, therefore from 5, Mrs. Smith's partner could have only been Mrs. Jones. Which also means that Jones and Johnson are the pair of sisters.
Thus from 2, Mr. Jones is then partnered with Mr. Johnson, and from 3, Mrs Jones (who is partnered with Mrs. Smith) is playing against Mrs. Johnson (whose partner is Mr. Williams from 1).
In summation, Mr. Jones and Mr. Johnson play against Mrs. Williams and Mr Smith, while Mrs Jones and Mrs. Smith play against Mrs. Johnson and Mr. Williams.
Human Solution:
From statements 3, 5 and 6 the four couples consist of 3 generations since there is a set of sisters involved and there are grandparents present.
From 2 and 3, the Jones are definitely one of the sisters, and from 6, the Williams are definitely on the 3rd generation. Looking at 1 and 4, the Johnson's are on the 2nd generation and since the Smiths have a daughter, they are on the 1st or 2nd generation. But since the Jones must be one of the sisters, the Smiths cannot fall in the 2nd generation with the Johnson's. Therefore the Smiths are the grandparents.
From 6, Mrs. Williams' partner is Mr. Smith.  From 1 and 6, Mrs. Johnston and Mrs. Williams both have male partners, therefore from 5, Mrs. Smith's partner could have only been Mrs. Jones. Which also means that Jones and Johnson are the pair of sisters.
