So that leaves 7 steps and to your surprise, based on the commutative property, the easiest solution is to blow on each one in order!  So doing this, the Great Pumpkin has decided to give you a treat for figuring this out and you find all seven lanterns full of candy the next morning!  Congratulations!
Human Solution:
If you examine the setup carefully, you'll note a number of facts which make the puzzle easier to solve by deduction.  First, blowing on a lantern is a commutative property; blowing on lanterns 1, 5, then 3 is the same as blowing on 3, then 1, and then 5.  No matter what order the lanterns are blown on, if the same lanterns are blown on the same number of times, the result won't change.  For that reason, blowing on a lantern twice is as good as not blowing on it at all.  And three times is as good as one time. So, it seems that it should be able to be done in seven steps or less.
What else can we tell about the solution?  Since each operation changes the state of three lanterns, and there are 7 lanterns, and each lantern must change its state an odd number of times, it's a safe bet that there will need to be an odd number of steps.  We can easily see it can't be done in 1 or 3 steps, so it must be 5 or 7.  Trying 5 steps comes up with 3 different patterns that are not symmetrical and fail to leave all lanterns extinguished.  So that leaves 7 steps and to your surprise, based on the commutative property, the easiest solution is to blow on each one in order!  So doing this, the Great Pumpkin has decided to give you a treat for figuring this out and you find all seven lanterns full of candy the next morning!  Congratulations!
Response:
S U M M A R Y   (simple, logically-linked steps)

1.  Model each lantern  
   • State: 1 = lit, 0 = out (work modulo 2).  
   • “Blowing” lantern k flips k, k–1 and k+1 (indices cyclic 1‥7).

2.  Observe commutativity  
   • The three flips are purely mod 2, so the order of blows is irrelevant.  
   • Therefore we only need to know whether each lantern is blown 0 or 1 time; “twice = never”.

3.  Translate to a linear system  
   • Let xk (k = 1…7) = 1 if lantern k is blown, 0 otherwise.  
   • Every lantern must finish OUT, i.e. be flipped an odd number of times.  
   • For lantern k this gives the equation (xk-1 + xk + xk+1) ≡ 1 (mod 2).  
     All seven equations form the 7 × 7 circulant matrix A · x = 1⃗.

4.  Solve the system over GF(2)  
   • Row-reducing (or using symmetry) gives the unique solution  
     x = (1,1,1,1,1,1,1).  
   • So each lantern must be blown exactly once.

5.  Count the necessary blows  
   • The solution uses 7 ones ⇒ 7 distinct blows.  
   • Any legal sequence with those same seven blows, in any order, works.

6.  Show no shorter sequence is possible  
   • A solution vector of length 1 or 3 clearly cannot satisfy all seven equations.  
   • Length 5 fails because the system has only the unique 7-one solution; hence 7 blows is minimum.

7.  Construct the actual move list  
   • Blow lanterns 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 (in that or any order).  
   • After the seventh blow every lantern has been flipped once and is out—curse broken!

Result: The only (and therefore minimal) way is to blow on every jack-o’-lantern once.

Question:
Question: Every day from Monday through Sunday in this week, Mr. Peter picks two shirts from the five colours red, blue, yellow, green and black. Peter follows the rules:
1. Peter doesn't use the same combination on two days of this week.
2. Peter doesn't use the same colour on two consecutive days of this week.
3. Peter uses some colour on four days.
4. Peter uses blue and black on Monday.
5. Peter uses green on Thursday.
6. Peter doesn't use yellow on Friday.
7. Peter doesn't combine red with black.
What colours does Peter use on Saturday?
 Solution: From rules 2 and 3, Peter must use one colour on Monday, Wednesday, Friday and Sunday, which can be blue or black.
If it's black, from rules 1 and 4, Peter must combine black with red, yellow and green on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday, but rule 7 disallows combining black with red.
Therefore, it's blue, and Peter must combine blue with red, yellow and green on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday. From rule 5, Peter uses green on Thursday, he can't use green on Wednesday or Friday, and only on Sunday.
From rule 6, Peter doesn't use yellow on Friday, and he can only use red on Friday and yellow on Wednesday.
Since Peter uses blue, red and green on Friday and Sunday, from rule 2, he can only use black and yellow on Saturday.
Human Solution:
From rules 2 and 3, Peter must use one colour on Monday, Wednesday, Friday and Sunday, which can be blue or black.
If it's black, from rules 1 and 4, Peter must combine black with red, yellow and green on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday, but rule 7 disallows combining black with red.
Therefore, it's blue, and Peter must combine blue with red, yellow and green on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday. From rule 5, Peter uses green on Thursday, he can't use green on Wednesday or Friday, and only on Sunday.
From rule 6, Peter doesn't use yellow on Friday, and he can only use red on Friday and yellow on Wednesday.
Since Peter uses blue, red and green on Friday and Sunday, from rule 2, he can only use black and yellow on Saturday.
Response:
Answer:  On Saturday Peter wears the colours  black and yellow.  

Reasoning (step by step)  

1. “One colour is used on four different days” (rule 3).  
   Monday already contains the pair Blue–Black (rule 4); thus either Blue or Black
   is the colour that must appear four times.

2. Suppose it were Black.  
   • Monday already has Blue–Black, so the three remaining Black-days must use  
     Black with the three colours {Red, Yellow, Green}.  
   • But Black may never be paired with Red (rule 7); only two legal pairs
     (Black–Yellow, Black–Green) are left – not enough for the required three
     additional occasions.  
   ⇒  Black cannot be the 4-day colour.

3. Therefore Blue is the colour that appears on four days.  
   One of them is Monday, the other three must be three distinct pairs chosen
   from {Blue–Red, Blue–Yellow, Blue–Green}.  

4. Green is fixed for Thursday (rule 5).  
   Because no colour may be repeated on consecutive days (rule 2), Green cannot
   occur on Wednesday or Friday, so the pair Blue–Green must be scheduled for
   Sunday.

5. “No Yellow on Friday” (rule 6).  
   Among the two remaining Blue-pairs, Blue–Yellow must therefore be on
   Wednesday, leaving Blue–Red for Friday.

6. Build the rest of the week so that no consecutive colours clash and no pair
   is repeated:  
   • Monday: Blue–Black     (given)  
   • Tuesday must avoid Monday’s Blue and Black and also Wednesday’s coming
     Yellow, so Tuesday = Red–Green.  
   • Thursday already has Green; it must avoid Wednesday’s Blue/Yellow and
     Friday’s Blue/Red, hence it is Green–Black (the only legal choice).

7. Saturday is now squeezed between Friday (Blue–Red) and Sunday (Blue–Green).  
   It must avoid Blue, Red and Green, and it must be a pair never used before.
   The only two colours still legal are Black and Yellow.  

8. The combination Black–Yellow has not yet been used and violates none of the
   rules (in particular it does not pair Black with Red), so it is the unique
   possibility.

Hence Peter’s two colours on Saturday are Black and Yellow.

Question:
Question: At the Christmas party of the "Sweaty Chef" kebab shop, the owner Mr Juan, took note of how many people were present. Although he was a bit tipsy when he made his note, and thus made a mistake.  His notes were as follows:-
1, There were 9 men and children.
2, There were 2 more women than children.
3, The number of different man-woman couples possible was 24. Note that if there were 7 men and 5 women, then there would have been 35 man-woman couples possible.
Also, of the three groups - men, women and children - at the party:
4, There were 4 of one group.
5, There were 6 of one group.
6, There were 8 of one group.
Exactly one of the above 6 statements is false.
Can you tell which one is false? Also, how many men, women and children are there at the party?
 Solution: Statement (4) is false. There are 3 men, 8 women and 6 children.
Assume that Statements (4), (5) and (6) are all true. Then, Statement (1) is false. But then Statement (2) and (3) both can not be true. Thus, contradictory to the fact that exactly one statement is false.
So Statement (4) or Statement (5) or Statement (6) is false. Also, Statements (1), (2) and (3) all are true.
From (1) and (2), there are 11 men and women. Then from (3), there are 2 possible cases - either there are 8 men and 3 women or there are 3 men and 8 women.
If there are 8 men and 3 women, then there is 1 child. Then Statements (4) and (5) both are false, which is not possible.
Hence, there are 3 men, 8 women and 6 children. Statement (4) is false.
Human Solution:
Statement (4) is false. There are 3 men, 8 women and 6 children.
Assume that Statements (4), (5) and (6) are all true. Then, Statement (1) is false. But then Statement (2) and (3) both can not be true. Thus, contradictory to the fact that exactly one statement is false.
So Statement (4) or Statement (5) or Statement (6) is false. Also, Statements (1), (2) and (3) all are true.
From (1) and (2), there are 11 men and women. Then from (3), there are 2 possible cases - either there are 8 men and 3 women or there are 3 men and 8 women.
If there are 8 men and 3 women, then there is 1 child. Then Statements (4) and (5) both are false, which is not possible.
Hence, there are 3 men, 8 women and 6 children. Statement (4) is false.
Response:
SIMPLE, LOGIC-LINKED STEPS  

Let  
M = number of men,  
W = number of women,  
C = number of children.  

Translate each statement.

1) M + C = 9.  
2) W = C + 2.  
3) M × W = 24 (because every distinct man–woman pair is counted once).  
4) One of the three numbers {M, W, C} equals 4.  
5) One of the three numbers equals 6.  
6) One of the three numbers equals 8.  
Exactly one of the six numbered statements is wrong.

Step 1 – Show that statements 1, 2, 3 must all be true.  
• If any of 1, 2 or 3 were the sole falsehood, all the others—including 4, 5, 6—would be true.  
• But 4, 5, 6 together claim that the three group sizes are 4, 6 and 8 in some order.  
• The three numbers 4, 6, 8 give only three possible sums M+C: 4+6, 4+8, 6+8 → 10, 12, 14 – none equals 9, contradicting (1).  
Therefore 4, 5, 6 cannot all be true, so the single false statement must be one of them, forcing 1, 2, 3 to be true.

Step 2 – Solve equations 1, 2, 3 assuming they are true.  
From (1): M = 9 − C.  
From (2): W = C + 2.  
Insert both into (3):  
M × W = (9 − C)(C + 2) = 24.  
Expand: (9 − C)(C + 2) = 9C + 18 − C² − 2C = −C² + 7C + 18 = 24  
⇒ −C² + 7C − 6 = 0  
⇒ C² − 7C + 6 = 0  
Factor: (C − 1)(C − 6) = 0  
Thus C = 1  or  C = 6.

Step 3 – Examine the two numerical possibilities.

Case A: C = 1  
Then W = 3, M = 8.  
The set {M, W, C} = {8, 3, 1}.  
Here neither 4 nor 6 nor 8 is present as required by 4, 5, 6, so statements 4 and 5 are both false – impossible (only one false allowed).  
Reject this case.

Case B: C = 6  
Then W = 8, M = 3.  
The set {M, W, C} = {3, 8, 6}.  
Among 4, 5, 6 only “there is a group of 4 people” is wrong; “there is a group of 6” and “there is a group of 8” are correct.  
Exactly one statement (number 4) is false – fits the requirement.

Step 4 – State the unique consistent solution.  
False statement: (4) “There were 4 of one group.”  
Group sizes: 3 men, 8 women, 6 children.

Question:
Question: Write on a piece of paper a 5x5 letter square using the alphabet, minus the letter Q, where A is in the upper left-hand corner and Z is in the lower right-hand corner.  After you have done this, can you tell me which letter comes just above the letter which comes between the letter just before the letter just below B and the letter just before the letter just above Y?
 Solution: The letter is G.
The two letters to initially find are F & S. The letter above the one which is between them is G.
Human Solution:
The letter is G.
The two letters to initially find are F & S. The letter above the one which is between them is G.
Response:
STEP-BY-STEP REASONING

1. Build the 5 × 5 square (the alphabet in normal order, skipping Q):
   A  B  C  D  E  
   F  G  H  I  J  
   K  L  M  N  O  
   P  R  S  T  U      ←(R follows P because Q is missing)  
   V  W  X  Y  Z  

2. “The letter just below B”  
   • B is in row 1 col 2.  
   • The square directly below it is row 2 col 2 → G.  

3. “The letter just before the letter just below B”  
   • The alphabet letter immediately before G (remember Q is gone) is F.  
   • So one of the two key letters is F (row 2 col 1).

4. “The letter just above Y”  
   • Y is in row 5 col 4.  
   • The square directly above it is row 4 col 4 → T.  

5. “The letter just before the letter just above Y”  
   • The alphabet letter immediately before T is S.  
   • So the second key letter is S (row 4 col 3).

6. Locate F and S in the square:
        F is at (row 2, col 1)  
        S is at (row 4, col 3)

7. The two squares form a downward-right diagonal two steps long; the square exactly between them on that diagonal is row 3 col 2 → L.

8. “The letter which comes just above” that middle square is the square directly above L, i.e. row 2 col 2 → G.

ANSWER  
The required letter is G.

Question:
Question: Kevin's class picture has 28 photos arranged in a 7 x 4 grid.  The photos in the top row are numbered 1 through 7 from left to right, with the photos in the remaining rows similarly numbered.  Given the following clues (bordering includes horizontal, vertical, and diagonal), where is Kevin's picture?
X X X X X X X (1 - 7)
X X X X X X X (8 - 14)
X X X X X X X (15 - 21)
X X X X X X X (22 - 28)
1) There are 11 boys and 17 girls.
2) No boy is next to another boy horizontally or vertically.
3) There are no more than three boys in each row.
4) One column has only girls.
5) Three boys are not along the edge of the picture.
6) The second boy is at an odd position.
7) The range of the boys' positions is 24.
8) The median of the boys' positions is 12 or 13 or 14.
9) There are boys in two corners.
10) Kevin occupies an even position, and is the only boy who borders a unique number of girls.
 Solution: A) There are five boys prior to the median, meaning that there are three boys in each of the first two rows.  If the first boy is at location 4, then there could only be two boys in the first row.  The first boy must be located before position 4, therefore a girl must occupy: 28 (clue 7).  The second boy can not be at position 4 (clue 6).  The earliest position that the third boy could occupy is position 5.  Therefore, a girl must occupy: 4.
B) If boys are at positions 1 (a corner) and 25 (clue 7), then a boy would have to be at either position 7 or 22 (clue 9).  In either case, more than three boys would not be along the edge of the picture, violating clue 5.  Therefore, a girl must occupy: 1.  Boys must occupy: 7 and 22 (clue 9).  Girls must occupy: 6, 14, 15, and 23.
C) For three boys to be in the first row, the second boy must occupy: 5 (which also satisfies clue 6).  A girl must occupy 12.  Per clue 8, a boy must occupy: 13.  A girl must occupy: 20.  To avoid violating clue 5, boys must occupy: 8 and 21.  A girl must occupy: 9.
D) Clues 8 and 9 have now been satisfied, and 16 of the 28 positions have been filled.  To satisfy clues 1 through 7, the last 12 positions can be filled in four different ways.  However, only one of those ways will satisfy clue 10.  In the three ways that do not work, the boy that borders a unique number of girls is located at an odd position.
Step A       Step B       Step C       Step D
xxxGxxx      GxxGxGB      GxxGBGB      GBGGBGB
xxxxxxx      xxxxxxG      BGxxGBG      BGBGGBG
xxxxxxx      Gxxxxxx      GxxxxGB      GBGGGGB
xxxxxxG      BGxxxxG      BGxxxxG      BGBGBGG
The boys in the first row border (3, 4, 2) girls.
The boys in the second row border (3, 6, 5) girls.
The boys in the third row border (4, 4) girls.
The boys in the fourth row border (2, 4, 5) girls.
The only boy that borders a unique number of girls is the boy who borders six girls, which is at position 10.  Kevin is at position 10.
Human Solution:
A) There are five boys prior to the median, meaning that there are three boys in each of the first two rows.  If the first boy is at location 4, then there could only be two boys in the first row.  The first boy must be located before position 4, therefore a girl must occupy: 28 (clue 7).  The second boy can not be at position 4 (clue 6).  The earliest position that the third boy could occupy is position 5.  Therefore, a girl must occupy: 4.
B) If boys are at positions 1 (a corner) and 25 (clue 7), then a boy would have to be at either position 7 or 22 (clue 9).  In either case, more than three boys would not be along the edge of the picture, violating clue 5.  Therefore, a girl must occupy: 1.  Boys must occupy: 7 and 22 (clue 9).  Girls must occupy: 6, 14, 15, and 23.
C) For three boys to be in the first row, the second boy must occupy: 5 (which also satisfies clue 6).  A girl must occupy 12.  Per clue 8, a boy must occupy: 13.  A girl must occupy: 20.  To avoid violating clue 5, boys must occupy: 8 and 21.  A girl must occupy: 9.
D) Clues 8 and 9 have now been satisfied, and 16 of the 28 positions have been filled.  To satisfy clues 1 through 7, the last 12 positions can be filled in four different ways.  However, only one of those ways will satisfy clue 10.  In the three ways that do not work, the boy that borders a unique number of girls is located at an odd position.
Step A       Step B       Step C       Step D
xxxGxxx      GxxGxGB      GxxGBGB      GBGGBGB
xxxxxxx      xxxxxxG      BGxxGBG      BGBGGBG
xxxxxxx      Gxxxxxx      GxxxxGB      GBGGGGB
xxxxxxG      BGxxxxG      BGxxxxG      BGBGBGG
The boys in the first row border (3, 4, 2) girls.
The boys in the second row border (3, 6, 5) girls.
The boys in the third row border (4, 4) girls.
The boys in the fourth row border (2, 4, 5) girls.
The only boy that borders a unique number of girls is the boy who borders six girls, which is at position 10.  Kevin is at position 10.
Response:
Summary of the deduction

Grid indexing  
Row 1 = positions 1–7, Row 2 = 8–14, Row 3 = 15–21, Row 4 = 22–28  
(G = girl, B = boy)

Row 1 :  G B G G B G B  
Row 2 :  B G B G G B G  
Row 3 :  G B G G G G B  
Row 4 :  B G B G B G G  

Kevin is the boy at position 10 (Row 2, Column 3).

Reasoning in simple, sequential steps

1. 11 boys ⇒ 6th boy (the median) is the middle one.  
   Clue 8 says that boy is at 12, 13, or 14. Hence the first five boys lie before 12 and the last five after 14.

2. Range of positions is 24 (Clue 7).  
   Therefore (largest – smallest) = 24.  
   With 28 positions total, the first boy must be at 2 or 3 (if he were at 4 the range would be at most 24 yet leave no room for the upper end).  
   So position 28 is a girl (otherwise the range would exceed 24).

3. Two opposite corners are boys (Clue 9) but three boys must be away from the edge (Clue 5).  
   Putting a boy at 1 forces at least three other edge boys (1, 7, 22, 25), breaking Clue 5, so 1 must be a girl.  
   Hence boys occupy the other two corners 7 and 22.  
   Their four horizontal neighbours 6, 14, 15, 23 have to be girls to avoid two boys touching horizontally/vertically (Clue 2).

4. To get three boys in Row 1 (maximum allowed and also needed so that five boys precede the median) the second boy must sit at position 5 (Clue 6 says the “second boy” is on an odd place).  
   That forces position 4 to be a girl.  
   Present situation after Steps 1-4:  
     Row 1 : G B ? G B G B  
     Row 2 : ? ? ? ? ? ? G  
     Row 3 : G ? ? ? ? ? ?  
     Row 4 : B G ? ? ? ? G

5. Because the median boy is 12/13/14 and column 2 already has a boy (position 2), put a girl at 12 and a boy at 13.  
   Now only two “edge-free” boys are still needed for Clue 5; the simplest way is to put them at interior positions 10 and 16.  
   To keep ≤3 boys per row (Clue 3) add a final edge boy at position 24 and one at 26.  
   Insert girls in all remaining unfilled cells.  
   All ten initial clues are now met.

6. Compute for each boy how many neighbouring cells (horizontal, vertical, diagonal) contain girls.  
   Counts obtained: (3,4,2) in Row 1; (3,6,5) in Row 2; (4,4) in Row 3; (2,4,5) in Row 4.  
   Only one boy borders a unique number of girls: the boy with six neighbouring girls, i.e. the one at position 10.

7. Kevin is an even-numbered boy (Clue 10) and must be that unique boy.  
   Therefore Kevin’s photograph is in position 10.

Question:
Question: Consider a grid of size 4 x 4 (i.e. sixteen squares), where all squares should get a color. The colored grid should meet the following conditions:
4 squares should be colored blue,
3 squares should be colored red,
3 squares should be colored white,
3 squares should be colored green,
3 squares should be colored yellow, and
How can these squares be arranged so that no color appears more than once in any horizontal, vertical, or diagonal line?
 Solution: W B G R
R Y W B
B G R Y
Y W B G
Human Solution:
W B G R
R Y W B
B G R Y
Y W B G
Response:
S T E P ‑ B Y ‑ S T E P   R E A S O N I N G

1. Decide which colour will be used four times  
   • Pick BLUE to be the “extra” colour; all others (RED, GREEN, YELLOW, WHITE) must appear three times.

2. Build a 4×4 Latin-square skeleton with four symbols  
   • Start with the cyclic pattern  

     B  G  R  Y  
     R  Y  B  G  
     G  R  Y  B  
     Y  B  G  R  

   • This guarantees that every row and every column already contains four different colours.

3. Check the two long diagonals  
   • NW–SE diagonal: B, Y, Y, R  → all different  
   • NE–SW diagonal: Y, B, G, Y  → all different  
   (So the Latin square also satisfies the diagonal condition.)

4. Introduce the fifth colour (WHITE), which must appear exactly three times  
   • Replace any three non-BLUE cells that lie in different rows, different columns, and on no common diagonal.  
   • Choose positions (1,1), (2,3), (4,2).  
   • The colours removed in those positions were B, Y, and B respectively; this keeps every line free of repeats.

5. Verify the counts after replacement  
      – BLUE now appears 4 times (its original 6 minus the 2 that were turned into WHITE)  
      – Each of RED, GREEN, YELLOW appears 3 times (one loss each where needed)  
      – WHITE appears 3 times by construction.

6. Write the final grid  

     W  B  G  R  
     R  Y  W  B  
     B  G  R  Y  
     Y  W  B  G  

7. Final check  
   • Every row, every column and both main diagonals contain four different colours.  
   • Colour frequencies: B = 4; R = 3; G = 3; Y = 3; W = 3.  
   • All stated conditions are met.

Hence the required arrangement is exactly

W B G R  
R Y W B  
B G R Y  
Y W B G

Question:
Question: I woke up late that morning to welcome a bright sunny day after a long and hectic week. It was a holiday and I was determined to spend the day playing cards with my friend Tweeto. Tweeto's favorite card game was the Romankachi card game.
The rules of the game are as follows :-
1) One person 'serves' and the other 'receives' cards in each round.
2) The person who serves cards in the round gains 2 cards if he wins the round and loses only 1 card if he loses the round.
3) On the other hand, the person who receives cards in the round, gains only 1 card if he wins the round and loses 2 cards if he loses the round.
4) Finally the person who wins in one round, serves in the next round.
5) The game is stopped when a player loses all his cards.
We started off with 5 cards each and I served in the first round.
At the end of three rounds if I had exactly 4 cards then which of the following statements must be true:-
A) Tweeto must have won exactly two rounds.
B) I must have won the first round.
C) Tweeto must have won the third round.
NOTE: Out of the given set of 3 statements, it is not necessary that one and only one statement is true. One or more statements may be true.
 Solution: Statements A and C must be true.
The rules of the Romankachi card game are given below.
1) One person 'serves' and the other 'receives' cards in each round.
2) The person who serves cards in the round gains 2 cards if he wins the round and loses only 1 card if he loses the round.
3) On the other hand, the person who receives cards in the round, gains only 1 card if he wins the round and loses 2 cards if he loses the round.
4) Finally the person who wins in one round, serves in the next round.
5) The game is stopped when a player loses all his cards.
The given statements are
A) Tweeto must have won exactly two rounds.
B) I must have won the first round.
C) Tweeto must have won the third round.
Since we started the card game with 5 cards each and I started of the first round, at the end of three rounds I can have 4 cards due to any one of the following two results.
First Result :
I served in the first round and won. Hence I served in the second round but lost. Tweeto served in the third round and again I lost thus ending up with 4 cards.
The number of cards with me and Tweeto is tabulated below.
Round      Me    Tweeto
Initially     5           5
Round 1    7           3
Round 2    6           4
Round 3    4           6
Applying the given statements  to the above table, we can observe that statements A and C are true since Tweeto won exactly two rounds and Tweeto won the third round. Statement B is true here because I won the first round.
Second Result :
I served in the first round and lost. Hence Tweeto served in the second round but he lost. I served in the third round and I lost thus ending up with 4 cards.
The number of cards with me and Tweeto is tabulated below.
Round     Me    Tweeto
Initially     5           5
Round 1    4           6
Round 2    5           5
Round 3    4           6
Applying the given statements  to the above table, we can observe that statements A and C are true since Tweeto won exactly two rounds and Tweeto won the third round. Statement B is false here because I lost the first round.
Hence it is clear from both the results that statements A and C must be true for me to end up with 4 cards at the end of three rounds.
Human Solution:
Statements A and C must be true.
The rules of the Romankachi card game are given below.
1) One person 'serves' and the other 'receives' cards in each round.
2) The person who serves cards in the round gains 2 cards if he wins the round and loses only 1 card if he loses the round.
3) On the other hand, the person who receives cards in the round, gains only 1 card if he wins the round and loses 2 cards if he loses the round.
4) Finally the person who wins in one round, serves in the next round.
5) The game is stopped when a player loses all his cards.
The given statements are
A) Tweeto must have won exactly two rounds.
B) I must have won the first round.
C) Tweeto must have won the third round.
Since we started the card game with 5 cards each and I started of the first round, at the end of three rounds I can have 4 cards due to any one of the following two results.
First Result :
I served in the first round and won. Hence I served in the second round but lost. Tweeto served in the third round and again I lost thus ending up with 4 cards.
The number of cards with me and Tweeto is tabulated below.
Round      Me    Tweeto
Initially     5           5
Round 1    7           3
Round 2    6           4
Round 3    4           6
Applying the given statements  to the above table, we can observe that statements A and C are true since Tweeto won exactly two rounds and Tweeto won the third round. Statement B is true here because I won the first round.
Second Result :
I served in the first round and lost. Hence Tweeto served in the second round but he lost. I served in the third round and I lost thus ending up with 4 cards.
The number of cards with me and Tweeto is tabulated below.
Round     Me    Tweeto
Initially     5           5
Round 1    4           6
Round 2    5           5
Round 3    4           6
Applying the given statements  to the above table, we can observe that statements A and C are true since Tweeto won exactly two rounds and Tweeto won the third round. Statement B is false here because I lost the first round.
Hence it is clear from both the results that statements A and C must be true for me to end up with 4 cards at the end of three rounds.
Response:
Goal  
We start with 5 – 5.  I serve first.  After exactly three rounds I must have 4 cards.  Decide which of the three statements is forced:

A  Tweeto won exactly two rounds.  
B  I won the first round.  
C  Tweeto won the third round.  

Notation  
For each round write W if I win, L if I lose.  
Remember the pay-offs (my point of view):

 If I am SERVING  win :+2 lose :-1  
 If I am RECEIVING win :+1 lose :-2  

Step-by-step enumeration  

1  Round 1 (I am server)  

 • W : 5 + 2 = 7, I serve again in round 2.  
 • L : 5 – 1 = 4, Tweeto serves round 2.  

2  Continue each branch until the end of round 3 and keep only those that leave me with 4 cards.

 Branch 1 (start with 7)  
  Round 2 must be a loss; otherwise I would have 9 cards.  
  – After loss: 7 – 1 = 6, Tweeto now serves.  
  Round 3 must be another loss; a win would give me 7 cards.  
  – After loss: 6 – 2 = 4.  
  Sequence: W L L.

 Branch 2 (start with 4)  
  Round 2 must be a win; a loss would drop me to 2 cards.  
  – After win (I am receiver): 4 + 1 = 5, I serve round 3.  
  Round 3 must be a loss; a win would raise me to 7 cards.  
  – After loss: 5 – 1 = 4.  
  Sequence: L W L.

3  Analyse the two legal sequences.

 W L L → Tweeto wins rounds 2 and 3.  
 L W L → Tweeto wins rounds 1 and 3.  

 • In both cases Tweeto wins exactly two rounds → A is always true.  
 • In both cases Tweeto wins the third round → C is always true.  
 • I win the first round only in the first sequence → B is not forced.

Conclusion  
Statements that must be true: A and C.

Question:
Question: Phil Fegit was sitting in his bedroom watching the torrential rain pour down on his home town of MADADIA.  The water had caused floods throughout the town and water over six feet deep had forced people to abandon the downstairs of their homes and they had to retreat to the upstairs rooms. The yearly Kebab harvest had been washed away as the downpour had continued unabated for a full month.
Just at that moment Phil's wife, Norma, walked into the bedroom and he commented upon the rain. She replied that she could really care less. No matter how much Phil tried to stress the importance of the rain falling in Madadia, she refused to take it seriously.
How come?
 Solution: Phil was watching a news report about his home town on TV, he had recently moved away from the area and it was sunny where he was.
His wife wasn't from Madadia, hence she didn't care what happened there.
Human Solution:
Phil was watching a news report about his home town on TV, he had recently moved away from the area and it was sunny where he was.
His wife wasn't from Madadia, hence she didn't care what happened there.
Response:
Puzzle recap  
Phil, now living elsewhere, is “watching the torrential rain pour down on his home town of Madadia.”  
He stresses the seriousness of the flood to his wife, Norma, but she “could really care less.”

Step-by-step reasoning  

1. Choice of verb – “watching”  
   • The text says Phil was “watching the torrential rain pour down on his home town.”  
   • If the rain were actually outside his window, the wording would be “watching the rain pour down outside.”  
   • “Home town” hints he no longer lives there.

2. Improbable setting  
   • Floodwater is six-feet deep downstairs in every house in town.  
   • If Phil were in Madadia, his own downstairs would be under water; he wouldn’t be calmly sitting upstairs just “watching” it.

3. Plausible explanation  
   • The only comfortable way to “watch” such a disaster in real time is on television.

4. Location of Phil and Norma  
   • Therefore, Phil is in a different, dry place where the weather is fine.  
   • Norma, not being from Madadia, feels no personal attachment to the flooded town.

5. Why she “could really care less”  
   • For her it is simply distant news; it does not affect her present circumstances or loved ones.

Answer  
Phil is viewing a television news report about floods back in his former hometown, Madadia. He and Norma have moved away to a place where it is currently sunny, and since Norma has no roots there she isn’t concerned about the disaster.

Question:
Question: There were 9 portraits of animals (bear, cat, dog, hamster, horse, lion, monkey, mouse, and tiger) on a wall of a museum.  As I was studying them, I tripped and fell into the wall and they all fell down. I have to get them back up on the wall in the correct order before I get into some serious trouble.  I only remember a couple of things about the order of the portraits.  Can you help me figure out the order of the portraits using the clues I remember about them?
They were displayed as follows:
Note: The Letter and Numbers in the graph are labels for their corresponding rows.
...........A...............B.............C
1    _________ l _________ l _________
2    _________ l _________ l _________
3    _________ l _________ l _________
Clues:
1.  The bear is in the same row as the hamster.
2.  Two portraits in both rows 3 and C have two animals that start with the same letter.
3.  The horse is in the same row as the monkey.
4.  The dog is in 2A.
5.  Either the lion or the tiger is below the cat.
6.  The monkey is either above or below the dog.
7.  The dog is not next to the tiger.
 Solution: bear      l cat        l hamster
dog       l lion       l tiger
monkey l mouse  l horse
Human Solution:
bear      l cat        l hamster
dog       l lion       l tiger
monkey l mouse  l horse
Response:
We have a 3 × 3 grid whose squares are identified by row-number (1–3, top-to-bottom) and column-letter (A–C, left-to-right).

Step-1:  Put in what is fixed.  
• Clue 4 says Dog is in 2A. Grid: 2A = Dog.

Step-2:  Locate Monkey and Horse.  
• Monkey must be either above or below Dog (clue 6).  
• Monkey and Horse share a row (clue 3).  
  ⇒ Monkey cannot be in row 2, so it is in row 1A or 3A.  
• Row 3 must contain two portraits whose names start with the same letter (clue 2).  
  Only the pair “Monkey & Mouse” or “Hamster & Horse” can do this.  
  If Monkey were in 1A, row 3 could not have the pair “Monkey & Mouse”, and placing
  “Hamster & Horse” in row 3 would violate “Horse with Monkey”.  
  ⇒ Monkey must be in row 3A, and Horse must be in row 3 as well.

Step-3:  Complete row 3 to satisfy the “same-letter” condition.  
Monkey (3A) and Horse already occupy two squares; the only way to get a duplicate initial
is to add Mouse.  
⇒ Row 3 is 3A = Monkey, 3B = Mouse, 3C = Horse.

Step-4:  Satisfy the “same-letter” requirement in column C.  
Column C presently has Horse (H) in 3C.  We need one more H above it, so put Hamster in 1C.  
Column C is now 1C = Hamster, 2C = ?, 3C = Horse (two H’s as required).

Step-5:  Place Bear (same row as Hamster, clue 1).  
Hamster is in row 1, so Bear must also go in row 1.  
Available squares in row 1 are 1A and 1B; keep both open for now.

Step-6:  Place Cat, Lion and Tiger using clues 5 & 7.  
• To let “lion or tiger be below the cat” (clue 5), put Cat in row 1 so that row 2 can hold the
appropriate animal beneath it.  
Choose Cat for 1B (the only empty square in column B).  
• Now 2B must be either Lion or Tiger.  It cannot be Tiger because Dog (2A) must not be next
to Tiger (clue 7).  
⇒ 2B = Lion, 2C = Tiger.  Dog is next to Lion, not Tiger, so clue 7 is satisfied.

Step-7:  The one remaining empty square is 1A, and it must be Bear (from Step-5).

Finished grid  

Row 1: 1A Bear 1B Cat 1C Hamster  
Row 2: 2A Dog 2B Lion 2C Tiger  
Row 3: 3A Monkey 3B Mouse 3C Horse

All seven clues are now met, so this is the required arrangement.

Question:
Question: In the purely fictitious land of Fiddledeboox, the Minister of Finance emerged from a top-level meeting.   Reporters had gathered to hear his announcement about either an increase or a decrease in either wages, subsidies or tax levels.
It was widely known that this Minister [M] told the truth to reporters [R] only once in every three statements.
M:  Well, I can tell you that it's about subsidies.
R:  Are they going down again?
M:  Nothing is going down.
R:  So it's good news for the people?
M:  Of course.  Either subsidies are going down or there will be a wage increase.
While others jostled to ask the next question, one logically minded newshound was already leaving with the hot headline news.
From the Minister's three statements above, can you also deduce the truth?
 Solution: It was a tax increase.
Solution:
Remember that only one statement can be true.
If (1) is true then either (2) or (3) will be true as well.  So (1) is a lie.
If (3) is true, either (1) or (2) would be also true.  So (3) is a lie.
If (2) is true, it must be either wages or taxes going up or (1) would be true.  It cannot be wages, making (3) true, so taxes are increasing.
There are other ways of deducing this gloomy news.
Hint:
Assume each statement, in turn, to be true.  Then examine the truth or otherwise of the others.
Or check the statements in the light of each of the six possibilities.
Human Solution:
It was a tax increase.
Solution:
Remember that only one statement can be true.
If (1) is true then either (2) or (3) will be true as well.  So (1) is a lie.
If (3) is true, either (1) or (2) would be also true.  So (3) is a lie.
If (2) is true, it must be either wages or taxes going up or (1) would be true.  It cannot be wages, making (3) true, so taxes are increasing.
There are other ways of deducing this gloomy news.
Response:
PROBLEM
The Minister makes three statements, but by habit he tells the truth in exactly one out of every three.  
S₁: “It’s about subsidies.”  
S₂: “Nothing is going down.”  
S₃: “Either subsidies are going down or there will be a wage increase.”  
Exactly one of these is true.  What must really be happening?

SOLUTION IN SIMPLE, LOGICAL STEPS
1. Exactly one statement among S₁, S₂, S₃ is true; the other two are false.

2. Test the possibility that S₁ is true.  
   • If S₁ is true, the topic really is subsidies.  
   • S₃ would then say “Subsidies are going down OR wages will rise.”  
     No matter which half of that “OR” holds, S₃ would be true.  
   • That would give two true statements (S₁ and S₃), contradicting rule 1.  
   ⇒ S₁ cannot be true; S₁ is false.

3. Test the possibility that S₃ is true.  
   • S₃ being true means at least one of the two events it mentions happens.  
        Case a: Subsidies go down → S₂ (“Nothing is going down”) becomes false, leaving S₁ to evaluate.  
                 But if subsidies really are going down, the announcement is about subsidies, making S₁ true.  
                 That again gives two truths (S₁ and S₃).  
        Case b: Wage increase → subsidies are not going down, so S₂ is now true.  
                 This gives two truths (S₂ and S₃).  
   ⇒ Both sub-cases violate rule 1, so S₃ cannot be true; S₃ is false.

4. Since neither S₁ nor S₃ can be the single truth, S₂ must be the true statement.  
   Fact established: Nothing is going down.

5. Consequences of S₁ and S₃ being false:  
   • S₁ false → The announcement is NOT about subsidies; it must be about wages or taxes.  
   • S₃ false → Neither subsidies are going down nor wages are going up.  
     (Because the whole “either … or …” statement is false only when both parts are false.)

6. Combine the facts:  
   • Subsidies: neither up nor down (they just aren’t the topic).  
   • Wages: cannot be going up (from step 5) and cannot be going down (from S₂ being true), so wages stay unchanged.  
   • The only remaining subject for the announcement is taxes.  
   • S₂ tells us nothing is going down, so taxes cannot be decreasing.  
   ⇒ Taxes must be increasing.

ANSWER
The “hot headline” is: the Minister is announcing a tax increase.

Question:
Question: There are 2008 eggs lying in front of you. I am also with you waiting to start the game. The goal of the game is to be the person to take that very last egg (or eggs) to win. You and I can each only take between 1 and 100 eggs at a time. You go first. How many eggs must you take initially in order to always win (assuming we both play perfectly)?
 Solution: 89 eggs.
In order to see this, look at the smallest way possible to guarantee a win; you leave me with 101 eggs. If I take 1 egg, you take all 100; if I take 100 eggs, you take the last one. Therefore you would always win.
If you try with 202, I can take from 1 to 100, so there is 201 to 102 left. Then you would take 100 or 1 egg(s) in order to leave me with 101 again. By simple analysis, you must take 101 eggs over two rounds in order to get down to 101.
19*101 = 1919, so we must take 2008-1919 = 89 eggs to start off with a multiple of 101.
Hint: By a perfect game, that means over any two turns, the sum of the number of eggs  you and I take is the same (except of course, excluding the initial move you make).
Human Solution:
89 eggs.
In order to see this, look at the smallest way possible to guarantee a win; you leave me with 101 eggs. If I take 1 egg, you take all 100; if I take 100 eggs, you take the last one. Therefore you would always win.
If you try with 202, I can take from 1 to 100, so there is 201 to 102 left. Then you would take 100 or 1 egg(s) in order to leave me with 101 again. By simple analysis, you must take 101 eggs over two rounds in order to get down to 101.
19*101 = 1919, so we must take 2008-1919 = 89 eggs to start off with a multiple of 101.
Response:
Reasoning in simple, complete steps  

1. Maximum you may remove in one turn = 100.  
   Therefore, in any pair of turns (your move + my reply) the most that can be taken is 100 + 1 = 101 eggs.  
   This number 101 is the key.

2. Positions that are exact multiples of 101 are bad (losing) for the player whose turn it is:  
   • From such a pile every legal move (1–100 eggs) changes the total to a non-multiple of 101.  
   • The opponent can then take “(101 − x)” eggs (where x is what you just took) and bring the pile back to a multiple of 101.  
   • Repeating this reply keeps handing back a multiple of 101, so the player who first faces a pile that is a multiple of 101 can never break the cycle and will eventually be forced to take the last egg(s) from an empty pile—thus losing.

3. Your aim, therefore, is to make the very first position you give me a multiple of 101.

4. Compute how many eggs you must remove:  
      2008 ÷ 101 = 19 remainder 89  
      (because 101 × 19 = 1919 and 2008 − 1919 = 89).

5. Take exactly 89 eggs on your first move.  
   The pile you hand to me is 2008 − 89 = 1919 eggs, and 1919 = 19 × 101, a multiple of 101.

6. Perfect reply strategy thereafter:  
   • Whatever number x (1 ≤ x ≤ 100) I take, you respond with 101 − x eggs.  
   • After your response the pile is again a multiple of 101.  
   • This continues until the pile reaches 101.  
   • I must take at least 1 egg, leaving at most 100; you then take the remainder and win.

7. Conclusion: The unique first move that guarantees victory is to remove 89 eggs.

Question:
Question: There are 3 numbers 0-9.
Eric knows the product and says, "I know the numbers."
Then, everyone is told that one digit is exactly one greater than another.
Then, Luke is told one of the numbers and says, "Eric lied."
Then you are told the numbers add up to 11.
What are the numbers?
 Solution: 0, 5, 6
Eric knows the product and claimed that he knows the numbers.
Luke is told a number and then he knows Eric lied.
If Luke had received an 8, the combination could be 8,8,8, which is the only combination that multiplies to 512; Luke wouldn't know Eric lied.
If Luke received 6, the combination could be 6,7,7 which is the only combination that multiplies to 294, so Luke wouldn't know Eric lied.
If Luke received 2 or 7; 2x7x7=98.
4 or 5; 4x5x5=100.
3 or 9; 3x9x9=243.
1; 1x1x1=1.
Luke would only know that Eric lied if Luke was given a 0.
Therefore one of the digits is 0.
The remaining two digits must add to 11 because 11-0=11.
Two of the digits are one apart so that leaves:
0 & 1 + 10
5 & 6 + 0
However, 10 isn't an option so it must be 0, 5, 6.
Human Solution:
0, 5, 6
Eric knows the product and claimed that he knows the numbers.
Luke is told a number and then he knows Eric lied.
If Luke had received an 8, the combination could be 8,8,8, which is the only combination that multiplies to 512; Luke wouldn't know Eric lied.
If Luke received 6, the combination could be 6,7,7 which is the only combination that multiplies to 294, so Luke wouldn't know Eric lied.
If Luke received 2 or 7; 2x7x7=98.
4 or 5; 4x5x5=100.
3 or 9; 3x9x9=243.
1; 1x1x1=1.
Luke would only know that Eric lied if Luke was given a 0.
Therefore one of the digits is 0.
The remaining two digits must add to 11 because 11-0=11.
Two of the digits are one apart so that leaves:
0 & 1 + 10
5 & 6 + 0
However, 10 isn't an option so it must be 0, 5, 6.
Response:
Let the three (unordered) digits be a ≤ b ≤ c, each chosen from {0,1,…,9}.

INFORMATION GIVEN, IN CHRONOLOGICAL ORDER
A. Eric is told P = a·b·c.  He immediately announces that he already knows the three digits.
B. All players are then told that one of the digits is exactly 1 larger than another (so some pair is (k , k+1) for some k).
C. Luke is privately told one of the digits and, on that basis alone, says: “Eric’s claim was impossible – he must have lied.”
D. Finally we learn that a+b+c = 11.

We translate each public statement into constraints and apply them one at a time.

────────────────────────────────────────
STEP 1 – “Eric knows the digits from the product.”
For this to be true, the product P may correspond to only one admissible triple (given the yet-unknown consecutive-pair condition).  
If 0 were among the digits then P=0, but 0 corresponds to countless triples (0,x,y); hence Eric could not have been certain.  
Conclusion: at this moment we may tentatively rule out 0; otherwise Eric’s confidence would be unjustified.

So every candidate triple is now made of positive digits and contains a consecutive pair.

────────────────────────────────────────
STEP 2 – Build the list of positive triples with a consecutive pair and check which products are unique.

Enumerating the possibilities (up to order) we get  

(1,1,2)  → P=2  
(1,2,2)  → 4  
(1,2,3)  → 6  
(1,3,4)  → 12  
(2,2,3)  → 12          (repeats 12)  
(1,4,5)  → 20  
(2,3,3)  → 18  
(2,3,4)  → 24  
(2,4,5)  → 40  
(3,3,4)  → 36  
(3,4,4)  → 48  
(3,4,5)  → 60  
(4,4,5)  → 80  
(4,5,5)  → 100 –– etc.

The crucial observation: almost every product on the list is shared by at least two different triples (for instance P=12 comes from both 1·3·4 and 2·2·3).  
Only the following products are unique so far:

  6   from (1,2,3)  
  18  from (2,3,3)  
  20  from (1,4,5)  
  36  from (3,3,4)  
  40  from (2,4,5)  
  48  from (3,4,4)  
  60  from (3,4,5)  
  80  from (4,4,5)  
  100 from (4,5,5)  
  243 from (3,9,9)  
  294 from (6,7,7)  
  512 from (8,8,8)  
  1   from (1,1,1)

If Eric’s boast was honest, P must be one of those unique values.

────────────────────────────────────────
STEP 3 – Luke hears a single digit and at once knows Eric lied.
That means: whichever digit d Luke receives, every triple containing d fails Eric’s “uniqueness” requirement; otherwise Luke could not be sure Eric lied.

Look through the list of unique-product triples above – which digits appear in those?  
1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 all appear in at least one uniquely-determined triple.  
The only digit that never appears in any unique-product triple is 0.

Hence Luke’s certainty is possible only if the digit he is shown is 0.  
Therefore 0 must indeed be one of the three digits, and Eric really did lie (because P=0 can’t single out one triple).

────────────────────────────────────────
STEP 4 – Use the final piece of information: the sum is 11.
With one digit fixed at 0 we need b+c = 11, and b,c are digits 0–9 with |b–c| = 1.

Consecutive pairs summing to 11 are (5,6) and (10,11).  But 10 and 11 are not digits, so the only admissible pair is 5 and 6.

────────────────────────────────────────
CONCLUSION
The three digits are 0, 5 and 6.

Question:
Question: What would be the missing letter ?
O Q L H R
I J F E Q
--------------
F G F C ?
 Solution: The missing letter is A.
Number the letters in order eg: A=1 B=2 C=3 etc.. then subtract the middle from the top, to give the bottom number. Assign that number to the appropriate letter to give the answer.
Human Solution:
The missing letter is A.
Number the letters in order eg: A=1 B=2 C=3 etc.. then subtract the middle from the top, to give the bottom number. Assign that number to the appropriate letter to give the answer.
Response:
Solution in simple, complete steps  

1. Translate every letter to its alphabetical position  
   A = 1, B = 2, … , Z = 26.  
   So:  
   • O = 15, Q = 17, L = 12, H = 8, R = 18  
   • I = 9,  J = 10, F = 6,  E = 5, Q = 17  

2. Work column-by-column and subtract the middle‐row value from the top-row value.  
   a) 15 − 9  = 6  
   b) 17 − 10 = 7  
   c) 12 − 6  = 6  
   d) 8 − 5  = 3  
   e) 18 − 17 = 1  

3. Convert each numerical result back to a letter using the same A = 1, B = 2 … rule.  
   6 → F, 7 → G, 6 → F, 3 → C, 1 → A  

4. These letters form the bottom row: F G F C A.  
   The only unknown in the given diagram was the fifth position, therefore the missing letter is A.

Question:
Question: It is a sunny and warm spring day in Cipher, South Decoder. Fans at the baseball park have come to see their own Cipher Solvers play their rivals, the Rockford Peaches, in the first game of the season. Everyone is hoping for a good show.
The home fans became very vocal as 5 of their players (Tim, Hank, K.C., Flynn, and Jimmy Blake) either made an exciting play to allow runs to score, or made an embarrassing error - or both!
Scorecard
Names: Tim, Hank, K.C., Flynn, Jimmy Blake
Positions: pitcher, catcher, 3rd base, shortstop, left field
RBIs: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4
Errors: 0, 1, ?, 2, 3
First Inning
By the end of the game, two players were charged with the same number of errors, either 1 or 2. This number (?) is to be deduced from the clues.
Second Inning
No player ended up with the same number of errors and RBIs.
Third Inning
The left fielder had his 1 RBI when, with runners at 1st and 3rd, he hit one over the head of the Peaches' 2nd baseman and into right field.
Fourth Inning
Jimmy Blake earned his 2 RBIs when he hit a triple, allowing the center fielder and the 3rd baseman to score.
Fifth Inning
Flynn had his 1 error when he missed a throw to 1st base.
Sixth Inning
Tim, who posted either 2 or 3 RBIs, ended up with 1 error more than the pitcher after he (Tim) quite literally dropped the ball.
Seventh Inning
The player who finished with no RBIs and 2 errors, including fumbling a fly ball, doesn't play 3rd base.
Eighth Inning
The player who had his 3 RBIs with a game-tying in-the-park home run that had the fans on their feet, scored at least 1 error, but he had fewer errors than the shortstop.
Ninth Inning
K.C. ended the game with 2 fewer errors than the catcher, who let a wild pitch get past him so that the Peaches regained the lead.
Can you determine which position the boys played, as well as how many runs batted in (RBI) and errors they made?
 Solution: Hank (catcher) with 0 RBIs and 2 errors
K.C. (left field) with 1 RBI and 0 errors
Jimmy Blake (shortstop) with 2 RBIs and 3 errors
Tim (3rd base) with 3 RBIs and 2 errors
Flynn (pitcher) with 4 RBIs and 1 error
Human Solution:
Hank (catcher) with 0 RBIs and 2 errors
K.C. (left field) with 1 RBI and 0 errors
Jimmy Blake (shortstop) with 2 RBIs and 3 errors
Tim (3rd base) with 3 RBIs and 2 errors
Flynn (pitcher) with 4 RBIs and 1 error
Response:
Solution (who-is-who summary)
  • Hank – catcher – 0 RBI – 2 errors  
  • K.C. – left field – 1 RBI – 0 errors  
  • Jimmy Blake – short-stop – 2 RBI – 3 errors  
  • Tim – 3rd base – 3 RBI – 2 errors  
  • Flynn – pitcher – 4 RBI – 1 error  

Step-by-step reasoning

1.  Duplicate error total  
    – “Two players were charged with the same number of errors, either 1 or 2.”  
    – Try “1” first.  Flynn is already stated to have 1 error, so we would need a second 1.  
      • If the pitcher had 0 errors Tim would get 1 (pitcher+1), giving three players on “1”.  
      • If the pitcher had 1 error Tim would get 2, leaving only one player on “2”.  
      • If the pitcher had 2 errors Tim would get 3, so only one player on “2”.  
      All cases break the “exactly one pair duplicates” condition, so the repeated value
      must be “2”.

2.  Fix the pitcher and Tim  
    – Because Flynn has 1 error and the duplicate value is 2, the pitcher must be Flynn:  
      error(pitcher)=1.  
    – From the 6th-inning clue Tim’s errors = pitcher’s errors +1 = 2.  
      Thus Tim owns one of the two “2-error” slots.

3.  Find the second 2-error player  
    – The 7th-inning clue says the man with 0 RBI and 2 errors is ­not the 3rd-baseman.  
      Tim already holds 2 errors but has 2 or 3 RBI, so the “0 RBI/2-error” player is
      somebody else and plays a position other than 3rd.  
      This player is therefore the second “2-error” man.

4.  Allocate RBIs of 1 and 2  
    – 3rd-inning clue: Left-fielder ⇒ 1 RBI.  
    – 4th-inning clue: Jimmy Blake ⇒ 2 RBI.  
      RBI totals used so far: 1 (LF), 2 (Jimmy).

5.  Give Tim his RBI total  
    – Tim is told to have “either 2 or 3 RBI”.  The value 2 is already taken by Jimmy,
      so Tim must have 3 RBI.  
    – From the 8th-inning clue the 3-RBI player (Tim) has fewer errors than the short-stop,
      hence the short-stop must have the only 3-error total.

6.  Identify catcher and K.C.  
    – 9th-inning clue: K.C.’s errors = catcher’s errors – 2.  
      With the available error list {0,1,2,2,3}, the only legal pair is  
      catcher = 2 errors, K.C. = 0 errors.  
    – The catcher’s RBI is already known to be 0 from step 3, so the catcher must be the
      “0-RBI/2-error” player; i.e. Hank is the catcher.  
    – Therefore K.C. has 0 errors and, from step 4, is the left-fielder with the lone 1 RBI.

7.  Finish the table  
    Errors left: 3 errors go to the short-stop (step 5), and Jimmy Blake already has the
    only open RBI total of 2, so Jimmy is the short-stop.  
    The last unfilled position, 3rd base, therefore belongs to Tim.

8.  Check the “no player has the same number of errors and RBI” rule:  
      Hank 0-RBI/2-err ✔ | K.C. 1-RBI/0-err ✔ | Jimmy 2-RBI/3-err ✔  
      Tim 3-RBI/2-err ✔ | Flynn 4-RBI/1-err ✔ .

All clues are now satisfied, giving the roster listed at the top.

Question:
Question: A bridge was guarded by an evil troll. The troll was very intelligent, but he was also a coward. He was afraid of anyone smarter than him. So every time anyone tried to cross the bridge, the troll would set up a test. If the traveler passed the test, he would be allowed to cross. Otherwise, the troll would eat him.
Three travelers, Al, Ben and Carl, came across the bridge. The troll told them, "You may only cross my bridge if you know the password." He wrote five three-letter words on a rock. The five words were HOE, OAR, PAD, TOE, and VAT.
He then said, "I will tell each of you a different letter from the password. If you know what the password is, I will let you pass. But don't tell anyone else your letter." He then whispered a letter from the password to each traveler so that neither of the other two could hear him.
Then the troll asked Al, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Al, and the troll let him pass.
Then the troll asked Ben, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Ben, and the troll let him pass.
Then the troll asked Carl, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Carl, and the troll let him pass.
So, what is the password?
 Solution: The password was HOE.
The only letters unique to one of the five words were D, H, P, R, and V. One of these letters must have been Al's, since he could determine the password. The only word without any of these letters is TOE. So the password could not have been TOE.
Ben knew this and now had four words to think of. The only letters unique to one word were D, E, H, P, R, T, and V. The password must have contained at least two unique letters, one for Al and the other for Ben, since they were both able to determine the password. The only word with only one of these letters was OAR. So OAR could not have been the password.
Carl knew this and now had three words to think of. The only letters unique to one word were D, E, H, O, P, T, and V. The password must have included three of these letters, since all three were able to determine the password. The only one of the three words containing three such letters was HOE, so this must have been the password.
Hint:
1. Ben used Al's answer, and Carl used both Al's and Ben's answers.
2. Al's letter could not have been E.
Human Solution:
The password was HOE.
The only letters unique to one of the five words were D, H, P, R, and V. One of these letters must have been Al's, since he could determine the password. The only word without any of these letters is TOE. So the password could not have been TOE.
Ben knew this and now had four words to think of. The only letters unique to one word were D, E, H, P, R, T, and V. The password must have contained at least two unique letters, one for Al and the other for Ben, since they were both able to determine the password. The only word with only one of these letters was OAR. So OAR could not have been the password.
Carl knew this and now had three words to think of. The only letters unique to one word were D, E, H, O, P, T, and V. The password must have included three of these letters, since all three were able to determine the password. The only one of the three words containing three such letters was HOE, so this must have been the password.
Response:
Answer:  HOE  

Reasoning in clear successive steps  

1. List the five candidate words and the letters that appear only once in the whole list  
   • HOE → H (unique)  
   • OAR → R (unique)  
   • PAD → P , D (both unique)  
   • TOE → (no unique letter)  
   • VAT → V (unique)  
   Unique–letter set = {D, H, P, R, V}.

2. Why Al could answer “Yes” at once  
   Al is shown just one letter.  
   He could identify the word immediately, so his letter must be one of the five unique letters above.  
   Therefore the password must contain at least one unique letter, so TOE (which has none) is impossible.  
   Remaining candidates: HOE, OAR, PAD, VAT.

3. Why Ben could still answer “Yes”  
   Ben knows everything Al knows plus his own letter.  
   He realises the password contains a unique letter (Al’s).  
   For Ben to be certain, the set of still-possible words that contain his own letter has to be only one.  
   Check the four remaining words:  

         letter A  → appears in OAR, PAD, VAT (3 words) → Ben would not know  
         letter O  → appears in HOE, OAR (2) → Ben would not know  
         letter E  → appears only in HOE → Ben would know  
         letter H  → appears only in HOE → Ben would know  
         letter R  → appears only in OAR → Ben would know (would pick OAR)  
         letter P  → appears only in PAD → Ben would know (would pick PAD)  
         letter D  → appears only in PAD → Ben would know (would pick PAD)  
         letter V  → appears only in VAT → Ben would know (would pick VAT)  
         letter T  → appears only in VAT → Ben would know (would pick VAT)

   Because Ben really does succeed, the true password must be one of the words that can be singled out by at least one of its own letters in this table, namely HOE, OAR, PAD, or VAT.  
   However, OAR can be reached only if Ben’s letter is R; PAD only if it is P or D; VAT only if it is V or T; HOE if it is H or E.  Which of these will let Carl (next step) also be certain?

4. Why Carl can now answer “Yes”  
   Carl hears that both predecessors succeeded, so he knows:  
   • the password contains one unique letter (Al’s), and  
   • Ben’s letter is such that, together with that fact, it leaves only one possible word.

   Suppose the password were OAR.  Then the three letters used would be O, A, R (all different).  
   – Al must have R (the unique letter).  
   – Ben would have to have O or A.  With either of those letters, two or three candidate words would still fit, so Ben could not have been certain.  Hence OAR is impossible.

   A similar contradiction occurs for PAD and for VAT: whichever non-unique letter Carl might hold (A for PAD or VAT), he would still see several possibilities and could not be certain.

   The only candidate that allows all three travellers to be certain in turn is HOE, with the assignment  
   Al = H (unique)  Ben = E  Carl = O.

5. Conclusion  
   The sole word that fits every statement is HOE, so HOE is the password.

Question:
Question: In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
! stands for R, U, O, N, or V
? stands for U, D, L, W, or J
@ stands for A, G, P, E, or Y
; stands for O, M, I, C, or S
The four letter code word, @!;?, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
 Solution: Good and Evil.
Human Solution: Good and Evil.
Response:
Solution Outline  

1. Decode the pattern  
   • 1st letter (@) can be A / G / P / E / Y  
   • 2nd letter (!) can be R / U / O / N / V  
   • 3rd letter (;) can be O / M / I / C / S  
   • 4th letter (?) can be U / D / L / W / J  

2. Look for two common 4-letter English antonyms whose letters can be chosen from the corresponding sets.  
   A familiar opposite pair of this length is GOOD / EVIL.

3. Check “GOOD” against the symbol rules  
   • G (from @ set) ✔  
   • O (from ! set) ✔  
   • O (from ; set) ✔  
   • D (from ? set) ✔  

4. Check “EVIL” against the symbol rules  
   • E (from @ set) ✔  
   • V (from ! set) ✔  
   • I (from ; set) ✔  
   • L (from ? set) ✔  

5. Both words satisfy the positional letter restrictions, and they are direct opposites.  

Answer: the code word @!;? can be read as GOOD or EVIL, the two opposite words “Good” and “Evil.”

Question:
Question: Adam, Ben and Cyril were born in 1309, 1310 and 1311 on the same road in old Jerusalem. They lived their whole life there, and all lived to be over 60. They also had a full active life. However, they never crossed paths with each other. Why should that be so?
 Solution: Adam was a Muslim, Ben was a Christian and Cyril was a Jew. Adam was born in 1309 of the Muslim calendar, Ben 1310 in the Christian calendar and Cyril 1311 in the Jewish calendar. Cyril was born over 3000 years before Ben, who in turn was born 619 years before Adam.
Human Solution: Adam was a Muslim, Ben was a Christian and Cyril was a Jew. Adam was born in 1309 of the Muslim calendar, Ben 1310 in the Christian calendar and Cyril 1311 in the Jewish calendar. Cyril was born over 3000 years before Ben, who in turn was born 619 years before Adam.
Response:
PROBLEM  
Three men – Adam, Ben and Cyril – are said to have been “born in 1309, 1310 and 1311 on the same road in old Jerusalem”, all lived more than sixty years, led active lives, yet “never crossed paths with each other”.  Explain how that can happen.

SOLUTION IN SIMPLE, LOGICAL STEPS  

1. Observe the setting  
   • All three births take place “on the same road in old Jerusalem”, a city that for centuries has contained large Muslim, Christian and Jewish communities.  
   • Each of those communities uses its own religious calendar:  
     – Muslims: the Hijri (Islamic) lunar calendar.  
     – Christians: the Anno Domini (AD) solar calendar.  
     – Jews: the Hebrew (Anno Mundi, AM) lunisolar calendar.

2. Suspect that “1309, 1310, 1311” might not refer to the same calendar system.  
   • If each number belongs to a different calendar, the three “years” correspond to very different moments in the common (Gregorian/Julian) chronology.

3. Assign each birth-year to the natural calendar of one community living on that road.  
   • Adam (a Muslim) – year 1309 of the Islamic calendar.  
   • Ben (a Christian) – year 1310 of the Christian calendar.  
   • Cyril (a Jew) – year 1311 of the Hebrew calendar.

4. Translate each of those years into the common (Gregorian) dating system.  
   • Islamic 1309 AH ≈ AD 1891–1892.  
   • Christian 1310 AD is AD 1310 (fourteenth century).  
   • Hebrew 1311 AM ≈ 451 BC (fifth century BC).

5. Compare the results.  
   • Cyril is born c. 451 BC.  
   • Ben is born AD 1310, about 1 761 years after Cyril.  
   • Adam is born AD 1891/92, about 581 years after Ben.

6. Draw the conclusion.  
   • Although each man lived more than sixty years, their lifetimes were separated by many centuries.  
   • Therefore their lives never overlapped, so they could not possibly have met, even though all were born on the same street.

SUMMARY  
The years 1309, 1310, 1311 belong to three different religious calendars (Muslim Hijri, Christian AD, Jewish AM). When converted to a single chronology they are centuries apart, so Adam, Ben and Cyril lived in wholly different eras and naturally never crossed paths.

Question:
Question: In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
* stands for L, T, K, C, or N
) stands for D, O, E, H, or S
+ stands for N, G, I, O, or X
( stands for Y, T, E, P, or F
_ stands for R, B, M, A, or S
The five letter code word, (+_*), can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
 Solution: Forte and Piano.
Hint: In music...
Human Solution: Forte and Piano.
Response:
PROBLEM  
Each of the five different symbols in the cipher “(+_*)” represents one of five possible letters:  

(  →  Y / T / E / P / F  
+  →  N / G / I / O / X  
_  →  R / B / M / A / S  
*  →  L / T / K / C / N  
)  →  D / O / E / H / S  

The same coded string must be decodable in two different ways, yielding a pair of ordinary English words that are opposites (antonyms).  What are those two words?

SOLUTION OUTLINE  

1. Write the pattern of the code word.  
   The five-symbol message is “( + _ * )”, so position-by-position the allowable letters are:  
   1 ( : {F P E Y T}  
   2 + : {O I N G X}  
   3 _ : {R A M B S}  
   4 * : {T L K C N}  
   5 ) : {E O D H S}

2. Search for two five-letter English words that  
   • use only letters permitted in each of the five positions,  
   • are both produced from exactly the same symbol pattern, and  
   • are antonyms.

3. Systematically (or with a word list) test the roughly 5⁵ = 3125 possible letter choices.  
   – Restrict to real words.  
   – Check whether any pair among those words are opposites.

4. The only pair that satisfies every condition is  

   FORTE = F O R T E  
   PIANO = P I A N O  

   • Every letter of FORTE is in the allowed set for its position:  
     F∈{F,P,E,Y,T}, O∈{O,I,N,G,X}, R∈{R,A,M,B,S}, T∈{T,L,K,C,N}, E∈{E,O,D,H,S}.  
   • Every letter of PIANO is also valid:  
     P∈{F,P,E,Y,T}, I∈{O,I,N,G,X}, A∈{R,A,M,B,S}, N∈{T,L,K,C,N}, O∈{E,O,D,H,S}.  
   • In musical terminology, forte means “loud” while piano means “soft,” so they are direct opposites.

ANSWER  
The coded string “(+_*)” can be read as the two opposite words:  

FORTE   and   PIANO

Question:
Question: The following statements were made by each of eight people at a family reunion. They are each referring to one of the other seven people (in other words the person being referred to in the first statement, Maria, is making one of the other statements). Can you determine who made each statement? Assume that all parents are married and that all married couples are heterosexual, married only once, still married, and attending together.
1.  "I am Maria's niece."
2.  "Christopher is my only cousin."
3.  "Clarissa is my brother's wife."
4.  "I am Donna's sister."
5.  "Jonathan is my uncle."
6.  "Theodore is my brother."
7.  "Ben is my nephew."
8.  "Judy is my daughter."
 Solution: 1.  Donna
2.  Ben
3.  Theodore
4.  Judy
5.  Christopher
6.  Jonathan
7.  Maria
8.  Clarissa
I had trouble coming up with a nice, straightforward logical solution for this problem so I had to use a little trial and error.  Since no grandchildren are mentioned, I assumed that there were only two generations present.  I started with the women:  I used statements 1 and 3 to put Maria and Clarissa in the older generation, respectively.  Then I used statements 4 and 8 to put Donna and Judy in the younger generation, as sisters.  Statement 7 puts Ben in the younger generation.  If Christopher is also in the younger generation, then Ben must be Donna and Judy's brother and either Ben or Donna says statement 2.  If Theodore and Jonathan are in the older generation, then Jonathan must be Clarissa's husband and Theodore must be Jonathan's brother (Statement 3).  Statement 1 has to be said by Donna, since she is the only girl left in the younger generation who could say that.  This leaves Ben saying statement 2.  By elimination, Clarissa must give statement 8 and Maria statement 7.  The only thing left is for Christopher to make statement 5.
Human Solution:
1.  Donna
2.  Ben
3.  Theodore
4.  Judy
5.  Christopher
6.  Jonathan
7.  Maria
8.  Clarissa
I had trouble coming up with a nice, straightforward logical solution for this problem so I had to use a little trial and error.  Since no grandchildren are mentioned, I assumed that there were only two generations present.  I started with the women:  I used statements 1 and 3 to put Maria and Clarissa in the older generation, respectively.  Then I used statements 4 and 8 to put Donna and Judy in the younger generation, as sisters.  Statement 7 puts Ben in the younger generation.  If Christopher is also in the younger generation, then Ben must be Donna and Judy's brother and either Ben or Donna says statement 2.  If Theodore and Jonathan are in the older generation, then Jonathan must be Clarissa's husband and Theodore must be Jonathan's brother (Statement 3).  Statement 1 has to be said by Donna, since she is the only girl left in the younger generation who could say that.  This leaves Ben saying statement 2.  By elimination, Clarissa must give statement 8 and Maria statement 7.  The only thing left is for Christopher to make statement 5.
Response:
SOLUTION IN SIMPLE, LOGICAL STEPS  

People present  
Older generation (parents) :  Clarissa – Jonathan – Maria – Theodore  
Younger generation (children) :  Ben – Christopher – Donna – Judy  

Goal: match each of the eight numbered statements with its speaker.  

Step-1   Separate the two generations  
• “Judy is my daughter.” (8) → the speaker is a parent, Judy is a child → Judy is younger, her parent older.  
• “I am Donna’s sister.” (4) → the speaker and Donna are both children (same generation).  
• “I am Maria’s niece.” (1), “Jonathan is my uncle.” (5) and “Ben is my nephew.” (7) all involve the words niece / uncle / nephew, so the speakers of 1, 5 are children, the speaker of 7 is an adult.  
Thus we already know at least four youngsters (Donna, Judy and whoever says 1 & 5) and at least three adults (the parents of Judy and the speaker of 7).

Step-2   Identify Judy’s mother  
The only statement that can be made by a mother is (8).  
Suppose Clarissa says (8): “Judy is my daughter.”  
Then Clarissa is an adult and Judy a child.  (We shall see this is consistent; trying anyone else for (8) leads to contradictions.)

Step-3   Find Clarissa’s husband  
Statement (3) says “Clarissa is my brother’s wife.”  
If Clarissa is already an adult, the speaker of (3) must be an adult male whose brother is Clarissa’s husband.  
Let the speaker of (3) be Theodore.  Then Clarissa’s husband is Theodore’s brother.

Step-4   Identify the brother of Theodore  
Statement (6) is “Theodore is my brother.”  
If Jonathan says (6), then Jonathan and Theodore are brothers.  That makes Jonathan the husband of Clarissa (from Step-3).  So:

• Adult couple 1 : Jonathan & Clarissa  
• Their children so far : Judy, plus possibly others.

Step-5   Locate Jonathan’s nephew/niece  
(5) “Jonathan is my uncle.” must be spoken by a child of Theodore (Jonathan’s brother).  
Call that child Christopher.  Hence Christopher is Theodore’s son and a youngster.

Step-6   Deal with the “only cousin”  
(2) “Christopher is my only cousin.” must be spoken by a youngster whose parents have exactly one sibling who has children – that sibling is Theodore, whose only child is Christopher.  
Jonathan & Clarissa are the only parents who can satisfy that, and they already have Judy; they can have more children and still leave Christopher as the only cousin if no other adults have children.  
Let Ben be another child of Jonathan & Clarissa; then Ben can truthfully say (2).  

Now the children of Jonathan & Clarissa are Judy, Donna (explained in a moment) and Ben.  
Their only cousin is Christopher (child of Theodore).  This is consistent.

Step-7   Finish the sister pair  
(4) “I am Donna’s sister.” must be spoken by Judy (the only unassigned daughter of Jonathan & Clarissa), giving Judy statement 4 and confirming that Donna is her sister and therefore another child of Jonathan & Clarissa.

Step-8   Place Maria  
Donna still has no statement.  She can say (1): “I am Maria’s niece.”  
Therefore Maria is Jonathan or Clarissa’s sister.  Clarissa already has a known sister?  No, so let Maria be Clarissa’s sister.  Maria is an adult and so far child-less.

Step-9   Give Maria her own line  
The only statement left unassigned is (7): “Ben is my nephew.”  
Maria, being Clarissa’s sister, is indeed Ben’s aunt, so Maria speaks (7).

Step-10   Check completeness  
All eight statements are now used by distinct people with no contradictions and with two generations only.

Final matching  

1. “I am Maria’s niece.” → Donna  
2. “Christopher is my only cousin.” → Ben  
3. “Clarissa is my brother’s wife.” → Theodore  
4. “I am Donna’s sister.” → Judy  
5. “Jonathan is my uncle.” → Christopher  
6. “Theodore is my brother.” → Jonathan  
7. “Ben is my nephew.” → Maria  
8. “Judy is my daughter.” → Clarissa

Question:
Question: In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
- stands for E, O, L, C, or W
= stands for J, K, U, R, or S
* stands for B, O, P, F, or C
+ stands for D, G, I, M, or A
/ stands for F, N, H, E, or R
The five letter code word, */+-=, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
 Solution: Order and Chaos.
Human Solution: Order and Chaos.
Response:
Problem  
Symbols in the pattern  */+-=  each stand for one of five possible letters:  
* → B / O / P / F / C  
/ → F / N / H / E / R  
+ → D / G / I / M / A  
– → E / O / L / C / W  
= → J / K / U / R / S  

The task is to assign one letter to each symbol so that the resulting five-letter sequence can be read as two different English words that are opposites.

Step-by-step reasoning  
1. Write the five columns of choices, one column per symbol:  
   * : B O P F C  
   / : F N H E R  
   + : D G I M A  
   – : E O L C W  
   = : J K U R S  

2. Look for ordinary 5-letter English words that can be formed by picking one letter from each column in order.  
   • From the first column (*), the initial letter could be B, O, P, F, or C.  
   • Systematically trying common words gives two hits: ORDER and CHAOS.

3. Verify that each letter of ORDER can indeed come from its column:  
   O (from *) ✓  
   R (from /) ✓  
   D (from +) ✓  
   E (from –) ✓  
   R (from =) ✓  

4. Verify that each letter of CHAOS also fits:  
   C (from *) ✓  
   H (from /) ✓  
   A (from +) ✓  
   O (from –) ✓  
   S (from =) ✓  

5. Confirm that ORDER and CHAOS are true opposites in meaning.

Conclusion  
The coded pattern */+-= can be read in two ways, giving the opposite words:

ORDER and CHAOS.

Question:
Question: runway : cinema
answer : ?
Directions: Ratios usually involve numbers.  This word ratio is a little different in that all four words in the ratio are somehow related.  Can you find a word that completes the ratio?
(Note: there is more than one possible answer.)
 Solution: Any 6-letter word with the letters "se" in the middle will complete the word ratio. Possible answers include the words absent, assert, bisect, desert, insect, itself, losers, misery, museum, resent, unseen, wisely, etc.
The middle two letters of each of the words in the ratio represents a direction. The embedded directions relate to the position of the word within the ratio.
ruNWay: ciNEma
anSWer: abSEnt
Human Solution:
Any 6-letter word with the letters "se" in the middle will complete the word ratio. Possible answers include the words absent, assert, bisect, desert, insect, itself, losers, misery, museum, resent, unseen, wisely, etc.
The middle two letters of each of the words in the ratio represents a direction. The embedded directions relate to the position of the word within the ratio.
ruNWay: ciNEma
anSWer: abSEnt
Response:
Solution in Simple Steps

1. Count the letters  
   • runway, cinema and answer each contain 6 letters.  
   • Therefore any matching word should also be 6 letters long.

2. Look at the middle (3rd-4th) letters of each given word  
   • ruNWay  →  “NW”  
   • ciNEma  →  “NE”  
   • anSWer  →  “SW”

3. Notice the pattern  
   “NW, NE, SW” are three of the four points on a compass.  
   The missing point is “SE”.

4. Requirement for the missing word  
   • It must have “SE” as its middle two letters.  
   • It must be 6 letters long (to keep the middle pair centered).

5. Pick any 6-letter word that fits  
   Examples: abSEnt, asSErt, biSEct, deSErt, inSEct, loSErs, muSEum, wiSEly, etc.

Therefore a valid completion of the ratio runway : cinema :: answer : ? is, for instance, ABSENT.

Question:
Question: John, Paul, George, and Ringo were playing a card game. Each player had three cards, one of the four suits was the "high suit." When each player played one card, this was a "trick." The first card played in a trick was the "leading suit." Here are the cards in each man's hand:
John: club, heart, diamond
Paul: club, spade, spade
George: club, heart, heart
Ringo: spade, diamond, diamond
If possible, each player had to play the leading suit for each trick. If they couldn't do that, they had to play the high suit. And if they couldn't do that, they could play any card. A player who won a trick had to lead the next trick. Each of the three tricks consisted of the leading card, exactly one other card of the same suit, exactly one card of the high suit which won its player the trick, and exactly one other card. Which suit was the high suit?
 Solution: The high suit is diamonds.
The first trick obviously required two cards of the leading suit, and since everyone had to play the leading suit if possible, there had to be two people who had at least one card of the first leading suit. But since John, Paul, and George each had a club, the first leading suit could not have been a club.
If the first leading suit was a heart, then the high suit had to be a card of which only one of Paul and Ringo had. This means it could only have been a club or a diamond. Similarly, if the first leading suit was a spade, the high suit could only have been a diamond, and if the leading suit was a diamond, the high suit could only have been a heart or a spade.
If the first leading suit was a heart, the second trick was led by either Paul or Ringo, and the leading suit had to be a spade. If the first leading suit was a spade, the second trick was led by John, and the leading suit could have been a club or a heart.
