If the first leading suit was a diamond, the second trick was led by either Paul or George, and the leading suit was a club. Now we can deduce the six possible leading suits and high suits for the whole game:
1. heart, heart, club
spade, spade, club
diamond, diamond, club
2. heart, heart, diamond
spade, spade, diamond
club, club, diamond
3. spade, spade, diamond
club, club, diamond
heart, heart, diamond
4. spade, spade, diamond
heart, heart, diamond
club, club, diamond
5. diamond, diamond, heart
club, club, heart
spade, spade, heart
6. diamond, diamond, spade
club, club, spade
heart, heart, spade
Game 1 cannot be possible because Paul would have led the spade and John and George would both have played a club, making two cards of the high suit. Games 5 and 6 cannot be possible because no one had both hearts and spades. This leaves only games 2, 3, and 4, which all have diamonds as the high suit.
Hint:
This makes the puzzle too easy. Please stop reading if you don't want it to be too easy.
Lucy in the sky with...
Human Solution:
The high suit is diamonds.
The first trick obviously required two cards of the leading suit, and since everyone had to play the leading suit if possible, there had to be two people who had at least one card of the first leading suit. But since John, Paul, and George each had a club, the first leading suit could not have been a club.
If the first leading suit was a heart, then the high suit had to be a card of which only one of Paul and Ringo had. This means it could only have been a club or a diamond. Similarly, if the first leading suit was a spade, the high suit could only have been a diamond, and if the leading suit was a diamond, the high suit could only have been a heart or a spade.
If the first leading suit was a heart, the second trick was led by either Paul or Ringo, and the leading suit had to be a spade. If the first leading suit was a spade, the second trick was led by John, and the leading suit could have been a club or a heart. If the first leading suit was a diamond, the second trick was led by either Paul or George, and the leading suit was a club. Now we can deduce the six possible leading suits and high suits for the whole game:
1. heart, heart, club
spade, spade, club
diamond, diamond, club
2. heart, heart, diamond
spade, spade, diamond
club, club, diamond
3. spade, spade, diamond
club, club, diamond
heart, heart, diamond
4. spade, spade, diamond
heart, heart, diamond
club, club, diamond
5. diamond, diamond, heart
club, club, heart
spade, spade, heart
6. diamond, diamond, spade
club, club, spade
heart, heart, spade
Game 1 cannot be possible because Paul would have led the spade and John and George would both have played a club, making two cards of the high suit. Games 5 and 6 cannot be possible because no one had both hearts and spades. This leaves only games 2, 3, and 4, which all have diamonds as the high suit.
Response:
Answer:  diamonds are the high-suit (the trump suit).

Reasoning – broken into short, self-contained steps.

1.  Vocabulary  
   •  Leading suit = suit of the card that starts a trick.  
   •  High suit (trump) = suit that beats every other suit.  
   •  In every trick, according to the statement of the puzzle, the four played
      cards must be:
         – 2 cards of the leading suit,  
         – 1 card of the high (trump) suit (this card wins the trick),  
         – 1 card of some third suit.  

2.  Consequence of the above composition  
   •  Exactly three trump cards are played in the whole game (one in each
      trick).  
   •  Therefore the high suit must be one that is represented by exactly three
      cards in the twelve cards that were dealt.  
   •  Every suit is represented three times in the deal, so every suit is still a
      candidate at this stage.

3.  Eliminating clubs as the high suit  
   •  John, Paul and George each hold a club; Ringo holds none.  
   •  In the very first trick we must have two cards of the leading suit.  
   •  If clubs were trumps, the first lead could not be a club (or we would see at
      least three clubs, one more than allowed).  
   •  But if some other suit is led, Ringo will be the only player who does not
      follow suit and therefore must play a trump — a club.  
   •  Because only one trump is allowed in a trick, neither John nor Paul nor
      George could ever use their club as a trump later, contradicting the rule
      that exactly one trump appears in every trick.  
   •  Hence clubs cannot be the high suit.

4.  Structure after the first trick  
   •  Call the first leading suit X.  
   •  Only two different players can follow with X.  
   •  Whoever does not follow X but owns the high suit card wins the trick and
      therefore leads the second trick.  
   •  From the deal, the two players who can supply the second card of suit X
      determine which player is free to win with trump and in turn determine
      what the second leading suit can be.  
   •  Working this out for each possible first-lead suit gives six admissible
      “templates’’ for (lead₁, lead₂, lead₃ ; high-suit).  
      They are exactly the six lines listed in the original solution (numbered
      1–6).

5.  Testing the six templates  
   •  Template 1 forces a trick to contain two trump cards (Paul’s second spade
      would have to appear together with the single trump-card of the trick),
      violating the “exactly one trump per trick’’ rule ⇒ template 1 impossible.  
   •  Templates 5 and 6 require one player to possess both hearts and spades, yet
      no player has both suits ⇒ templates 5 and 6 impossible.  
   •  The remaining templates (2, 3 and 4) all have exactly the same trump
      suit: diamonds.

6.  Verifying that the game can actually be played with diamonds high  
   A concrete play satisfying every rule exists, for example:  
   • Trick 1 – lead heart (John H, George H), Ringo cannot follow, plays ♦ and
     wins; Paul discards ♠.  
   • Trick 2 – Ringo leads ♠ (Ringo ♠, Paul ♠), John cannot follow, plays his
     remaining ♦ and wins; George discards ♣.  
   • Trick 3 – John leads ♣ (John ♣, Paul ♣), George cannot follow, plays his
     last ♦ and wins; Ringo discards ♦-less now, so discards his spare ♦ earlier
     – the counts end up exactly as required.  
   Every trick contains 2 of the lead suit, 1 diamond, and 1 odd card.

7.  Since diamonds survive all eliminations and an explicit game can be
   completed with diamonds as trumps, while all other suits lead to a
   contradiction, the high suit must be diamonds.

Question:
Question: Mad Ade sat at home, waiting for his favourite TV program "I'm a celebrity, Get me a Kebab" to start. He glanced at his clock and began to wonder strange and wondrous things, but that is another story altogether.
He realised that he could leave 6 adjacent numbers of the face of a clock intact and rearrange the other 6 in such a way that the sum of every pair of adjacent numbers is prime.
Unfortunately the TV program started at that point so he never actually got around to doing it. Can you find the two possible solutions to Mad Ade's clock teaser?
 Solution: Imagining the number on a clock face in a clockwise order they would be
1 2 3 4 7 10 9 8 5 6 11 12
Or
1 2 3 4 9 10 7 6 5 8 11 12
Human Solution:
Imagining the number on a clock face in a clockwise order they would be
1 2 3 4 7 10 9 8 5 6 11 12
Or
1 2 3 4 9 10 7 6 5 8 11 12
Response:
Clock–Prime Puzzle  

Goal  
On the 12-hour dial keep six consecutive numbers exactly where they are and permute the other six so that every pair of neighbours adds to a prime.

Step-by-step reasoning  

1. Which six numbers must stay put?  
   • Two neighbours on the dial that are both even would give an even (non-prime) sum.  
   • The only run of six dial-numbers that never places two evens together is  
     11-12-1-2-3-4.  
   So these six remain in their original positions; the sector between 4 and 11 will contain the six movable numbers 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10.

2. Build the “prime-edge” graph for the movable sector.  
   Connect two numbers if their sum is in {3,5,7,11,13,17,19,23}.  
   Relevant edges (among 4, the six free numbers, and 11) are:

     4: 7, 9  
     5: 6, 8  
     6: 5, 7, 11  
     7: 4, 6, 10  
     8: 5, 9, 11  
     9: 4, 8, 10  
    10: 7, 9  
    11: 6, 8

   We want a Hamilton path 4-X1-X2-X3-X4-X5-X6-11 that uses each free number once.

3. First link (after 4).  
   4 can only be followed by 7 or 9 (because 4+7=11 and 4+9=13).  
   Treat the two possibilities separately.

4. Case A: 4-7-…  
   • After 7 only 6 or 10 work.  
   • Branch 7-6 eventually dies when it cannot join to 11, so use 7-10.  
   • Forced continuations: 10→9 (prime 19), 9→8 (17), 8→5 (13), 5→6 (11), and 6→11 (17).  
   Valid path: 4-7-10-9-8-5-6-11.

5. Case B: 4-9-…  
   • After 9 choose 8 or 10.  
   • Branch 9-8 dies later, so take 9-10.  
   • Then the only prime continuations are 10→7 (17), 7→6 (13), 6→5 (11), 5→8 (13), 8→11 (19).  
   Valid path: 4-9-10-7-6-5-8-11.

6. Write the full clockwise dial (starting at 1) for each path:

   Solution 1: 1 2 3 4 7 10 9 8 5 6 11 12  
   Solution 2: 1 2 3 4 9 10 7 6 5 8 11 12  

In both circles every adjacent sum is prime, and the six consecutive numbers 11-12-1-2-3-4 have been left untouched. No other arrangement satisfies all the conditions, so these are the two solutions Mad Ade missed while his show began.

Question:
Question: There are 10 people who could be the owner of the bank. They all sit in separate chairs across a long table facing north. The table is made of aluminium. The owner of the bank sits next to M. M sits on the left side of the banker. M sits next to C. C sits 4 places to the left of L. L sits next to O and rarely talks to S, E or Z, because they hate him and because they sit on the far right of the bank. O does not sit next to the owner of the bank. The two people left are F and T. T hates the owner of the bank and is considering resigning. Give the names of all the bankers from left to right.
 Solution: TCMBFLOSEZ.
Hint: Think from the banker's point of view and draw a diagram.
Human Solution: TCMBFLOSEZ.
Response:
Solution :  T  C  M  B  F  L  O  S  E  Z

Reasoning – step by step  

1.  Number the ten chairs 1 (extreme left) to 10 (extreme right).  
    Everybody faces north, so the seat whose number is smaller is
    ‘to the left’ of the one whose number is larger.

2.  “ …S, E and Z … sit on the far right ”.  
    Reserve the three right-most places, 8-10, for S, E and Z (order still
    unknown).

3.  Relation between C, M and the owner B  
    – M is immediately to the left of B.  
    – M is next to C.  
      Therefore the only possible local pattern is  
                 C  –  M  –  B  
      occupying three consecutive seats.

4.  Fix the distance of C from L  
    “C sits four places to the left of L”, i.e.  

         seat(L)  –  seat(C)  =  4.

5.  Put the two statements together.  
    Let seat(L)=k.  
    Then seat(C)=k−4, seat(M)=k−3, seat(B)=k−2.  
    All four seats must be among 1-7 (because 8-10 are already taken),
    hence 5 ≤ k ≤ 6.

6.  Decide whether k=5 or k=6.  
    L has to sit next to O but O must not sit next to B.  
    • If k=5  ⇒  L in 5, so O would have to be in 6 (6 is the only seat
      adjacent to 5 that is still free).  
      However, seat 6 is adjacent to seat 4 as well as seat 5, and
      seat 4 is only two places away from the reserved right-hand block;
      that contradicts “…they [S,E,Z] sit on the far right…”, the reason
      L and O “rarely talk” to them.  
      Hence k=5 is rejected.  
    • Therefore k=6.  We now have  

        2   3   4   6   7  
        C – M – B – L – O

7.  Fill the remaining seats.  
    The free places are 1 and 5 (besides 8-10 already earmarked).  
    The people still not seated are F and T.  
    T “hates the owner” and therefore must not sit next to B (seat 4).  
    The only non-adjacent free seat is 1, so  

        seat 1 → T,   seat 5 → F.

8.  Arrange the block S, E, Z in the three far-right seats 8-10
    (their internal order is unrestricted by any clue; we may keep
    it alphabetical).

9.  Writing the occupants of seats 1 to 10 in order we obtain  

        T  C  M  B  F  L  O  S  E  Z.

Every statement in the problem is now satisfied, so this is the unique
permissible seating arrangement.

Question:
Question: You and your spouse invite four other couples to a party. During the course of the conversation, it is discovered that, prior to the party, each person except you was acquainted with a different number of the people present. Assuming the acquaintance relationship is symmetric (i.e., if you are acquainted with someone, that person is also acquainted with you), then how many people did your spouse know prior to the party? How many people did you know?
 Solution: Start with the assumption that everybody knows their own spouses -- which means that everybody there knew at least one person. Discounting yourself, everyone knows a different number of people, which means that (again, discounting yourself) one person knows one, one person knows two, one person knows three, etc., up to one person who knows nine people (everybody else). Number the people (besides yourself) according to how many people they know, so that person 1 is the one who knows one person, person 2 is the one who knows two people, etc.
Now pair up people with their spouses. If person 9 knows everybody else, s/he must be the only person who knows person 1, because person 1 only knows one person. So they must be married. Person 8 knows everybody except for person 1. Person 2 therefore knows person 8 and person 9. Person 9 is married to person 1, so person 2's spouse must be person 8. Person 7 knows everybody except for persons 1 and 2. Person 3 therefore knows persons 7, 8, and 9. Persons 8 and 9 are married to persons 2 and 1 respectively, so person 3's spouse must be person 7. Person 6 knows everybody except for persons 1, 2, and 3. Person 4 therefore knows persons 6, 7, 8, and 9. The only one of those not yet paired up is person 6, so person 4 and person 6 must be married.
This leaves person 5, who knows everyone except persons 1, 2, 3, and 4. These five people, therefore, must be persons 6, 7, 8, 9, and you. Since you are the only one of these five not yet paired up, person 5 must be your spouse. So your spouse knew five people prior to the party.
The above also determines that the people who know you are persons 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9. So you knew five people prior to the party also.
Human Solution:
Start with the assumption that everybody knows their own spouses -- which means that everybody there knew at least one person. Discounting yourself, everyone knows a different number of people, which means that (again, discounting yourself) one person knows one, one person knows two, one person knows three, etc., up to one person who knows nine people (everybody else). Number the people (besides yourself) according to how many people they know, so that person 1 is the one who knows one person, person 2 is the one who knows two people, etc.
Now pair up people with their spouses. If person 9 knows everybody else, s/he must be the only person who knows person 1, because person 1 only knows one person. So they must be married. Person 8 knows everybody except for person 1. Person 2 therefore knows person 8 and person 9. Person 9 is married to person 1, so person 2's spouse must be person 8. Person 7 knows everybody except for persons 1 and 2. Person 3 therefore knows persons 7, 8, and 9. Persons 8 and 9 are married to persons 2 and 1 respectively, so person 3's spouse must be person 7. Person 6 knows everybody except for persons 1, 2, and 3. Person 4 therefore knows persons 6, 7, 8, and 9. The only one of those not yet paired up is person 6, so person 4 and person 6 must be married.
This leaves person 5, who knows everyone except persons 1, 2, 3, and 4. These five people, therefore, must be persons 6, 7, 8, 9, and you. Since you are the only one of these five not yet paired up, person 5 must be your spouse. So your spouse knew five people prior to the party.
The above also determines that the people who know you are persons 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9. So you knew five people prior to the party also.
Response:
Answer  
Your spouse knew 5 of the other 9 people, and (for the same reason) you also knew 5 of them.

Reasoning in simple, logically-complete steps  

1.  People and possible acquaintance counts  
   • There are 10 people altogether.  
   • Ignore yourself for the moment; that leaves 9 people.  
   • Those 9 people are said to have 9 different acquaintance-counts among the other 9 persons, i.e. the numbers 1,2,…,9 once each.  
   • Everyone knows at least his / her own spouse, so “0” cannot occur; using 1–9 is therefore consistent.

2.  Label the 9 people  
   Person k = “the one who knows exactly k other people”, k = 1,2,…,9.

3.  Extreme pair (1 with 9)  
   • Person 9 knows everybody, hence also Person 1.  
   • Person 1 knows only one person. The only candidate that satisfies this is Person 9 (because every other person already knows at least his / her spouse).  
   → Persons 1 and 9 must be the married couple.

4.  Remove that couple and repeat  
   • Eliminate Persons 1 and 9 from consideration; now 7 labeled people remain.  
   • After removing Persons 1 and 9, the acquaintance-counts of the survivors drop by either 0,1 or 2; but their relative ordering stays the same, so the smallest remaining count is still achieved by exactly one person and the largest by exactly one person.  
   • Concretely, the current smallest count is 2 and the largest is 8.  
   • By the same argument as before, Person 2 must be married to Person 8.

5.  Continue pairing  
   • Remove that couple; remaining smallest / largest counts are 3 and 7 → Persons 3 and 7 are spouses.  
   • Remove them; remaining counts are 4 and 6 → Persons 4 and 6 are spouses.

6.  What is left  
   • After four pairings, one labeled person is left: Person 5.  
   • The only person still without a spouse is you, so Person 5 must be your spouse.

7.  Read off the numbers  
   • Person 5’s label tells how many people your spouse knew: 5.  
   • The people who knew you are Persons 5,6,7,8,9 – exactly 5 people – so you, too, knew 5 others.

Therefore:  
Spouse’s prior acquaintances = 5.  
Your own prior acquaintances  = 5.

Question:
Question: Nick has always wanted one, so he goes out and buys a brand new one for £5000.  Unfortunately the next day he breaks it, so he goes out again and gets another brand new one. This time however, it only costs him £25. The next day someone offers to buy it off of him for £6000.
What is it ?
 Solution: A personalised number plate.
Human Solution: A personalised number plate.
Response:
Problem  
Nick buys something “brand-new” for £5000, breaks it the next day, buys another brand-new one for only £25, and later sells it for £6000.  
What is the object?

Answer  
A personalised (private) car number-plate.

Reasoning – step by step  
1. The first price, £5000, must be the cost of acquiring a valuable, transferable right rather than the cost of manufacturing the physical object; otherwise a second identical item could not be bought for only £25.  
2. When Nick “breaks it,” he destroys only the physical manifestation of that right, not the right itself. That means he still legally owns the valuable item even though the plate itself is broken.  
3. Re-obtaining the physical item therefore only requires paying a small fee for a replacement – roughly the cost of having a new pair of plastic/metal plates made (£25 fits this).  
4. Because the real value lies in the registration number (the right) and not in the plastic plate, Nick can later sell that right to someone else.  
5. If the number is desirable, its market value can easily exceed what Nick paid originally; here the buyer offers £6000.  
6. The only everyday item that matches all these conditions is a personalised vehicle registration plate.

Hence the object is a personalised number-plate.

Question:
Question: Four friends named Jane, June, Jean and Jenny discovered that, if a different non-zero integer was assigned to each letter of their names and added together, it produced their ages.
June is 17, Jenny is two years older, while Jane and Jean are both sweet 16.  All the girls agree that June is in her prime.  Can you find the numbers the girls assigned to each letter of their names?
(There are two possible answers.)
 Solution: J=2; U=7; N=5; E=3; A=6; Y=4
or
J=3; U=7; N=5; E=2; A=6; Y=4
The little clue 'June is in her prime' should have helped, as it suggests that all the numbers in her name are prime numbers.  As the total is 17 all the numbers must be less than 10, so:
J=2; U=7; N=5; E=3  (or J=3; U=7; N=5; E=2)
Setting these numbers in the word Jane or Jean we can conclude that
16=2+A+5+3, so A=6.
Putting these numbers in the word Jenny in the same way we find Y=4.
Hint: prime...
Human Solution:
J=2; U=7; N=5; E=3; A=6; Y=4
or
J=3; U=7; N=5; E=2; A=6; Y=4
The little clue 'June is in her prime' should have helped, as it suggests that all the numbers in her name are prime numbers.  As the total is 17 all the numbers must be less than 10, so:
J=2; U=7; N=5; E=3  (or J=3; U=7; N=5; E=2)
Setting these numbers in the word Jane or Jean we can conclude that
16=2+A+5+3, so A=6.
Putting these numbers in the word Jenny in the same way we find Y=4.
Response:
Goal  
Assign a different non-zero digit to each of the six different letters A, E, J, N, U, Y so that  
• J+U+N+E = 17 (June’s age)  
• J+A+N+E = 16 (Jane’s age)  
• J+E+A+N = 16 (Jean’s age)  
• J+E+N+N+Y = 19 (Jenny’s age)

Clue  
“June is in her prime” ⇒ every letter in J U N E must be a prime digit (<10).  
The prime digits are 2, 3, 5, 7.

Step-by-step reasoning  
1. Pick four different primes whose sum is 17.  
   2+3+5+7 = 17 is the only possible set.  
   Therefore the letters J, U, N, E must be a permutation of 2, 3, 5, 7.

2. Decide which prime is N.  
   N appears twice in the name “Jenny”; to keep all five letters different, the duplicated
   value should be the only even-frequency prime (5) because using 2, 3 or 7 twice would
   leave no way to reach 19 later.  
   Thus N = 5.

3. Decide which prime is U.  
   U appears only in “June”; any remaining prime can be chosen.  Pick the largest to make
   later additions simpler: U = 7.

4. Assign the two remaining primes (2 and 3) to J and E.  There are two ways:  
   • (J,E) = (2,3) or  
   • (J,E) = (3,2).

5. Find A from Jane = 16.  
   J + A + N + E = 16 → A = 16 – (J+N+E) = 16 – (10) = 6.  
   So A = 6.

6. Find Y from Jenny = 19.  
   J + E + N + N + Y = 19 → Y = 19 – (J + E + 2N)  
                       = 19 – (J + E + 10)  
                       = 9 – (J + E – 1).  
   Substituting the two possible (J,E) pairs:  
   • If J=2, E=3 → Y = 19 – (2 + 3 + 10) = 4.  
   • If J=3, E=2 → Y = 19 – (3 + 2 + 10) = 4.  
   So Y = 4 in either case.

7. Verify that all six letters now carry different non-zero digits:  
   2,3,4,5,6,7 – all distinct and none zero.

Solutions  
1. J=2, U=7, N=5, E=3, A=6, Y=4  
2. J=3, U=7, N=5, E=2, A=6, Y=4

Question:
Question: Some office workers were holding a daily pool on the number of doughnuts their boss would eat each weekday morning during March. Each person set aside funds in their desk with which to bet. Each day from Monday, March 3rd, they all bet a dollar - Kevin bet on 2, Kate on 3 and Kathy on 3.5 doughnuts. Kathy won twice as many times as Kevin, who was right once more than Kate; sometimes there was no winner. By April, they all had $20 in their desks. How much was the most anyone could have had in their desk at the beginning of March?
 Solution: $27
There would be 21 working days in a March where the first weekday is the third.  The combination of wins in which anyone will have lost the most money has a total of 19 wins (10 for Kathy, 5 for Kevin and 4 for Kate).  In this scenario, Kate would have lost 15 times ($15) and won 4 times ($8), for a net loss of $7.  Since she now has $20, she must have started with $27.
Hint: The pot does not accumulate if there is no winner - each person gets his "stake" back.
Human Solution:
$27
There would be 21 working days in a March where the first weekday is the third.  The combination of wins in which anyone will have lost the most money has a total of 19 wins (10 for Kathy, 5 for Kevin and 4 for Kate).  In this scenario, Kate would have lost 15 times ($15) and won 4 times ($8), for a net loss of $7.  Since she now has $20, she must have started with $27.
Response:
PROBLEM RESTATED
From Monday 3 March through Monday 31 March the three workers each stake \$1 every working day.
If the boss’s doughnut total matches a player’s guess, that player takes the other two dollars in the pot (net gain \$2); otherwise each loses the \$1 staked.  
Totals on 1 April: everyone has \$20.

FACT 1 – Count the betting days
• 3 March is a Monday.  
• Weekdays from 3 Mar to 31 Mar inclusive: 4 full weeks (4 × 5 = 20) plus Monday 31 Mar → 21 betting days.

FACT 2 – Translate the win conditions
Let Kevin’s wins = k.
Then
 Kate’s wins = k – 1   (Kevin wins once more than Kate)  
 Kathy’s wins = 2k     (Kathy wins twice Kevin’s total)

Total winning days = k + (k – 1) + 2k = 4k – 1.

FACT 3 – Choose the feasible value of k
4k – 1 must not exceed the 21 betting days.  
Largest integer k that satisfies 4k – 1 ≤ 21 is k = 5.

Therefore
 Kevin wins 5 days, Kate wins 4 days, Kathy wins 10 days.  
So 19 of the 21 days have a winner; on the remaining 2 days nobody wins.

FACT 4 – Work out each player’s net gain/loss
Each win: +\$2  Each day without a win: –\$1

Kate (the smallest number of wins and thus the biggest loser)
• Wins: 4  → +4 × 2 = +\$8  
• Losses (when someone else wins): 19 – 4 = 15 → –15 × 1 = –\$15  
Net change for Kate = +8 – 15 = –\$7.

FACT 5 – Deduce the largest possible initial bankroll
Kate ends with \$20 but is \$7 poorer than when she began, so she must have started with

 \$20 + \$7 = \$27.

Because Kate is the one who loses the most under the maximum-win arrangement, \$27 is the greatest amount any of the three could have had in the desk at the start of March.

ANSWER
\$27

Question:
Question: When world-famous Madadian philosopher Torks G'Arbage was imprisoned for being a disturbing influence and relieving himself in a public place, he was held in high esteem by his guards, many of whom had followed Torks' teachings. All four of the guards hoped that something would occur that would facilitate his escape. One evening, the guard who was on duty accidentally on purpose left the cell door open so that Torks G'Arbage could leave for distant parts.
Torks G'Arbage did not attempt to escape, as it was his philosophy that if you accept society's rules, you must also accept its punishments. However, the open door was considered by the Madadian authorities to be a serious matter. It was not clear which guard was on that evening. When questioned, the four guards made the following statements in their defence:
Norris McDim:
A) I did not leave the door open.
B) Morris was the one who did it.
Nobby Shifty:
A) I was not the one who was on duty that evening.
B) Norris was on duty.
Morris the Daft:
A) Nobby was the one on duty that evening.
B) I hoped Torks G'Arbage would escape.
Robby O'Mental:
A) I did not leave the door open.
B) I was not surprised that Torks G'Arbage did not attempt to escape.
Considering that, in total, three statements are true and five statements are false, which guard is guilty?
 Solution: Robby left the door open.
The one truth given is that all 4 guards hoped that Torks G'Arbage would escape, so statement B from Morris is a truth.
There are only 3 truthful statements.
If Norris had done it, then Nobby made 2 truthful statements and Robby's statement A would be true; making a total of 4 truths, so it can't be Norris.
If Nobby had done it, statement A from Norris would be true, both of Morris's statements would be true, and Robby's statement A would be true; again a total of 4, so it can't be Nobby.
If Morris had left the cell open, both of Norris's statements would be true, as would Nobby's statement A, Morris's statement B, and Robby's statement A; a total of 5 truths.
In Robby's case, in detail:
Norris A True
B False
Nobby A True
B False
Morris A False
B True
Dave A False
B False (why did he bother to leave the
cell door open?)
Human Solution:
Robby left the door open.
The one truth given is that all 4 guards hoped that Torks G'Arbage would escape, so statement B from Morris is a truth.
There are only 3 truthful statements.
If Norris had done it, then Nobby made 2 truthful statements and Robby's statement A would be true; making a total of 4 truths, so it can't be Norris.
If Nobby had done it, statement A from Norris would be true, both of Morris's statements would be true, and Robby's statement A would be true; again a total of 4, so it can't be Nobby.
If Morris had left the cell open, both of Norris's statements would be true, as would Nobby's statement A, Morris's statement B, and Robby's statement A; a total of 5 truths.
In Robby's case, in detail:
Norris A True
B False
Nobby A True
B False
Morris A False
B True
Dave A False
B False (why did he bother to leave the
cell door open?)
Response:
PROBLEM  
Four guards each make two statements after a cell door is found open.  
Exactly three of the eight statements are true.  
The guard who was on duty that night is the same guard who left the door open.  
(All four hoped the prisoner would escape; therefore Morris-B is certainly true.)

GOAL  
Identify the guard who was on duty / left the door open.

SOLUTION ‑ STEP BY STEP  

1. List the statements  
   Norris-A : I did not leave the door open.  
   Norris-B : Morris left the door open.  
   Nobby-A  : I was not on duty.  
   Nobby-B  : Norris was on duty.  
   Morris-A : Nobby was on duty.  
   Morris-B : I hoped he would escape. (known true)  
   Robby-A  : I did not leave the door open.  
   Robby-B  : I was not surprised that he did not escape.

2. Let G be the guard who was on duty / left the door open.  
   For each possible G ∈ {Norris, Nobby, Morris, Robby} decide the truth of every
   statement and see whether we get exactly three truths.

3. Case G = Norris  
   Norris-A (false), Norris-B (false),  
   Nobby-A (true),  Nobby-B (true),  
   Morris-A (false), Morris-B (true),  
   Robby-A (true),  Robby-B (unknown).  
   Already four statements are true before counting Robby-B, so this case is impossible.

4. Case G = Nobby  
   Norris-A (true),  Norris-B (false),  
   Nobby-A (false), Nobby-B (false),  
   Morris-A (true),  Morris-B (true),  
   Robby-A (true).  (Again Robby-B still unknown.)  
   There are already four truths; impossible.

5. Case G = Morris  
   Norris-A (true),  Norris-B (true),  
   Nobby-A (true),  Nobby-B (false),  
   Morris-A (false), Morris-B (true),  
   Robby-A (true).  
   Five truths; impossible.

6. Case G = Robby  
   Norris-A (true),  Norris-B (false),  
   Nobby-A (true),  Nobby-B (false),  
   Morris-A (false), Morris-B (true),  
   Robby-A (false), Robby-B ( ? ).  
   So far: three truths (Norris-A, Nobby-A, Morris-B) and four false statements.
   To reach the required 3 true / 5 false split, Robby-B must be false.
   That merely means Robby really was surprised by the prisoner’s conduct—
   a perfectly consistent assumption.

7. All other possibilities fail, while the Robby-guilty scenario fits the exact
   3-true / 5-false requirement.

ANSWER  
Robby O’Mental was the guard on duty and the one who deliberately left the cell door open.

Question:
Question: John, Pete, Tom, George, and Steve are brothers. One day, one of them broke a window. When their father asked them who did it, they gave the following answers:
John: "It was Pete or Tom."
Pete: "It was neither George nor me."
Tom: "Both of you are lying."
Steve: "No, only one of them is lying."
George: "No, Steve, you are wrong."
Then their mother added: "Three of my sons are telling the truth, but I do not believe what the two others said."
Who broke the window?
 Solution: By assuming that each of the five brothers broke the window and seeing how many told the truth, only Tom can be the person who broke the window.
Hint: If you find it difficult to use logic alone, then use trial and error by assuming each one of the five sons broke the window, and list whether they are telling a lie or the truth.
Human Solution: By assuming that each of the five brothers broke the window and seeing how many told the truth, only Tom can be the person who broke the window.
Response:
SIMPLE, STEP-BY-STEP REASONING  

1.  Translate every boy’s sentence into a logical statement that can be True (T) or False (F).  
   • John (J):  C = Pete  OR  C = Tom  
   • Pete (P):  C ≠ George  AND  C ≠ Pete  
   • Tom (T):   John is lying  AND  Pete is lying      →   ¬J  ∧  ¬P  
   • Steve (S): Exactly one of John, Pete is lying     →   J ⊕ P  
   • George (G): Steve is wrong                       →   ¬S  

   (C is the boy who broke the window.)

2.  Mother’s remark: exactly three of the five statements are true.  
   ⇒  J + P + T + S + G = 3 truths.

3.  Observe that S and G are logical opposites (G = ¬S).  
   ⇒  One of them is true and the other is false.  
   ⇒  Together they contribute 1 true and 1 false to the total.

4.  Therefore the remaining three statements (J, P, T) must supply the other 2 truths and 1 lie.

5.  Check whether Tom’s own statement (T) can be the true one.  
   • If T were true, it would force both J and P to be false.  
   • Then we would have only 1 true (T) among J, P, T, not the required 2.  
   • Contradiction → T is false.

6.  Since T is false, at least one of J or P must be true (because T says both are lying).  
   To reach 2 truths among J, P, T with T already false, BOTH J and P must be true.

7.  With J true and P true:  
   • S = J ⊕ P = F, because J and P have the same truth value.  
   • G = ¬S = T.  
   Totals:  J (T), P (T), T (F), S (F), G (T) → exactly 3 truths, as Mother required.  
   Consistency achieved.

8.  Deduce the culprit using the now-true statements J and P.  
   • J (true): C is Pete or Tom.  
   • P (true): C is NOT Pete and NOT George.  
   Intersecting the two truths leaves one possibility:  C = Tom.

ANSWER  
Tom broke the window.

Question:
Question: A telephone number has the form ABC-DEF-GHIJ, where each letter represents a different digit. The digits in each part of the number are in decreasing order; that is, ABC, DEF, and GHIJ. Furthermore, D, E, and F are consecutive even digits; G, H, I, and J are consecutive odd digits; and A+B+C=9. What is A?
 Solution: The consecutive even digits DEF can be 420, 642 or 864, while the consecutive odd digits GHIJ can be 7531 or 9753.
Since A+B+C=9, none of them can be 9, and GHIJ must be 9753, and one of A, B, C is 1.
The other two add up to 8, which is obtained by 8+0.
Therefore, A, the biggest number of the three, is 8.
Human Solution:
The consecutive even digits DEF can be 420, 642 or 864, while the consecutive odd digits GHIJ can be 7531 or 9753.
Since A+B+C=9, none of them can be 9, and GHIJ must be 9753, and one of A, B, C is 1.
The other two add up to 8, which is obtained by 8+0.
Therefore, A, the biggest number of the three, is 8.
Response:
Solution Outline – broken into clear, self-contained steps  

1. List the possible blocks DEF  
   • DEF must be three consecutive even digits written largest-to-smallest.  
   • Even digits come in runs … 864, 642, 420 are the only ones that fit.  

2. List the possible blocks GHIJ  
   • GHIJ must be four consecutive odd digits written largest-to-smallest.  
   • Only two runs exist: 9753 and 7531.  

3. Impose the “all digits different” condition  
   • Every letter is a different digit, so the digits appearing in DEF and GHIJ cannot be reused in ABC.  

4. Impose the “sum–of–three” condition on ABC  
   • ABC must satisfy A > B > C (decreasing order) and A + B + C = 9.  
   • ABC must be formed from the three digits that remain after removing those used in DEF and GHIJ.  

5. Test each combination systematically  
   a) DEF = 864, GHIJ = 9753 → remaining digits {0,1,2}. 0+1+2 = 3 (≠9). Discard.  
   b) DEF = 864, GHIJ = 7531 → remaining digits {0,2,9}. 0+2+9 = 11. Discard.  
   c) DEF = 642, GHIJ = 9753 → remaining digits {0,1,8}. 0+1+8 = 9 and they can be ordered 8 > 1 > 0, so ABC = 810 works. KEEP.  
   d) DEF = 642, GHIJ = 7531 → remaining digits {0,8,9}. Sum 17. Discard.  
   e) DEF = 420, GHIJ = 9753 → remaining digits {1,6,8}. Sum 15. Discard.  
   f) DEF = 420, GHIJ = 7531 → remaining digits {6,8,9}. Sum 23. Discard.  

6. Conclude  
   • The only viable phone number uses DEF = 642, GHIJ = 9753, and ABC = 810.  
   • Therefore A, the first digit of the entire number, is 8.

Question:
Question: I have 3 dads and 4 sisters. My immediate family (living in my house) consists of 7. Two of my sisters only have 2 dads. How is this possible?
 Solution: I have a biological dad, who I don't know. An adopted dad- my sisters' dad and a step dad- who lives with me. My two younger sisters never knew my biological dad. My oldest sister (19) lives by herself. Her son lives with me, my 3 other sisters, my mom, and step dad.
Hint: My nephew lives with me and I'm the middle child.
Human Solution: I have a biological dad, who I don't know. An adopted dad- my sisters' dad and a step dad- who lives with me. My two younger sisters never knew my biological dad. My oldest sister (19) lives by herself. Her son lives with me, my 3 other sisters, my mom, and step dad.
Response:
Summary of the explanation, broken into clear logical steps  

1. Parental history  
   • Mother’s first partner is the asker’s biological father (Dad #1).  
   • Mother later married a second man who is the biological father of all four sisters.  
     – He legally adopted the asker, so to the asker he is an “adoptive dad” (Dad #2).  
   • Mother is now married to a third man who lives in the home; he is step-father to all the children (Dad #3).

2. Why the asker has three dads  
   • Dad #1 = biological father (not in the home).  
   • Dad #2 = adoptive/legal father (also the sisters’ biological dad).  
   • Dad #3 = current step-father living in the house.

3. Why two younger sisters have only two dads  
   • They never had any relationship with Dad #1, who is not their father anyway.  
   • Their “dads” are therefore:  
     – Dad #2 (their own biological father) and  
     – Dad #3 (their step-father).

4. Household head-count of seven  
   • People living in the house:  
     – Mother  
     – Step-father (Dad #3)  
     – Asker  
     – Three of the four sisters (the eldest lives elsewhere)  
     – Nephew (eldest sister’s son)  
   • Total = 7 residents.

Thus the statement “I have 3 dads and 4 sisters; two sisters have only 2 dads; our household is 7” is consistent with one biological father, one adoptive/biological father of the sisters, one current step-father, four sisters (one living elsewhere), and the eldest sister’s child residing in the home.

Question:
Question: There are three brothers: Al, Ben, and Carl. Two of the three brothers are boxers. Here are some facts:
1. The shorter of Al and Ben is the older boxer.
2. The younger of Ben and Carl is the shorter boxer.
3. The taller of Al and Carl is the younger boxer.
Which brother is not a boxer?
 Solution: Carl is not a boxer.
From fact 1, we know that Carl is not the older boxer.
From fact 3, we know that Ben is not the younger boxer.
We now have three possible scenarios:
1. Al is the younger boxer and Ben is the older boxer.
2. Ben is the older boxer and Carl is the younger boxer.
3. Al is the older boxer and Carl is the younger boxer.
If scenario 1 is true, fact 1 tells us that Ben is shorter than Al.
If scenario 2 is true, fact 1 tells us that Ben is shorter than Al; fact 3 tells us that Carl is taller than Al, making Ben shorter than Carl.
If scenario 3 is true, fact 3 tells us that Carl is taller than Al.
We can now expand our three scenarios:
1. Al is the younger, taller boxer, and Ben is the older, shorter boxer.
2. Ben is the older, shorter boxer, and Carl is the younger, taller boxer.
3. Al is the older, shorter boxer, and Carl is the younger, taller boxer.
Scenario 2 cannot be possible because it contradicts fact 2 by making the younger of Ben and Carl the taller boxer.
Fact 2 also tells us that Al is not the shorter boxer, so scenario 3 cannot be possible, either.
Therefore, scenario 1 is true, which means that Carl is not a boxer.
Human Solution:
Carl is not a boxer.
From fact 1, we know that Carl is not the older boxer.
From fact 3, we know that Ben is not the younger boxer.
We now have three possible scenarios:
1. Al is the younger boxer and Ben is the older boxer.
2. Ben is the older boxer and Carl is the younger boxer.
3. Al is the older boxer and Carl is the younger boxer.
If scenario 1 is true, fact 1 tells us that Ben is shorter than Al.
If scenario 2 is true, fact 1 tells us that Ben is shorter than Al; fact 3 tells us that Carl is taller than Al, making Ben shorter than Carl.
If scenario 3 is true, fact 3 tells us that Carl is taller than Al.
We can now expand our three scenarios:
1. Al is the younger, taller boxer, and Ben is the older, shorter boxer.
2. Ben is the older, shorter boxer, and Carl is the younger, taller boxer.
3. Al is the older, shorter boxer, and Carl is the younger, taller boxer.
Scenario 2 cannot be possible because it contradicts fact 2 by making the younger of Ben and Carl the taller boxer.
Fact 2 also tells us that Al is not the shorter boxer, so scenario 3 cannot be possible, either.
Therefore, scenario 1 is true, which means that Carl is not a boxer.
Response:
Goal  
Exactly two of the three brothers (Al, Ben, Carl) are boxers.  
We must decide who is not.

Translate the three statements  
(Older / Younger refer to age, Taller / Shorter to height.)

1. “The shorter of Al and Ben is the older boxer.”  
   • The older boxer is either Al or Ben, never Carl.  
   • Whichever of Al/Ben is shorter is that older boxer.

2. “The younger of Ben and Carl is the shorter boxer.”  
   • Among the two boxers, the one who is shorter in height is also the brother who is younger between Ben and Carl.

3. “The taller of Al and Carl is the younger boxer.”  
   • The younger boxer is either Al or Carl, never Ben.  
   • Whichever of Al/Carl is taller is that younger boxer.

Step-by-step elimination

A. Combine 1 and 3.  
   • Older boxer ∈ {Al, Ben} and Younger boxer ∈ {Al, Carl}.  
   • Therefore the two boxers can only be  
     (i) Al & Ben or (ii) Al & Carl.  
     (Ben & Carl is impossible because Ben cannot be the younger boxer and Carl cannot be the older boxer.)

B. Test possibility (ii)  Al & Carl are the two boxers.  
   • From 3, if Al & Carl are the boxers, the younger boxer must be the taller of Al and Carl.  
     – So the younger boxer is Carl if Carl is taller, or Al if Al is taller.  
   • From 1, the older boxer must be the shorter of Al and Ben, but the older boxer cannot be Carl, so it must be Al.  
     – Thus Al is older, Carl is younger.  
     – Hence Al is the shorter boxer (older) and Carl is the taller boxer (younger).  
   • Now apply 2: the younger of Ben and Carl must be the shorter boxer.  
     – Between Ben and Carl, the younger is Carl (since Ben is not a boxer, his age is unrestricted, but Carl is already the younger boxer).  
     – Yet the “shorter boxer” is Al, not Carl.  
     – Contradiction.  
   • Therefore Al & Carl cannot both be boxers.

C. The only viable pair is (i) Al & Ben are the two boxers.  
   • From 3, the younger boxer cannot be Ben, so it must be Al.  
   • From 1, the older boxer is the shorter of Al and Ben, so Ben must be shorter than Al.  
   • Check 2: who is younger between Ben and Carl?  
     – For 2 to hold, that younger brother must coincide with the shorter boxer (Ben, because Ben is shorter than Al).  
     – So Ben must be younger than Carl — perfectly feasible.  
   • All three facts can now be satisfied consistently.

Conclusion  
Only Al and Ben can be the two boxers, leaving Carl as the brother who is not a boxer.

Question:
Question: Andy dislikes the catcher. Ed's sister is engaged to the second baseman. The center fielder is taller than the right fielder. Harry and the third baseman live in the same building. Paul and Allen each won $20 from the pitcher at pinochle. Ed and the outfielders play poker during their free time. The pitcher's wife is the third baseman's sister. The pitcher, catcher, and infielders except Allen, Harry, and Andy, are shorter than Sam. Paul, Andy, and the shortstop lost $50 each at the racetrack. Paul, Harry, Bill, and the catcher took a trouncing from the second baseman at pool. Sam is involved in a divorce suit. The catcher and the third baseman each have two children. Ed, Paul, Jerry, the right fielder, and the center fielder are bachelors. The others are married. The shortstop, the third baseman, and Bill each cleaned up $100 betting on the fight. One of the outfielders is either Mike or Andy. Jerry is taller than Bill. Mike is shorter than Bill. Each of them is heavier than the third baseman.
Using these facts, determine the names of the men playing the various positions on the baseball team.
 Solution: Harry is the pitcher, Allen the catcher, Paul the first baseman, Jerry the second baseman, Andy the third baseman, Ed the shortstop, Sam the left fielder, Mike the right fielder, and Bill the center fielder.
Human Solution: Harry is the pitcher, Allen the catcher, Paul the first baseman, Jerry the second baseman, Andy the third baseman, Ed the shortstop, Sam the left fielder, Mike the right fielder, and Bill the center fielder.
Response:
SIMPLE, LOGIC-TIGHT CHAIN OF REASONING  

1.  Who can NOT be catcher or third baseman  
    •  Catcher and third baseman each have two children (Clue 12) → must be married.  
    •  The bachelors are Ed, Paul, Jerry, the right fielder and the center fielder (Clue 13).  
    ⇒  Ed, Paul, Jerry, RF and CF are ruled out for catcher and for third baseman.  

2.  Fixing the center- and right-fielders from the height data  
    •  CF is taller than RF (Clue 3).  
    •  Jerry is taller than Bill, and Bill is taller than Mike (Clues 16-17) ⇒ Jerry > Bill > Mike.  
    •  To satisfy CF > RF with the above order, Bill must be CF and Mike RF.  
    •  CF and RF are bachelors (Clue 13); Bill and Mike therefore fit that requirement.  

3.  Getting the second baseman  
    •  Paul, Harry, Bill (CF) and the catcher lost to the second baseman at pool (Clue 10);  
      so 2B is none of those four.  
    •  Ed’s sister is engaged to the second baseman (Clue 2) so 2B is not Ed himself.  
    •  From Step 1 the only remaining bachelor not yet assigned is Jerry.  
    ⇒  Jerry is the second baseman.  

4.  Who is NOT pitcher  
    •  The pitcher must be married (his wife is the 3B’s sister, Clue 7); so pitcher ≠ any bachelor  
      (Ed, Paul, Jerry, Bill, Mike).  
    •  Paul and Allen each won $20 from the pitcher (Clue 5) ⇒ pitcher ≠ Paul, ≠ Allen.  
    ⇒  Only Andy, Harry, or Sam can be pitcher.  
    •  Sam cannot be pitcher: the pitcher is shorter than Sam (Clue 8).  
    ⇒  Pitcher is either Andy or Harry.  

5.  Pinning down the catcher  
    •  Andy dislikes the catcher (Clue 1) ⇒ catcher ≠ Andy.  
    •  If the pitcher is Andy, the married players left for catcher are Harry or Allen;  
      but Harry would then be both pitcher and catcher – impossible.  
    ⇒  To keep roles distinct: make Harry pitcher, Allen catcher.  

6.  Fixing the third baseman  
    •  Harry (pitcher) and the third baseman live in the same building (Clue 4).  
    •  The 3B cannot be any bachelor (Step 1) and cannot be Allen (already catcher).  
    ⇒  Third baseman is Andy.  
    •  This also satisfies Clue 7: Harry’s wife (he is married) is Andy’s sister.  

7.  Shortstop versus first baseman  
    •  Ed is not an outfielder (“Ed and the outfielders …”, Clue 6).  
    •  Ed is still unplaced and cannot be pitcher, catcher, or 3B (Steps 1, 4, 6).  
    ⇒  Ed is an infielder; possible slots: SS or 1B.  
    •  Paul, Andy and the shortstop lost $50 at the racetrack (Clue 9) → shortstop ≠ Paul, ≠ Andy.  
      That leaves Ed as the only candidate for shortstop.  
    ⇒  Ed is the shortstop.  
    •  The remaining open infield position is 1B, so Paul becomes first baseman.  

8.  Left fielder by elimination  
    •  Positions now assigned: P (Harry), C (Allen), 1B (Paul), 2B (Jerry), 3B (Andy),  
      SS (Ed), CF (Bill), RF (Mike).  
    •  The only position (and person) still unassigned is left field; the only unplaced player is Sam.  
    ⇒  Sam is the left fielder.  

9.  Final roster (all earlier clues re-checked and satisfied)  
    Pitcher – Harry  
    Catcher – Allen  
    First base – Paul  
    Second base – Jerry  
    Third base – Andy  
    Shortstop – Ed  
    Left field – Sam  
    Center field – Bill  
    Right field – Mike

Question:
Question: On Sunday, December 22, four Madadian cruise ships - W, X, Y, Z - started their series of winter cruises to various ports around Madadia.
Ship W left at 4:00 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of 8-days cruises to Madport.
Ship X left at 4:30 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of alternating 11-days and 13-days cruises to Adeville.
Ship Y left at 5:00 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of 5-days cruises to Kebabtown.
Ship Z left on Monday for a series of 7-days cruises.
Each ship is scheduled to return back early in the morning after the last day of the cruise and leave again late in the afternoon of the same day.
On how many days occasions between December 22 and February 28 will three ships be moored at the port?
 Solution: On no occasions (other than start date December 22) between December 22 and February 28, three ships will be moored at the port.
Find out the days on when each ship will be in port:
Ship W will be in port on days 1, 9, 17, 25, 33, 41, 49, 57 and 65.
Ship X will be in port on days 1, 12, 25, 36, 49, 60 and 73.
Ship Y will be in port on days 1, 6, 11, 16, 21, 26, 31, 36, 41, 46, 51, 56, 61 and 66.
Ship Z will be in port on days 1, 2, 9, 16, 23, 30, 37, 44, 51, 58 and 65.
From above data, it is clear that - on no occasion (other than December 22) will three ships be moored at the port.
Also, on 8 occasions, there will be 2 ships moored at the port.
Human Solution:
On no occasions (other than start date December 22) between December 22 and February 28, three ships will be moored at the port.
Find out the days on when each ship will be in port:
Ship W will be in port on days 1, 9, 17, 25, 33, 41, 49, 57 and 65.
Ship X will be in port on days 1, 12, 25, 36, 49, 60 and 73.
Ship Y will be in port on days 1, 6, 11, 16, 21, 26, 31, 36, 41, 46, 51, 56, 61 and 66.
Ship Z will be in port on days 1, 2, 9, 16, 23, 30, 37, 44, 51, 58 and 65.
From above data, it is clear that - on no occasion (other than December 22) will three ships be moored at the port.
Also, on 8 occasions, there will be 2 ships moored at the port.
Response:
PROBLEM (restated)
Between Sunday 22 Dec and Friday 28 Feb (69 calendar days) four cruise ships repeat fixed-length cruises.  
Whenever a ship is “in port” we mean the early-morning it has just returned and the late-afternoon it departs again – one calendar day.

 •  W: constant 8-day cruises (return every 8 days).  
 •  X: 11-day, 13-day, 11-day, … (alternating) cruises.  
 •  Y: constant 5-day cruises.  
 •  Z: constant 7-day cruises, first departure Monday 23 Dec (the others left Sunday 22 Dec).

Question: From 22 Dec (day 1) through 28 Feb (day 69), on how many dates (other than the common start day) will three different ships be simultaneously in port?

ANSWER: None.  (There are 8 dates on which exactly two ships coincide.)

REASONING – STEP BY STEP
1.  Encode the calendar.  
    Let day 1 = Sunday 22 Dec, … , day 69 = Friday 28 Feb.

2.  Work out each ship’s sequence of “in-port” days (≤ 69).

    a) Ship W: leaves day 1, cruises 8 days, so returns day 9; repeats every 8 days.  
       Days in port: 1, 9, 17, 25, 33, 41, 49, 57, 65.

    b) Ship X: pattern 11, 13, 11, 13, …  
       • first cruise 11 days → return day 12  
       • next 13 days → return day 25  
       • next 11 days → day 36  
       • next 13 days → day 49  
       • next 11 days → day 60  
       • next 13 days → day 73 (beyond 28 Feb, so stop)  
       Days: 1, 12, 25, 36, 49, 60.

    c) Ship Y: 5-day cycle.  
       Returns day 6, 11, 16, …  
       Days: 1, 6, 11, 16, 21, 26, 31, 36, 41, 46, 51, 56, 61, 66.

    d) Ship Z: leaves Monday 23 Dec, so first “in-port” day is day 2; 7-day cycle.  
       Days: 2, 9, 16, 23, 30, 37, 44, 51, 58, 65.

3.  Look for triple overlaps.  
    Combine the four lists and check each day 1–69:

       • Day 1 (22 Dec): W, X, Y are all present (Z departs next morning).  
         This is the only day with ≥ 3 ships.

       • For every other day compare the four sets; no other date appears in three lists simultaneously.

4.  Therefore, between 23 Dec and 28 Feb inclusive there is NO occasion when three ships are in port.  
    (A quick scan also shows exactly eight dates with two-ship overlaps: days 9, 16, 25, 36, 41, 49, 51, 65.)

CONCLUSION
Apart from the common departure day (22 Dec), there are zero dates up to 28 Feb on which three of the four cruise ships are simultaneously moored.

Question:
Question: Henry and Gretchen are going to play a game.  Henry explains, "You and I will take turns saying numbers.  The first person will say a number between 1 and 10.  Then the other person will say a number that is at least 1 higher than that number, and at most 10 higher.  We will keep going back and forth in this way until one of us says the number 50.  That person wins.  I'll start."
"Not so fast!" says Gretchen.  "I want to win, so I will start."
What number should Gretchen say to start?
 Solution: She wants to say, "6."
The series of numbers she will say is 6, 17, 28, 39, 50.
Since she wants to say 50, she needs Henry to say a number between 40 and 49.  Therefore, she wants to say 39.
Knowing she wants to say 39, she needs Henry to say a number between 29 and 38.  So she wants to say 28.  Following this same logic recursively, she will want to say 17, and she will want to say 6 to start the game, and be assured victory.
Hint: By following this strategy, she is assured a victory.  Think of all of the numbers she will want to say.
Human Solution:
She wants to say, "6."
The series of numbers she will say is 6, 17, 28, 39, 50.
Since she wants to say 50, she needs Henry to say a number between 40 and 49.  Therefore, she wants to say 39.
Knowing she wants to say 39, she needs Henry to say a number between 29 and 38.  So she wants to say 28.  Following this same logic recursively, she will want to say 17, and she will want to say 6 to start the game, and be assured victory.
Response:
SOLUTION IN SIMPLE, LOGICAL STEPS  

1.  Winning goal  
   – Whoever says 50 wins.  
   – On any turn you may add from 1 to 10 to the last number spoken.

2.  Work backwards to find the “must-say” (safe) numbers.  
   – If you can say a number from which every legal reply leaves you able to finish on 50, you are guaranteed to win.  
   – From 39 this is true: whatever Henry answers (40–49), Gretchen can add just enough (1–10) to reach 50.  
   – Therefore 39 is a safe number.

3.  Repeat the backward step: subtract 11 (the range 1–10 plus 1) each time.  
   – 39 − 11 = 28; if Gretchen says 28, Henry’s reply (29–38) lets her jump to 39.  
   – 28 − 11 = 17; if Gretchen says 17, Henry’s reply (18–27) lets her jump to 28.  
   – 17 − 11 = 6; if Gretchen says 6, Henry’s reply (7–16) lets her jump to 17.

4.  List of safe numbers (for the player whose turn it is): 6, 17, 28, 39, 50.

5.  Gretchen moves first, so she chooses the first safe number, 6.  
   Then she can always respond with 17, 28, 39, and finally 50, regardless of Henry’s plays.

Answer: Gretchen should start by saying 6.

Question:
Question: One of four people - two men (Jack and Mike) and two women (Carol and Lily) - was murdered.
The following facts refer to the people mentioned:
(a) Jack's sister argued exactly once with Carol's legal husband after the murder.
(b) Mike's sister argued twice with the victim's legal spouse after the murder. Who was the victim?
 Solution: Mike is the victim.
If Mike's sister and Jack's sister are the same person, then (a) reads "Lily argued exactly once with (Mike or Jack)" and (b) reads "Lily argued twice with (the same Mike or Jack)".  These two statements contradict each other.  Therefore Mike's sister must be different from Jack's sister.
If this is the case then there are two possibilities:
1)  Jack and Carol are brother and sister.  Mike and Lily are brother and sister.  Jack is married to Lily and Mike is married to Carol.  If this is the case, then (a) reads "Carol argued once with Mike" and (b) reads "Lily argued twice with herself", leaving Jack dead.  Since Lily did not likely argue with herself, this is not the solution.
2)  Jack and Lily are brother and sister.  Mike and Carol are brother and sister.  Jack is married to Carol and Lily is married to Mike.  If this is the case, then (a) reads "Lily argued once with Jack" and (b) reads "Carol argued twice with Lily", leaving Mike dead.  Since there are no contradictions, this is the solution.
Human Solution:
Mike is the victim.
If Mike's sister and Jack's sister are the same person, then (a) reads "Lily argued exactly once with (Mike or Jack)" and (b) reads "Lily argued twice with (the same Mike or Jack)".  These two statements contradict each other.  Therefore Mike's sister must be different from Jack's sister.
If this is the case then there are two possibilities:
1)  Jack and Carol are brother and sister.  Mike and Lily are brother and sister.  Jack is married to Lily and Mike is married to Carol.  If this is the case, then (a) reads "Carol argued once with Mike" and (b) reads "Lily argued twice with herself", leaving Jack dead.  Since Lily did not likely argue with herself, this is not the solution.
2)  Jack and Lily are brother and sister.  Mike and Carol are brother and sister.  Jack is married to Carol and Lily is married to Mike.  If this is the case, then (a) reads "Lily argued once with Jack" and (b) reads "Carol argued twice with Lily", leaving Mike dead.  Since there are no contradictions, this is the solution.
Response:
SUMMARY OF THE REASONING

1.  Read the two clues literally.  
    a) “Jack’s sister argued exactly once with Carol’s legal husband.”  
    b) “Mike’s sister argued twice with the victim’s legal spouse.”  
    All these arguments happened after the murder, so every person who argues must still be alive.

2.  Decide whether the two men could share the same sister.  
    • If Jack’s sister = Mike’s sister, then the same woman would have to quarrel once with someone (clue a) and twice with that same someone (clue b), an impossibility.  
    ⇒ Jack’s sister and Mike’s sister must be two different women.

3.  There are only two ways to assign those different sisters to the two women (Carol, Lily).  
    Case I Jack’s sister = Carol and Mike’s sister = Lily  
    Case II Jack’s sister = Lily  and Mike’s sister = Carol

4.  Examine Case I (Jack–Carol siblings, Mike–Lily siblings).  
    • Carol cannot marry her own brother Jack, so Carol’s legal husband must be Mike.  
    • Clue a then says: “Carol argued once with Mike.”  That is possible, but Carol must be alive, so Carol is not the victim.  
    • Clue b says: “Lily argued twice with the victim’s spouse.”  With Carol alive and Jack alive (he was quarreled with), the only candidate left for the victim is Jack.  Jack’s spouse would be Lily, forcing Lily to have argued twice with herself—impossible.  
    ⇒ Case I is inconsistent and must be rejected.

5.  Examine Case II (Jack–Lily siblings, Mike–Carol siblings).  
    • A woman cannot marry her own brother, so the only feasible marriages are Jack ↔ Carol and Mike ↔ Lily.  
    • Clue a now reads: “Lily argued exactly once with Carol’s legal husband Jack.”  This is consistent.  
    • Clue b reads: “Carol argued twice with the victim’s spouse.”  
        – If the victim were Jack, his spouse is Carol; that would force Carol to argue twice with herself, impossible.  
        – If the victim were Carol or Lily, they would be dead and could not do any arguing, contradicting the clues.  
        – If the victim is Mike, his spouse is Lily, so Carol (alive) can argue twice with Lily (alive).  No contradiction arises.  
    ⇒ All requirements are satisfied only when Mike is the victim.

6.  Conclusion:  Mike must have been the one who was murdered.

Question:
Question: Walter, Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke crossed a river in a tiny rowboat. They all started on the same side of the river. They made three trips from the starting side to the destination side, and two trips from the destination side to the starting side. Here are some facts:
1. On each trip from the starting side of the river to the destination side, two people were in the boat, but only one person rowed the boat, and that person rowed the boat for the entire trip.
2. On each return trip, only one person was in the boat.
3. Walter is the weakest of the group. He could only row the boat if no one else is in it.
4. Xavier is the second weakest of the group. He can only row the boat if he is by himself or if Yoshi, the lightest of the group, is a passenger.
5. Each man rowed the boat at least once.
Who rowed twice?
 Solution: Yoshi rowed twice.
Fact 5 tells us that Walter had to row the boat at least once, but fact 3 tells us that he had to go by himself. This means he could only row the boat on a return trip, which means he rowed on at least one return trip.
The man who rowed twice could not have rowed on two trips from the starting side to the destination side, because he would have had to make a third trip by himself back to the starting side. So the man who rowed twice must have made a return trip at least once.
Now we know that if Walter made two trips, they must both have been return trips, and Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke each rowed for one of the other three trips. If Walter made only one trip, the other person who made a return trip must have been the person who rowed twice (Xavier, Yoshi, or Zeke) and that person would also have made one of the other three trips. So the three trips from the starting side to the destination side must have been rowed by Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke.
Fact 1 tells us that Xavier's trip to the destination side must have had a passenger, and fact 4 tells us that that passenger must have been Yoshi. Yoshi would have had to row back to row his trip to the destination side, or else Yoshi rowed to the destination side, then back to the start, then got rowed across by Xavier.
Human Solution:
Yoshi rowed twice.
Fact 5 tells us that Walter had to row the boat at least once, but fact 3 tells us that he had to go by himself. This means he could only row the boat on a return trip, which means he rowed on at least one return trip.
The man who rowed twice could not have rowed on two trips from the starting side to the destination side, because he would have had to make a third trip by himself back to the starting side. So the man who rowed twice must have made a return trip at least once.
Now we know that if Walter made two trips, they must both have been return trips, and Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke each rowed for one of the other three trips. If Walter made only one trip, the other person who made a return trip must have been the person who rowed twice (Xavier, Yoshi, or Zeke) and that person would also have made one of the other three trips. So the three trips from the starting side to the destination side must have been rowed by Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke.
Fact 1 tells us that Xavier's trip to the destination side must have had a passenger, and fact 4 tells us that that passenger must have been Yoshi. Yoshi would have had to row back to row his trip to the destination side, or else Yoshi rowed to the destination side, then back to the start, then got rowed across by Xavier.
Response:
Answer: Yoshi is the only man who can (and must) row twice.

Step-by-step reasoning
1. Total rows  
   • 3 outward trips (two men in the boat) → 3 rowers  
   • 2 return trips (one man in the boat) → 2 rowers  
   ⇒ 5 different pieces of rowing are required, but there are only 4 men, so one man rows twice.

2. Walter’s limitation  
   • Walter can row only when he is alone (Fact 3).  
   • Therefore every time Walter rows it has to be on a return trip.  
   • Fact 5 says everyone rows at least once, so Walter occupies one of the two return trips.

3. Where the “double rower’’ must appear  
   • The second return trip must be done by the man who rows twice (because Walter already took one).  
   • Consequently that same man must also row once on an outward trip (so he rows twice in all).

4. Who rows the three outward trips  
   • Walter cannot row outward, so those three outward rows must be done by Xavier, Yoshi and Zeke (one of these three being the double rower).

5. Xavier’s restriction forces Yoshi to be with him  
   • If Xavier rows outward, his passenger must be Yoshi (Fact 4).  
   • Therefore one outward trip is “Xavier rows, Yoshi rides.”

6. How can Yoshi be back on the starting bank to ride with Xavier?  
   • After Yoshi first reaches the destination side he must return alone (only one man is allowed in a return boat) so that he can sit in the boat with Xavier later.  
   • That solo return satisfies the “second return trip’’ identified in Step 3.  
   • Hence Yoshi is necessarily the man who rows twice: he rows the solo return and one outward trip.

7. Concrete feasible schedule (showing all rules work)  
   Trip 1:  Xavier rows over with Yoshi as passenger.  
   Trip 2:  Yoshi rows back alone.  
   Trip 3:  Zeke rows over with Walter as passenger.  
   Trip 4:  Walter rows back alone.  
   Trip 5:  Yoshi rows over again with Walter as passenger.  
   – All four end on the destination side.  
   – Rowers: Xavier (1×), Zeke (1×), Walter (1×), Yoshi (2×).  
   – All rowing restrictions are met.

8. Conclusion  
   The only arrangement that satisfies every condition forces Yoshi to be the man who rows twice.

Question:
Question: There is a famous diamond displayed in a room that measures 15 meters by 15 meters by 15 meters. The room is made entirely of concrete blocks and the floor is covered with a thick carpet. The only thing in the room is the diamond that is housed under a glass cube. The glass cube stands on a one-meter pedestal in the centre of the room. Alarm wires spaced eight centimetres apart and running parallel to each other lie under the carpet. The alarm will trigger if more than four kilograms of pressure is applied to any individual wire. Will Carlo who weighs 74 kilograms was able to steal the famous diamond using the following equipment: a five meter 2 x 4 board, four leather straps (each two meters long and five cm wide), a hammer, and a saw. How could he do it without triggering the alarm?
 Solution: Will Carlo stole the diamond in the following manner: First, he cut five meter 2 x 4 boards in half. Then using the available straps, he fastened the two boards to his feet like skies. With the boards strapped to his feet, his weight was displacing enough so that he did not exceed the wire's weight tolerance and triggers the alarm. Carlo then slowly and carefully walked to the centre of the room, smashed the glass cube with the hammer, took the diamond and returned the same way he came in.
Human Solution: Will Carlo stole the diamond in the following manner: First, he cut five meter 2 x 4 boards in half. Then using the available straps, he fastened the two boards to his feet like skies. With the boards strapped to his feet, his weight was displacing enough so that he did not exceed the wire's weight tolerance and triggers the alarm. Carlo then slowly and carefully walked to the centre of the room, smashed the glass cube with the hammer, took the diamond and returned the same way he came in.
Response:
Summary of the method Will Carlo used to remove the diamond without setting off the pressure alarm  

Step-by-step reasoning  

1. Understand the alarm restriction  
   • Alarm wires lie 8 cm apart under the carpet.  
   • Any single wire that receives >4 kg of force triggers the alarm.  
   • Will Carlo’s mass is 74 kg, so standing normally would put far more than 4 kg on each wire beneath his feet.

2. Decide to spread the load over many wires  
   • If Carlo can rest his weight on a long, rigid surface, every wire under that surface will share part of the load.  
   • The more wires touched at once, the smaller the load on each.

3. Prepare two long “skis” from the supplied timber  
   • Saw the 5 m “2 × 4” board into two equal 2.5 m lengths.  
   • Each board is now about 2.5 m long, 9 cm wide and 4 cm thick (nominal 2 × 4).  

4. Attach the boards to his feet  
   • Use the four leather straps (2 m each) to lash one board firmly under each foot, creating a pair of skis.  
   • Straps secure the toes, insteps and heels so the boards stay flat against the carpet.

5. Check that the load per wire is safe  
   • A 2.5 m board spans 2.5 m / 0.08 m ≈ 31 wires.  
   • Each ski carries roughly half of Carlo’s 74 kg → 37 kg per ski.  
   • 37 kg ÷ 31 ≈ 1.2 kg per wire, well below the 4 kg limit.

6. Cross the room on the skis  
   • Because every step keeps each board flat, the load stays distributed; no single wire is overloaded.  
   • Carlo moves slowly to avoid tilting the ski and concentrating weight.

7. Remove the diamond  
   • At the pedestal he uses the hammer to smash the glass cube, lifts out the diamond, and pockets it.

8. Exit the room the same way  
   • Retraces his path on the skis, again keeping the weight spread.  
   • No wire ever receives more than ~1.2 kg, so the alarm remains silent.

Thus Carlo’s improvised skis let him distribute his 74 kg over dozens of wires at every moment, staying well under the 4 kg threshold and enabling him to steal the diamond undetected.

Question:
Question: One day, in baking class, 15 students were baking cakes when the fire alarm went off. Everyone exited the building, but when they got back, they found someone had dumped all the sugar into two of the batter-filled bowls. Everyone was puzzled over what to do until Alice had an idea: why not mix the batters together and then separate the contents back in the bowls. Here is what happened in chronological order:
Alice mixed with Flare
June pours some into Emma's
Luke mixed with Callie
June mixed with Gabbi
Flare mixed with Gabbi
Watt mixed with Tina
Flare mixed with Tina
Luke mixed with Flare
Gabbi mixed with Callie
Daniel, Emma, & Alice mixed with each other
Oscar mixed with Quinn
Misty mixed with Callie
Alice, Misty, & Oscar mixed with each other
Tina mixed with Emma
Kaleb mixed with Quinn
June mixed with Daniel
Luke mixed with June
Ryan, Luke, & Watt mixed with each other
Callie, Alice, & Flare mixed with each other
Kaleb pours some into Daniel's
Watt mixed with Ryan
Watt pours some into Kaleb's
Daniel mixed with Luke
Misty mixed with Gabbi
Kaleb mixed with Tina
Emma & Quinn had no sugar; which 2 bowls started with sugar?
Everyone was able to figure it out.
 Solution: Luke & Callie
To start, it can't be Emma or Quinn or anyone who mixed/gave to them. This leaves Flare, Luke, Callie, Gabbi, Watt, Misty, and Ryan.
It can't be Flare because he exchanged with Alice before Alice exchanged with Emma. It can't be Watt because he mixed with Tina before Tina exchanged with Emma. This leaves Luke, Callie, Gabbi, Misty, and Ryan.
It can't be Gabbi because she mixed with Flare before Flare mixed with Tina who mixed with Emma later. This leaves Luke, Callie, Misty, and Ryan.
If only one of Luke & Callie started with sugar it wouldn't be solvable because no interactions happened before them and the outcome would be the same, therefore the solution is either Misty and Ryan or Luke and Callie.
However, it can't be Ryan and Misty because they can't give June sugar!
Hint: Everyone was able to figure it out.
Human Solution:
Luke & Callie
To start, it can't be Emma or Quinn or anyone who mixed/gave to them. This leaves Flare, Luke, Callie, Gabbi, Watt, Misty, and Ryan.
It can't be Flare because he exchanged with Alice before Alice exchanged with Emma. It can't be Watt because he mixed with Tina before Tina exchanged with Emma. This leaves Luke, Callie, Gabbi, Misty, and Ryan.
It can't be Gabbi because she mixed with Flare before Flare mixed with Tina who mixed with Emma later. This leaves Luke, Callie, Misty, and Ryan.
If only one of Luke & Callie started with sugar it wouldn't be solvable because no interactions happened before them and the outcome would be the same, therefore the solution is either Misty and Ryan or Luke and Callie.
However, it can't be Ryan and Misty because they can't give June sugar!
Response:
PROBLEM  
Only two of fifteen cake-batters started out sweetened (they had all of the sugar).  
After the pupils performed the listed “mix” (two–way) and “pour” (one–way) actions it was seen that Emma’s and Quinn’s bowls contained no sugar.  
Which two bowls were the original sweet ones?

RULES WE USE  
• mix A with B  → afterwards both A and B have sugar if either of them had it beforehand.  
• A pours into B → B gets sugar if A had it; A keeps whatever sugar it already had.  
• Sugar can never disappear; it only spreads.  

TARGET FACT  
At the very end Emma and Quinn are still sugar-free, so no sugar may reach either of them at any time.

LOGICAL STEPS  

1.  Eliminate every bowl that can feed sugar (directly or indirectly and in the correct time order) to Emma.  
    – Emma’s direct partners (time order in brackets) are  
      June (2), Alice (10), Tina (14), Daniel (10).  
    – Anyone who could have given sugar to those partners ​before​ those moments is also impossible:  
      Flare and Watt (paths via Tina), Gabbi (via Flare), etc.  
    → June, Alice, Tina, Daniel, Flare, Watt, Gabbi can ​not​ have started sweet.

2.  Eliminate every bowl that can feed sugar to Quinn.  
    – Quinn’s partners are Oscar (11) and Kaleb (15).  
    – That knocks out Oscar and Kaleb, and—because Watt pours into Kaleb later—confirms Watt is already out.  

3.  After the two rounds of eliminations only four names remain possible:  
      Luke, Callie, Misty, Ryan.

4.  Test every possible pair among those four.  Five of the six pairs lead to sugar reaching Emma or Quinn, or leave some other bowl eternally sugar-free (contradicting the statement that the class could solve the mystery).  Typical failures:  
    – Luke & Misty: sugar travels Luke → Daniel (23) → Emma (10).  
    – Callie & Ryan: sugar travels Ryan → Luke (18) → Daniel (23) → Emma (10).  
    – Misty & Ryan: they never connect to June, so June would still be sugar-free and the puzzle would have ​three​ sweet-less bowls, not two.

5.  The only pair that passes every test is Luke & Callie.  
    • They mix very early (step 3).  
    • Their sugar spreads through the class, but—because of the precise time order—never manages to get to Emma (all links to Emma occur ​before​ sugar reaches those intermediaries) and never reaches Quinn (her contacts are isolated from the sugar path).  
    • Everybody except Emma and Quinn eventually receives sugar, so the class can deduce the answer uniquely.

CONCLUSION  
The two bowls that originally contained the sugar were Luke’s and Callie’s.

Question:
Question: Hans Ernest Froopaloop, Jr. will marry one of three women: Audrey, Brenda, and Charlotte. Here are some facts:
1. Of Audrey and Brenda:
a. Either they both have blue eyes or neither has blue eyes.
b. One has red hair and the other does not.
2. Of Audrey and Charlotte:
a. Either they both have red hair or neither has red hair.
b. One is 5'11" and the other is not.
3. Of Brenda and Charlotte:
a. One has blue eyes and the other does not.
b. One is 5'11" and the other is not.
4. Of the three characteristics; blue eyes, red hair and 5'11":
a. If any of the three women has exactly two of the three characteristics, Mr. Froopaloop will marry the one with the least number of characteristics.
b. If any of the three women has exactly one of the three characteristics, Mr. Froopaloop will marry the one with the greatest number of characteristics.
Who will Mr. Froopaloop marry?
 Solution: Mr. Froopaloop will marry Charlotte.
Facts 1a and 3a tell us that Charlotte is either the only one with blue eyes or the only one without blue eyes. Facts 1b and 2a tell us that Brenda is either the only one with red hair or the only one without red hair. Facts 2b and 3b tell us that Charlotte is either the only one who is 5'11" or the only one who isn't 5'11". Fact 4 tells us that no one woman can have one characteristic while another has two characteristics. This gives us two scenarios:
1. Audrey has blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is 5'11". Brenda has blue eyes, red hair, and is 5'11". Charlotte does not have blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is not 5'11".
2. Audrey does not have blue eyes, has red hair, and is not 5'11". Brenda does not have blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is not 5'11". Charlotte has blue eyes, red hair, and is 5'11".
Fact 4a tells us that in scenario 1, Mr. Froopaloop will marry Charlotte. Fact 4b tells us that in scenario 2, Mr. Froopaloop will marry...Charlotte.
Human Solution:
Mr. Froopaloop will marry Charlotte.
Facts 1a and 3a tell us that Charlotte is either the only one with blue eyes or the only one without blue eyes. Facts 1b and 2a tell us that Brenda is either the only one with red hair or the only one without red hair. Facts 2b and 3b tell us that Charlotte is either the only one who is 5'11" or the only one who isn't 5'11". Fact 4 tells us that no one woman can have one characteristic while another has two characteristics. This gives us two scenarios:
1. Audrey has blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is 5'11". Brenda has blue eyes, red hair, and is 5'11". Charlotte does not have blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is not 5'11".
2. Audrey does not have blue eyes, has red hair, and is not 5'11". Brenda does not have blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is not 5'11". Charlotte has blue eyes, red hair, and is 5'11".
Fact 4a tells us that in scenario 1, Mr. Froopaloop will marry Charlotte. Fact 4b tells us that in scenario 2, Mr. Froopaloop will marry...Charlotte.
Response:
Summary of the reasoning

1.  Translate the three properties  
   B = blue eyes, R = red hair, T = 5′ 11″.  

2.  Eye‐colour deductions  
    •  1a says Audrey (A) and Brenda (B) match on blue eyes.  
    •  3a says Brenda and Charlotte (C) opposite on blue eyes.  
       Therefore C is opposite to A as well.  
       ⇒  Charlotte is the only one with (or the only one without) blue eyes.

3.  Hair-colour deductions  
    •  1b says exactly one of A, B has red hair.  
    •  2a says A and C match on red hair.  
       Thus the red-hair verdict that singles out one woman must be Brenda.  
       ⇒  Brenda is the only one with (or the only one without) red hair.

4.  Height deductions  
    •  2b says exactly one of A, C is 5′ 11″.  
    •  3b says exactly one of B, C is 5′ 11″.  
       Charlotte must therefore differ from A and also differ from B in height.  
       ⇒  Charlotte is the only one who is 5′ 11″ or the only one who is not.

5.  List the two consistent global patterns (the “only one” choices can be made in two opposite ways):
